webTitle: Closing ranks behind the thirtysomething toddlers and their tiresome tantrums

fields.headline: Closing ranks behind the thirtysomething toddlers and their tiresome tantrums
fields.standfirst: Collymore's career in the balance
fields.trailText: Condoned, excuses made, blame apportioned elsewhere: it is the daily diet of the modern footballer. Football has been overrun by a bastardised form of Californian regression therapy.
fields.body:
Gazza and Stan: what a pair. Sixty-one years of experience between them and Messrs Gascoigne and Collymore appear to have accumulated the collective wisdom of a toddlers' play group.

First Gazza, offered his umpteenth chance to reshape his own destiny, self-destructs once more. Remember the old joke about the victim of police brutality who is charged with assaulting an officer after attacking one of their boots with his teeth? Gazza appears to have made a career out of it.

In the 1991 FA Cup final he destroyed his right knee in making violent contact with someone else's shin, then on Monday he broke his left forearm declaring war on someone else's forehead. He only needs to fracture his own forehead on the bridge of someone else's nose to complete a memorable hat-trick.

Meanwhile, on Tuesday night the swanky La Manga Club in Spain ejected the entire Leicester City squad after, among other things, a fire extinguisher was set off in the bar, causing substantial damage. La Manga's management took the unprecedented step of naming the culprit: Stanley Victor Collymore.

If it were not so pathetic, the incident would be funny: Stan, for so long pilloried as someone incapable of fitting in with the team ethic, attempts to ingratiate himself as one of the lads with a student prank. Except he isn't a student. He is a 29-year-old professional athlete who - if the La Manga allegations are true - has profoundly embarrassed the club who offered him a last chance all of five days ago.

We might never know the full facts but one thing is certain: a safety curtain of obfuscation and excuse will be drawn around the two to ensure neither need face up to their responsibility. Because that is football's way. Gazza's agent Mel Stein is already at it, claiming in a television interview that there was no intent in his client's action. "He's always played with his elbows up," says Stein. "He was looking at the ball as he clashed with the other player."

"Yeah," weighed in Bobby Robson, "but the lad doesn't know what he's doing. He needs to be looked after 24 hours a day." He is, lest we be confused by Robson's analysis into thinking him a babe in arms, 32 years old.

Condoned, excuses made, blame apportioned elsewhere: it is the daily diet of the modern footballer. Football has been overrun by a bastardised form of Californian regression therapy. There is no need to take responsibility for your own actions because it is always someone else's fault: referees, opponents, the media.

Behave like a psychopath on the pitch and the manager will stick up for you. Flounce out of your contractual obligations and your agent will say it's all the chairman's fault for not having the ambition to keep you. Fail to knuckle down in the first few days at your 15th club and, no worry, another one will come in and pay you £20,000 a week; they always have up till now.

Footballers at the top of the English game have been allowed to operate within a moral framework that bears no relation to the outside world. And on the rare occasions that they impinge on the outside world, they behave as if football rules still apply.

Caught speeding? It was the media's fault, they harassed me. Kick eight bells out of someone in a bar? Well, you're the real victim because you can't go anywhere without getting hassled by those jealous of your success. Beat up your wife? Never mind, the Priory awaits.

And so Gazza and Stan, the two who might have been, will continue to squander themselves. Because the last thing they will learn in the mad, bad, dangerous world that football has become is self-knowledge. And if anyone ever needed a dose of reality it was Gazza and Stan.

fields.headline: Collymore's career in the balance
fields.standfirst:
Striker in hot water again as Leicester players make a mess of Spanish bar
Comment: Jim White
fields.trailText: Leicester City will decide within the next 24 hours whether to terminate the contract of Stan Collymore after barely a week following claims that he let off a fire extinguisher during a night of drunken revelry at the high-class Spanish resort of La Manga.
fields.body:
Leicester City will decide within the next 24 hours whether to terminate the contract of Stan Collymore after barely a week. It follows claims that the former England striker let off a fire extinguisher, covering 40 guests with foam, during a night of drunken revelry at the high-class Spanish resort of La Manga.

Several other Leicester players were involved in the incident on Tuesday night, allegedly harassing women, dancing on tables and engaging in generally "unacceptable and irresponsible behaviour" at the piano bar.

The entire team were ordered to leave the training complex by the resort's management yesterday morning. They have been banned indefinitely. The team arrived back at Gatwick airport yesterday afternoon, and were shepherded home to Leicester in a tinted-window coach.

"They were insulting and rude to people, asking ladies to dance who didn't want to and being obnoxious," said Tony Coles, the managing director of the complex where the England team were based prior to the 1998 World Cup.

"Around a dozen of them were drinking for several hours and they became increasingly loud and drunk. They were jumping on chairs and tables and generally being unruly, upsetting a lot of our other clients. When the entertainment finished, Collymore then decided to let off a fire extinguisher which has caused considerable damage."

Collymore signed for Leicester from Aston Villa only last Thursday, after being ostracised by the Birmingham club following the off-field problems that led to him being treated for clinical depression, most notably the attack on his then girlfriend, the television personality Ulrika Jonsson, in June 1998.

The 29-year-old hailed the move across the midlands as a chance to re-establish himself as one of the country's finest strikers but, with a classic sense of ill-timing and after just one first-team appearance, at Watford last Saturday, he has discredited himself faster than anyone could have imagined.

"Every member of security and witnesses have confirmed this behaviour," Coles maintained. "We have been visited by over 250 teams since opening in 1998 and there have never been any problems until now. Unfortunately Stan Colly more and a few others have let down their club very badly."

The Leicester manager Martin O'Neill had been due to join his players in Spain last night after organising a three-day break at the 1,400-acre complex in south-east Spain as part of their preparations for the Worthington Cup final against Tranmere Rovers on Sunday week, for which Collymore is cup-tied. In O'Neill's absence, his assistant John Robertson was placed in charge, along with the coaches Paul Franklin and Steve Walford.

O'Neill, who immediately launched an internal inquiry, said: "The idea was to go for some light-hearted fun and serious training, as well as giving Stan an opportunity to integrate as one of the lads.

"I don't know exactly what has gone on because I was not there and there are always two sides to the story. But if any of the players have been in breach of club discipline they will be dealt with seriously. They have a responsibility when representing the club and it's something I won't tolerate.

"Maybe high jinks are understandable but, against that, if a fire extinguisher has been used and property damaged the people involved will pay for it. It's the least we can expect. The players should have known to behave themselves and you do not need to ask me if we will be considering disciplinary action, whether it's Stan or anybody."

O'Neill insisted on having several "safeguard" clauses written into Collymore's contract to stipulate the club would not tolerate misbehaviour. They must now decide whether to abandon Collymore. However they are more likely to impose a fine of two weeks' wages - £30,000 - the maximum allowed under Professional Footballers' Association guidelines.

The Football Association indicated it would not take action despite the clampdown on indiscipline that has seen four Premiership clubs, five players and a coach charged with misconduct during a damaging week for the game's image.

What they said

Thursday February 10

I don't consider it [the signing of Collymore] a risk at all in terms of football. He'll enhance the dressing room spirit because he's a bright lad.

He said he wanted to prove people wrong. He has the chance and I think he'll take it.
Martin O'Neill

We all make mistakes but mine have been lived out in the public eye. I'm not saying I'm an angel but I hope everybody gives me the opportunity because I think I deserve it.

People will bring up stuff that's happened in the past but I think everybody has a right to a future and I think I'm no different to anybody else.

But, God willing, things will improve to the point that I can look back on my career and say I had a really low spell but I came through it and I was a better person for it.
Stan Collymore

Wednesday February 16

As a result of an incident at the resort on Tuesday evening, it was decided that in the best interests of all parties we returned home today.

The club regrets any embarrassment or inconvenience caused to any guests and we apologise unreservedly.

The club will be launching its own internal investigation and will severely reprimand any individual or individuals found to be in breach of club discipline.
Leicester statement

webTitle: Yorke flies back for Leeds game after secret deal

fields.headline: Yorke flies back for Leeds game after secret deal
fields.trailText: Dwight Yorke is expected back at Manchester United today after the Premiership leaders negotiated a special release from international duty with Trinidad and Tobago.
fields.body:
Dwight Yorke is expected back at Manchester United today after the Premiership leaders negotiated a special release from international duty with Trinidad and Tobago.

Yorke will take his place in Sunday's league match at Leeds despite the likelihood of his country being involved in the Gold Cup quarter-finals in the United States that day. If necessary, he will then fly back to the tournament immediately after the game at Elland Road. United's manager Sir Alex Ferguson confirmed the agreement yesterday saying: "Dwight is flying back".

The deal has angered the Trinidad manager Richard Braithwaite, who claims it was done over his head by his country's football association. "If we are knocked out without Dwight I will be very unhappy," he said.

"He is our best player and I never wanted him to leave. But what can I do?" The United striker scored his country's final goal in the 4-2 win over Guatemala in Los Angeles on Tuesday night and Trinidad will be in Sunday's quarter-finals unless the Guatemalans pull off a highly unlikely win by three goals or more over Mexico tonight.

Bryan Robson came under further pressure yesterday as the Middlesbrough director George Cooke warned that the club must avoid relegation this season.

Boro's manager has said that he will review his position at the end of the season depending on his team's place. But it is clear that relegation will give Robson no room to ma noeuvre. Cooke, Boro's only director alongside the chairman Steve Gibson, said: "Our priority is to be in the Premier League; we have said all along that's where we've got to be.

"The future is sound, when you look at all the development at the club, but we must preserve our Premier League status. We need to be in the upper echelons of it."

Scotland's captain Colin Hendry is set to return to England next week. The 33-year-old defender has been frozen out at Rangers this season.

Derby, West Ham, Sheffield Wednesday and Watford are all thought to have been in touch about a possible loan move until the end of the season with a view to a permanent transfer. Hendry's former clubs, Manchester City and Blackburn, have also expressed interest.

Bristol City have appointed Tony Fawthrop as caretaker manager until the end of the season. Leroy Rosenior and David Burnside will continue as assistants to Fawthrop, who took over after Tony Pulis left for Portsmouth last month.

The future of a Uefa Cup place for the winners of the Worthington Cup will be examined by the Premier League's 20 club chairmen at a meeting today. This is the last season of a three-year agreement under which Uefa has protected the right of the League Cup winners to enter Europe.

The Football League is anxious to preserve this reward for its competition but several leading clubs may prefer the alternative of this Uefa Cup place going to the Premiership's fifth-placed team.

webTitle: Timely swipe at the World Club Championship

fields.headline: Timely swipe at the World Club Championship
fields.trailText: Europe is set on a collision course with Fifa, football's world governing body, over the timing of the World Club Championship, in which Manchester United controversially took part last month.
fields.body:
Europe is set on a collision course with Fifa, football's world governing body, over the timing of the World Club Championship, in which Manchester United controversially took part last month.

Conflict between the two footballing factions is also likely as Europe's top clubs are opposed to Fifa's plan for a harmonised worldwide season running from February to November.

The clubs made their objections to Fifa's ideas known at a workshop run by Uefa, the European governing body, which finished in Nyon, Switzerland yesterday. Over 40 of Europe's top clubs attended, including Manchester United and Arsenal, and their strident criticism of two of the Fifa president Sepp Blatter's pet projects demonstrates just where they believe the power in the game resides.

The workshop unanimously agreed that Fifa's world club tournament should not be played in the middle of the European domestic season in January, as Fifa insists, but in the northern summer, thus avoiding a repeat of the farce which forced United's withdrawal from the FA Cup to participate in the inaugural tournament last month.

The clubs also called for a summer rescheduling of competitions such as the African Nations Cup, which finished this week but took players such as Nwankwo Kanu away from Arsenal and Rigobert Song from Liverpool at a crucial time of the season.

The Uefa general secretary Gerhard Aigner summed up the European clubs' depth of feeling over the World Club Championship by saying: "It was said that it is absurd and absolutely not acceptable to have an additional competition played at such an unsuitable period in the European calendar. It is a problem."

As for the idea of changing the season, Arsenal's vice-chairman David Dein said: "We have all agreed that it is virtually universally accepted that February to December is unworkable. But it is a problem and there needs to be some fixture harmonisation."

With regard to competitions such as the African Nations Cup, Dein added: "Most European clubs have about seven or eight foreign players who are being pulled all over the shop during the course of the season because of various international tournaments.

"There is conflict growing all the time because you have clubs who are paying their salaries but are losing their players, and of course they can get injured playing for somebody else."

 Scotland could have two representatives in the Champions League for the 2001-2002 season. Uefa confirmed yesterday that a rise from 21st to 14th in the rankings means the top two in Scotland next term will enter the qualifying section of the Champions League the following season.

The Scottish Football Association's chief executive David Taylor welcomed the news: "This opens the prospect of two Scottish clubs being in with a chance of reaching the Champions League final when it is held at Hampden Park in Glasgow in 2002."

fields.headline: Moravcik hands Dalglish final chance
fields.trailText: Celtic 1 - 0 Kilmarnock
fields.body:
Celtic will be in one final at least in their troubled season. They beat Kilmarnock narrowly and unconvincingly last night to earn the right to contest the last match in the CIS Cup.

But the very idea that Kenny Dalglish would bring instant balm to heal their wounds was confounded at Hampden Park.

They won this semi-final when, in the 66th minute, Alan Stubbs produced a ball into space on the right wing for Jackie McNamara to cross and for Lubomir Moravcik to head home - one of the few moments of skill in the game.

Otherwise they looked very ordinary indeed. When a few minutes later Kilmarnock's Henri Cocard was sent off, the outcome became a forgone conclusion in front of an audience that was bored almost to distraction.

The general opinion that the first semi-final between Dundee United and Aberdeen had hardly enhanced the reputation of the game was continued three days later, at least in the first half.

Neither side gave any evidence at all that they could do anything to cheer up their supporters on another cold occasion. There were distinct rumblings from the Celtic fans who detected that their side remains fragile even if under new management.

It might have been different had Celtic's Mark Burchill, in the very first minute, taken about the only chance either team carved out before the interval. Seizing on a loose ball well inside the penalty area, he hit a cross short which eluded the Kilmarnock goalkeeper Colin Meldrum only to bounce back into play off the post.

If anyone was was a hero it was Meldrum. In the 22nd minute he surged off his line to block a Jackie McNamara run and needed extensive treatment for a gashed arm before he was able to continue. By making two similar saves in the next few minutes he at least proved that he was bringing some courage to the contest - but the fans were crying out for some signs of class.

McNamara and Moravcik's combination provided that brief moment of quality, but the goal spurred the visitors into action. Ian Durrant curled a free-kick wide before Cocard's bizarre dismissal for two bookings within the space of a minute. Unperturbed, Kilmarnock again went close with Alex Burke thwarted at the last by Kharine. But, for once, it was Celtic's night.

fields.headline: Akinbiyi leads the hungry pack
fields.trailText: Wolve 4 - 0 Tranmere
fields.body:
Wolves boosted their chances of qualifying for the First Division play-offs last night with a comprehensive victory that leaves Tranmere Rovers little time to regroup in advance of two key cup ties.

Rovers take on Newcastle in the FA Cup's sixth round at the weekend and then Leicester City in the final of the Worthington Cup at Wembley on Sunday week. But there was little from their display here to suggest they were capable of causing further cup upsets.

The prodigious throw-ins of the centre-back Dave Challinor have been a key component of Tranmere's ability to unlock the defences of their so-called betters. And it was via this simple yet mightily effective method that Rovers almost went ahead in the 15th minute.

Wolves, with plenty of land lying fallow at Molineux, were left regretting not widening the pitch when Challinor launched his first missile of the night. Alan Mahon, with the home defenders either watching in admiration or taken by surprise, was first to the ball but Scott Taylor squandered his neat chip by heading straight at Michael Oakes.

Within seconds Challinor showed there was more to his game than long-throw merchant when he was on hand to clear a shot from Ade Akinbiyi after the striker had, using questionable means, dispossessed the Rovers goalkeeper John Achterberg.

Neither Achterberg nor Challinor were in positions of influence when Wolves opened the scoring 10 minutes before the interval.

Andy Sinton created the opportunity with a perfectly flighted left-wing cross that found Akinbiyi unmarked. The striker, however, made a meal of executing his 15th strike of the season, heading the ball firmly into the ground before it bounced into the roof of Achterberg's net. Wolves' second, in the closing stages of the first half, was a much more cleanly dispatched effort.

Steve Sedgley tapped a free-kick and the full-back Lee Nay lor responded with a fierce left-foot shot that cleared the defensive wall before passing just under the right-hand angle of Rovers' goal.

With his defence looking increasingly threadbare, Achterberg was beaten again in the 70th minute when Darren Bazeley turned the former Wolves defender Andy Thompson every which way before cutting inside to score the third.

In the dying seconds Akinbiyi scored his second goal from close range to complete the rout .

webTitle: Sunday best suits Taylor's sharp Gills

fields.headline: Sunday best suits Taylor's sharp Gills
fields.standfirst: The Second Division side relish date with Chelsea
fields.trailText: Dominic Fifield profiles Gillingham manager Peter Taylor ahead of the Gills' quarter-final date with Chelsea on Sunday.
fields.body:
It is just over 24 years to the day since a young, fleet-footed winger dumped Chelsea unceremoniously out of the FA Cup. Peter Taylor's two goals stunned a Valentine's Day crowd of over 54,000 at Stamford Bridge and propelled Malcolm Allison's Crystal Palace, of the Third Division, into the sixth round.

Times have changed. "The phone rang earlier while I was in the bath and I couldn't quite make it in time," says Taylor. "I've lost some of my pace."

On Sunday, he returns to Stamford Bridge to mastermind Gillingham's first FA Cup quarter-final. Already this year Bradford and Sheffield Wednesday have succumbed to the Second Division promotion hopefuls, but victories over Premiership strugglers are one thing. Confronting Chelsea's foreign legion has given the former England under-21 coach a few sleepless nights.

"It's not going to be easy, not bloody easy," he admits. "People think I'm trying to con them, but Chelsea are favourites. Any of the managers left in the hat would have wanted Gillingham at home. It's a very hard game, but we could have been drawn against a less attractive side than Chelsea and been beaten. To me, this draw is the reward for our Cup run."

In the build-up to the Wednesday game, Taylor treated his side to a training break in sunny Bournemouth. In the hope that a repeat routine might produce a similarly rousing performance, the Gills have also spent this week on the south coast.

"I think the change of scenery did them good against Wednesday," he says. "But although Sheffield had some great players - one of my lads joked we had Bob the Builder and they had Gilles de Bilde - we had something going for us: the weather.

"We had to defend the difficult end first and came in only 1-0 down. It was easy for me to tell my players that I thought they would win the game. They just had to go for it."

Amid the joyous scenes at Priestfield that afternoon, Taylor took the time to console Wednesday's Richard Cresswell. "I told him to keep going," he recalls. "I didn't want Cressie's head to go down. I'd be delighted to say the same thing to Jody Morris at the end of Sunday's game, should it come to that of course."

Both Cresswell and Morris know Taylor from his highly successful three-year tenure as coach of the England under-21s. His record was more than impressive - four defeats in 24 and six successive qualifying games for the European Championship won without conceding a goal. But, having secured qualification while their senior counterparts were not even guaranteed a play-off place, the juniors' coach and mentor was quietly relieved of his duties.

"I thoroughly enjoyed my time with England," he says. "Blimey, they were a brilliant three years and I helped to build a real team - not just from the playing side, but also amongst the backroom staff. It was disappointing for it all to end as it did, and I would have loved to have carried on, but I can be philosophical. The memories are still there."

Taylor says he was merely a victim of Howard Wilkinson's desire, as the FA's technical director, to reform the structure of the English game and exert more control over the under-21s. "I've got a lot of respect for Howard [Wilkinson]," he says. "The under-21s fell under his brief and he had his own plans for how he wanted things to progress. Those plans meant my job wasn't there any more.

"I certainly don't have a problem with Howard. I sincerely hope he doesn't have a problem with me."

His successor will do well to retain the homespun atmosphere created by Taylor. "We never seemed to get any cry-offs," he says. "People wanted to come to our sessions and if someone pulled out it was always because they were genuinely injured.

"The biggest testament to our success was the number of lads who have already gone on to full international level, but it was a pleasure to work with them all. Once it had finished it was time to move on to the next thing."

Opportunity knocked more quickly than he might have expected. When the already delicate relationship between the Gillingham manager Tony Pulis and his chairman Paul Scally finally ruptured, Taylor was handed his chance. He assumed the reins at a club which had just experienced its own heartbreak.

Having led Manchester City 2-0 with a minute remaining in the 1999 play-off final at Wembley, goals from Kevin Horlock and Paul Dickov had ruined a season's work in the blink of an eye. Defeat on penalties was inevitable.

But Taylor is not thinking about a return to Wembley just yet. "I just want the players to enjoy Sunday," he adds. "Stamford Bridge is an incredible stadium. If anything, Chelsea away is as good as being at Wembley.

"I'd love us to win, or even draw, but I want the lads to enjoy it and be pleased with their performance at the end."

fields.headline: League snubs £2bn Sky offer
fields.trailText: Sky received a blunt reminder of the new order in televised football yesterday when its multi-billion pound offer for exclusive live rights was snubbed by the Premier League.
fields.body:
Sky received a blunt reminder of the new order in televised football yesterday when its multi-billion pound offer for exclusive live rights was snubbed by the Premier League. The staggering deal, thought to be worth around £2bn, was presented to a meeting of Premier League chairmen as Sky tried to make a pre-emptive strike for a new four-year contract.

Rupert Murdoch's satellite channel has enjoyed a monopoly of Premiership live coverage since 1992. But it no longer enjoys a monopoly in purchasing power. There are now other major players who can compete with Sky's wealth. So Sky tried to lure the Premier League into signing now.

But the Premier League's position is so strong that it resisted temptation and stuck to its commitment to conduct a tendering process for the new deal, which has to be agreed by June.

Sky won the rights to the last four-year deal, which runs out this season, by paying £670m. No other TV company could come anywhere near that. So the Premier League was more than happy to take the money, even though it meant relinquishing some control, notably the decisions on which games would be televised and when.

But now the Premier League is in the driving seat as other companies are eager to get their hands on its product, notably the American cable giant NTL and OnDigital, which has shown it means business by buying the rights to some live Champions League games.

The Premier League meeting received an update from the chief executive Richard Scudamore. He has canvassed clubs individually and is now compiling a tender document for potential bidders.

fields.headline: Blair is worst among equals
fields.trailText:
For such a strict disciplinarian, Tony Blair must have felt a slight shudder
        yesterday when it was confirmed that he has slipped to near the bottom of
        the class.
fields.body:
For such a strict disciplinarian, Tony Blair must have felt a slight shudder yesterday when it was confirmed that he has slipped to near the bottom of the class.

Official figures released by the House of Commons library revealed that the prime minister has the worst voting record of the 20 cabinet ministers who sit in the Commons. Since the Queen's speech in November, Mr Blair has only managed to turn up for 5% of votes, ranking him in 622nd place out of 659 MPs. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has a similar record, although he has the excuse of many overseas trips.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, turned up for a mere 16% of votes. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, has one of the cabinet's more impressive records, turning up for 53% of votes.

The prime minister's defenders will say that he cannot be expected to vote regularly because he has endless meetings to attend at night and numerous red boxes to devour.

But opponents will say that his dismal voting record , which is far lower than those of Margaret Thatcher and John Major, shows that the prime minister is indifferent about the workings of parliament.

Bob Marshall-Andrews, the maverick Labour MP for Medway who is close to the top of the class with an 85% record, said the figures were ` very regrettable. If ministers do not attend parliament, they lose touch with democracy''.

William Hague, who has more time on his hands than the cabinet, only managed to turn up for 27% of votes, slipping to 586th place. Top of the class was the Labour MP for Bolton SE, Brian Iddon, who attended 98% of votes.

There were 19 MPs at the bottom of the class, with a voting record of 0%, including the Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, his deputy, the Liberal Democrat, Jim Wallace, and Ron Davies, the former Welsh secretary who now sits in the Welsh assembly.

webTitle: Collymore fined for fire extinguisher folly

fields.headline: Collymore fined for fire extinguisher folly
fields.standfirst:
Collymore speaks
Collymore's career in the balance
fields.trailText: Would you want this man mowing your lawn? Stan Collymore, who was kicked out by Montpellier after two days and cost Aston Villa £7m in two and a half years, will be spending some time on "good causes" this year.
fields.body:
Would you want this man mowing your lawn? Stan Collymore, who was kicked out by Montpellier after two days and cost Aston Villa £7m in two and a half years, will be spending some time on "good causes" this year.

Leicester City have fined Collymore two weeks' wages, warned him about his conduct and required him to undertake community service for his part in the schemozzle in La Manga last week. He will also have to pay a share of the costs of the Spanish trip, including a £700 bill for damage to the bar area, where Collymore enlivened Tuesday night by setting off a fire extinguisher.

"Unless an incident involving Stan had been incredibly serious I had no intention of sacking Stan," Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill said today. "I still think it is a warning to Stan. This, in footballing parlance, is a yellow card."

O'Neill admitted that the hotel's version of events that led to the Leicester squad being asked to leave was essentially accurate. "I would love to find an excuse but no, there was no provocation.

"The players realise they have let down supporters and the club, and wish to make a full apology.

"I'm not best pleased with Stan at the moment and I'm not best pleased with a number of people. I'm not best pleased with my staff, in terms of them looking after the players. John Robertson (O'Neill's assistant) was in charge of looking after the party and he is very contrite at the moment.

"My annoyance stems from a party of us representing the club not behaving properly. I am not talking in terms of Stan being made the scapegoat for the whole hullabaloo." O'Neill said that Collymore had apologised to staff and players. "I always felt when he came here that there would probably be an incident involving Stan in some way," the manager said, "but I've got to say I didn't expect it to come so quickly."

The club will require Collymore to perform some tasks for local good causes this season. "I want Stan and other players to give hope, time and concern for other people apart from ourselves all the time," O'Neill said. "If it widens his eyes to other people's predicaments and other people being less well off than himself, in terms of health not money, then I will be delighted."

fields.headline: Collymore speaks
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore has gone on the record to apologise for getting his new club Leicester sent home from their training break in La Manga earlier this week. But the controversial striker has tempered his penitence somewhat by claiming his actions were all in good fun.
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has gone on the record to apologise for getting his new club Leicester sent home from their training break in La Manga earlier this week. But the controversial striker has tempered his penitence somewhat by claiming his actions were all in good fun.

"Yes, I did let the fire extinguisher off over our physio who was about two or three yards away. After that, we were packed off to bed," Collymore told a radio station this afternoon.

"I will take the consequences and I do apologise to the manager, who has been put in a situation where he has had to give a press conference. But we were just having a laugh with the lads."

Collymore has been fined two week's wages and warned as to his future conduct. But the impression given by the 29-year-old is that events may have been blown out of proportion. "I fully accept the fine that the club has imposed," he said, "but a million players have done it and a million more will do it in the future."

Collymore was at pains to stress how indebted he is to Leicester for giving him a chance to resurrect his Premiership career. "As soon as I came to the club, one of the ladies from the backroom staff took me around and introduced me to everybody at Filbert Street," he said. "The lads embraced me and said they wanted me to come here and play well." After the events of the last couple of days, Leicester will expect him to concentrate on his playing and nothing else.

fields.headline: White on black
fields.standfirst:
The Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence is being ignored, says Michael Mansfield

Race issues in the UK: special report
Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: This week marks the first anniversary of the publication of the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, whose murderers were never brought to justice. What progress has been made in implementing the report's 70 recommendations? Sadly, the picture is a grim one, littered with broken promises, inaction and reticence.
fields.body:
This week marks the first anniversary of the publication of the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, whose murderers were never brought to justice. What progress has been made in implementing the report's 70 recommendations? Sadly, the picture is a grim one, littered with broken promises, inaction and reticence.

Sir William Macpherson and his inquiry panel stated "we hope and expect that implementation of our recommendations will ensure that the opportunity for radical thinking and root and branch action is seized. Nothing less will satisfy us, and all those who so passionately spoke to us during our hearings".

But there has been very little feedback from the government about what steps they are taking towards implementation. There are working parties, advisory groups and, even for that matter, a task force involved. Yet so far, no public report has been issued. Surely, at very least, the public is entitled to know how many targets have so far been achieved?

The core finding of the Macpherson report was that of "institutional racism" defined as "unwitting prejudice, ignorance, thoughtlessness and racist stereotyping which disadvantage minority ethnic people". The commissioner of the metropolitan police, Sir Paul Condon, staunchly and steadfastly resisted this conclusion .

But on the back of this finding the inquiry recommended "that the full force of the race relations legislation should apply to all police officers".

The panel plainly wanted the "full force" to apply to indirect systemic racism as much as to direct, overt racism. The race relations amendment bill, however, did not do this until the very day on which the home secretary was faced with defeat in the House of Lords. The government's attitude thus far does not sit well with all its heartfelt declarations about race.

Daily policing too remains largely untouched: Stephen Lawrence's father, Neville, and his cousin were subsequently stopped by police and questioned about their car. And one of the Lawrence inquiry panelists, Bishop John Sentanu, was stopped and ordered to open the boot of his car. There was no good reason for suspecting the bishop of committing any offence.

In 1998 and 1999 black people were six times more likely to be stopped and searched than white people (compared to five times in 1998). This disparity resulted in specific recommendations in the Macpherson report. If implemented, number 61 would have entitled the bishop to a copy of the record of why he was stopped and searched.

There is still an unwillingness to recognise the existence and incidence of racial crime. This attitude is perhaps exemplified in the first investigation into the murder of Michael Menson, the initial investigation into the death of Ricky Reel and, currently, it would appear, the racial harassment surrounding the McGowan hangings.

Other specific and far-reaching Macpherson recommendations included : "Victims or victims' families should be allowed to become civil parties to criminal proceedings, to facilitate and to ensure the provision of all relevant information to victims or their families." This is currently the position in France.

Moreover, it was suggested that the crown prosecution service ensure that a victim or victim's family should be kept informed of any proposal to discontinue proceedings, that decisions to discontinue any prosecution should be carefully and fully recorded in writing, and that normally decisions should be disclosable to the family. At all times the family should be personally informed with speed and sensitivity.

In the matter of inquests, the report suggested that there should be advance disclosure of evidence and documents, as of right, to parties and that consideration should be given to extending legal aid to victims, or their families. Importantly, it was also suggested that police complaints authority reports could be disclosed to complainants, subject only to a "substantial harm" test.

Yet one year on and we are no nearer the implementation of even these proposals.

The most crucial aspect concerning any police investigation is freedom of information. The home secretary has not incorporated into the FoI bill the obvious and clear recommendation put forward by Macpherson that any such act should apply to all areas of policing, both operational and administrative, subject only to the "substantial harm" test for withholding disclosure.

Not only has this test been watered down to merely "causing prejudice", and Jack Straw, needless to say without consultation, has recently added a new power to ban the release of any public documents; but also clauses 28 and 29 expressly exempt the police and law enforcement agencies. Therefore, Doreen and Neville Lawrence would face very similar difficulties today in their hunt for the truth as they had to face in the past.

It is perhaps ironic that the only proposal that has been actively and positively pursued by the government in the last year is one that was not, in fact, proposed by any of the parties to the Lawrence inquiry and that did not receive detailed examination and debate. Sir William Macpherson did, however, suggest that consideration be given to ending the double jeopardy rule to permit prosecution after acquittal where fresh and viable evidence is presented.

In the circumstances of the Lawrence case where the original investigation was so dilatory and defective, and where five suspects have behaved in public with arrogance and aggression, it is perfectly understandable that the panel would feel an urgent desire to enable the prosecuting authorities to pursue those responsible. Yet we must be extremely careful to guard against letting emotion sweep away some of the basic tenets of criminal jurisprudence .

If an investigating authority is allowed a "second bite of the cherry" we run the risk that, in order to obtain convictions, the police may resort to the activities that bedevilled so many of the miscarriage of justice cases of the 1980's. For example "confession evidence" may be said to have been discovered for the first time after an acquittal, relating either to conversations with cell-mates, prison officers or, perhaps, passing police officers. Or evidence "overlooked" at the scene of a crime may suddenly emerge for the first time. So, with the exception of this one flawed proposal, the excellent framework so assiduously laid out in the Macpherson Report remains to be implemented. No doubt the government hopes that if enough time passes the detail will be lost in the wash.

Yet a groundswell of public opinion demands action. Victims of racial crime, and their families, must be confident that they will be acknowledged, respected and consulted throughout the dark days of their grief. A failure to act betrays them as much as it betrays the memory of Stephen.

 Michael Mansfield QC is president of the National Civil Rights Movement.

webTitle: Cutting off our nose to spite a race

fields.headline: Cutting off our nose to spite a race
fields.standfirst:
Britain faces a skills shortage. A home office report finds most successful asylum-seekers are highly skilled but racism stops them working

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Surprisingly, perhaps, in the light of Jack Straw's promise to expel all those aboard the hijacked Afghan plane, it is official government policy that Britain has long benefited from the rich culture, energy and diversity that refugees have brought to this country.
fields.body:
Surprisingly, perhaps, in the light of Jack Straw's promise to expel all those aboard the hijacked Afghan plane, it is official government policy that Britain has long benefited from the rich culture, energy and diversity that refugees have brought to this country.

Mr Straw recognised that 18 months ago when he abolished the need for recognised refugees to wait four years before it was decided whether they could stay in Britain indefinitely. Under the Labour government the proportion of those given refugee status or exceptional leave to remain has risen from under 20% of all asylum applicants to over 30%. Yet the debate continues to be dominated by claims that Britain's asylum system is being "swamped" by poor economic migrants whose only interest is to milk the social security system.

However, most refugees go home when the political situation in their country makes that possible. For example, some 1,570 Kosovans who came to the UK last summer have already gone back under a voluntary return programme. The most recent figures show that in the 10 years between 1988 and 1998 a total of only 58,350 people were given the right to settle in Britain, including children and dependents. All were officially recognised as having come to Britain because they had been living in fear or had suffered persecution and even torture.

Home office research published in 1995 exploded the myth that these people have few skills to offer Britain. "Two-thirds had been in jobs in their countries, but only a quarter had employment at the time of the interview. Of those seeking work, almost two-thirds were unemployed. Only 14% had been regularly earning for most of their time in this country. Their unemployment rate was far above that even for ethnic minorities generally in the inner city.

"Many of those who were employed considered themselves to be in jobs well below the level for which they were qualified. A high proportion were found to be highly qualified people, many with university degrees," said the official study into the settlement of refugees in Britain. The one in seven who had found work were either working for themselves or in the "ethnic job sector" such as fast food ethnic restaurants.

Home office researchers found that most came from big cities and only one in 10 had lived in rural areas. One- third of all those accepted as genuine refugees had a university degree, post-graduate or professional qualification. Only 18% had no educational qualifications.

Many had been in good jobs in their own countries when they fled. "There were academics, senior civil servants, doctors, accountants, teachers, lawyers, engineers, businesspeople, managers, members of the armed forces, office workers, nurses, technicians, mechanics, drivers, electricians, shop assistants, factory workers, security guards and waiters." The unskilled only accounted for 5% of recognised refugees.

Disturbingly, the same research found that half had encountered racism since they had been in Britain, with almost a third having suffered verbal abuse and threats. Some 18% had been attacked.

Although the number of recognised refugees has grown sharply in the five years since that research was undertaken, a home office report published last October argued that there was now a pressing need to help them get settled in Britain.

"Many encounter high levels of unemployment, have poor housing and health, and achieve limited access to welfare services. In addition, many suffer social isolation, discrimination and marginalisation," says the official paper on the integration of recognised refugees in the UK.

"Social justice and human rights concerns demand that refugees should be able to live in dignity while receiving the surrogate protection of and being in a position to contribute to the host country. Once a refugee is granted permission to stay, there is a need to invest early in integration to promote a quick move from dependency to self-value and sufficiency."

This home office document stresses that those recognised as refugees should be regarded as equal members of society. But five years on from the 1995 report and it is still reporting the same problems. Many still are not able to speak English and special language classes are still not provided. Although Britain's unemployment rate is now at its lowest for many years, the opportunity to ensure that they can participate in the economic life of the country is being missed. The net result is that many end up living on social security benefits as their tormentors in the Conservative party and on the Daily Mail sneeringly predict. But as the experience of the Ugandan Asians, the Vietnamese boat people and others suggest they may soon develop their own businesses if they can't find employment. The drive of the Asian community in Britain was a major factor underlining Thatcher's 1980s economic boom.

The lack of a job exacerbated by difficulties in communicating well in English often mean refugees have problems in finding somewhere satisfactory to live. The psychological problems that many face as a result of past persecution mean that they need specialist health services. Some have been maimed. Single women, with or without children, may need separate secure accommodation.

The new national system of dispersal of asylum seekers throughout Britain which comes into effect in April has meant that in the "cluster areas" a special effort is being made to develop new networks to support refugees in this situation. A lot of this work is done in London and the south-east by voluntary organisations or community associations but the dispersal decision means that the government is having to start from scratch in these "cluster" areas. The deep hostility, bordering on racism, towards asylum seekers seen in much of the media in the past week does not bode well for the political will that is needed in these new parts of the country for the future reception and settlement of refugees.

Alan Travis is the Guardian's home affairs editor. The Settlement of Refugees in Britain, home office research study 141, 1995. Consultation Paper on the Integration of Recognised Refugees in the UK, home office, October 1999

fields.headline: Gorman faces Commons suspension
fields.standfirst: The full standards and privileges committee report
fields.trailText: Maverick Tory backbencher Teresa Gorman is set to be suspended from the House of Commons for a month after the parliamentary standards watchdog found that she failed to register lucrative business interests.
fields.body:
Maverick Tory backbencher Teresa Gorman is set to be suspended from the House of Commons for a month after the parliamentary standards watchdog found that she failed to register lucrative business interests.

The recommendation to suspend the MP for Billericay, in Essex, came in a report by the Commons committee on standards and privileges.

The committee's recommendation was in response to a finding by the commissioner for parliamentary standards, Elizabeth Filkin, that Mrs Gorman failed to log in the Commons interests register three properties in south London during the period 1987 to 1994, which were let to tenants and from which she derived substantial income.

Mrs Gorman, who earlier withdrew her cooperation with the committee, dismissed the findings in a written statement.

"I totally reject the findings of the committee," she said. "Since my election I have been disposing of my outside interests to concentrate on my job."

She branded the committee's procedures as "unfair" and said they "inevitably" led to injustice. "I totally agree with the Neill Committee [on standards in public life] report on reinforcing standards, which recommends 1. that the chairman [of the standards and privileges committee] should not come from the Government party 2. there should be equal representation of parties on the committee 3. there should be an appeal procedure before an independent judge and senior figures from the Commons."

"Judge for yourself whether this committee is independent or if it is a tool of the Labour party spin doctor industry," she added.

In her report, Mrs Filkin also concluded:  Mrs Gorman failed to register two properties in Portugal from 1987-90 and 1989-99 respectively which were let to tenants for rent;  Mrs Gorman gave "seriously misleading" information in 1995 and 1999 about her connections with the offshore companies Partingdale Holdings, Loxhill Investments and Kinloch Investments, owned by the Queenstown Trust, and did not specify them in the register;  Mrs Gorman should not have introduced a 10 minute rule bill in 1990 proposing the repeal of the rents act without registering and declaring her financial interest.

fields.headline: Wiles, Walls and Wheels
fields.trailText: JUSTICE - FOXY STYLE
fields.body:
JUSTICE - FOXY STYLE

Martin O'Neill knew it, you see. You don't get to be manager of the Foxy Foxes without having something of the vulpine about you, and Mart knew that Stanley Victor Collymore would get in trouble at some point. "I always felt when he came here that there would probably be an incident," he said today. Mart knew it alright - just couldn't do anything about stopping it, that's all.

Stanley has been fined two week's wages, the maximum allowed under PFA rules, and warned as to his future conduct after Tuesday night's rumpus in the La Manga football resort (it's got a great driving range too! - K Dalglish). He will also be asked to perform some community service, but O'Neill claims he had no intention of kicking the former bedroom dweller out of Filbert Street. "Unless an incident had been incredibly serious I had no intention of sacking Stan," he told a press conference. "I still think it is a warning. This, in footballing parlance, is a yellow card."

Spot the occasional Match of the Day pundit. But O'Neill did not restrict his censure to Stanley, forcing his players to pay for the entire trip including a £700 bill for damage to the hotel. He also claimed, "My annoyance stems from a party of us representing the club not behaving properly. In terms of behaviour, I don't believe it's acceptable, especially in the current climate when players' behaviour is under scrutiny."

O'Neill in no way defended his players, but he didn't appear to be too chuffed with the star of La Manga Uncovered, managing director Tony Coles either. "I have spoken to Mr Coles this morning and he admits a couple of things written did not happen," O'Neill revealed in an understated fashion. "It was said players were stood on their chairs," he said, "One player stood on a chair and was told to sit down by one of my staff and he did." Send 'em home!

What, they have already?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I've got a nice present for him when he comes back." - The venerable Bobby Robson Esq. on his Peruvian winger Nolberto Solano who went to the Gold Cup against his manager's wishes, and is coming back injured.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NAMING NAMES

The Fiver reckons you've got to put your faith in youth. Mainly because there's no way we're going to trust anything old codgers like Kelvin Koogan get up to. So it is with mixed emotions that we announce England's squad to face Argentina next week - Koogan's picked it (bah! boo!), but on the other hand he's selected Liverpool youngster Steven Gerrard (whoop!) and Villa tot Gareth Barry (wahey!).

Koog explains Gerrard and Barry have made the squad "on merit". Which is nice. But while the Liverpool youngster was the recipient of some lovely praise - "In all the games I've seen I don't think anybody has played as well as he has done over the last six to eight weeks" - Barry had to make do with some indecipherable claptrap - "He came from Brighton straight into Villa's first team and he hit the wall." Ah well, you're in the squad, Gareth, that's the main thing.

Also named in the squad is Dennis Wise, even though the tiny cockney has been charged with misconduct after challenging Kenny Cunningham to isotonic beverages at dawn. "It would be wrong of me to pre-empt anything that happened against Wimbledon," explained Koog. "If I missed Dennis out of this squad, I would set a precedent that I would regret in the future."

Whether you agree or not, England will certainly need Wise's battling qualities in a game seen as a "severe test" by Koog. "I don't think there will be any better team in Euro 2000 than Argentina," he opined, totally ignoring Uefa's qualification rules in one of those I-know-what-he-means-but-dear-me-what-an-eejit statements we're finally getting used to.

* The full squad: Seaman (Arsenal), Martyn (Leeds), Wright (Ipswich), G Neville (Man Utd), P Neville (Man Utd), Barry (Aston Villa), Southgate (Aston Villa), Campbell (Tottenham), Keown (Arsenal), Ferdinand (West Ham), Beckham (Man Utd), Ince (Middlesbrough), Froggatt (Coventry), Wilcox (Leeds), Dyer (Newcastle), Gerrard (Liverpool), Parlour (Arsenal), Scholes (Man Utd), Sinclair (West Ham), Wise (Chelsea), Cole (Man Utd), Phillips (Sunderland), Heskey (Leicester), Shearer (Newcastle).

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CRIME PAYS

Russian football doesn't make much of an appearance in the Fiver. At least not since Citizen Fiver nipped off to a rally in Volgograd and never came back. But recently the game in the frozen wastes has seen more action than a Taggart three-parter. Chairmen have been murdered, top players have been caught heading through customs with suitcases of cash, and now, to top it all, Andrei Tikhonov has had his car nicked.

Tikhonov, Leeds fans may remember (or even those who stay up late for Gabby Yorath's Big Cup), is Spartak Moscow's star midfielder and one of the biggest names in Russian footy. But the other day he had his jeep stolen from outside his house and his baby dumped out of the front window. "I'm leaving Russia to play abroad," Tikhonov told a Russian paper today, "I no longer want to fear for my family every single day." Tikhonov will follow the lead of Russian captain Viktor Onopko who left Russia for Spain when he had his jeep nicked four years ago.

The Fiver can only offer its sympathies to Russian footballers - who can afford 4x4s while their compatriots can barely afford their fuel bills. The Fiver must also congratulate Manchester United who know a situation when they see one. What better market in which to look for a transfer bargain than one in which all the players are looking to leave? "I know that the coach of Manchester United is interested in me," Alexei Smertin of Spartak's local rivals Lokomotiv Moscow said today. "I will now play as well as I can in next week's international to show Mr Ferguson what I can do." Hurrah.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Juventus are said to be preparing an £8m bid for Joe Cole. The Italian giants are in the middle of rejuvenating their squad and, along with their recent purchase from West Brom Enzo Maresca, see Cole as central to their plans.

Meanwhile, Serie A rivals Inter Milan are ready to offer Newcastle United a £4m profit on Kieron Dyer within a season, by offering the club £10m for his services.

Everton look set to sign Sheffield Wednesday's Swedish midfielder Niclas Alexandersson at the end of the season.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Chelsea don't know where Celestine Babayaro is. There has been no contact between the Nigerian defender and Chelsea since Nigeria's defeat in the final of the African Nations Cup last Sunday. Gianluca Vialli said: "He could be back tomorrow. Anything can happen. At the moment he's officially still in Nigeria but in reality we don't know for sure." If you know where Celestine is, email the.boss@theguardian.com with the subject 'Chelsea have only gone and lost Babayaro, innit?'

Portsmouth have received planning permission to build a new £30m, 35,000 all-seater stadium. The new ground will be part of a new £80m retail development site on Fratton goods yard, next to the club's existing ground.

Leeds have requested personal hearings for the misconduct charges issued by the FA earlier this week.

Greenock Morton have confirmed that court action has been taken against the club by Strathclyde Police over unpaid police charges amounting to around £29,000.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (3.15am)

Football isn't just played in Britain, you know.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.45am)

See?!?

Channel 5: Live And Dangerous (11.45pm)

An unfunny comedian previewing the FA Cup quarter-finals is not dangerous in the Fiver's book, pal.

Dutch Football (12.25am)

It's flat. It's round.

Argentinian Football (2.05am)

It's round. It's covered in ticker tape.

Footy Shorts (3.45am)

This week, an average FA Cup run by Aston Villa.

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.15am)

Sepp Blatter's sketch-and-a-song show continues with a guest appearance from Mr Chicken-and-broken-microphone himself, Norman Collier.

The Last Word (7.30pm)

Seeing as it's about Alan Shearer, the last word will probably be "creosote".

Spanish Football (8pm, 12.45am)

Pour yourself a lovely pint of sangria. Relax.

You're on Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am)

Fiver reader Colin McLaren on McCaff: "His finely chiseled features make me wonder if he was popped out the oven before he was completely done." We're saying nothing.

Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1)

Phil Babb chairs a debate which takes in the Oscar nominations, the latest jazz releases and whether William Hague is right to give Michael Portillo such a high profile post in the shadow cabinet.

Sky Sports 3: World Cup Classics (10pm)

England, Argentina, the 1966 World Cup and Alf Ramsey's guide to race relations.

Sky One: Dream Team (6.30pm, 11pm)

A red-faced racing-obsessed Scottish bloke in charge of a Premiership football team? Who writes this far-fetched tosh?
fields.bodyText: JUSTICE - FOXY STYLE Martin O'Neill knew it, you see. You don't get to be manager of the Foxy Foxes without having something of the vulpine about you, and Mart knew that Stanley Victor Collymore would get in trouble at some point. "I always felt when he came here that there would probably be an incident," he said today. Mart knew it alright - just couldn't do anything about stopping it, that's all. Stanley has been fined two week's wages, the maximum allowed under PFA rules, and warned as to his future conduct after Tuesday night's rumpus in the La Manga football resort (it's got a great driving range too! - K Dalglish). He will also be asked to perform some community service, but O'Neill claims he had no intention of kicking the former bedroom dweller out of Filbert Street. "Unless an incident had been incredibly serious I had no intention of sacking Stan," he told a press conference. "I still think it is a warning. This, in footballing parlance, is a yellow card." Spot the occasional Match of the Day pundit. But O'Neill did not restrict his censure to Stanley, forcing his players to pay for the entire trip including a £700 bill for damage to the hotel. He also claimed, "My annoyance stems from a party of us representing the club not behaving properly. In terms of behaviour, I don't believe it's acceptable, especially in the current climate when players' behaviour is under scrutiny." O'Neill in no way defended his players, but he didn't appear to be too chuffed with the star of La Manga Uncovered, managing director Tony Coles either. "I have spoken to Mr Coles this morning and he admits a couple of things written did not happen," O'Neill revealed in an understated fashion. "It was said players were stood on their chairs," he said, "One player stood on a chair and was told to sit down by one of my staff and he did." Send 'em home! What, they have already? * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "I've got a nice present for him when he comes back." - The venerable Bobby Robson Esq. on his Peruvian winger Nolberto Solano who went to the Gold Cup against his manager's wishes, and is coming back injured. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NAMING NAMES The Fiver reckons you've got to put your faith in youth. Mainly because there's no way we're going to trust anything old codgers like Kelvin Koogan get up to. So it is with mixed emotions that we announce England's squad to face Argentina next week - Koogan's picked it (bah! boo!), but on the other hand he's selected Liverpool youngster Steven Gerrard (whoop!) and Villa tot Gareth Barry (wahey!). Koog explains Gerrard and Barry have made the squad "on merit". Which is nice. But while the Liverpool youngster was the recipient of some lovely praise - "In all the games I've seen I don't think anybody has played as well as he has done over the last six to eight weeks" - Barry had to make do with some indecipherable claptrap - "He came from Brighton straight into Villa's first team and he hit the wall." Ah well, you're in the squad, Gareth, that's the main thing. Also named in the squad is Dennis Wise, even though the tiny cockney has been charged with misconduct after challenging Kenny Cunningham to isotonic beverages at dawn. "It would be wrong of me to pre-empt anything that happened against Wimbledon," explained Koog. "If I missed Dennis out of this squad, I would set a precedent that I would regret in the future." Whether you agree or not, England will certainly need Wise's battling qualities in a game seen as a "severe test" by Koog. "I don't think there will be any better team in Euro 2000 than Argentina," he opined, totally ignoring Uefa's qualification rules in one of those I-know-what-he-means-but-dear-me-what-an-eejit statements we're finally getting used to. * The full squad: Seaman (Arsenal), Martyn (Leeds), Wright (Ipswich), G Neville (Man Utd), P Neville (Man Utd), Barry (Aston Villa), Southgate (Aston Villa), Campbell (Tottenham), Keown (Arsenal), Ferdinand (West Ham), Beckham (Man Utd), Ince (Middlesbrough), Froggatt (Coventry), Wilcox (Leeds), Dyer (Newcastle), Gerrard (Liverpool), Parlour (Arsenal), Scholes (Man Utd), Sinclair (West Ham), Wise (Chelsea), Cole (Man Utd), Phillips (Sunderland), Heskey (Leicester), Shearer (Newcastle). * * * * * * * * * * * * * CRIME PAYS Russian football doesn't make much of an appearance in the Fiver. At least not since Citizen Fiver nipped off to a rally in Volgograd and never came back. But recently the game in the frozen wastes has seen more action than a Taggart three-parter. Chairmen have been murdered, top players have been caught heading through customs with suitcases of cash, and now, to top it all, Andrei Tikhonov has had his car nicked. Tikhonov, Leeds fans may remember (or even those who stay up late for Gabby Yorath's Big Cup), is Spartak Moscow's star midfielder and one of the biggest names in Russian footy. But the other day he had his jeep stolen from outside his house and his baby dumped out of the front window. "I'm leaving Russia to play abroad," Tikhonov told a Russian paper today, "I no longer want to fear for my family every single day." Tikhonov will follow the lead of Russian captain Viktor Onopko who left Russia for Spain when he had his jeep nicked four years ago. The Fiver can only offer its sympathies to Russian footballers - who can afford 4x4s while their compatriots can barely afford their fuel bills. The Fiver must also congratulate Manchester United who know a situation when they see one. What better market in which to look for a transfer bargain than one in which all the players are looking to leave? "I know that the coach of Manchester United is interested in me," Alexei Smertin of Spartak's local rivals Lokomotiv Moscow said today. "I will now play as well as I can in next week's international to show Mr Ferguson what I can do." Hurrah. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Juventus are said to be preparing an £8m bid for Joe Cole. The Italian giants are in the middle of rejuvenating their squad and, along with their recent purchase from West Brom Enzo Maresca, see Cole as central to their plans. Meanwhile, Serie A rivals Inter Milan are ready to offer Newcastle United a £4m profit on Kieron Dyer within a season, by offering the club £10m for his services. Everton look set to sign Sheffield Wednesday's Swedish midfielder Niclas Alexandersson at the end of the season. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Chelsea don't know where Celestine Babayaro is. There has been no contact between the Nigerian defender and Chelsea since Nigeria's defeat in the final of the African Nations Cup last Sunday. Gianluca Vialli said: "He could be back tomorrow. Anything can happen. At the moment he's officially still in Nigeria but in reality we don't know for sure." If you know where Celestine is, email the.boss@theguardian.com with the subject 'Chelsea have only gone and lost Babayaro, innit?' Portsmouth have received planning permission to build a new £30m, 35,000 all-seater stadium. The new ground will be part of a new £80m retail development site on Fratton goods yard, next to the club's existing ground. Leeds have requested personal hearings for the misconduct charges issued by the FA earlier this week. Greenock Morton have confirmed that court action has been taken against the club by Strathclyde Police over unpaid police charges amounting to around £29,000. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: World Football (3.15am) Football isn't just played in Britain, you know. Channel 4: Football Italia (2.45am) See?!? Channel 5: Live And Dangerous (11.45pm) An unfunny comedian previewing the FA Cup quarter-finals is not dangerous in the Fiver's book, pal. Dutch Football (12.25am) It's flat. It's round. Argentinian Football (2.05am) It's round. It's covered in ticker tape. Footy Shorts (3.45am) This week, an average FA Cup run by Aston Villa. Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (7pm, 12.15am) Sepp Blatter's sketch-and-a-song show continues with a guest appearance from Mr Chicken-and-broken-microphone himself, Norman Collier. The Last Word (7.30pm) Seeing as it's about Alan Shearer, the last word will probably be "creosote". Spanish Football (8pm, 12.45am) Pour yourself a lovely pint of sangria. Relax. You're on Sky Sports! (10.15pm, 2.45am) Fiver reader Colin McLaren on McCaff: "His finely chiseled features make me wonder if he was popped out the oven before he was completely done." We're saying nothing. Sky Sports 2: Football League Review (5.30pm, 6.30pm SS1) Phil Babb chairs a debate which takes in the Oscar nominations, the latest jazz releases and whether William Hague is right to give Michael Portillo such a high profile post in the shadow cabinet. Sky Sports 3: World Cup Classics (10pm) England, Argentina, the 1966 World Cup and Alf Ramsey's guide to race relations. fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.trailText: An eye mask
fields.body:
An eye mask

Burberry decided to inject a spot of colour into its range a couple of years ago and started producing all sorts of oddities apart from raincoats. The most puzzling addition was probably the Burberry dog coat, but the label has excelled this year with an eyemask priced at £22.50.

Gucci, Hermès and Louis Vuitton must be so cross not to have thought of it first, but congratulations are due to Burberry for opening up a whole new area of useless consumerism. You can see the point of waterproofs, even dog coats - they must get cold too. But what is the point of a designer eyemask? You can't even see yourself in it, for heaven's sake.

But other people can and the distinctive check of the Burberry mask on your brow will no doubt tell them what a stylish person you are so they can treat you with extra respect. Except you'll be asleep and won't notice. Call Burberry on 0171-930 3343 if you feel the need.

fields.headline: How green is your baby?
fields.standfirst: The expensive organic baby goods market is booming. But are recycled nappies and natural cotton clothes really better for children or does clever marketing make us think we're doing our bit for the environment by buying it?
fields.trailText: The expensive organic baby goods market is booming. But are recycled nappies and natural cotton clothes really better for children or does clever marketing make us think we're doing our bit for the environment by buying it?
fields.body:
"Busy?" says author Tanyia Maxted-Frost when I ask whether the organic baby business has been good recently. "Busy? We are flat out trying to keep up with demand." She has already written The Organic Baby Book and is about to publish The Organic Baby Cook Book; business is booming.

Michelle Riley, who started her organic baby business so she could work from home, has been so successful that she is preparing to open a shop, Little Green Earthlets, in Putney, South London. "I wanted to work from home to be with my daughter, so in that respect I have totally failed."

Then there is Nigel Dawson, who gave up banking to set up a wooden toys and games business. He also reports strong demand.

Babies may not care what we make them wear or eat, as long as it doesn't have nasty tight elastic or taste too horrible. But grown-ups seem to care, and quite a lot. In Japan the market for environmentally con scious businesses is expected to grow by 58% over the next decade. In Germany organic baby food accounts for more than 90% of the baby-food market. In Britain, Lizzie Vann, of Organix, says that organic baby food is the only area of the baby food market which is showing any growth at all. A year-on-year growth of 80% means that last year it took 25% of the baby food market.

The advantages of organic baby food have been well rehearsed by its advocates. "Babies and children are most at risk from pesticide residues," says Maxted-Frost, "and if they do react to them and get an upset stomach, it's a much bigger problem than it is for an adult." And in many cases, it is no more expensive than conventional baby food: for example, a 125g pot of Heinz creamed potato with broccoli is only 5p less than a similar product from HIPP but has higher levels of fat, sugar and salt.

In her book, she cites evidence that every non-organic apple has been dosed approximately 40 times with up to 100 chemicals before you eat it. She also examines theories that the dramatic decrease in fertility in the west is linked to pesticides, antibiotics and hormones in food.

But is there a good reason to buy organic nappies and toys and clothes as well as food? Barbara Griggs, who has been writing about alternative health for 20 years, has long been a champion of organic food (although she has concerns about the speed with which the availability is spreading: are all those cartons of organic milk genuine?). "But organic clothes are different," she says.

"I feel a little sceptical about them because some people buying them may think they're making a decision about their health.

"In fact, it's really nothing to do with your health: it's to do with helping reduce the amount of pesticides used in producing cotton. As long as people realise that, it's all right; but you have to understand that you're paying quite a lot more for an essentially altruistic gesture."

The green toy market falls into the same category: playthings made out of wood from replenishable sources do nothing extra for your child - but you could argue that you are doing your bit to save the planet.

The same applies to nappies made from organic cotton. Reusable nappies are considered by some to be as wasteful, in terms of the electricity and water it takes to wash and dry them, as disposables.

The argument has raged for so long that the National Association of Nappy Services commissioned a comparison study by Landbank Consultancy. Using figures produced by Procter & Gamble, the study measured impact per infant per year and found that disposable nappies (Britons use nine million a day) use 3.5 times more energy than cotton washables, 2.3 times more waste water, 8.3 times more non-regenerative materials, 90 times more renewable materials, and 4-30 times more land for raw materials. But you may wonder whether doing your bit for the environment is worth the extra effort.

Many cities and towns now have nappy laundries but if even the prospect of keeping that smelly bucket of soiled squares until the van comes to collect them is too much, you can also buy eco-disposables which biodegrade rather than lingering for decades in a landfill site.

The range of clothes and toys available in the growing green market means that you no longer need to buy organically produced goods just to salve your conscience. This particular consumer revolution has been all about creating options. You've heard all the arguments, now make up your mind whether the saving to the environment is worth the extra cost to you.

Toys

Dawson & Son Wooden Toys and Games. Tel: 01799 526 611; www. dawson-and-son.com. Run by a former banker, Nigel Dawson, who set up the company when he couldn't find good wooden toys for his young son. The wood is from replenishable sources.

Stuart Lennie Woodcrafts. Tel: 01453 750 791. Award-winning wooden toys crafted from replenishable British and European wood; also makes "green" furniture.

Clothes and nappies

Clothworks. Tel 0208 299 1619; www.clothworks.co.uk. Adult and children's clothes - and nappies - made from environmentally friendly fabrics.

Greenfibres. Tel: 01803 868 001; email: mail@greenfibres.com; www.greenfibres.com. Clothing for women, men and children made from organic natural fibres.

Schmidt Natural Clothing. Tel: 01342 822 169. One of the longest-running organic family clothing companies in Britain. Also does nappies.

Green Baby. Tel: 0207 226 4345; www.greenbabyco.com. Small shop with ultra-tasteful goods: bib and burp mat for £8.99; nightgown, hat and stuffed bunny for £18.99. Pricey but tempting.

Naturally for Baby. Tel: 0141 7733241. Lovely clothes and nappies.

Spirit of Nature. Tel: 01582 847 370. Organic nappies and disposable alternatives. Funky clothes.

Little Green Earthlets. Tel: 01825 873 301. Organic nappies; other products, though attractive, have fewer organic credentials.

The Organic Baby Company, Eastbourne. Tel: 01323 411 515. Organic nappies and food.

The National Association of Nappy Services. Call 0121 693-4949 to find out where your nearest nappy laundering service is.

Books

The Organic Baby Book (£7.95), by Tanyia Maxted-Frost, available from Green Books, tel: 01803 863 260. The Organic Baby Cook Book is due out soon, also from Green Books.
