fields.headline: A touch of Mars
fields.standfirst:
Sanjida O'Connell looks at an earthbound scientist's attempt to feel the surface of a distant planet through a robot's fingers
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Sanjida O'Connell looks at an earthbound scientist's attempt to feel the surface of a distant planet through a robot's fingers
fields.body:
As soon as he wires himself up, the thing that immediately comes to mind is: "Prepare to be assimilated. We are the Borg." Professor Mark Cutkosky is elaborately easing his hand into a glove complete with hooks, wires, and flashing lights that looks as if it belongs on a Star Trek set rather than in a laboratory at Stanford University, California.

Even more Trekian, the glove controls a robot called Marvin situated on the other side of the lab. Cutkosky flexes his hand; in response Marvin roots around in some dried peas and picks up a tennis ball. One day, Marvin might pick up something a little more useful - a Martian rock perhaps, while whoever wears the gloves remains firmly back on earth.

Marvin, to describe him fully, is a tele-operated robot hand with two fingers. Each finger has force and tactile sensors embedded within it. The glove also contains sensors, and an algorithm generated by an attached computer "translates" the forces "felt" by the robot to the glove so that the wearer receives a realistic sensation of touch. The glove registers the position of the wearer's fingers, and these signals are also sent via the computer to the robot.

For demonstration purposes, Cutkosky has built a mini seabed. With its dried peas for the sea floor, a plastic fish and a block of salvage with radioactive stripes, it looks like something a toddler might construct. Nevertheless, Cutkosky shows how the robot fingers can pick up and manipulate the block.

"I can come in and grasp this block," says Cutkosky, "and as soon as I do, I can feel the block's weight, and how hard I'm squeezing, so it's very much like I have a block between my own fingers."

If the sensors are turned off, the relationship between Mark and Marvin is less amicable. "I feel like a four month old infant," says Cutkosky, dropping the block on the sea bed.

The technology developed at Stanford could be used for computer games to make interactions in a virtual world more plausible; it might even transform shopping on the internet into a more pleasurable experience by allowing users to feel their potential purchases, from the texture of fabric to the ripeness of a peach. Another application would be to use the robot in a remote or hostile environment.

"A couple of years ago when there was that crash of the airliner in the Florida everglades there was a quote from one of the divers - they were groping around in mucky water, they couldn't see what they were doing, they wanted to know if they had grabbed hold of a root or part of an airplane," says Cutkosky, "and it occurred to me that this would be a lovely environment to have a robot in instead of people."

Recently Cutkosky's team has concentrated on sending Marvin to Mars. For inspiration, they turned to an expert on touch. Professor Geerat Vermeij, from the university of Davis, California, is a palaeontologist who has been blind since he was three. He specialises in classifying fossil shells and has travelled globally in pursuit of his passion. Vermeij believes that parts of the visual cortex in his brain have now become devoted to his sense of touch.

His hunch is backed up partly by brain scans on other blind people showing this very phenomenon, and partly because of the rapidity and accuracy of his tactile ability. Once in Guam he accidentally unearthed a stonefish. These fish can kill. The moment they are touched their spines become erect and they inject a potent nerve toxin into the victim. Geerat, realising it was a stonefish, reacted so swiftly the creature didn't have time to sting him.

Cutkosky's colleague, Michael Costa, spoke to Vermeij at length about his sensation of touch and how best to replicate it in a robot. Vermeij explained that for him there are three scales of dexterity: the first is the whole hand scale where he feels the overall shape of an object like a shell. It is for this reason that he doesn't like traditional sculpture. A Rodin, he claims, is an object to be viewed, not felt: it's cold to the touch and it's impossible to grasp its overall coherence using one's hands. Secondly he feels more minute details with the tip of his fingers or his nails, and finally he uses a needle to probe for ridges and indentations, thus picking up traits in fossil species that sighted palaeontologists sometimes overlook.

Armed with this information, Costa and Cutkosky developed a simpler version of Marvin - a robot probe that acts like Vermeij's needle. The 3GM, as it's known, is a probe that transmits the vibrations of objects. By programming in the different vibrational frequencies of materials, the user can now touch virtual blocks of wood, aluminium and rubber in a computer while holding the probe and feeling a realistic sensation as if he or she were tapping real objects with a 3GM. The idea is that the next robot to explore Mars will be armed with the 3GM.

A geologist on earth will control the robot's probing and feel what it feels. The technology to enable geologists to see and feel in space is being developed by Ted Blackmon and Daryl Rasmussen in conjunction with Nasa.

The robot will have "eyes" - two separate video cameras which will send images back to earth via the Deep Space Network - three landbased antenna that pick up radio waves. The pictures will then be processed at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Lab and sent to the geologist who will be able to view them in 3D by wearing a set of virtual reality goggles. The tactile data from the probe will also be sent in a similar fashion. The lag time is estimated to be 15 minutes.

However, Costa admits that because the data is being converted in this way, anyone using the 3GM on earth will only feel a simulation of what space really feels like.

Moreover, Vermeij might use a needle to extract secrets from shells, but he also uses his finger tips and hands.

As Cutkosky says: "It'll feel like you're probing the world with a wooden spoon."

"A couple of years ago when there was that crash of the airliner in the Florida everglades there was a quote from one of the divers - they were groping around in mucky water, they couldn't see what they were doing, they wanted to know if they had grabbed hold of a root or part of an airplane," says Cutkosky, "and it occurred to me that this would be a lovely environment to have a robot in instead of people." Recently Cutkosky's team has concentrated on sending Marvin to Mars. For inspiration, they turned to an expert on touch. Professor Geerat Vermeij, from the university of Davis, California, is a palaeontologist who has been blind since he was three. He specialises in classifying fossil shells and has travelled globally in pursuit of his passion. Vermeij believes that parts of the visual cortex in his brain have now become devoted to his sense of touch. His hunch is backed up partly by brain scans on other blind people showing this very phenomenon, and partly because of the rapidity and accuracy of his tactile ability. Once in Guam he accidentally unearthed a stonefish. These fish can kill. The moment they are touched their spines become erect and they inject a potent nerve toxin into the victim. Geerat, realising it was a stonefish, reacted so swiftly the creature didn't have time to sting him. Cutkosky's colleague, Michael Costa, spoke to Vermeij at length about his sensation of touch and how best to replicate it in a robot. Vermeij explained that for him there are three scales of dexterity: the first is the whole hand scale where he feels the overall shape of an object like a shell. It is for this reason that he doesn't like traditional sculpture. A Rodin, he claims, is an object to be viewed, not felt: it's cold to the touch and it's impossible to grasp its overall coherence using one's hands. Secondly he feels more minute details with the tip of his fingers or his nails, and finally he uses a needle to probe for ridges and indentations, thus picking up traits in fossil species that sighted palaeontologists sometimes overlook. Armed with this information, Costa and Cutkosky developed a simpler version of Marvin - a robot probe that acts like Vermeij's needle. The 3GM, as it's known, is a probe that transmits the vibrations of objects. By programming in the different vibrational frequencies of materials, the user can now touch virtual blocks of wood, aluminium and rubber in a computer while holding the probe and feeling a realistic sensation as if he or she were tapping real objects with a 3GM. The idea is that the next robot to explore Mars will be armed with the 3GM. A geologist on earth will control the robot's probing and feel what it feels. The technology to enable geologists to see and feel in space is being developed by Ted Blackmon and Daryl Rasmussen in conjunction with Nasa. The robot will have "eyes" - two separate video cameras which will send images back to earth via the Deep Space Network - three landbased antenna that pick up radio waves. The pictures will then be processed at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Lab and sent to the geologist who will be able to view them in 3D by wearing a set of virtual reality goggles. The tactile data from the probe will also be sent in a similar fashion. The lag time is estimated to be 15 minutes. However, Costa admits that because the data is being converted in this way, anyone using the 3GM on earth will only feel a simulation of what space really feels like. Moreover, Vermeij might use a needle to extract secrets from shells, but he also uses his finger tips and hands. As Cutkosky says: "It'll feel like you're probing the world with a wooden spoon."

fields.headline: Shuttle astronauts watch the petrol
fields.trailText: With a wary eye on the fuel gauge, Nasa managers on Wednesday contemplated cutting short an ambitious Earth-mapping mission to save enough fuel to "barbecue" the shuttle Endeavour before its return.
fields.body:
With a wary eye on the fuel gauge, Nasa managers on Wednesday contemplated cutting short an ambitious Earth-mapping mission to save enough fuel to "barbecue" the shuttle Endeavour before its return.

The six Endeavour astronauts and Mission Control have been watching the shuttle's fuel supply for days, uncertain whether there is enough to complete the 11-day mission.

The shuttle must keep enough fuel in reserve to perform a heat-distributing manoeuvre before re-entering Earth's atmosphere - a "barbecue roll" in the vernacular of the US space agency.

The roll evens out temperatures over the shuttle's surface, exposing it to the sun like meat turning on the grill. When the shuttle makes its fiery re-entry into Earth's atmosphere, engineers want everything uniformly fiery.

"The barbecue roll that we would do is a gas hog," Milt Heflin, a mission operations manager told reporters. "It takes more propellant than we would like."

Heflin said Nasa must calculate how much fuel is needed for the barbecue roll before Mission Control can give the astronauts a thumbs up to finish their mission.

Ground controllers want enough fuel to complete more than one barbecue roll if bad landing weather forces the shuttle to stay up one or two extra days.

The fuel problem grew from the failure of a tiny thruster at the end of a 20-story radar mast rising out of Endeavour's cargo bay.

The thruster, designed to keep the mast stable in flight, delivers less than an ounce (28 grams) of force. To compensate, Endeavour is having to fire control jets that each deliver 24 pounds (10.8 kg) of thrust.

Engineers are ready to try other fuel-saving measures, such as using one of the daily firings of Endeavour's fuel jets to raise its orbit.

"I'm still optimistic," Heflin said. "We basically are sharpening our pencils as best as we can."

Endeavour is using radar pulses from the orbiter and from the end of the 197-foot (60-meter) mast to make a high-resolution three dimensional map of the planet's surface.

Astronaut Janice Voss reported seeing something "white, the size of a pebble" come speeding out of the orbiter's cargo bay Wednesday afternoon.

Engineers had speculated that ice might be clogging a nitrogen gas line that feeds the tiny mast thruster. Heflin said Voss's observation might have confirmed that.

In any case, Mission Control has ruled out counting on the thruster for any additional help on this flight.

Endeavour and its crew of six is expected to land at the Kennedy Space Centre on Feb. 22.

Scientists say it will take about 18 months to process the onboard data and create the best topographical maps ever produced.

Nasa has been releasing lower resolution pictures based on data relayed to ground station by the shuttle, and scientists already say they have noted characteristics of the Earth's surface that were not available on the best existing maps.

fields.headline: Cybershopping: men's fashion
fields.trailText: When men go shopping for clothes, they already know what they want (or so they claim)
fields.body:
When men go shopping for clothes, they already know what they want (or so they claim). But you would expect the sort of man who shops at dressmart.com to know more than most. Dressmart caters for the "money-rich, time-poor" businessman. It sells Jermyn Street-type brands (Thomas Pink, Charles Tyrwhitt, Eton).

Send an email, giving three possible dates, and a Gieves & Hawkes tailor will pop round and measure you up in the office. Made-to-measure suits start at £595.

You won't find the same level of sophistication at swerve.co.uk, which claims to be the cheapest UK-based online retailer of designer wear, but it does have amazing discounts - up to 80% on ends of ranges. Zercon.com, on the other hand, does designer discounts with considerably more style. If you can't afford Marc Jacobs' latest corduroy creations, try the Boss jeans in soft-ribbed fabric (aka cord) for only £46.99. The Tommy Hilfiger hooded sailing jacket may lack the latest tartan trim, but is perfect for those slightly more energetic weekends.

La Redoute is the place to go for surfwear. The Quicksilver Cross Lock fleece sweatshirt (£69.99) is a best-seller and there are cotton twill, drawcord safari trousers at £44.99.

Rip Curl fans will find jumbo cord trousers in beige or navy (£44.99) and can snuggle up in a zipped parka with padded interior (£79.99 - in khaki or navy blue). La Redoute's Soft Grey line is good for basics such as crew-neck merino wool sweaters (£37.99).

Tedbaker.co.uk has plenty of chunky knits. The site is being updated to include the spring collection, but there are still a few sale items, including a ribbed back rollneck in 100% lambswool, (down from £52 to £39) or a hooded drawstring jersey top (down to £34 from £56). The more formal Edward Baker collection has cashmere jumpers for only £86.

fields.headline: This is Earth calling...
fields.standfirst:
Alastair Gunn on why Nasa is banking on Britain to find its missing space probe
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Alastair Gunn on why Nasa is banking on Britain to find its missing space probe
fields.body:
The world's most powerful "ears" have been straining to hear faint peeps from the planet Mars. The university of Manchester's Jodrell bank observatory in Cheshire has joined in an attempt to contact Nasa's missing Mars polar lander (MPL) spacecraft.

The MPL was launched from Cape Canaveral on January 3, 1999 for an 11-month flight to the red planet. The lander was designed to touch down near the planet's south pole and study the Martian surface and climate history. But as it hurtled through the Martian atmosphere on December 3, flight controllers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California lost radio contact. After repeated attempts to contact the lander, they concluded the main antenna on the probe had been damaged during the landing.

There are two radio systems on the MPL. The first, a high-power system, is the one normally used for two-way communication between earth and Mars and is the one probably damaged on arrival. The other, a low power UHF transmitter, was to be used to relay the probe's scientific data to earth via other spacecraft orbiting Mars. Unfortunately, this link with the Mars lander is "one-way" and cannot be used to tell the stricken probe what to do.

Since the lander's arrival on Mars, Nasa engineers have been transmitting commands to the probe telling it to switch on its low-power UHF transmitter. They are hopeful that, although the probe cannot communicate directly with earth, it can still pick up commands through its damaged antenna. But since they can't confirm the relay satellite orbiting Mars is working properly, they have used a 150ft dish antenna at Stanford university, California, to listen for the faint signals from the missing mission.

The spacecraft's UHF transmissions are extremely weak. As one Nasa scientist put it: "It's like trying to see a single Christmas tree light on Mars". Finding such a faint signal amongst all the background noise requires many days of careful analysis of the data.

Recently Nasa announced it had found a signal that seemed to match expectations. It was certainly artificial but it could have originated on or near Earth. Several radio observatories around the world have since offered Nasa their assistance in finding the missing probe.

The university of Manchester's huge Lovell telescope at Jodrell Bank is ideally suited to this kind of search. Its 250ft dish makes it about three times more sensitive than the dish at Stanford university. In 1993, Nasa called on Jodrell Bank to help in an attempt to contact its ill-fated Mars Observer spacecraft and the Jodrell Bank scientists were more than willing to lend a hand searching for the latest vagrant probe. Jodrell Bank and other radio telescopes in the Netherlands and Italy have since been on the lookout for the signals.

The early results of the experiment have shown no obvious signs of the lander. Some very faint signals were found but they did not appear at each telescope at the same time. This suggests they were not of Martian origin, although the final results of these attempts won't be known for some weeks.

Scientists admit there may be several reasons for their continued failure to detect the probe. It may not be in the state they assume and may not have executed the command to transmit. There is now speculation that the probe's batteries or solar panels are damaged and the transmitter doesn't have the required power. Later in the month, Nasa hopes to try once again to find the MPL using a huge radio dish in Puerto Rico. Ian Morison, who coordinated the Jodrell Bank involvement, said: "The signs are not hopeful but it may still be worth another look."

Even if these efforts prove successful, it's unlikely the Mars Polar lander will accomplish any of its tasks. If the signals are found, then Nasa will know the probe survived the journey to Mars, is generating power and at least some of its systems are working. There won't be any useful scientific results, but it would be helpful for future missions to find the cause of the failure.

For British astronomers the search has again demonstrated the continued value of the Lovell telescope, now almost 50 years old.

 Alastair Gunn is an astronomer at Jodrell Bank

webTitle: Livingstone seals landslide wins in four union ballots

fields.headline: Livingstone seals landslide wins in four union ballots
fields.trailText: Four more unions have today emphatically backed Ken Livingstone in his bid to become Labour's candidate in the London mayoral race.
fields.body:
Four more unions have today emphatically backed Ken Livingstone in his bid to become Labour's candidate in the London mayoral race.

The GMB, the postal workers' union and two rail unions all declared support for Mr Livingstone against his rivals Frank Dobson and Glenda Jackson.

The GMB said 67% of its members voted for Mr Livingstone, 19% for Mr Dobson and 13% for Ms Jackson. The union will now cast its vote proportionately in Labour's electoral college.

Postal and BT workers in the Communication Workers Union, the third largest in the capital, gave Mr Livingstone more than 70% of the vote against his two rivals, Frank Dobson and Glenda Jackson. The union will now cast all its votes for Mr Livingstone.

Mr Livingstone gathered 11,941 votes, with just 2,548 backing Downing Street's preferred candidate Mr Dobson and 2,291 supporting Ms Jackson.

Members of train drivers belonging to Aslef and the Transport Salaried Staffs' Association also backed Mr Livingstone. In the latter ballot, he received almost 75% of the vote.

Mr Livingstone is now the firm favourite to win the union section of Labour's electoral college, while Mr Dobson is set to win the clear backing of a large majority of MPs, MEPs and Greater London Authority candidates, who make up another third of the electoral college.

But Mr Livingstone's emphatic margin of victory in union ballots must also give him encouragement in the ballot of London Labour members, which constitutes the final third of the electoral college. Many observers widely believe this vote will be the decisive contest in the bitter battle to become Labour's London mayoral candidate.

Other results, including Unison, the country's biggest union, are expected tomorrow.

The result set to be announced on Sunday afternoon.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Murderers cite Seven as inspiration; Robert De Niro apologises for no-show, and Academy reveals suprise at Carrey snub
fields.body:
 Two convicted murderers yesterday cited the Kevin Spacey film Seven as a grisly inspiration for their killing of a local woman in Metz, France. Pierre Navelot and Laurent Trottin were sentenced to 30 years and 28 years respectively for the premeditated 1998 murder of 20-year-old Alexandra Fernandez, the former girlfriend of Trottin. Aping the movie's climactic scene, Navelot and Trottin planned to sever Fernandez's head and post it to an ex-girlfriend of Navelot's. In the event, they stabbed Fernandez to death but were caught in the act and apprehended. "I wanted to be the number-one serial-killer," Navelot told the court. "I imagined I was something good. But, like the prosecutor says, I'm a monster."

 Robert De Niro has apologised to the organisers of the Berlin Film Festival for his no-show appearance at a special tribute arranged in his honour. De Niro said that a combination of "personal and professional reasons" had prevented him from attending the event. A special video message from the actor was played to festival-goers before last night's retrospective screening of The Deer Hunter.

 It turns out that it wasn't just Jim Carrey's friends and family who were surprised by the actor's lack of a mention in Tuesday's Academy Award nominations. The Academy themselves were taken aback too. Carrey had been tipped for a Best Actor nomination for his sterling performance in the Andy Kaufman biopic Man on the Moon yet significantly failed to impress Academy members. Variety reports that writers for March's Oscar ceremony are now having to rewrite a script that was packed with references to Carrey's role in Man on the Moon. Meantime Academy president Robert Rehme, who announced the nominations alongside Dustin Hoffman, admits to being startled over the nominations. "The biggest surprise for me when I read the list was that Jim Carrey was shut out again," he told reporters yesterday.

fields.headline: Cannabis goes for ecstasy
fields.standfirst:
Britain Home-grown 'superweed' exchanged for Dutch tablets

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's drug barons are exporting home grown, high grade cannabis to Holland in exchange for Dutch manufactured ecstasy tablets, American intelligence officers have warned the home office.
fields.body:
Britain's drug barons are exporting home grown, high grade cannabis to Holland in exchange for Dutch manufactured ecstasy tablets, American intelligence officers have warned the home office.

The US drug enforcement agency has told Paul Boateng, the home office minister, that Britain is now one of the top centres for growing "nederweed" - a superior grade of cannabis which is 30% stronger than the standard drug on the market. It is grown in illegal laboratories using strong lights and water to aid its growth.

Details are revealed in a previously secret report given to Mr Boateng last summer when he held talks in Washington with Donnie Marshall, the deputy US drug tsar. They were released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act. The equivalent British documents for the meeting will remain secret until 2030.

The report - prepared by US intelligence officers who monitor Europe's illegal drug trade - says the export trade is a recent development which builds on Britain's growing reputation in the drugs world for growing superior weed. It says that customs officers are already worried that Britain is being flooded with nederweed grown in Holland - but now Britain seems to have a big enough home grown market to export it back to the Netherlands.

"Cannabis is the most abused drug in the United Kingdom. Customs and Excise reports seizing an all-time record 82.5 metric tonnes of cannabis in the United Kingdom in 1997," says the report.

The trade was often carried out by air rather than through the ports. And Colombia - traditionally one of Britain's top suppliers of cocaine - has recently become a big supplier for traditional strength marijuana.

"In a relatively short period of time Colombia has become an important marijuna source country for the UK." Most of the cannabis was imported by ship rather than by air.

Yesterday customs and excise made it clear that cannabis was still a top target. "I think the figures speak for themselves," said a spokeswoman.

Stuart Crookshank, deputy head of anti-smuggling operations at customs and excise, said: "We are aware and alert to the risk posed by nederweed and all cannabis derivatives."

webTitle: Oscar-nominated Law feathers nest with movie roles

fields.headline: Oscar-nominated Law feathers nest with movie roles
fields.trailText: Buoyed by an Oscar nomination for his work in The Talented Mr. Ripley, Jude Law's acting career appears about to go into overdrive
fields.body:
Buoyed by an Oscar nomination for his work in The Talented Mr. Ripley, Jude Law's acting career appears about to go into overdrive. The 26-year-old actor has just signed up to take the lead role as a British army officer in a remake of the 1939 swashbuckling adventure The Four Feathers, previously directed by Zoltan Korda. The Four Feathers will be scripted by Hossein Amini (who wrote The Wings of a Dove) and directed by Shekhar Kapur, who won plaudits for his work helming the Oscar-nominated Elizabeth. The picture will be financed in a joint venture by Paramount and Miramax, the same team behind The Talented Mr Ripley.

A classic tale of derring-do and stiff-upper lips in colonial Britain, The Four Feathers concerns an army officer branded as a coward in the Sudan campaign of the 1890s who battles to regain his reputation. Production on the picture is scheduled to begin in the summer.

In the meantime Law is also considering a starring role in MGM's The Good Shepherd, which will be directed by Robert De Niro in his second directing stint after 1993's A Bronx Tale. Law has been involved in script rehearsals for the film, which traces the origins of the CIA in the years after the second world war. The actor would take the lead role of a rookie agent in the fledgling organisation who is recruited out of an Ivy Leage university. MGM are not yet confirming whether Law has signed to the project.

webTitle: New model Ford signs on for Soderbergh's Traffic

fields.headline: New model Ford signs on for Soderbergh's Traffic
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford has committed to star as a federal judge turned drugs tzar in Traffic, the new film from writer-director Steven Soderbergh
fields.body:
Harrison Ford has committed to star as a federal judge turned drugs tzar in Traffic, the new film from writer-director Steven Soderbergh. The choice heralds a significant change of direction for Ford, who has confessed to feeling dissatisfied with the roles he has been offered over recent years. Last month, the star signed to an acting agency (UTA) for the first time in 15 years in the hope of gaining access to edgier, more interesting scripts from younger film-makers. If nothing else, Traffic shows that he was serious in his intentions.

After lengthy negotiations, Ford has agreed to a substantial cut in his usual $20m fee and the film's backers Fox have now greenlit a total budget of just under $30m. Ford will star alongside another credibility-hungry star in Catherine Zeta-Jones, and Traffic goes before the cameras on April 2.

Loosely based on a BBC mini-series (Traffik), the film has become a labour of love for Soderbergh, a famously maverick talent who won the Palme D'Or for his audacious debut Sex, Lies and Videotape back in 1989, and gained a small measure of Hollywood legitimacy with the polished crime caper Out of Sight in 1998. His last film, The Limey, was an eccentric, rigorously non-linear thriller starring Terrence Stamp as a vengeful Sixties throwback in Nineties LA. Left-field and unpredictable, Soderbergh could scarcely be more dissimilar to the solid, conservative film-makers Ford is generally drawn to.

But Ford is not entirely turning his back on the big-budget blockbuster. After Traffic, he plans to embark on the fourth instalment in the Indiana Jones story alongside old collaborator Steven Spielberg. "I want it to happen," Ford told the audience while taping a TV show for the Bravo channel earlier this week. "We're waiting for a script everyone is happy with. Very little progress has been made, but Steven Spielberg and I are ready."

fields.headline: Moore set for Hannibal
fields.trailText: One of the year's most protracted casting decisions finally draws to a close this week with the news that Julianne Moore is all set to take on the role of FBI agent Clarice Starling
fields.body:
One of the year's most protracted casting decisions finally draws to a close this week with the news that Julianne Moore is all set to take on the role of FBI agent Clarice Starling in Universal's Silence of the Lambs sequel, Hannibal. Universal chairman Stacey Snider admitted last night that Moore was the "most likely" replacement for the absent Jodie Foster, and said that Hannibal - dogged not just by casting problems, but by script niggles as well - was now "95% greenlit". Production, Snider added, could begin on June 7.

Across the Atlantic at the Berlin Film Festival, Moore was still more optimistic, telling reporters that Hannibal may even go before the cameras in May. The 39-year-old actress was Oscar-nominated on Tuesday for her role in Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair and was attending Berlin to promote a supporting turn in Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia. Instead, Moore found herself fielding Hannibal questions from attendant reporters. "I'm very, very excited about Hannibal," Moore admitted. "We're in negotiations now and I'm looking forward to it."

fields.headline: Bloomsbury goes to Hollywood
fields.trailText: Bloomsbury, the British publisher which discovered Harry Potter, has reached agreement with a Hollywood literary and talent agency to identify unpublished books for films. They have five projects in mind initially.
fields.body:
Bloomsbury, the British publisher which discovered Harry Potter, has reached agreement with a Hollywood literary and talent agency to identify unpublished books for films. They have five projects in mind initially.

Creative Artist Agency in Beverly Hills, which represents Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow and Steven Spielberg, will work with Bloomsbury and authors' agents to sell books to studios.

Bloomsbury chief executive Nigel Newton said it would allow the company to participate financially in film deals for the first time.

The English Patient, The Piano (pictured), Shine, and Snow Falling on Cedars are all Bloomsbury books made into successful films without the publisher's having a direct financial involvement, though it benefited from increased book sales.

Warner Brothers has signed a film deal for Harry Potter but this was arranged by author JK Rowling's agent.

Last night Bloomsbury shares closed at 697p.

fields.headline: Hague has trouble focussing
fields.trailText:
In rejecting the findings of a market research company suggesting that the 
opposition looks "increasingly backward looking" on Europe, Conservative 
leader William Hague has done more than defend his ever more sceptic stance. 
He has taken a butcher's poleaxe to one of the most sacred cows of modern 
politics: the focus group.
fields.body:
In rejecting the findings of a market research company suggesting that the opposition looks "increasingly backward looking" on Europe, Conservative leader William Hague has done more than defend his ever more sceptic stance. He has taken a butcher's poleaxe to one of the most sacred cows of modern politics: the focus group.

The research, carried out by pollsters ICM, found that voters were indeed antipathetic to the European single currency, but that they had "no coherent reasons for staying out, just xenophobia, fear, loathing, based on stereotypes of the past".

Among the Europhobic comments from the ICM focus group, was the observation that the French "don't shave under their arms". The researchers summarised the mood in three crisp lines: 1. Fear (and) loathing of krauts/frogs/eyeties. 2. Who won the war anyway. 3.Keep them in sights of loaded gun, just in case.

The researchers' conclusion, that it could be counterproductive for the Tories to be associated with such views, was leaked by senior party mandarins reportedly infuriated by the influence of what they call the "voodoo priests" of market research.

The leak of the ICM report, which like all focus group findings was supposed to be strictly confidential, will deeply embarrass Conservative Party chiefs, not least because they have been battling to counter the party's pre-election image as aloof and unresponsive to public opinion.

Last year, amid muted publicity, the party launched a campaign bravely entitled Listeni ng to Britain. It promised the electorate that We Will Listen, and encouraged voters to attend meetings up and down the country.

The problem was that such meetings, like the quasi-scientific studies carried out by professional market researchers, produced unwanted results. It was reported that focus groups were no longer being invited to comment on Hague's leadership, because they commonly produced the view that he was a 'nerd'.

There is little chance however, that the focus group has been diminished as an instrument of policy making. The Labour party no longer emphasises them - < A HREF="http://www.labour.org.uk">the party's website talks more coyly of policy forums - but the prime minister and the Millbank headquarters are still reportedly all but addicted to them. The Liberal Democrats too have caught the bug, though they have limited resources for market research.

Given that Britain generally lags a step or two behind the USA in such matters, it is clear that the focus group and the other apparatus of market research as a tool of management, both political and commercial, is going to spread inexorably. Enter the words 'focus group' on the Yahoo! search engine, and it spits out 608 matching sites, and 414,632 web pages.

webTitle: £23m bid to give Trafalgar Square back to pedestrians

fields.headline: £23m bid to give Trafalgar Square back to pedestrians
fields.trailText: Traffic-choked Trafalgar Square, in London, is to be transformed under plans unveiled today by the Minister for London, Keith Hill, and the architect Lord Foster.
fields.body:
Traffic-choked Trafalgar Square, in London, is to be transformed under plans unveiled today by the Minister for London, Keith Hill, and the architect Lord Foster.

Vehicles are to be barred from the north side of the square, opening up more space for pedestrians, and it is proposed that a new central staircase will link the National Gallery and the square itself.

The changes, set to cost £23m, will mean that pedestrians will only have to negotiate one major road crossing between Soho and the South Bank. Crossing Trafalgar Square from north to south currently takes an average of nine minutes on foot.

The plans are part of the World Squares for All masterplan, which extends as far as Whitehall and Parliament Square. Lord Foster said: "Our proposals will create a new heart for London by improving the balance between pedestrians and vehicles. The new pedestrian piazza in St Martin's Place [part of Trafalgar Square] will become a focus for the great cultural institutions around it."

Closing off the north side of the square will increase traffic journey times across central London by about 5% for taxis and under 3% for buses.

Mr Hill said that the government was determined to create an urban renaissance in London. "People now have an opportunity to see the Trafalgar Square proposals for themselves and let us know what they think." Full details of the masterplan are online at worldsquares.com.

webTitle: Direct Line reaches out on car sales

fields.headline: Direct Line reaches out on car sales
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special reportDirect Line
fields.trailText: Direct Line, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland which recently bought Green Flag, is spending £50m on developing an internet site for motorists, including an auction facility, insurance, loans and route planners.
fields.body:
Direct Line, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland which recently bought Green Flag, is spending £50m on developing an internet site for motorists, including an auction facility, insurance, loans and route planners.

"Our intention is to steal a march on rivals," said Ian Chippendale, chief executive of Direct Line which is credited with revolutionising the insurance industry 15 years ago.

"Direct Line is looking to make an aggressive move into the wider motoring market at a time when consumers and the government are demanding value for money."

Mr Chippendale said Direct line was in talks with retailers to sell their cars over the net. A website which would go online in the summer would offer new and nearly new cars.

webTitle: Gerrard and Barry to face Argentina

fields.headline: Gerrard and Barry to face Argentina
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has, as expected, called up teenagers Gareth Barry and Steven Gerrard to the England squad to face Argentina at Wembley next week. The England manager has also selected Dennis Wise, despite his involvement in the Stamford Bridge tunnel fracas last weekend.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has, as expected, called up teenagers Gareth Barry and Steven Gerrard to the England squad to face Argentina at Wembley next week. The England manager has also selected Dennis Wise, despite his involvement in the Stamford Bridge tunnel fracas last weekend.

Keegan named a squad of 24 to face the South Americans, but reserved most of his comments for the two youngsters. Of Liverpool midfielder Gerrard he said: "In all the games I've seen I don't think anybody has played as well as he has done over the last six to eight weeks."

As for Villa defender Barry, not yet 19, Keegan said: "We've been looking for left-sided players but he is in on merit. He is one of those players who is dependable who finds time on the ball and uses it well."

More controversial were Keegan's thoughts on Dennis Wise. Wise has the worst disciplinary record in the Premiership and also faces a misconduct charge following Saturday's events. But while a similar indiscretion excluded Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher from contention, Keegan said of Wise: "If I missed Dennis out of this squad, I would set a precedent that I would regret in the future because I believe he deserves to be in the squad on playing ability."

Finally, it wouldn't be a Keegan press conference without at least one gaffe. Talking about the prowess of next week's opponents, the England coach said: "I don't think there will be any better team in Euro 2000 than Argentina."

England squad to face Argentina in international friendly at Wembley on Wednesday, February 23:

Seaman (Arsenal), Martyn (Leeds), Wright (Ipswich), G Neville (Man Utd), P Neville (Man Utd), Barry (Aston Villa), Southgate (Aston Villa), Campbell (Tottenham), Keown (Arsenal), Ferdinand (West Ham), Beckham (Man Utd), Ince (Middlesbrough), Froggatt (Coventry), Wilcox (Leeds), Dyer (Newcastle), Gerrard (Liverpool), Parlour (Arsenal), Scholes (Man Utd), Sinclair (West Ham), Wise (Chelsea), Cole (Man Utd), Phillips (Sunderland), Heskey (Leicester), Shearer (Newcastle).

fields.headline: Shayler's letter: MI6 and Gadafy
fields.trailText: "Shayler's apparent exaggeration gave Cook an easy way out", asserts Richard Norton-Taylor (Words of a weasel, February 15) about the MI6 report which has appeared on the internet. I would like to confirm that the report is genuine and that its source was Tunworth, who passed his information to PT16/B (an MI6 officer). PT16/B explained to me that MI6 put it out to Whitehall so that MI6's customers would be informed of the planned coup but would not be alerted to MI6's involvement.
fields.body:
"Shayler's apparent exaggeration gave Cook an easy way out", asserts Richard Norton-Taylor (Words of a weasel, February 15) about the MI6 report which has appeared on the internet. I would like to confirm that the report is genuine and that its source was Tunworth, who passed his information to PT16/B (an MI6 officer). PT16/B explained to me that MI6 put it out to Whitehall so that MI6's customers would be informed of the planned coup but would not be alerted to MI6's involvement.

I would like to make it clear that I have exaggerated nothing. I have never claimed the CX report in question confirmed that MI6 funded the plot. The coup plan it discusses does though match exactly the account I gave of the Gadafy plot in Secrets and Lies, a document I prepared to defend myself in June 1999.

I have pointed out that Robin Cook told the Frost programme of August 9 1998: "There was no government-inspired plan to assassinate Colonel Gadafy. There was no [MI6] proposal to do it, and I'm fairly clear there has never been any [MI6] involvement." The CX report demonstrates that an MI6 agent was involved in a plot to assassinate Colonel Gadafy. All MI6 agents are run by at least one officer so, by extension, an MI6 officer was involved.
David Shayler
Paris, France

fields.headline: The best camera scene
fields.standfirst: The Beach
fields.trailText: Richard (Leonardo DiCaprio), Etienne (Guillaume Canet), and his girlfriend Francoise (Virginie Ledoyen) are travelling together across Thailand to find a mythical beach. Camping out by the sea, sleeping under the stars, Richard - who secretly lusts after Francoise - wakes up in the night to find her setting up her camera.
fields.body:
Richard (Leonardo DiCaprio), Etienne (Guillaume Canet), and his girlfriend Francoise (Virginie Ledoyen) are travelling together across Thailand to find a mythical beach. Camping out by the sea, sleeping under the stars, Richard - who secretly lusts after Francoise - wakes up in the night to find her setting up her camera.

"What's all this?"

"Shhh. Etienne will be angry if I wake him. He thinks I waste time taking photographs of the sky."

Richard laughs.

"I think so too."

"Yeah? Have a look."

He puts his eye to the camera and sees the night sky through the lens.

"One night I will get the perfect photograph."

Richard keeps staring through the camera, until a giant figure appears - it's Francoise leaning into the lens.

"Hi."

He nearly jumps out of his skin. Once he's regained his composure he turns to Francoise.

"You realise that in the eternity of space there's probably a planet out there, right, just like this one where another you is photographing back down towards us. I mean, essentially, you are photographing yourself in a parallel universe."

"Incredible."

"Yeah. There are infinite worlds out there, you know, where anything you want to happen does happen."

"Richard, you know something? This is just the kind of pretentious bullshit Americans always say to French girls so they can sleep with them."

See also: Blow Up, Peeping Tom, High Art

Don't see also: The Eyes Of Laura Mars

Pointless trivia: When he began his acting career, Leonardo DiCaprio was advised by an agent to change his name to Lenny Williams.

fields.headline: Postmaster Pat
fields.standfirst:
Martin Wainwright warns we should be wary of letting the humble local post office die out unnoticed
Plus: Name a stone
fields.trailText: Martin Wainwright warns we should be wary of letting the humble local post office die out unnoticed
fields.body:
The chancellor's welcome plans for reforming family benefits would gain even more from a humbler measure, affecting a world of which many netsurfers may scarcely know. The visionary sweep of the tax changes reaches its point of delivery for most of those in greatest need at the sub-post office. And that is a feature of the British landscape in genuine danger of extinction.

The issue has been the subject of debates in the Commons this week, with the opposition unusually invigorated by the strength of concern, especially in the countryside. Across north Yorkshire, for instance, a modest piece of petition gathering has bandwagoned into 30,000 signatures, and there is equal concern in Wales where Plaid Cymru's victory in the Ceredigion byelection, Simon Thomas, made sub-post offices the subject of his eloquent maiden speech.

The part played by the little buildings as a lifeline for rural communities, with their sidelines of groceries or newspaper deliveries, is at least comparatively well known. It pulls at some powerful, thatched cottage, roses-round-the-door, English heartstrings. But their much more important role in big cities' peripheral council estates, and other centres of the dispossessed which are the absolute target of Gordon Brown's benefit reforms, is much less highlighted.

This is not a world of bank accounts into which the proposed new "seamless system of support for children" can be electronically transferred. It is the place where the electric, gas and TV licence are paid for by weekly stamps and the elderly queue on Thursdays for their pensions.

It is the local bank, too; a business wholly absent from most socially excluded areas and often beyond the reach of anyone doddering, or encumbered with a pushchair plus toddler, in a swathe of less obviously deprived parts of town. It is not a bank in terms of ISAs and leaflets about wonderful borrowing schemes and credit extensions, but simply a place - the only place locally - where those on low incomes can get actual money.

All manner of other transactions take place across the counter, of course, from driving licence and vehicle tax applications to the first step in the bureaucratic marathon of getting a passport. But it is the readies, the greenbacks, the child credit, pensions and income support which make sub-post offices so vital.

The government justifies its drive to shift benefit to bank transfer by 2003 on straightforward cost grounds, saving Mr Brown's exchequer some £400m a year. Leaving aside the fact that this sum is a minnow in public spending terms (it would run the department of social security for less than a week), it ignores the far greater costs which lie in store when the issue arises of how to make bank transfers to people who don't want accounts and haven't got a local bank anyway.

The postal services bill's other measure, a £480m scheme to increase computer use in sub-post offices, is the wiser way to use IT's huge potential, cutting the extraordinary number of forms and die-stamps over which sub-postmasters and mistresses puzzle. With that in place, direct electronic transfer and its savings will in due course follow naturally. The other way round, and there will be few, if any, sub-post offices left in the places which need them most.

Name a stone

Anyone who has tramped the lovely, heather-covered wilderness of the North York Moors will know Fat Betty, Ralph Cross and Blue Man-i-th-Moss. Not quaint local characters, they are standing stones from the misty past which guide you along the Lyke Wake Walk between the Cleveland escarpment and the North Sea.

Two days ago, with much grunting and the clanking of a mobile crane, a new obelisk was levered into place on Danby High Moor, after 10,000 years of lying underground on a neighbouring hillside. The five-tonne sandstone monolith is a millennium marker - three millennia after Fat Betty and one-and-a-half after Ralph Cross - and a welcome new recruit to the tradition.

It needs one thing, though: an appropriately colourful name of its own, and preferably before May 6 when everyone interested is invited to walk to the site for a dedication service. Suggestions, rude, fantastic or poetical, are welcome - click here to make your own contribution to Britain's topography.

fields.headline: David Lynch: Blue Velvet
fields.standfirst:
Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies.
This week, number 55: David Lynch's Blue Velvet
fields.trailText: Those celebrating the success of Sam Mendes's Oscar- nominated American Beauty as a scorching exposure of American suburbia might benefit from taking another look at David Lynch's Blue Velvet, a much more radical fable on the same subject. It is one of the seminal films of the 80s, from which sprang a good many inferior imitations. I wouldn't say the more mainstream Mendes film was seminal. But it would have looked more original had the Lynch film never been made.
fields.body:
Those celebrating the success of Sam Mendes's Oscar- nominated American Beauty as a scorching exposure of American suburbia might benefit from taking another look at David Lynch's Blue Velvet, a much more radical fable on the same subject. It is one of the seminal films of the 80s, from which sprang a good many inferior imitations. I wouldn't say the more mainstream Mendes film was seminal. But it would have looked more original had the Lynch film never been made.

Lynch is not a director everyone likes, except when it comes to The Straight Story, his latest and most orthodox film, and The Elephant Man, an earlier, comparatively straight narrative. Both these were excellent films, but the power and originality of Eraserhead, Blue Velvet and possibly the first Twin Peaks were what makes his place in cinema history secure.

Blue Velvet, like American Beauty and Todd Solontz's Happiness, places sex at the base of domestic trauma. So much so, in fact, that what Lynch delivered to his audiences was considered reprehensible by many. This is because it was taken literally. But as Isabella Rossellini, who plays the masochistic nightclub singer, has said, Lynch's films are not so much psychological studies of character as surreal impressions - "more of a sensation than a story".

It is the different levels of Blue Velvet that puzzle people. On the one hand we have an ironic, deadpan portrait of small-town Lumberton that encourages us to think that the film is some sort of satire. On the other, what lies behind this often ludicrous facade also qualifies the film as a horror story.

When the college student played by Kyle MacLachlan finds a severed ear in a field and he and his girl (Laura Dern) try to solve the mystery, the film takes an abrupt turn. The trail leads to the nightclub singer in whose flat, hidden in a closet, the student first watches Dennis Hopper submit her to a sadomasochistic ritual and is then horrified when she discovers him after Hopper has left and forces him to undergo similar treatment. This is the disturbing core of the film. And Rossellini's selfless performance, during which she has to submit to a myriad of indignities, is the equal to Lynch's curious imagination.

If this caused the outrage at the time, it was the director's capacity to change tack and revert to an irony verging on parody that disturbed audiences further. Was this simply a joke in very bad taste?

Actually, it wasn't. It was a recognition that behind even the most banal of circumstances and people lie some pretty peculiar truths. "Are you a detective or a pervert?", asks Dern of her boyfriend at one point. The answer is a bit of both - and maybe, Lynch suggests, that goes for all of us.

The film is one of the most uncomfortable I have seen, and it is by no means flawless. For instance, Hopper's character is never fully explained, and there are passages of psychotic excess that don't make much sense. But the power of the whole is undeniable, and distinctively augmented by Angelo Badalamenti's music.

Perhaps the best summation of it comes from Lynch himself, quoted in Chris Rodley's book Lynch on Lynch: "Well, film is really voyeurism. You sit there in the safety of the theatre, and seeing is such a powerful thing. And we want to see secret things, we really want to see them. New things. It drives you nuts, you know! And the more new and secret they are, the more you want to see them."

fields.headline: Diplomat accused over film funds
fields.standfirst: Appointment of Cambridge academic as high commissioner risks backfiring spectacularly as row erupts over Jinnah script and money
fields.trailText: Pakistan's London high commisioner Akbar Ahmed faces allegations of wrongful use of funds from a feature film he sponsored about Mohammed Ali Jinnah, the country's founder, which stars the actor Christopher Lee.
fields.body:
When Akbar Ahmed was chosen to be Pakistan's high commissioner in London by the country's new military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, after last October's coup, the appointment seemed to be a masterstroke by a regime struggling to avoid international isolation.

Here was an unexpectedly respectable frontman for the generals, a Cambridge academic acclaimed for his success in presenting a liberal face of Islam to the west, who might win understanding for the coup leaders' proclaimed mission to root out corruption in Asia's new nuclear power.

Three months later, the posting risks backfiring in spectacular fashion as Mr Ahmed faces allegations of wrongful use of funds from a feature film he sponsored about Mohammed Ali Jinnah, the country's founder, which stars the actor Christopher Lee in the lead role.

He also finds himself at the centre of a bitter dispute over whether he - or the Indian-born, non-Muslim former Channel 4 commissioning editor Farrukh Dhondy - co-wrote the screenplay. Mr Ahmed, who conceived the film as Pakistan's answer to Richard Attenborough's Gandhi and acted as executive producer, is accused by the film's British-based producer, director and co-writer, Jamil Dehlavi, of unjustifiably paying himself more than £50,000 for the script and diverting £70,000 to an offshore bank account to pay his son and son-in-law for jobs they did not carry out.

Mr Dehlavi, who is also suing the high commissioner over the film's credits and unpaid debts, says Mr Ahmed "did not write a word" of the screenplay, and insists his co-author was Mr Dhondy.

Mr Dhondy has confirmed his role, which he says he was asked to keep secret. He was hired by Mr Ahmed, who asked for some minor amendments to parts of the script which he decided were "not Islamic enough", he says, and was paid £12,000 for his work.

Mr Ahmed rejects the allegations - though he accepts Mr Dhondy was involved in the screenplay - and insists he has earned nothing from his years of involvement in the £3m Jinnah project.

He says he is preparing to go to the fraud squad with counter-claims about Mr Dehlavi's handling of the film's accounts.

The high commissioner says the accusations against him by Mr Dehlavi and Mr Dhondy are part of a campaign by the "Indian lobby" to discredit him and, by extension, the new military regime.

He claims credit for the film's philosophy and says his collaboration in the script was an essential part of the process.

The eruption of controversy around the film, which is expected to be released in Pakistan in the spring but has yet to be sold in the west, follows a series of bitter disputes during shooting, when it was wrongly alleged at one point that Salman Rushdie, author of The Satanic Verses, was the real scriptwriter.

Jinnah is a revered figure in Pakistan and his portrayal by an actor best known for his role as a Dracula caused outrage in some quarters. The alarmed Pakistani government eventually withdrew £1m from the film.

During its production, Mr Ahmed let it be known that he would take no more than one rupee for his involvement - a claim witnessed by several of those involved in the production. The declaration was in emulation of Jinnah, who took a salary of only one rupee as Pakistan's first president.

Documents seen by the Guardian confirm that Mr Ahmed was paid £51,500 by QPL, the company he set up to oversee the project, as a "writer's fee".

They also show that £35,000 was paid through the film production company to Mr Ahmed's son, Babar, as co-producer, and another £35,000 to his son-in-law, Arsallah Khan Hoti, as associate producer, into a private family bank account in Jersey in the name of his wife, Zeenat Ahmed, who acted as an unpaid company secretary for QPL.

Mr Ahmed - an author of books and a television series on Islam and an Iqbal fellow, sponsored by the Pakistan government, at Selwyn college, Cambridge, until his recent high commission appointment - rejects all accusations of wrongdoing, as does his wife. They say that they have had to sell jewellery and land to keep the film afloat.

The high commissioner says that, although he paid tax on his £51,500 writer's fee, he has ploughed the money back into the film, and his executive producer's fee of £70,000 has been deferred.

He has, he says, taken nothing for his role as head of the project, but like Jinnah, is entitled to his "professional fees". Future profits will, his spokesman now says, go to an "educational trust".

Mr Ahmed rejects the claim that he was not co-writer of the script and says his son and son-in-law were fairly paid for work for the film, notably helping to raise hundreds of thousands of pounds from their family.

Their fees have gone back into the project and will entitle them to a share of any profits. All Pakistani legal regulations have, he says, been followed over the Jersey account.

Mr Dehlavi denies that Mr Ahmed's son or son-in-law played any role in the production. Two other men who worked on the film, production accountant Peter Winstanley and production supervisor Andrew Wood, also insist that neither of the men was to their knowledge involved in any way.

webTitle: Prescott's air traffic privatisation bid savaged

fields.headline: Prescott's air traffic privatisation bid savaged
fields.standfirst: More about air traffic privatisation
fields.trailText: A committee of MPs today savaged government plans to sell off part of Britain's air traffic control system.
fields.body:
A committee of MPs today savaged government plans to sell off part of Britain's air traffic control system.

The proposed public-private partnership would be the "worst possible option" for the future of national air traffic services (NATS), the environment, transport and regional affairs committee argued.

In a blunt report, the cross-party committee warned that a private company would "very likely" have to raise charges or cut costs - both moves which would "jeopardise safety".

John Prescott, the secretary of state for transport, announced in June 1998 that the government planned to sell 46% of NATS to a "strategic" private partner, with 5% going to staff, and the remaining 49% retained in the public sector.

NATS argued that the sale would allow the investment it needed - estimated at £1.3bn over the next 10 years - to cope with a forecasted 43% rise in air traffic by 2010. But the sell-off plan, part of the transport bill going through parliament, has run into heavy flak. The British Airline Pilots Association and some Labour MPs, including the former transport minister Gavin Strang, have attacked the idea.

The committee said that if the government wrote off NATS' debt of £300m, the expected £350m proceeds from the proposed sale would result in revenue of "only £20m" after £30mcosts. It is also anticipated that some of the public shares would not have voting rights which would, in effect, pass "operational control" of the organisation into private hands.

The committee agreed that making no change to NATS was not an option because it was already operating ''close to the limit of its capacity", but it urged the government to consider making NATS an independent trust.

"In no other country is a public-private partnership like that proposed for the UK planned," it noted. The committee pointed to the success of Canada's NavCanada, funded by a bonds issue and governed by 15 directors, including five from the aviation industry, two from the unions and three from the government.

The committee said the trust model would free NATS to borrow on the private market, and separate the company more clearly from its regulator, the civil aviation authority. It argued: "Since customers, staff and the government would all be involved in the provision of air traffic services, the trust model answers concerns about rising charges, lower safety standards, national security considerations, and the future development of air navigation services."

The committee also warned that private investors would want to increase revenues from NATS by raising charges to its customers, putting airlines and airports in the United Kingdom at a competitive disadvantage.

fields.headline: Will the-bullet hit the target?
fields.standfirst: A web business run from a back-bedroom may turn two women into big shots, writes  Sean Dodson
fields.trailText: A web business run from a back-bedroom may turn two women into big shots, writes Sean Dodson
fields.body:
It's 7am, the sun is rising over north London and in a small flat in Chalk Farm Josephine Monroe is getting up. As editor and budding entrepreneur of the-bullet.com - a pair of websites catering for the TV and publishing industries - she has to move quickly.

Switching the kettle on and booting the computer, she logs on to the net while leaving the tea to brew in her cup. Within two hours a full briefing of the morning's papers will be on the web - just in time to catch the-bullet's audience of media executives as they arrive at their desks. In less than a year, the self-styled "guerrilla force in UK media" has grown a modest, but significant audience that has left the fledgling company with an estimated value of £2m, making Monroe, and technical director, Geraldine Billam, living proof that it is still possible to build a millionaire internet company without the help of venture capital, while still operating out of a back-bedroom. It has cost no more than the £35 a month cost of hosting the site plus their lost earnings.

"When we started we didn't think we needed venture capital, we thought that between us we had the skills to do it," explains Monroe, who left her job as TV critic at Time Out to help start the company. Billam was a housing benefit officer with Islington council.

"I still think that there are a couple of things more important than money. One is contacts, and the other is being able to get your message out. The most crucial thing is networking and telling everybody about what you do."

Valuing net companies is far from a science. The £2m valuation was based on the projected revenues of the-bullet through banner advertising. The-bullet.com/tv generates a regular audience of over 5,000, and the new www.the-bullet.com/ink hopes to attract at least as much. The valuation was made by Kickstart Ventures on the basis that each customer adds £200 to the value of the company.

It might sound like a lot, but it is the same yardstick that has been applied to much larger companies like Freeserve and eBookers, both of which have a far less targeted audience than the-bullet. Unlike most net start ups - even those enjoying the benefits of venture capital - the-bullet has made modest profits for several months.

"We've just about managed to keep going on ad revenue alone,' says Monroe. "But it has been very difficult at times. Especially now that we are trying to expand. We think we've got a good opportunity here and a distinctive voice. It would be nice to be able to afford to take on some staff, and to have some money to be able to speculate."

What makes the-bullet so distinctive is how it edits news, paper round-ups and industry gossip into a series of bullet points. Although it is rivalling subscription-based press cutting services like Early Bird, the-bullet claims it doesn't hope to compete with the trade papers and the media pages of the national press, but rather to serve them. "What we hope is that our users will come to the bullet for the story, but still go to the paper for the real detail," says Monroe. The-bullet is full of links to other papers' websites and, where none exists, to relevant page numbers. "It's like we are a five minute cup of coffee and a sticky bun, while the more established players are more like a five course lunch at Quaglinos."

"It's an idea that works, its pretty simple to replicate and you don't need to spend a quarter of a million. The web doesn't have to cost millions of pounds in consultancy fees and market research."

Would Monroe and Billam recommend going it alone to other budding net entrepreneurs? "I can't tell you how many times I've wished there had been money behind us," admits Monroe. "And at times it has been very hard to keep the faith.

"Going it alone is definitely not the easy option, and I've nearly given up two or three times. But I would still say absolutely go for it, trust your instincts, work hard and you might just come up with something."

fields.headline: NHS bugs kill 5,000 a year
fields.standfirst: Download the report
fields.trailText: As many as 5,000 people may be dying each year from infections picked up during NHS hospital treatment and a further 15,000 deaths could be partly attributable to such bugs, a study by the national audit office (NAO) has revealed.
fields.body:
As many as 5,000 people may be dying each year from infections picked up during NHS hospital treatment and a further 15,000 deaths could be partly attributable to such bugs, a study by the national audit office (NAO) has revealed.

The study said more than 100,000 people are being infected annually by potentially deadly bugs they contract while staying in hospitals. Treating such infections is costing the NHS £1bn a year in England. Increasing resistance to antibiotics is part of the problem, but some hospitals are not doing enough to prevent infections, experts said.

At any one time 9% of patients are suffering from infections, which can add to the length of stay and affect treatment of their original condition. The young and old are the most vulnerable.

The NAO calls for stricter hygienecontrols and better procedures which could reduce the rate of infections by 15%.

The most common bugs are urinary tract infections, often caught after invasive surgery. Surgical wounds, the skin and the bloodstream can also become infected with potentially deadly bacteria. In extreme cases, antibiotic-resistant superbugs such as MRSA - methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus - can spread through hospitals.

The report calls for more money and resources to be spent on preventing and controlling hospital bugs, and better information about infection rates. One fifth of NHS trusts do not have an infection control programme and only 40% have a designated budget for hospital infections.

NHS chief executive Sir Alan Langlands acknowledged the seriousness of the problem, but said the report needed to be put "in perspective". He said the problem affects health services across the world

"We in this country have, for the first time, a national strategy for dealing with this," Sir Alan said. "Better information systems, good standards and the dissemination of good practice and of course, as the NAO suggests, some investment in training and in systems."

He said many of the people now being treated in hospital would not have received treatment previously, and were "more susceptible" to infection because of weaker immune systems.

"Hospital acquired infections are a huge problem for the NHS. They prolong patients' stays in hospital and, in the worse cases, cause permanent disability and even death," John Bourn, the head of the NAO, said in a statement. The report made 29 recommendations to improve the control of skin, chest, urinary tract and blood infections and post-operative procedures.

They include improving control programmes and commissioning research on the staffing levels needed to reduce rates of infection.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's tittle-tattle including teenage transfers galore
fields.trailText: Daily Mail Internazionale are ready to offer Newcastle £10m for Kieron Dyer. The Italians have been impressed with the England international's form this season and coach Marcello Lippi wants Dyer to play right midfield, allowing captain Javier Zanetti to play a more central role in the team.
fields.body:
Daily Mail Internazionale are ready to offer Newcastle £10m for Kieron Dyer. The Italians have been impressed with the England international's form this season and coach Marcello Lippi wants Dyer to play right midfield, allowing captain Javier Zanetti to play a more central role in the team.

Juventus have been scouting West Ham's Joe Cole and could be prepared to splash out £8m on the 18-year-old.

Arsene Wenger is prepared to sell off some of his biggest names in the summer after Arsenal slunk out of the Championship race. After the Gunners' home defeat against Liverpool on Sunday, Wenger laid down the law to his players, some of whom he accused of letting him down with their lack of commitment.

The Mirror Henning Berg wants to leave Manchester United for another Premiership club, and he could be set for a move to Spurs, a deal that would see Sol Campbell moving in the other direction.

The Sun Coventry have joined Southampton in expressing an interest in Rangers defender Colin Hendry. Hendry, who is available on loan for the rest of the season, has said: "I don't think any move will depend on how glamorous the club is."

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Offer you can refuse

A number of readers may have been cold-called by a company offering a £23.70 first-aid kit and promising that a third of the proceeds will go to charity. Worse, they may have found an unsolicited kit on the door step, along with an invoice listing eight charities, including the British Red Cross and Mencap, as beneficiaries. But there's a catch. None of these charities has authorised the campaign or has a legal contract with the telesales company as required under the charities act 1992. Royal Consulting, which is based in the Netherlands, has admitted sending out up to 8,000 kits to British householders. In November, it promised to stop mentioning the charities in its promotions but, says the Red Cross, this hasn't happened.

In Holland, Don Brouwers, managing director of Royal Consulting, giggles awkwardly when Consumer calls. "A few call-centre sales agents in the UK were misusing the information we gave them and naming charities," he says. The three rogue agents have now been fired and, he says, there is "no possibility" that the charities' names are being taken in vain. "We still give 34% of the profits to charities but we don't name them." So how much has he given so far? "We don't have exact figures yet and we didn't have much net profit last year because we're still investing, but we will be giving a third this year. I'm trying to find a way to prove that to people so they'll believe me."

The office of fair trading has received complaints and alerted Dutch authorities, but is powerless because Royal Consulting is based abroad. If you receive unsolicited goods and an invoice, don't be intimidated. It's the responsibility of the sender to arrange collection. If you write to the firm explaining that you reject them, the goods become yours if there's no reply within 30 days. If you don't write (and don't use them), they're yours after six months.

Cover story

Often it seems that all you get for your money from an insurance product is the decorative policy document. Michael Flack of Milton Keynes didn't even get that. Last June he took out car insurance with Gladiator Insurance in Cardiff, paid a deposit and set up a direct debit. The £169.50 was deducted and Flack received two temporary cover notes, but by November he still hadn't received a certificate. He rang customer services to discover that Gladiator had not taken payments for two months. Another department had cancelled the policy, leaving Flack without cover. His attempts to investigate failed - he was cut off each time customer services put him on hold. A letter of complaint went unanswered.

Gladiator's explanation highlights the joys of modern technology. "When the cover began we needed Mr Flack to return documentation to us," explains a spokesman. "He returned it, but it was sent from us to the insurer in paper form rather than electronically, which meant it was never registered as received. Normally a seven-day notice of cancellation would be sent if the insurer had not set up the policy. On this occasion the letter was not sent, but the policy was still cancelled." Flack is to be refunded and will be get £50 compensation.

Trouble with gas

Check the fine print of wondrous new offers. SafeGas, a Leeds-based company offering gas service contracts, made a price rise look like a concession when it told consumers that in the interests of customer choice its full breakdown and boiler replacement cover had been reduced to £89. The odd thing was that MG Crowhurst of Leeds had paid £99 the previous year for a package which included an annual service, a perk deleted from the new offer. Nor was there any evidence of increased choice, except, says Crowhurst, "whether or not to take an annual service at an additional charge of £29, making the overall package a total of £118 - a £19 increase on last year."

SafeGas says it wanted to give the customer choice by separating service charges from the package and denies its boasts of a price decrease are misleading. "The price would have gone up anyway, so this new deal can be seen as a reduction."

C&W: Calls still queueing

Mark Thomas tried to get a C&W phone and cable connection last autumn. First he was told the "box" in the road wasn't big enough and it would take six to eight weeks to sort out. After six weeks he waited 20 minutes on the helpline to be told it would be eight weeks. Later still, he was told it couldn't be done. He demanded that the contract be cancelled and was told it would be sorted out. That was December and he's still waiting.

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: 'Petrified' Posh's catwalk debut
fields.standfirst: London fashion week: special report
fields.trailText: Posh Spice yesterday made her catwalk debut, for designer Maria Grachvogel. The pop singer modelled two outfits: a minuscule pair of green satin hotpants with a clingy cashmere tank top, and a dramatic crimson and pink gown in the designer's signature flamenco style.
fields.body:
Posh Spice yesterday made her catwalk debut, for designer Maria Grachvogel. The pop singer modelled two outfits: a minuscule pair of green satin hotpants with a clingy cashmere tank top, and a dramatic crimson and pink gown in the designer's signature flamenco style.

Victoria Beckham, a keen follower of fashion, is a longtime admirer of Grachvogel's evening wear. Despite her experience on stage, she found the experience "absolutely petrifying".

Across town at Burberry, the crowd were just as excited: but this time it was a beige check, rather than a celebrity model, that caused the fuss. After 143 years, the company is enjoying a spell in the fashion sunshine with its signature beige check currently the fashion world's favourite pattern.

Yesterday, Burberry took centre stage with a show of its own. This brand was once the epitome of chic and even before the models appeared, it was evident from the sea of Burberry check bags, jackets, shoes and scarves in the audience that the company has once more found favour with the fashion crowd.

By the mid 1990s 75% of Burberry's sales were in the Far East, which meant that the company was badly wounded by the Asian financial crisis. The team brought in to turn the ailing brand around was Rose Marie Bravo of American retailers Saks Fifth Avenue, and New York born, Italian raised designer Roberto Menichetti. Despite critical acclaim and the adoration of the fashion world, Burberry is not yet reaping the financial rewards of its efforts.

Turnover in the year ending March 1999 was just £207m, down nearly 20% on the previous year. It has been widely rumoured that Great Universal Stores, which owns the company, may sell - likely bidders might be continental luxury giants LVMH, Thomas Pink or Prada, which has invested in classic English shoe company Church's.
