fields.headline: The gloss menagerie
fields.standfirst: His father's novel Catch 22 exposed the insanity of America at war. Now Ted Heller's written his own savage send up of the world of US magazines. But there's just one question on the lips of the New York slick set: who did he base his characters on?
fields.trailText: Ted Heller presents an incongruous figure in New York's Times Square, rather as though he were a technician who had ambled on to the wrong side of the camera and been press-ganged into taking part in the sort of television game show your friends wouldn't admit to watching. Perhaps even worse, Ted the technician has won a prize. "My life has gone crazy," he says, hands deep in pockets amid the animated gaudiness of the brashest location on Earth, sports bars competing for attention with the flicker and throb of come-ons for must-haves, everything cancelling out everything else in the electronic playpen. "I'm beginning to regret it."
fields.body:
Ted Heller presents an incongruous figure in New York's Times Square, rather as though he were a technician who had ambled on to the wrong side of the camera and been press-ganged into taking part in the sort of television game show your friends wouldn't admit to watching. Perhaps even worse, Ted the technician has won a prize. "My life has gone crazy," he says, hands deep in pockets amid the animated gaudiness of the brashest location on Earth, sports bars competing for attention with the flicker and throb of come-ons for must-haves, everything cancelling out everything else in the electronic playpen. "I'm beginning to regret it."

It is, of course, his own fault. Anyone who chooses to write a roman à clef ("I am very tired of that phrase") about the magazine world must expect to have his book used as the text for games of Spot the Gilded Condé Nast Scribe.

The steel, glass and monumental brick home of the Condé Nast magazine empire is just around the corner from the vulgar business end of Times Square, an aloof rebuke to the sort of open-to-the-street establishment where Heller labours for Viacom, a beacon for hordes of teenagers because it contains the MTV studios. "There is nothing interesting about my life." Well, there is the fact that he is the son of the late Joseph Heller, author of Catch-22, but Ted is not about to discuss that. "I don't deny it. I didn't change my name or anything, but that is something I refuse to exploit." And he says he will throw the tape recorder against the wall if anyone tries to discuss his father.

"A week ago nobody wanted to talk to me," he says. But now that his first published novel is in the shops, everyone wants to, and they all want to know the same things. Which one of the book's character's is Anna Wintour, editor of US Vogue? Is that Tina Brown, editor of the recently launched Talk? "I have this character Leslie Usher-Soames and I've just seen this piece where someone says I based her on Emma Soames [editor of the Telegraph magazine]. I'd never heard of Emma Soames before. It's a little upsetting."

It is true that Heller's book, Slab Rat, reads like an insider's account of the nepotism, prejudice, bitterness, ambition, rivalry and hatreds of the magazine world. But it is true, also, that he picked up his material operating as something of a peripheral. "I don't remember saying, 'I'm going to base this fictional person on that real person.' I don't know if people believe me. I would think that I was lying, too. But I can see why people would say 'That's Anna Wintour' or 'That's Tina Brown.' I don't think I have the power to hurt Anna Wintour's feelings and, believe it or not, she doesn't give a shit about me." He says he invented British characters for the book only because it would not have been accurate otherwise.

Slab Rat - slab as in midtown Manhattan skyscraper, rat as in someone who works in it - could barely have received more positive reviews, and was not damaged by the assumption that the writer is one of the slick set. The Ted Heller in Times Square is dressed mostly in standard-issue Manhattan black, it is true, though somehow the colour fails to make any sort of tribal statement when applied to his frame.

Heller did not research his skewering of the glossies by joining Wintour for her daily, overpriced lean beefburger. Nor did he hothouse buzz-phrases with Brown when she was editor of Vanity Fair or the New Yorker, prior to launching Talk, home of The American Conversation. He was more likely to have been searching out an elusive transparency with one hand and clutching half a sandwich in the other.

Heller, who has between five and 10 unpublished novels on the stocks, spent most of his 20s in the fashion industry, though his involvement was not quite as glamorous as it might sound. His presence was not required, for instance, in the front row facing the catwalk during New York Fashion Week. But someone had to do the fetching and the carrying, the lifting and the pushing, and Heller was that man. The author was into his 30s - he is 43 now - by the time he arrived in magazines, the door opened by a friend who worked at the now-deceased satirical publication Spy. Here he met the co-founder Kurt Andersen, one of New York's cleverest media figures, author of last year's Turn of the Century and now co-chairman of an internet company: "He laid me off. I don't know what year it was but it was January 17, so every January 17 a few of us get together and have a drink. I wouldn't put a bullet in his brain for laying me off. Not in his brain. Then I was at Vanity Fair for two weeks, standing in for someone who was off having a sex-change."

Then came Premiere and more photo research. "Details: that was very unpleasant. I can't tell you how happy I am that no one at Details remembers me. The only time anyone ever noticed me was to yell. I asked someone, 'Who makes Jeep?' and he just yelled at me, 'Jeep makes Jeep.' It's hard to yell at someone using so few letters."

I wanted to call people to tell them, but no one was at home because it was Saturday night. I had to wait until Sunday."

A few days later, he got another call, this time from Gregory Mosher, former director of the Lincoln Center Theater and one of the producers of The Dead on Broadway. "He called me at work." Work for the past six years has been the children's magazine Nickelodeon, where Heller is picture editor/senior writer and where, he would like it known, the people are great. "I'm counting slides on the floor and the phone goes and it's Mosher. We ended up quoting lines from Glengarry Glen Ross at each other. There was some interest there for a movie. webTitle: A full set of Test centuries

fields.headline: A full set of Test centuries
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who was the first man to score a century against each of the Test-playing countries? asks Ivan O'Riordan
fields.body:
Who was the first man to score a century against each of the Test-playing countries? asks Ivan O'Riordan

The first to score centuries against eight different teams - the maximum number at the moment - was Steve Waugh, who completed his full set against India in December. He was nearly beaten to it by his brother Mark, who needed to reach three figures against Zimbabwe in October - but he was out for 90. It should be borne in mind that only in recent years has it been possible to play against so many different teams - Sri Lanka played their first Tests in 1981-82 and Zimbabwe in 1992-93, the year after South Africa returned to the international fold. Don Bradman, for example, played 37 of his 52 Tests against England - and five each against South Africa, West Indies and India.

A friend of mine remembers listening to the commentary from Headingley, as Bob Willis bowled out the Australians in 1981, while watching a county game. He knows it was a close finish, but can't remember where it was! Can you tell us which matches ended that day? asks Tim Beard from Madrid

That famous day was July 21, 1981. The county matches which finished that day were at Southend (Essex drew with Lancashire), Bristol (Gloucestershire drew with Glamorgan), Portsmouth (Surrey beat Hampshire by 130 runs), Leicester (Kent beat Leicestershire by 111 runs), Lord's (Middlesex drew with Worcestershire), Trent Bridge (Nottinghamshire beat Yorkshire by eight wickets), Taunton (Somerset drew with Derbyshire) and Hove (Sussex beat Warwickshire by five wickets). Notts won with only 11 balls to spare, so I'd guess that your friend was at Trent Bridge that day. I was at Lord's - watching the play from Headingley on the television!

How many Test centuries did Sir Richard Hadlee score? asks Charlie Watts

He made two - 103 against West Indies at Christchurch in 1979-80, and 151 not out v Sri Lanka at the Colombo Cricket Club in 1986-87. He also made 99 against England at Wellington in 1983-84 - more than England managed in either innings. They were shot out for 82 and 93, and New Zealand won easily. In all Hadlee made 3124 runs in 86 Tests at 27.16, to go with his 431 wickets.

I recently watched Zimbabwe lose to South Africa by a huge margin. What is the biggest margin of victory in a Test? asks Adeeb

It was recorded by England at The Oval in 1938, when they beat Australia by an innings and 579 runs. England scored 903-7 (Len Hutton 364), then bowled Australia out for 201 and 123. Don Bradman had injured his ankle and was unable to bat - it's said that England's captain Walter Hammond delayed his declaration until he was assured that The Don wasn't fit enough to go in.

I remember a cricketer who died at the crease recently, possibly while on tour with his country. What was his name? asks Jack Higginbotham

You are probably thinking of Wilf Slack, the Middlesex and England opener, who collapsed and died at the crease while playing for a touring side in The Gambia in Africa in January 1989. He was only 34. A stylish and popular left-hander, Slack played three Tests in 1986, and was still a Middlesex regular at the time of his tragic death, although he had already suffered four unexplained blackouts at the wicket. He was buried in his England blazer, with his bat by his side.

In what year were eight-ball overs used in the County Championship? asks Paul Harrop

Eight-ball overs were tried in England in 1939. It was supposed to be a two-year experiment, but the Second World War meant there was no county cricket in 1940. It seems to have been an unpopular innovation, and when county cricket resumed in 1946 the six-ball over was back.

I am an Australian bar manager in Hong Kong. It is part of my job to keep the peace in the bar, so please help me with this question: Did a Scot ever captain England? asks Nick Wade

Mike Denness, who captained England in 19 Tests between 1973-74 and 1975, was born in Bellshill in Lanarkshire in 1940. He played a few matches for Scotland before moving south to play county cricket for Kent (and later Essex).

I have an ancestor called John P Whiteside who is listed on the 1891 census record for Leyland, Lancashire, as a professional cricketer. Do you have any information on him? asks Sandra in the USA

I think this must be John Parkinson Whiteside, who was born in Fleetwood, Lancashire on June 11, 1861, and died in Leicester on March 8, 1946. He was a wicketkeeper who played six matches for Lancashire between 1888 and 1890, then moved to Leicestershire, for whom he played 215 matches between 1894 and 1906. He made 340 catches and 98 stumpings in first-class cricket, and also scored 1362 runs at the low average of 6.16. The Cricketers' Who's Who reveals that he was also a first-class umpire. If you contact Leicestershire County Cricket Club they may be able to let you have more details about him (david.collier.leics@ecb.co.uk)

Can you give me details of England's home Tests this season? asks Paul Nicholas

England are playing two Tests against Zimbabwe - at Lord's (May 18-22) and Trent Bridge (June 1-5) - and then five against West Indies, at Edgbaston (June 15-19), Lord's (June 29-July 3), Old Trafford (August 3-7), Headingley (August 17-21) and The Oval (August 31-September 4). In between the second and third Tests against West Indies there is a three-way one-day tournament also involving Zimbabwe.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: HKT may hold key to the internet in Asia

fields.headline: HKT may hold key to the internet in Asia
fields.standfirst:
Cable & Wireless benefits as suitors invite themselves to the dinner party

E-finance: special report
Cable & Wireless
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless was forced to do its homework on 33-year-old Richard Li, chief executive of youthful internet group Pacific Century Cyberworks, when his company became the surprise suitor for C&W's Hong Kong operation, HKT.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless was forced to do its homework on 33-year-old Richard Li, chief executive of youthful internet group Pacific Century Cyberworks, when his company became the surprise suitor for C&W's Hong Kong operation, HKT.

Mr Li - the son of Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's richest man and a member of the world's 10th richest family according to Forbes magazine - has been wheeling and dealing in the past nine months since PCCW's rebirth from a telecoms equipment distributor to a company linked to the internet. He can muster billions of dollars in the space of a few phone calls.

Almost overnight PCCW became valued at $29bn (£18bn), the sixth biggest company on the Hong Kong stock exchange. As investment bankers and institutional shareholders wait months to get a meeting with Mr Li, it is Cable & Wireless's chief executive, Graham Wallace who has gained the young Hong Kong tycoon's attention.

Mr Li's company wants a slice of C&W's 54% owned Hong Kong operation that has become peripheral to its parent's strategy but not to its bottom line as it accounts for almost two-thirds of the British telecoms group's operating profit.

Its rich seam of cash has ensured that Mr Wallace must carefully structure a deal that will see C&W exit part or all of its shareholding in its Hong Kong division with the best price for its shareholders. Mr Wallace has let it be know he wants a deal in cash or cash and shares.

C&W's appetite for funds is underpinning its rapid restructuring and expansion into a business telecommunications and data network company. It had begun negotiations with the state-owned SingTel with which it was proposing to merge its Hong Kong operations to create a new company worth £37bn by June.

The British group was planning to own about 27% after taking out cash. But the emergence of Mr Li and his new empire has spoiled plans by the Singaporean government to cement itself as the new telecommunications and, more importantly, internet hub for Asia, through the deal with Cable & Wireless HKT. SingTel said its talks were still ongoing but declined to comment further.

It is all good news for C&W. As one observer put it: "Wallace is sitting at the dinner table and the more options on the menu the merrier." The speculation on potential bidders, which grows daily to include Vodafone, AT&T and even Deutsche Telekom, has seen HKT's market capitalisation soar to over $40bn.

One theory is that Mr Li will join a consortium of bidders that will include the wealthy partner Hutchison Whampoa, the conglomerate controlled by his father. Mr Li's advisers, Bank of China, have been reported as saying that PCCW is raising as much as $1bn in a share sale to help it fund a merger with HKT. Peter Allen, chief financial officer and director at Pacific Century, has also built up expectations confirming that Warburg Dillon Read and Bank of China International are there "to assist in assessing all alternatives including possible investment in HKT".

While it appears to be going C&W's way, the 7% shareholding by China Telecom in HKT may prove a bone of contention. "China is not interested in merger and acquisitions, it is interested in what is in China's commercial defence," said one insider.

What this could mean is that China Telecom, the operational arm of China's ministry of post and telecommunications, may force a swing in C&W's thinking and see the deal go to PCCW. It would cer tainly weaken any chance of Singapore dominating telecommunications in Asia.

A deal linking HKT and PCCW, now Asia's largest internet group outside Japan, would also offer significant opportunities in the Chinese communications market.

Tressan MacCarthy European telecommunications analyst at Credit Lyonnais said: "The Credit Lyonnais view is that a preferred outcome is Pacific Century Cyberworks fronting some sort of consortium that gives Cable & Wireless HKT the most opportunities in China." Ms MacCarthy said the British ownership of HKT may have hindered such expansion.

"Graham Wallace's strategy on global operations has been business to business telecoms, data and internet service providers and that means not being in everything. I think what will happen is that Cable & Wireless will not continue as a majority shareholder of HKT. In terms of group strategy, Europe, the US and Japan where Cable & Wireless is, account for 80% of the global telecoms market. Hong Kong adds something like 0.6% to that," she said.

PCCW investments in satellite, digital and internet technology in Asia means HKT could give it a digital broadband network in Hong Kong and access to half a million internet subscribers, cashflow and access to China where its real aspirations lie.

PCCW is understood to want to have its satellite broadband connecting China, India and Japan.

An announcement on HKT's future was expected next month. The timetable may be blown out by the longer list of suitors joining Mr Wallace's dinner party.

The outcome may surprise those expecting a PCCW win. Nevertheless, PCCW's ambitions ensure that it may yet become of the world's biggest internet firms. A thought C&W should remember as it pursues the data network strategy that may see it meet PCCW in the future.

Father and son

Richard Li, age 33

Computer science graduate of Stanford University and second son of Li Ka-shing. Estimated to own 54.5% of Pacific Century Cyberworks.

Established Star TV in 1990 with $125m and sold it five years later to News Corp for $950m.

Companies: Pacific Century Cyberworks, Cyberworks Ventures.

Sources of wealth: Technology, property, insurance, media.

Li Ka-shing, age 72

The son of poor migrants. Hong Kong's richest man known as a local "superman" with self-made wealth of $12.7bn. The Li family is the 10th richest in the world according to Forbes magazine.

Companies: Hutchison Whampoa, Cheung Kong.

Source of wealth: Real estate, telecommunications and other diversified investments.

fields.headline: Ex-MEP gains £3m paper profit overnight
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special reportJust2Clicks
fields.trailText: Alan Donnelly, who unexpectedly quit as a Labour MEP in December, was yesterday sitting on a paper profit of almost £3m, seven weeks after investing £1,250 in an unquoted cash shell.
fields.body:
Alan Donnelly, who unexpectedly quit as a Labour MEP in December, was yesterday sitting on a paper profit of almost £3m, seven weeks after investing £1,250 in an unquoted cash shell.

Mr Donnelly's 1.2m shares in Just2Clicks, which has transformed itself into an operator of vertical business-to-business trading communities on the internet, were valued at just under £3m after its first day on the stock market.

The shares, which were placed at 150p, touched 295p before closing at 244p, valuing the company at more than £200m.

Karl Watkin, chief executive, said Just2Clicks was merely a cash shell with ideas and ambition when Mr Donnelly was appointed a non-executive director. Acquisitions had transformed the value of the company. City interest in business-to-business internet companies had grown dramatically since then, he added.

Just2Clicks is expected to spend some of the £50m the float raised to expand its trading communities to include the automotive industry. The company will draw on Mr Donnelly's expertise in the area if that happens.

Before resigning as MEP for Tyne and Wear, Mr Donnelly was European Parliamentary spokesman on the automotive industry.

Just2Clicks operates trading communities in the pulp and paper, electric power and road transport industries.

Figures released yesterday by Gartner Group predicted worldwide business-to-business e-commerce will pass $7.29 trillion by 2004.

fields.headline: Deutsche makes French connection
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report<A HREF="http://www.dtag.de/english/" TARGET="Deustche Telekom
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom is linking with France's Lagardère group in an attempt to expand its online reach into non-German speaking countries.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom is linking with France's Lagardère group in an attempt to expand its online reach into non-German speaking countries.

Its T-Online subsidiary is acquiring 99.9% of Lagardère's internet service provider, Club Internet, in exchange for the French group receiving a 6.5% stake in the merged online business which will have 4.2m users. That compares with AOL Europe, which has some 3.8m customers.

Although the exact value of the deal will not be known un til T-Online is floated in the spring, initial estimates put a price tag of about euro1bn (£610m) on Club Internet. That would value each Club Internet subscriber at just over £2,000 - less than half the value of Freeserve subscribers.

However, the deal could help T-Online command a higher value because it extends its operations outside its current confines of Germany and Austria but analysts are expecting further online deals from the German company.

"This is good news for the flotation of T-Online which we expect in April. It's really an internationalisation story - Germany, Austria and now France," according to Holger Grawe, telecoms analyst at WestLB.

Deutsche Telekom shares have soared in recent months but the group remains under pressure to put together an international expansion strategy in the face of the consolidation of the telecoms industry, exemplified by Vodafone acquisition of Mannesmann.

It is protected from potential predators by its size - it has a market capitalisation in excess of £160bn - and by the fact that the German state still owns about two thirds of the shares. The state holding has proved a handicap in the past - notably when Deutsche Telekom sought to pre-empt Olivetti's bid for Telecom Italia only to be thwarted by the Italian government's concerns about state ownership.

However, the level of the German government's control of Deutsche Telekom is likely to be reduced via the sale of further shares. The deal with Lagardère underline's Deutsche telekom's strategy in floating the T-Online operation.

News of yesterday's deal lifted Deutsche Telekom shares by 1.2% while Lagardère shares ended a volatile day's trading up 2.9%.

webTitle: Gloves are off for South Carolina finale

fields.headline: Gloves are off for South Carolina finale
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

CNN video of the debate
fields.trailText: With 48 hours to go before Saturday's all-important South Carolina Republican primary, George W Bush and John McCain took off the gloves yesterday, trading insults and accusations in the final televised debate of this phase of the campaign.
fields.body:
With 48 hours to go before Saturday's all-important South Carolina Republican primary, George W Bush and John McCain took off the gloves yesterday, trading insults and accusations in the final televised debate of this phase of the campaign.

In a frequently bad-tempered 90-minute studio spat, Mr Bush accused Mr McCain of throwing "as low a blow as you can give" in comparing the Texas governor to President Bill Clinton, while the Arizona senator said his rival "should be ashamed" of his campaign tactics.

"You're putting out stuff that is unbelievable, George, and it's got to stop," Mr McCain told his opponent.

After a succession of earlier campaign debates, which had been generally marked by civility and exchanges of compliments as well as frequent moments of humour, the Republican contest finally got dirty as the two candidates struggled for the advantage in what appears to be an exceedingly close contest in South Carolina.

Mr Bush appeared more confident and aggressive than in earlier debates, with Mr McCain making marginally less of an impact than previously.

It was clear throughout the debate that each man was aiming at a different constituency of voters, with the Texas governor focusing on conservative issues and the Arizona senator pitching for independent voters. Both men blamed one another for the increasingly acrimonious tone of the South Carolina campaign, in which each side has invested heavily in both overt and covert campaigning.

A report in the New York Times yesterday claimed that Mr Bush has been spending close to $3m (£1.8m) a week in the state and said that his once limitless war chest was getting empty, necessitating a number of emergency fund-raising events in the coming weeks.

Asked whether he was fighting a "dirty campaign", Mr Bush said that Mr McCain had promised to fight clean but had then "run an ad that equated me to Bill Clinton. He questioned my trustworthiness. That's about as low a blow as you can give in a Republican primary".

"Let me tell you what went over the line," Mr McCain retorted. Mr Bush organised a campaign event in which "a spokesman for a fringe veterans' group", had said Mr McCain, a former US Navy pilot who spent five-and-a-half years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam, "had abandoned the veterans".

"You should be ashamed," Mr McCain said to Mr Bush.

The Arizona senator said he had ordered an end to his campaign's use of so-called "negative ads" - television advertising which attacks an opponent rather than promoting the candidacy - after a woman had told him that her son had been distressed by a Bush camapign phone call which labelled Mr McCain as "a liar and a thief and a cheat".

Mr Bush responded by waving a negative campaign leaflet that had been placed on a car windscreen earlier in the day, in which the Texas governor was accused of planning not to give "one red cent" of new funding to the Social Security pension scheme and of wanting to "nationalise" education policy, traditionally a state-level responsibility.

"You didn't pull this," Mr Bush charged. "That was not put up by my campaign," Mr McCain replied." It says paid for by John McCain," Mr Bush countered. McCain campaign aides later confirmed that the leaflet had been produced by their campaign and claimed it was "an accurate flier".

After Mr McCain's victory in the New Hampshire primary two weeks ago, both he and Mr Bush are desperately aware that the winner of Saturday's rematch in South Carolina will become the clear frontrunner as the campaign moves into top gear in the run-up to the Super Tuesday contests on March 7. More than half of the delegates to the Republican national convention will then be chosen in 16 simultaneous state primaries and caucuses.

Voters in South Carolina - where independents and even, in theory, Democrats can register to vote in the February 19 Republican "open" primary - therefore hold the key to the Bush-McCain contest.

"Those 400,000 people have more power to determine the next Republican nominee and possibly the next president than anyone else in America, whether they know it or not," Mr McCain's pollster Bill McInturff said. If the Arizona senator wins "even by 10 votes at 2 o'clock Sunday morning", Mr McInturff said, then Mr Bush could no longer be regarded as the favourite.

Candidates clash over trust and abortion in TV debate

Larry King: Governor, what do you make of all the charges and countercharges?

George Bush: John [McCain] and I shook hands and we said we weren't going to run ads and he ran an ad that equated me to Bill Clinton. He questioned my trustworthiness. That's about as low a blow as you can give.

John McCain: Well, let me tell you what happened. There was an ad run against me, we ran a counter-ad in New Hampshire, Governor Bush took the ad down. And then I was beat up very badly by all of his surrogates - called Clinton, called Clinton-lite, called a hypocrite. Turn on the radio, turn on the television, pick up the telephone and you'll hear a attack against John McCain.

But let me tell you what really went over the line. Bush had an event and stood next to a spokesman for a fringe veterans' group. That fringe veteran said John McCain had abandoned the veterans. Now that really hurts, that really hurts.

GB: I believe that you served our country nobly and I've said it over and over again. That man wasn't speaking for me.

JMC: He was at your event.

GB: If you're going to hold me responsible for what people say, I'm going to do the same for you. Warren Rudman, your campaign man in New Hampshire, said about the Christian Coalition that they're bigots. You don't believe that, do you?

JMC: He's entitled to his opinion on that issue.

GB: Well, so is this man.

JMC: You paid for an event and stood next to a person. And when you were asked if you would repudiate him, you said, no.

GB: No. Let me say what I said. Let's discuss the issues. Let's discuss the issues.

JMC: Let me finish, OK? So here's what happened. We ran an ad that was a response ad. At a town hall meeting a mother stood up and said, "Senator McCain, my son was 13 last year. Now he told me not long ago, 'John McCain is my hero'."

Well, last night he came into her room, she said, and he had tears in his eyes because he had answered the phone and the caller - even though he told the caller that he was 14 - said: "Do you know that John McCain is a liar, and a thief and cheat?"

Well, that night I called my people together. I said, "Take down our response ad. We're running nothing but a positive campaign from now." I committed to that, I promise that.

LK: Are you saying Bush was responsible for that call?

JMC: I don't know who was responsible. But I know that the attacks go on.

GB: Let me just say one thing. This ended up in a man's windshield yesterday...

JMC: : Yes, I...

GB: This is an attack piece.

JMC: That is not by my campaign.

GB: Well, it says "paid for by John McCain". The political questions around abortion are these, and this is one that's going to differentiate us from the Democrat nominee, I will sign a ban on partial-birth abortion. All three of us will sign a ban on partial-birth abortion. Vice-president Gore, if he's the nominee, will sit there and justify partial-birth abortion.

JMC: Do you believe in the exemption of abortion for rape, incest and life of the mother?

GB: Yes, I do. I do.

JMC: You were talking about printed material that's mailed out. Here's one that says that George Bush supports the pro-life plank.

GB: I do.

JMC: So in other words you believe there's an exemption for rape, incest and the life of the mother, but you want the platform that you're supposed to be leading to have no exemption.

GB: The platform doesn't talk about what specifically should be in the constitutional amendment.

JMC: It doesn't have the exemptions in it.

GB: I think we need to keep the platform the way it is. This is a pro-life party.

LK: All right, this conservative-liberal thing - are you saying John McCain is a liberal?

GB: No, I'm not.

LK: Do you think he is a conservative?

GB: Yes. I also think he's a fine man.

LK: Why mention conservative in a race where everybody's conservative?

GB: Because I'm more conservative on certain issues.

JMC: Because we all...

(Laughter)

JMC: We don't like to go around portraying ourselves as liberals.

(Laughter)

LK: Do you think you've been labelled liberal?

JMC: I've been labelled everything except I think they missed fascist.

(Laughter)

GB: Listen, you're playing the victim here. Wait a minute. Remember who called who untrustworthy.

webTitle: Budget to focus on child poverty

fields.headline: Budget to focus on child poverty
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will step up the "war on child poverty" in next month's budget, unveiling an integrated system which aims to lift more than a million of Britain's poorest children out of hardship.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will step up the "war on child poverty" in next month's budget, unveiling an integrated system which aims to lift more than a million of Britain's poorest children out of hardship.

Labour insiders hope the move - once spoken of as an aspiration but now brought forward as a firm policy - will placate disaffected activists in the party's heartlands. It will be billed as a radical restucturing of the welfare state - and a key step on the way to achieving the government's proclaimed mission: halving child poverty in 10 years and eradicating it in 20.

Under the plan, child benefit will remain separate and distinct but the current raft of state allowances for children will be brought under a single banner, "the integrated child credit".

By next year, even before the new machinery is in place, the poorest families should be receiving £45 weekly for each child, which government officials insist amounts to the most generous state help for children ever.

Hinting at a release of fresh money in the March 21 budget, treasury sources made clear that help for poor children will form the centrepiece of the chancellor's speech.

In what is clearly designed as a public-relations offensive to win over Labour's increasingly disillusioned supporters, advisers to Mr Brown say that the chancellor has now cracked the problem of implementing the change - allowing him to bring in the streamlined system much earlier than he previously thought possible. Labour aims to be able to offer it to voters at the next election as a concrete achievement - not just a manifesto pledge.

Mr Brown will argue that the trebling of child poverty in the past 20 years is "the biggest single problem" facing the country. Four in 10 children born in Britain are born into low-income households, according to ministers.

"If in the next 10 years this huge problem - which is dividing society - is not addressed, then we will have failed," said one source close the chancellor.

Anxious to be seen by Labour activists as a redistributive chancellor, Mr Brown plans to draw attention to the new drive with a tour later this month of Britain's hardest-pressed regions. In tow will be the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the education secretary, David Blunkett, and the DTI's Stephen Byers. They and the chancellor will visit the "pockets of poverty" which have missed out on the prosperity of south-east England.

But the tour, which will seek to drum up investment and enterprise in deprived areas, will also be seen as an attempt to reassure the old Labour faithful that the government is not solely concerned with affluent middle England.

Other headline-grabbing measures known to be under discussion include a stay-at-home credit for new mothers on low incomes, enabling them to raise newborn children without having to return early to work.

A leading advocate of the move is the former social security secretary, Harriet Harman, who remains close to Mr Brown. She argues that while women have the legal right to remain home for up to six months without losing their jobs, statutory maternity pay lasting only 18 weeks causes many to leave their babies sooner than they would like.

A "baby premium" - conceivably of up to £70 a week - added to the working families' tax credit could mean that families already qualifying for the WFTC receive enough extra income to allow the mother to take her six-month leave.

Mr Brown is likely to use his budget speech to rally the Labour troops in what is almost certainly the last full year before the general election.

After the resignation in late January of the Blairite loyalist Peter Kilfoyle - who accused the government of lavishing too much attention on middle England - MPs want to hear a clear statement of purpose.

Mr Brown will tell them that they are achieving Labour's highest purpose: having lifted 800,000 children out of poverty, the government aims to aid a million more.

The chancellor also intends to announce more money for the Sure Start scheme, which helps nursery-age children, and launch a Children's Fund, to support local and charity projects that work with children.

But the heart of the strategy seeks to be "a seamless system of support for children", bringing the children's tax credit and the portion of either income support or working families' tax credit currently allocated for a child into a single package.

fields.trailText: Genius on a plate | The perfect boiled egg
fields.body:
Flash of genius on a plate
Chemists in Taipei have found that inexpensive clay minerals containing iron form a blue pigment when exposed to light. Conventional film is based on the photochemistry of silver bromide, which is sacrificed in the development process . ChemComm, a journal of the Royal Society, reports that a "primitive" film was produced by spraying a clay preparation on to glass. The letters C.H.E.M were produced on exposure and then erased by weak acid. Even after 20 re-exposures it was possible to get an image of reasonable quality - a reason for the snap-happy to flex their trigger fingers.

Shell out for eggs over-easy
The perfect boiled egg is a gift, and some just don't have it. The European Journal of Physics shows how to get dream consistency every time. Egg boiling follows the Fourier principle of heat transfer rates - you can find the formula in any physics text. You need to know the surface area of the egg; the temperature at which yolk and white will cook; the temperature of the egg before it enters the water, and the temperature of the water. Apply the right thermodynamic constants (also in your physics book), set your watch. No egg will ever disappoint again.

It never rains but it pours...
Caleta, a mountain village in north Chile, gets less than 700mm of annual rainfall. Chilean environmentalists and Canadian researchers assembled a "rain machine" to catch the camanchaca, a low-lying cloud that passes over the mountains every night. Eighty six nylon-mesh panels, each the size of a billboard, were placed on the mountainside. At night, water from the cloud condenses on the mesh. When the droplets get big enough they fall through the mesh and are collected.On a good day, one panel alone can capture 700 litres. The cost of the process is one-fifth that of imported water.

fields.headline: PM to spearhead Europe campaign
fields.standfirst:
Threat to jobs is focus of cross-party project

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to spearhead a new campaign to warn voters of the catastrophic dangers of Euro-scepticism, amid ministerial fears that opposition to the European Union is growing at an alarming rate.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to spearhead a new campaign to warn voters of the catastrophic dangers of Euro-scepticism, amid ministerial fears that opposition to the European Union is growing at an alarming rate.

The prime minister will kick off the campaign - which will have the slogan Out of Europe, Out of Work - with a speech next week warning that isolation in Europe would cost hundreds of thousands of British jobs.

The initiative, which follows William Hague's launch of his Keep the Pound campaign this week, will reopen Tory splits over Europe, with Kenneth Clarke and Michael Heseltine throwing their weight behind the prime minister. They will also be supported by Gordon Brown, Robin Cook, and Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy.

The Out of Europe, Out of Work campaign, which is being seen as the most important pro-European drive since a cross-party group successfully secured a yes vote in the 1975 EEC referendum, will fuel speculation that the prime minister is warming to the euro.

Labour sources made clear, however, that the new campaign has the more modest aim of turning public opinion in favour of Europe, after a recent BBC opinion poll found that 34% of voters were in favour of withdrawal from the European Union. The prime minister will not countenance a referendum if the public mood remains the same.

At the heart of the campaign, which is being masterminded by the cross-party Britain in Europe group, will be a series of reports by independent experts which will set out the dangers of isolation in Europe. The reports will set out the dangers, starting with the danger to the British economy of following the Tories' unofficial position of ruling out membership of the euro forever. One of the reports, which sets out the economic costs of withdrawing from the EU, was last night passed to the Guardian. Although no mainstream politicians are demanding withdrawal, the pro-Europeans believe it is important to warn of such dangers because of the Tories' growing opposition to Europe.

The report, which has been compiled by the independent National Institute for Economic and Social Research, says withdrawal would lead to a £12bn rise in the price of British exports to the EU because new tariffs would be imposed. This would force companies to slash costs and wages to compete.

The report also says that withdrawal would lead to:

 The British economy shrinking by 2% a year, creating a deep recession. This would reduce the economy by £15.24bn a year, which is almost the NHS's entire annual budget;

 A tax rise by of 3p in the pound to compensate for the shrinking of the economy. This would cost a household on £25,000 an extra £600 a year;

 A 2.5% fall in consumer spending after the increase in taxes.

A Britain in Europe source denied that the new initiative was a kneejerk reaction to the Tories' Keep the Pound campaign because Britain in Europe has spent the past three months preparing for next week's launch. The disclosure of the new pro-European campaign came as the prime minister clashed with Mr Kennedy over Europe.

The Lib Dem leader called on the prime minister "to engage more seriously" in the task of winning public support for euro entry, warning: "Sentiment is slipping away from the sensible pro-euro case." His remarks came after vacuum cleaner entrepreneur, James Dyson, said he was planning to invest money and jobs in Asia.

fields.headline: Time to act on bullies
fields.trailText: The news that a 13-year-old girl had been given her own 'bodyguard' after a year of persistent abuse is both shocking and worrying. The media storm which followed may explain why her parents quickly decided today to withdraw their daughter from the Nottingham comprehensive that was suddenly thrown into the spotlight.
fields.body:
The news that a 13-year-old girl had been given her own 'bodyguard' after a year of persistent abuse is both shocking and worrying. The media storm which followed may explain why her parents quickly decided today to withdraw their daughter from the Nottingham comprehensive that was suddenly thrown into the spotlight.

While classroom abuse in any shape or form cannot be condoned, this was surely an extreme action which was in danger of singling the girl out and possibly creating an entirely new set of problems for her.

Reading between the lines, it became clear that Amie Salmon was not being given the services of a uniformed bouncer at Glaisdale school, but the assurance that her form teacher will be her own personal 'minder', on hand for constant supervision if she needed it. Over the last two weeks this meant virtually constant supervision, through most school lessons, during lunch breaks and even when the poor girl went to the toilet.

At the same time, however, Glaisdale admitted that the girls responsible for the bullying - alarmingly, an eight-strong gang - have been allowed to continue their own lessons unaffected. The action was taken last week after Amie's parents threatened to withdraw her from the school. Although the move was described as a temporary measure until Amie starts to feel safe again, her parents were furious that their once 'bubbly' daughter should have been singled out for special treatment. They rightly felt that she was the one being punished, while no action had been taken by the school to discipline or suspend the perpetrators.

The headteacher, Tim Moralee, has defended his decision not to suspend them, saying that it doesn't solve bullying. Nottingham education authority supports the school's decision.

But offering 'protection' in this way is simply pushing the problem under the carpet rather than dealing with its root causes. Schools are not 24-hour institutions. What happens beyond the school gates when bullies are free to follow their victims? What would happen to Amie on her way home from school when her form teacher was not there to protect her? What message does the whole stunt send out to other bullies and potential bullies at the same school and in the same area?

Ten years ago, bullying was barely recognised as a day-to-day problem for schools. Today, while the department for education and employment offers guidance on tackling bullying, it is left to individual schools and local education authorities to decide how they implement that guidance. Many forward-thinking schools throughout the UK have devised innovative strategies to deal with offenders, such as assigning victims their own 'minders' - but these have been fellow classmates rather than teachers. That gives the minders a sense of responsibility for others, without singling the victims out. Other schemes include anonymous bullying reporting systems.

But for every Amie Salmon who hits the headlines, there are hundreds of other cases who go unreported. Perhaps it is time the DfEE looked again at its own guidance and gave schools more practical help to deal with a problem that makes so many children's lives a misery.

webTitle: Olive oil power plants could give Opec the slip

fields.headline: Olive oil power plants could give Opec the slip
fields.trailText: It was in use before a written language was invented. Today it is being studied as a possible means of staving off ailments ranging from bowel cancer to gallstones. It has been used to provide heating and lighting for centuries. Even the trendiest of today's celebrity chefs does not disdain to slosh it around.
fields.body:
It was in use before a written language was invented. Today it is being studied as a possible means of staving off ailments ranging from bowel cancer to gallstones. It has been used to provide heating and lighting for centuries. Even the trendiest of today's celebrity chefs does not disdain to slosh it around.

Now olive oil, the golden liquid on which commercial empires, to say nothing of the Mediterranean diet, have been built is about to get yet another use.

Endesa, one of Spain's biggest utilities, yesterday announced plans to build two olive oil fired power stations at a cost of almost £25m.

Well the fuel was not quite olive oil. Actually the solid residue - known in the trade as orujillo - left after every drop of oil has been pressed from the fruit.

At a time when the other stuff that comes out of places like the North Sea, the Middle East and some of the less hospitable parts of Russia is heading for $30 (£19) a barrel Endesa's initiative has obvious commercial potential.

But it is environmentally friendly too. The fibrous mass that is orujillo - though it has a high thermal value when burnt - is otherwise pretty tricky for the olive growers to get rid off.

Spain is handily placed as a provider of orujillo. It has getting on for 200m olive trees making it the world's largest producer of olive oil and consequently of fuel for the new plants. They will be built in Jaen and Cuidad Real at the heart of Spain's olive growing region and when they come into operation in the second half of next year will produce a total of 32 megawatts, or enough to supply 100,000 people. They will be the first in the world to use olive residues to generate electricity.

If the technology turns out to be a commercial success Spain's neighbours - olive oil producers all - could well be tempted to follow Endesa's lead.

That could give Opec a whole new meaning. Instead of the Organisation of Oil Exporting Countries it might find itself reinvented to become the Olive Producers Electricity Cooperative.

Now that would give them something to thing about - be it in Aberdeen or Azerbaijan.

webTitle: Soften law on ecstasy, says police inquiry

fields.headline: Soften law on ecstasy, says police inquiry
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Ecstasy, said to be used by half a million people every weekend in Britain's dance clubs, should no longer be treated as a class-A drug such as heroin, but instead should be downgraded and classed as a soft drug such as cannabis, a Police Federation inquiry will recommend next month.
fields.body:
Ecstasy, said to be used by half a million people every weekend in Britain's dance clubs, should no longer be treated as a class-A drug such as heroin, but instead should be downgraded and classed as a soft drug such as cannabis, a Police Federation inquiry will recommend next month.

The two and half year inquiry enjoys semi-official status with home secretary Jack Straw who, after rejecting calls for a royal commission into drugs, said he would wait for the federation report before considering if any change is needed to Britain's 30-year-old drug laws.

Although the popularity of ecstasy and other amphetamine derivatives peaked in 1996 when police forces seized some 5.75m doses, they have started to make a comeback - the seizure of 2m doses in 1998 was the second highest figure ever recorded.

Any decision to remove ecstasy from the group of drugs which are highly addictive would mark a sharp change in official policy. It would also be sure to spark a fierce reaction from anti-drug campaigners and the families of ecstasy victims such as the Essex teenager Leah Betts.

As a class-A drug, possession of ecstasy attracts a sentence of up to six months but this would be reduced to a maximum of three months or a £200 fine if it were reclassified as a class-C drug.

Most ecstasy taken in the UK is made in the Netherlands and smuggled into Britain. About 3,000 people were convicted of ecstasy related offences in 1998.

The Police Federation inquiry is chaired by Lady Runciman, the former head of the government's advisory council on the misuse of drugs, and includes two chief constables as well as former home office civil servants on its team.

It is expected to recommend that instead of imprisoning people caught possessing cannabis, the offence should be treated as a minor civil offence. This policy of "penalisation" stops far short of decriminalisation because cautions and fines would still be widely used.

However, it is expected to recommend that those caught in possession of more than two grams of cannabis - enough to make five joints - should be treated as dealers by the police and the courts and face much tougher penalties. Drug law reform campaigners fear this will be a retrograde step.

The change of classification for ecstasy would mean much more lenient penalties and end cases where teenagers have been jailed for supplying a small group of friends with a tablet each.

Figures published yesterday showed that 127,900 people were found guilty of drug offences last year - 90% of them for possession of cannabis, most of whom were cautioned or fined. The number of offences rose 13% on 1998.

Despite claims that the police increasingly turn a blind eye to cannabis possession, the figures show that there has been a massive increase in cannabis arrests in the last decade. In 1988 only 30,500 were arrested for drug offences in England and Wales. The figures show that last year 5,700 people were jailed for possession of drugs - but they do not spell out how many were for cannabis alone.

The drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, yesterday insisted after meeting Tony Blair at 10 Downing Street, that his 10-year strategy was not failing and was given the public backing of the prime minister. "These figures prove we are clamping down on drugs with the arrest of more offenders and more seizures."

But the government is coming under renewed pressure to set up a royal commission to look at the possibility of legalising soft drugs such as cannabis. The Cleveland police force has become the first to question whether the "war on drugs" can ever be won and suggest that legalisation might be the only serious alternative.

webTitle: Bakewell quits BBC show in protest

fields.headline: Bakewell quits BBC show in protest
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Joan Bakewell, one of the BBC's leading broadcasters on religious and ethical topics, is leaving the moral debate programme Heart of the Matter, citing frustration at financial cutbacks and its late night scheduling.
fields.body:
Joan Bakewell, one of the BBC's leading broadcasters on religious and ethical topics, is leaving the moral debate programme Heart of the Matter, citing frustration at financial cutbacks and its late night scheduling.

Ms Bakewell, 66, who has presented the show for the past 12 years, said yesterday that she felt the BBC had neglected its religious output, but that she understood the corporation's priorities changed.

"Religion has had year-on-year budget cuts and has been moved later and later at night," she told the Daily Telegraph. "When you've experienced that for 10 years you begin to wonder whether anyone's got much trust in you. But I've learnt not to expect very much because I understand the different priorities of the BBC today."

The BBC has recently come under fire for its religious coverage. Two days ago the Church of England criticised the corporation for cutting religious broadcasting and replacing it with "trite drivel".

Ms Bakewell's decision to leave the programme comes just before the new series of Heart of the Matter begins on Sunday, which the BBC said would probably be the last.

A BBC spokeswoman last night made it clear that Ms Bakewell would continue to work with the BBC on other programmes.

She currently presents The Brains Trust on BBC radio and is working on a social study series called My Generation, as well as the BBC2 history programme One Foot in the Past. She is also working on an eight-part "spiritual audit" of the country called the Soul of Britain which will be broadcast in the autumn.

Ms Bakewell was appointed CBE for services to broadcasting in the Queen's birthday honours last year.

Peter Salmon, the controller of BBC1, said: "I'm very grateful to Joan for the work she's done but she doesn't know the full picture about what's happening to religion on BBC1 and our plans for new output and new programmes.

"Times have changed and we need to reflect that and to look at things differently."

webTitle: Prisoner tells of 22 years in solitary

fields.headline: Prisoner tells of 22 years in solitary
fields.trailText: A notorious category A prisoner who has spent the last 26 years in jail - 22 years of them in solitary confinement - yesterday told a court of his life of purgatory among inmates including "our very own Hannibal the Cannibal".
fields.body:
A notorious category A prisoner who has spent the last 26 years in jail - 22 years of them in solitary confinement - yesterday told a court of his life of purgatory among inmates including "our very own Hannibal the Cannibal".

Charles Bronson, 47, who was originally jailed for seven years for armed robbery in 1974, said he felt "dehumanised" by a prison system which forced him to live in a windowless cell for 23 hours a day.

He told Luton crown court that if he were an animal the RSPCA would be fighting his case for him.

Sporting a shaven head and eight-inch moustache and wearing sunglasses, Bronson spelled out details of prison life and told of fellow inmates such as "our very own Hannibal the Cannibal".

Bronson, from Luton, Bedfordshire, is accused of false imprisonment and criminal damage during a prison siege at Hull prison in January last year. It is alleged that he took teacher Phil Danielson, 37, of Bridlington, East Yorkshire, hostage for 44 hours. Mr Danielson had been visiting the jail.

A jury of seven men and five women has heard that Bronson tied a skipping rope around Mr Danielson's neck and pulled him around the jail.

Bronson, who is currently held in Woodhill prison, in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, denies both charges. He says he was forced to take Mr Danielson hostage because he was under duress.

He was cleared of making threats to kill Mr Danielson and of assault after Judge Ronald Moss ruled there was insufficient evidence.

Bronson said: "I first came to prison when I was 21 in 1974. I have been in prison ever since, barring three months. We are talking about 26 years I have served.

"Twenty-two years of that have been in solitary confinement. Isolation. On my own. No contact. Think about that. At times I feel like I am dehumanised. I get panic attacks when I am with people." Bronson said his family, with the exception of his elderly mother Eira Peterson, were strangers to him.

"At the moment my bed is a concrete slab four and a half inches from the ground. So I am sleeping on the floor. I haven't got a bed.

"My cell is about 12 feet long and nine feet wide and I live in that room for 23 hours of a 24-hour day. Every time my door is opened there are never less than six prison officers to feed me at my door. Plastic plates, plastic spoons. Everything is plastic.

webTitle: School gives bullied girl a bodyguard

fields.headline: School gives bullied girl a bodyguard
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A 13-year-old girl has been given a full-time "bodyguard" at school after enduring a year of bullying by a gang of pupils.
fields.body:
A 13-year-old girl has been given a full-time "bodyguard" at school after enduring a year of bullying by a gang of pupils.

Amie Salmon is able to call on her form teacher to act as her personal bodyguard at any time and has to be accompanied through most school lessons, during lunch breaks, and even when she goes to the toilet.

While Amie has been constantly supervised over the past two weeks, the gang of eight girls, who she claims have subjected her to a year of verbal and physical abuse, have been allowed to continue their lessons unaffected, the school admitted.

Glaisdale comprehensive, in Nottingham, appointed the female teacher as the teenager's minder last week as a temporary measure after her worried parents threatened to withdraw Amie from the school.

The girl has also been allowed to have a mobile phone at all times to summon help immediately if she is picked on, and she starts and finishes her school day at different times to other pupils.

Amie has also attended her form teacher's classes instead of her normal one to avoid contact with the bullies.

Her parents, who want the bullies to be suspended, have criticised the school's decision to take Amie out of normal classes as increasing the victimisation of their daughter. Amie, who joined the school in 1998, was originally friends with the gang which began bullying her last year. But the abuse, orchestrated by two ringleaders, became so bad that her parents considered asking their GP to prescribe her tranquillisers.

Amie, whose sisters, Chanine, 21, and Hailey, 18, attended the school without problems, said: "It's horrible. There were some days when I wanted to be dead. They've hit me and because I'm small they call me anorexic and make fun of me. It was happening every day and I started to dread going to school."

She added: "Someone has to bring me work that my classes are doing because I cannot be with them while the bullies are in there. I cannot even go to the toilet by myself. It is very difficult."

Amie's parents have spoken to her teachers about the problem six times in the past year.

Paul and Michelle Salmon, who chose Glaisdale because of its hard line on bullying, took Amie out of school after she was punched in the face by another girl.

They only agreed to her returning if action was taken to protect their daughter and to punish the bullies.

Mr Salmon said: "We feel her education is now suffering while the bullies are carrying on as normal. My daughter has been made a victim by the bullies and now by the school as well."

The headteacher, Tim Moralee, defended his decision not to suspend the bullies, saying: "It doesn't solve bullying. In Amie's case we are increasing the protected time and decreasing the unprotected time. It can make her appear to be the one who is being punished, which is unjust, but it is a way of helping victims, when often they feel unhappy about attending school." Mr Moralee said the measures were temporary and that the bullies were being monitored.

The school is also introducing a new bullying reporting system and instigating staff training on the problem.

A spokeswoman for the education department said schools were offered guidance, adding: "It is up to individual schools and local education authorities as to how they implement that guidance."

fields.headline: Clash of the web chemists
fields.standfirst: Plans to deliver drugs to your door have thrown up problems, reports  Michael Brooks
fields.trailText: Plans to deliver drugs to your door have thrown up problems, reports  Michael Brooks
fields.body:
A row is brewing between Britain's web pharmacists. Allcures will launch its web service on Monday, offering prescription medicines delivered to the customer's door by Parcel Force and Securicor. Its only competitor, Pharmacy2u, began serving its customers at the end of last year using its own fleet of vans. It is furious that Allcures is being allowed to use a standard courier service.

Selling drugs over the net is not as simple as selling books and CDs. The Royal Pharmaceutical Society's code of ethics forbids the use of "third party carriers" for medicines in an attempt to ensure that medicines are not stolen, and that patients are always properly informed about treatment regimes and possible problems. When Pharmacy2u set up its venture in November, it also bought a courier company so that the society could not object to the service.

But Allcures' distribution methods will work out significantly cheaper, allowing it to undercut Pharmacy2u.

Daniel Lee, managing director of Pharmacy2u, believes that his competitor's arrangements will compromise standards in the pharmaceutical industry. "It's against the code of ethics - it's important that the supply chain is fulfilled by the pharmacy," he says. Lee fears that medicines could get lost among other parcels, be left on doorsteps or with neighbours, or be held in unsuitable conditions in a depot.

Alex Dickson Leach, project manager for Allcures, says its distributors will always get a signature for the medicines. The company has already secured the approval of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society. "They're very happy with what we're doing, and they've given us the go-ahead," she says. Stephen Lutener, head of pharmacy law at the society, could not confirm or deny that Allcures had the RPS approval.

Allcures is delivering NHS prescriptions for free, and hopes to make up its deficit with a £3.49 delivery charge on private prescriptions and other products, such as nappies and toiletries. Pharmacy2u is charging £5 for delivery on all products and prescriptions.

Using an internet pharmacy within the UK means filling out a health questionnaire and placing an order. However, prescriptions must still be sent through the post to the pharmacy premises before any shipment is made. Lee believes that the tight regulations will gradually be eroded by internet pharmacies attempting to cut costs and waiting times.

The US is already facing problems with internet pharmacy. Some doctors are prescribing pills online without meeting patients and assessing their condition (a man with a history of heart disease died after using Viagra bought online), and illegitimate online pharmacies are operating without licensed pharmacists. While some customers are left unaware of side effects or dangerous drug combinations, others are using the system to buy GHB, the date rape drug.

The US government is now beginning a $10m effort to crack down on the illegal sale of pharmaceuticals through the internet. The initiative includes a public education campaign about the dangers of buying prescription drugs online, and the introduction of a mark to identify legitimate and approved internet pharmacies. Lee says he would like to see a similar move in the UK.

"We are ethical and professional, but we don't know what the next people are going to be like. I'd like to see some kind of kitemark, so they meet certain criteria and are actively policed."

When Pharmacy2u was launched, there were no regulations for internet pharmacy, Lee says. "We did try and ask the society and the medicines control agency if what we were doing was legal; they didn't really have an opinion."

Within three days of the launch the Royal Pharmaceutical Society visited Lee's premises in order to inspect the operation. The society then published interim regulations in January. Lee felt exonerated by the regulations which, he says, reflected his company's standards. But he now feels that he is going to pay for taking the ethical high ground.

He has arranged an emergency meeting with the RPS to question the new stance on deliveries; if the standards are to be lowered, he will sacrifice his principles to stay in the market. "If it's being allowed then I guess we'll be going down that road," he says.

fields.headline: How kids can cash in
fields.standfirst: They're streetwise, e-wise and have plenty to spend. But the trick is to let them spend it online. Justin Hunt sees how the e-traders are wooing the next generation
fields.trailText: Not so long ago the cult novelist Douglas Coupland introduced us to Generation X. Over-educated, disaffected and unable to find satisfying jobs, these alienated twenty somethings drifted aimlessly across the bleak rolling deserts of California.
fields.body:
Not so long ago the cult novelist Douglas Coupland introduced us to Generation X. Over-educated, disaffected and unable to find satisfying jobs, these alienated twenty somethings drifted aimlessly across the bleak rolling deserts of California.

Now the UK internet industry has discovered Generation Y. This e-marketing buzzword is a direct reference to the large number of UK teenagers who have grown up in a world of exploding technology and for whom being wired up is as natural as having electricity.

"Their bedrooms are usually filled with a computer, a scanner, a mobile phone, a pager, a stereo and their PlayStation. They are using all the latest technology to empower themselves. It's part of their life," explains the Cartoon Network's head of content, Dorenna Newton. "Their bedroom is like a virtual world. They have a social life out of their bedroom. They do not know a world without technology."

According to the online industry's latest estimates, more than one in four UK teenagers regularly accesses the web, and the average 14- to 16-year-old has an annual disposable income, based on pocket money and part-time jobs, of £600.

To win the loyalty of Generation Y, new services to encourage teenagers to spend online are being launched; a flurry of student portals have gone live; the BBC is planning to introduce a new online teenage service in the spring, and consumer goods giant Procter & Gamble has just announced it is teaming up with Excite, the internet portal company, to create a major new teenage lifestyle site.

"The level of penetration among teenagers is growing higher and higher," says the director of BBC Online, Nigel Chapman. "They are very technology savvy. They are going to be large consumers of net material. They are the next generation and they are increasingly going to want to buy things online."

The BBC foresees TV viewing habits declining among teenagers due to the competing and powerful influences of new technologies, and realises that if it is to survive the corporation has to build relationships with teenagers over the internet.

Similarly, e-entrepreneurs have picked up on the fact that teenagers are often the key drivers of the purchase of hi-tech goods within British households. With computers being introduced into schools, technology is becoming a completely normal part of their culture. "The big barrier has been that you can get teenagers to surf but you cannot get them to buy because they are under age for having credit cards," explains director of Fletcher Research, Neil Bradford. This has been frustrating for e-marketeers because they know parents have been buying for teenagers but they have not been able to capitalise on the growing online teenage market.

But all this is about to change. New forms of internet payments and dedicated teenage shopping sites are being brought to the market. But, as usual, the UK internet industry is simply following in the footsteps of its US counterparts, who have already introduced specific teenage shopping sites such as DoughNet.com, ICanbuy.com and the wittily-named Cybermoola.com, to name but a few. In a direct pitch for Generation Y, a major teenage shopping service has been launched in the UK called Y-creds (www.Y-creds.co.uk).

Billing itself as the ultimate online high street for Generation Y, the site allows teenagers to shop online without a credit card. Y-creds operate like traditional offline book vouchers or record tokens. Parents buy Y-creds for their teenagers and set up online accounts for them. The Y-creds site is linked to various online retailers, and through a control menu parents can designate which shops their offspring can buy from. They cannot access their children's accounts: they are informed when a transaction has occurred but are not told what has been bought. Each Y-cred is worth a modest penny and they can be bought in units of 500 costing parents a fiver.

Goods for sale at this online high street are age-restricted so, for example, a 13-year old Madonna fan would not be allowed to buy 15-cert videos. Like most canny new online services, Y-creds has gone for a low key launch to avoid serious media scrutiny until the product has proved itself. The company is likely to begin seriously hyping itself at key commercial times such as summer holidays and half terms, as and when more retailers come on board. "I would like to see Y-creds being used by as many different retailers as possible across the UK, empowering teenagers to shop online with their parents' permission," says founder Kevin Sefton.

On the Y-creds web site, teenagers are encouraged to get their parents to "load up" their accounts so they can start spending, but Sefton denies he is whipping up online pester power to burn holes in the wallets of hard-working parents.

"I would say that parents will welcome Y-creds. They encourage financial responsibility. We are not advertising particular products. Instead we are providing mechanisms for paying for them." Sefton says many parents worry about how their teenagers spend money when they go shopping outdoors, and he feels Y-creds will put parents more in control and eradicate any fears of their children's pockets being picked. The long term plan, if Y-creds take off, is to create an online teenage bank.

Already Sefton is talking to potential online banking partners who will doubtless be keen to start a relationship with potential customers of the future. Once, high street banks used to attend freshers' fairs at universities to win new accounts. Now they are taking part in virtual ones being organised by the new crop of student portal sites such as student pages (www.studentpages.com).

Here students can visit online stalls of banks such as the Royal Bank of Scotland and click through to other sites to take advantage of specially-tailored discount deals. Students might have a reputation for spending most of their time and grant (what's left of it) boozing and eating Pot Noodles, but online marketeers know these older teenagers will be the architects of future consumer spending patterns.

One of the leading new student sites, NowNet (www.nownet.co.uk) has tied up with consumer brands such as Tango to run treasure hunt games across its site. There is also a virtual NowNet bar and once you've clicked on the 3D bouncer at the door you enter an environment which is like a film set. In the best traditions of Tinseltown, product placement is finding a home on the student portals. In NowNet's bar students can click on a book which just happens to be lying around, and then go straight through to Waterstone's site where they can buy books. Many of the new student sites are ISPs as well, and offer free email addresses.

The strategy is to hold on to students after they have graduated so they take their email addresses with them into the real world of work. Then the dial-up ISPs still continue to make money out of them.

The majority of student sites are positioned as entertainment zones and go all out to get on the side of the students, which underlines the importance of appropriate content. Getting the right image for its teenage service in the spring is preoccupying BBC Online at the moment.

"Our teenage service has the potential to have credibility with teenagers," explains Chapman, who has two teenage daughters of his own. "But we have to be very mindful of tone and be very contemporary. It is not going to be po-faced." Carving out its own public service niche against fierce competition from the e-entrepreneurs, BBC Online hopes to offer quality, trusted content for teenagers about issues such as drugs and health.

But it won't be easy. What's more, the scramble to colonise the emerging online teenage audience is being waged across all platforms. Interactive TV is in the sights of most of the new teenage shopping sites and student portals. But the key gateway to teenagers is the mobile phone.

The Cartoon Network is planning to introduce online cartoons and MP3 music files this year, and will be providing content through mobile phone companies as well. Asked about the importance of mobile phones for targeting teenagers, Cartoon Network's Dorenna Newton replies: "Enormous. Enormous. Enormous. They will be huge. Last Christmas was a mobile Christmas."

Techniques for profiling and marketing to teenagers are likely to become far more sophisticated this year. Traditionally, when a middle-aged parent bought a present for one of their children it was impossible to build up a profile of that child. But as teenagers part with their email addresses to join new teenage shopping sites, they can expect targeted offers (virtual mail shots) to automatically appear on their computer screens or phones when they log on.

Huge amounts of creative effort are going into understanding the online behaviour of teenagers. For the non-digital generation who are currently in charge of teenage online businesses, this is hard work. The Cartoon Network finds teenage focus groups wearying. "They always look pissed off, wearing their Nike caps the wrong way round and chewing gum," laughs Newton.

But she says they come alive when they are given the chance to start testing computer games. Games are a key way to generate affection for an online brand. But there are plenty of other ways. The Cartoon Network has a Scooby Doo web cam on its site. They took a life-sized stuffed Scooby Doo toy around London and filmed it to keep their online teenage audience amused. While they are logged on, laughing at Scooby, teenagers are also being encouraged to consume advertisers' messages for cereals and chocolate bars. Sometimes e-marketing to teenagers sounds fun. But don't kid yourself. Online teenagers are commercial gold dust. These e-entrepreneurs are not playing around. It's a war out there.

Sefton says many parents worry about how their teenagers spend money when they go shopping outdoors, and he feels Y-creds will put parents more in control and eradicate any fears of their children's pockets being picked. The long term plan, if Y-creds take off, is to create an online teenage bank. Already Sefton is talking to potential online banking partners who will doubtless be keen to start a relationship with potential customers of the future. Once, high street banks used to attend freshers' fairs at universities to win new accounts. Now they are taking part in virtual ones being organised by the new crop of student portal sites such as student pages (www.studentpages.com). Here students can visit online stalls of banks such as the Royal Bank of Scotland and click through to other sites to take advantage of specially-tailored discount deals. Students might have a reputation for spending most of their time and grant (what's left of it) boozing and eating Pot Noodles, but online marketeers know these older teenagers will be the architects of future consumer spending patterns. One of the leading new student sites, NowNet (www.nownet.co.uk) has tied up with consumer brands such as Tango to run treasure hunt games across its site. There is also a virtual NowNet bar and once you've clicked on the 3D bouncer at the door you enter an environment which is like a film set. In the best traditions of Tinseltown, product placement is finding a home on the student portals. In NowNet's bar students can click on a book which just happens to be lying around, and then go straight through to Waterstone's site where they can buy books. Many of the new student sites are ISPs as well, and offer free email addresses. The strategy is to hold on to students after they have graduated so they take their email addresses with them into the real world of work. Then the dial-up ISPs still continue to make money out of them. The majority of student sites are positioned as entertainment zones and go all out to get on the side of the students, which underlines the importance of appropriate content. Getting the right image for its teenage service in the spring is preoccupying BBC Online at the moment. "Our teenage service has the potential to have credibility with teenagers," explains Chapman, who has two teenage daughters of his own. "But we have to be very mindful of tone and be very contemporary. It is not going to be po-faced." Carving out its own public service niche against fierce competition from the e-entrepreneurs, BBC Online hopes to offer quality, trusted content for teenagers about issues such as drugs and health. But it won't be easy. What's more, the scramble to colonise the emerging online teenage audience is being waged across all platforms. Interactive TV is in the sights of most of the new teenage shopping sites and student portals. But the key gateway to teenagers is the mobile phone. The Cartoon Network is planning to introduce online cartoons and MP3 music files this year, and will be providing content through mobile phone companies as well.
