Last Christmas was a mobile Christmas." Techniques for profiling and marketing to teenagers are likely to become far more sophisticated this year. Traditionally, when a middle-aged parent bought a present for one of their children it was impossible to build up a profile of that child. But as teenagers part with their email addresses to join new teenage shopping sites, they can expect targeted offers (virtual mail shots) to automatically appear on their computer screens or phones when they log on. Huge amounts of creative effort are going into understanding the online behaviour of teenagers. Games are a key way to generate affection for an online brand. But there are plenty of other ways. The Cartoon Network has a Scooby Doo web cam on its site. They took a life-sized stuffed Scooby Doo toy around London and filmed it to keep their online teenage audience amused. While they are logged on, laughing at Scooby, teenagers are also being encouraged to consume advertisers' messages for cereals and chocolate bars. Sometimes e-marketing to teenagers sounds fun. But don't kid yourself. Online teenagers are commercial gold dust. These e-entrepreneurs are not playing around. It's a war out there.

fields.headline: Dreams crumble again for Schäuble
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: The most remarkable aspect of the press conference yesterday at which Wolfgang Schäuble announced his resignation was the smile playing across his lips. There were moments indeed when it seemed as if he were unable to contain his amusement and might actually burst out laughing.
fields.body:
The most remarkable aspect of the press conference yesterday at which Wolfgang Schäuble announced his resignation was the smile playing across his lips. There were moments indeed when it seemed as if he were unable to contain his amusement and might actually burst out laughing.

But then the Christian Democrats' soon-to-be-former leader has been so grotesquely tricked by fate that he could be forgiven a final, bitter laugh in the face of destiny.

Twice, the 47-year-old has reached what looked to be the pinnacle of a distinguished career. Twice, the savour of victory has turned to poison in his mouth.

The first time was when, as interior minister, he concluded the treaty with East Germany's last communist government that led to reunification. As he was being hailed as the engineer of German unity, he was shot by a mentally disturbed would-be assassin.

The bullet paralyzed him from the waist down, confining him to a wheelchair for the rest of his life. When Helmut Kohl visited him in hospital, the then chancellor left in tears.

But to his - and everyone else's - astonishment, the shooting did not put an end to Mr Schäuble's political career. Within weeks, the wiry interior minister was back at the cabinet table.

In the years that followed, Mr Schäuble, who is married with four children, won widespread admiration for the open, dignified way in which he coped with his disability. In interviews, he described what it was like to be paralyzed, once remarking that it was possible to have a sex life "of sorts".

In 1998, when Mr Kohl left the party leadership after his defeat at the last general election, Wolfgang Schäuble took over as his hand-picked successor. Once more, he was on top.

Even after the scandal erupted over his party's funding, Mr Schäuble looked safe. Last December, he told parliament that his only link to the affair was a brief meeting with the deal-maker whose revelations of secret payments are at its murky centre.

That was a terrible mistake, for it has since emerged that they met at least twice, and that - directly or indirectly - Mr Schäuble himself took a large, undeclared donation from the deal-maker turned whistleblower.

This time around, it is Mr Schäuble himself who has been instrument of his own cruel fate.

webTitle: Netradio owner falls into the hands of Liberty Surf

fields.headline: Netradio owner falls into the hands of Liberty Surf
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Liberty Surf, the French internet service provider jointly controlled by Britain's Kingfisher group and Bernard Arnault, the head of luxury goods group LVMH, has acquired a majority stake in Centpourcent, owner of internet radio broadcaster, Netradio.
fields.body:
Liberty Surf, the French internet service provider jointly controlled by Britain's Kingfisher group and Bernard Arnault, the head of luxury goods group LVMH, has acquired a majority stake in Centpourcent, owner of internet radio broadcaster, Netradio.

The deal will mean that Netradio programmes will become available to Liberty Surf's 610,000 subscribers.

The Netradio acquisition is the latest in a string of internet purchases by Liberty Surf which include the French language search engine Normade and the French language chatroom RESpublica.fr.

Use of the internet in France has lagged behind Britain and Germany, but is increasing rapidly.

Liberty Surf is one of five internet service providers alongside market leader, France Télécom's Wannadoo, Club Internet which yesterday announced it was merging with Deutsche Telekom's T-Online, AOL-France Compuserve and Free.fr.

fields.headline: Patent protection for Aids-link gene
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: A US biotechnology company has won patent protection over a gene which acts as a "docking point" in the body for the Aids virus.
fields.body:
A US biotechnology company has won patent protection over a gene which acts as a "docking point" in the body for the Aids virus.

The patent allows the Maryland firm, Human Genome Sciences, to control research into the gene, CCR5, which could be crucial in the search for a cure to the disease. The company's shares leapt 25% to reach a new 12-month high.

Craig Rosen, the company's vice president for research and development, said: "For several years people have known this gene is the main receptor in the body for HIV entry. It's one of the strong points of attack for new molecules to inhibit the virus."

Mr Rosen said the company would allow free access to the gene to academics. However, other drugs firms will be expected to "collaborate" with Human Genome Sciences.

Drugs companies including Schering-Plough, Japanese firm Takeda and Britain's SmithKline Beecham, have expressed interest in the gene.

webTitle: German opposition leader quits over funding scandal

fields.headline: German opposition leader quits over funding scandal
fields.standfirst:
Turmoil caused by corruption allegations may put democracy under threat, says CDU chief

German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Germany's scandal-ravaged conservatives were last night bracing themselves for a leadership struggle that will decide whether their party lives or dies as an effective force at the heart of European politics.
fields.body:
Germany's scandal-ravaged conservatives were last night bracing themselves for a leadership struggle that will decide whether their party lives or dies as an effective force at the heart of European politics.

The leader of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU), Wolfgang Schäuble, had earlier given up a month-long struggle to hold on to power - his authority devastated by an overnight party rebellion.

At a hastily convened press conference in Berlin, Mr Schäuble suggested the point had been reached at which the future of German democracy itself was in play. "The CDU's crisis must not be allowed to become a crisis for democracy," he said. "This goal overrides all others."

For almost four months, the public has watched in stupefaction as a scandal over the funding of the Christian Democrats has ripped through the right, wrecking the reputations of its former leader, Helmut Kohl, and many of his erstwhile aides. The authority of Mr Schäuble, a Kohl loyalist who repeatedly changed the story of his own role in the affair, was left in ruins.

He said he was making way for a younger leader, untainted by the shady practices of the Kohl era: "I have become convinced that the [Christian Democrat] Union cannot free itself from the clutches of this crisis without a visible new start at the top."

A party which has shown reluctance to cut itself free of the past will need to act boldly to salvage the situation. Recent polls have shown the CDU and its Bavarian sister party, the CSU, holding on to barely a quarter of the national vote.

Yet the timetable is comparatively leisurely. Mr Schäuble will be replaced as head of the parliamentary party next week. But the CDU is not due to elect a new leader until a conference in April.

In the meantime, it faces the prospect of a string of further revelations, as the origin of most of its undeclared financing is still unknown. It also looks set for electoral humiliation in the state of Schleswig-Holstein where voters go to the polls to choose a new government in 10 days' time.

It was the threat of yet more punishment in the May elections in North Rhine-Westphalia which sealed Mr Schäuble's fate. MPs from the area led a surprise revolt against the party leader at a meeting of the parliamentary group on Tuesday, held shortly after the Christian Democrats learned that they would have to forfeit some £14m in state subsidies as a penalty for past misdemeanours. The general secretary of the ruling Social Democrats, Franz Müntefering, claimed: "Panic broke out."

Mr Schäuble's credibility was already in doubt. Last month, he survived as leader despite admitting what he had earlier omitted to tell parliament - that he had accepted an anonymous cash donation from Karlheinz Schreiber, the German-Canadian businessman whose disclosures set off the scandal. He blamed the then party treasurer for failing to declare the gift as required by law.

But last weekend, the former treasurer, Brigitte Baumeister, swore an affidavit contradicting Mr Schäuble's version of events, and her account was backed by Mr Schreiber. Though a majority of senior party officials sided with Mr Schäuble, few were ready for a confrontation between him and Ms Baumeister.

There has also been growing concern over the creation of a vacuum on the right that could be filled by a populist demagogue. The entry into government of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party in Austria underscored the danger.

Mr Schäuble did not answer any questions after reading a statement yesterday. He left open the question of who should succeed him. The CDU was expected to split the posts of party leader, which he took over from Helmut Kohl in 1998, from that of head of the party's parliamentary group, which he has held since 1991.

Mr Kohl remains at the centre of the affair. He has admitted accepting £670,000 in secret funds, but refuses to identify the source of the money, saying he gave his word of honour not to do so.

But the contributions he handled are dwarfed by others known or alleged to have been made during the 25 years he held the party leadership.

The biggest single amount, which the former chancellor hotly denies receiving, was allegedly paid by the French state under President François Mitterrand. It is claimed that the money was skimmed from the price of an East German refinery sold to the oil company Elf Aquitaine.

The current administration has said that documents relating to the sale have gone missing and the Christian Democrats face further embarrassment today when a public hearing by an all-party parliamentary commission of inquiry will start looking into their disappearance.

The candidates for a tarnished crown

Volker Rühe

Post-war Germany's longest serving defence minister. Able and forceful, but handicapped by his long record of loyalty to the now discredited former chancellor, the 47-year-old Mr Ruhe's career has also brought him uncomfortably close to the course of the present scandal. He was general secretary when much of the money was flowing through slush funds

Bernhard Vogel

First choice if the party opts for an elder statesman as stop-gap leader. He is a 67-year-old westerner who runs the eastern region of Thüringen. He lectured at Heidelberg before embarking on a career that brought him the leadership of of the regional government in Rhineland-Palatinate, the speakership of the upper house and the chairmanship of Germany's second public broadcasting network, ZDF

Friedrich Merz

The Christian Democrats' budgetary expert. A 44-year-old Roman Catholic lawyer from Cologne, he has also been tipped to take over the parliamentary party if the leadership is split. When Angela Merkel became the first party official to distance herself from Helmut Kohl last December, Mr Merz was one of the few MPs to back her publicly

The CDU candidate to lead the government of North Rhine-Westphalia, epicentre of the revolt which yesterday toppled Mr Schäuble. The 48-year-old Mr Rüttgers used to hold the education and research portfolio in Mr Kohl's cabinet - a job which earned him the nickname "minister for the future". This past could hold him back now, though he is younger than Mr Rühe and less closely linked to the Kohl era

Angela Merkel

As general secretary, she has been the public face of the CDU since the crisis broke. Though she was a Kohl protege after reunification in 1990, there is no evidence Ms Merkel, a former East German dissident, knew of his shadier dealings. At 45, she is young enough to represent a clean start

webTitle: Windows open on another fortune for Microsoft

fields.headline: Windows open on another fortune for Microsoft
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The stock market is very strange. Later today in San Francisco, Microsoft will launch Windows 2000, said to be the best version of Windows it has produced, and one with a wider potential market. It is also a system with unprecedented industry support and, as the most expensive version of Windows , it should bring in unprecedented profits.
fields.body:
The stock market is very strange. Later today in San Francisco, Microsoft will launch Windows 2000, said to be the best version of Windows it has produced, and one with a wider potential market. It is also a system with unprecedented industry support and, as the most expensive version of Windows , it should bring in unprecedented profits.

Yet, last week Microsoft's shares were marked down $6.06 (£4) to $99.94, and they still have not quite recovered. It is not as though Windows 2000 was an unknown quantity. It is stretching a point to call it new, because the first "preview" version of what was then called Windows NT5 was handed out in 1996.

Tens of thousands of people, including Dell Computer's founder and chief executive Michael Dell, have been using it for at least six months, and it is powering thousands of websites, including Dell.com. Even the final "gold" code, which is in theory being launched today, has been available since December.

The launch is a good excuse for a party and will see packaged copies of Windows 2000 reach the shops, but the rest is just hype. The real questions about Windows 2000 are not whether it is going to be adopted by businesses, especially large corporations, but how widely they are going to deploy it, and when.

Windows 2000's predecessor, Windows NT4, has slowly become the standard operating software for corporate desktop PCs and entry-level servers, used to connect networks of PCs. Microsoft now has broader ambitions. Windows 2000 also works well on notebook PCs such as Dell's Latitude, and it is reliable enough to replace more expensive mid-range servers, which used to be called minicomputers. This is the area dominated by the 30-year-old Unix operating system, where Microsoft is a minnow with no track record and little market share.

So why switch? Instead of messing about with different versions of Windows on notebook and desktop PCs, with incompatible versions of Unix on Sun and SGI workstations, with SCO Unix and Novell Netware and Windows NT4 on servers, and with Digital or IBM or other minis, why not replace them all with one system - Windows 2000?

This may be why the European Union has just launched an inquiry into Windows 2000, but it is the kind of simplification that gives corporate IT managers a warm glow inside. A lot of them want it. They certainly will not be discouraged by their suppliers. Almost all the purveyors of corporate IT - IBM, Compaq, Dell, Data General, EDS, Hewlett-Packard and Unisys - have programmes to help buyers switch over to Windows 2000. And if they had cash registers, they would be ringing.

"The launch of Windows 2000 reflects an industry investing together to make the next generation of PC computing available to business customers," said Deborah Willingham, one of Microsoft's vice presidents in marketing.

What the big PC suppliers actually pay Microsoft for Windows, after various discounts, remains a secret, but speculation suggests that a copy of Windows 98 costs them about $45, (£28) on average, whereas a copy of Windows 2000 could cost $145. The price in American stores is $319, with upgrades from Windows NT4 selling for $149. Server versions range from $999 to $3,999. In Britain, the single user version will cost £260, with the NT4 upgrade at £100 and server prices from £950.

PC sales are running at more than 110m a year, so 100m could be running Windows. If Microsoft can switch only 20m buyers from Windows 98 to Windows 2000 that could earn it up to $2bn a year. Because producing copies of Windows 2000 costs much the same as Windows 98, that would be $2bn a year not just in sales - but in profits. The UK launch at Earls Court, London, this evening will be shown live on the web at www.microsoft.com/uk/technet.

Because producing copies of Windows 2000 costs much the same as Windows 98, that would be $2bn a year not just in sales - but in profits. The UK launch at Earls Court, London, this evening will be shown live on the web at www.microsoft.com/uk/technet.

fields.headline: Psion
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The value of Psion, the little British computer company which is somehow threatening to shoulder Bill Gates out of the wireless world of mobile internet devices, has broken through £4bn.
fields.body:
The value of Psion, the little British computer company which is somehow threatening to shoulder Bill Gates out of the wireless world of mobile internet devices, has broken through £4bn.

After the latest jump in the share price - from £43.87 to £52.03 yesterday after a 20% surge on Tuesday - the stock has risen 25-fold since Psion unveiled its Symbian joint venture with the world's leading mobile phone manufacturers in summer 1998.

It may seem ludicrous now, but when the plan appeared, City analysts ran around for a couple of days working out how many "units" Epoc might be used on and guessing what sort of licensing cut might filter down to Psion's bottom line.

After a bit of discounted cash flow analysis, the bulls proclaimed the company might even be worth £1bn.

The subsequent share price ascent has been achieved in the face of two profit warnings and a nasty wobble in December when one of Psion's Symbian partners, Motorola, entered a similar deal with Microsoft. The way things are going, Psion will breeze into the Footsie when the constituents committee meets early next month.

The latest spurt has come on the back of this week's alliance between Symbian and IBM to create software giving access to web and corporate data from Epoc devices. This deal was followed by news from Santa Clara in Silicon Valley of link-ups with another 11 chip and software developers, ranging from Britain's ARM Holdings to Wipro of India.

At these levels, holders of the stock will find it difficult to resist taking some profits. That would be wise, but should be kept to a minimum.

fields.headline: Forgiven, but not forgotten
fields.standfirst:
They went to Chechnya to help the children of Grozny. Then Camilla Carr and Jon James's mission turned into a nightmare. They were kidnapped and tortured, and Carr was raped. Now back in Britain, she tells Simon Hattenstone how she learned to deal with the humiliation and trauma - and why she has begun to campaign again for the rights of the Chechen people

Crisis in Chechnya: special report

fields.body:
Camilla Carr is sweeping through her photograph album. "Ah, there it is. I'm so glad I've found this picture." A woman is slumped against a man. The woman looks transparent, bloodless, malnourished, her mind long gone. She appears to be wearing a symbolic crown, but it is just a doodle in the background. She could be the craziest of Ophelias.

"That was taken when we were in captivity." The photograph is of Carr and her boyfriend, Jon James, who is now her husband, They were kidnapped in Grozny, Chechnya, on July 4 1997, and released 14 months later. Today, Carr looks strong and healthy, a good 20 years younger, and is back campaigning for the children of Chechnya.

Carr and James left Britain to work in a children's community centre in April 1997. She was an art and tai chi teacher, he was a builder who had worked with disabled kids. They bought a Lada for £500, stuffed it with paints and modelling clay and footballs and set off for the breakaway republic. The aid agency, the Centre for Peacemaking and Community Development, had asked them if they fancied spending six months developing a programme for The Little Star Centre. "It was just one of those occasions when you know it feels right, when your heart leaps."

It was always going to be an adventure as well as a mission. But as soon as they arrived, they realised they had made the right decision. "It was worth it, I tell you. They had nothing, literally nothing." The neediest children had been picked by local psychologists, and Carr and James set to work. "The main aim was to make them relax, start smiling again, to get them playing like children again. A lot of them had forgotten how to."

Carr flicks through the photo album to the pictures of the kids grinning through their face paint, dancing for joy, mastering silly walks.

The couple knew there were dangers in Grozny - it was already regarded as the kidnap capital of the world. They needed a guard and their building had bars on the windows. For two months, the scheme went brilliantly. Then they were abducted in the middle of the night.

Carr is now living with James at her mother's house in Bath. The broadcaster and former hostage John McCarthy once said it takes as long a time as you were kidnapped to return to normality. Carr says she's beginning to feel she's got there. She left Britain unknown, a slightly hippie-dippie free spirit, and returned a tortured cause célèbre . She had a great few weeks sucking in the fresh air, glowing in the natural light, talking to all the friends she had missed, hugging her son. Then she collapsed. "We were much more exhausted than we realised. I just went dizzy, and that was it. I was very weepy, had to lie in bed for three weeks. It was just like letting it all go."

Around that time, three British engineers who had been abducted in Grozny were found beheaded. Carr says that hit her as hard as anything, and she made a conscious decision to distance herself from that particular horror, to stop herself going under.

There was a great deal Carr and James had to let go of. They had been held captive in a cell four metres by three, with only a tiny drain for ventilation.The temperature at times was more than 38C (100F), at other times it was freezing, Carr was raped regularly over a six-week period by one kidnapper. James was threatened with a knife at his throat and beaten.

After a couple of months, James proposed. "We had had a really bad day . . . mental torture, threats. That night they said they were going to take Jon away. They were trying to make us admit we were spies. There would be two of them going on and on, 'Who d'you work for? Who d'you work for?' And saying 'I don't believe you, whatever you say.' " At times, Carr was tempted to say MI6, to give them what they wanted, even though it wasn't true. She giggles at the memory. Could she laugh at the time? "No. It was hell."

Carr has a lovely way with understatement. She says things were so much harder for James, what with the knife to the throat "and the odd punch to the chest". Even when she talks about the rapes, she says how awful it was for James, how brilliant he was about it. While she felt mainly grief, he felt anger. "He was manacled in another room. Impotent. He couldn't do anything. There were a couple of times when Jon could have overcome this guard who was raping me, and we decided not to because it could have made it worse."

Did they actually talk specifically about the rapes? Suddenly she loses her words. "No. Yes. No . . . after the first time . . . I hate using the word rape." She looks towards the photo album on the floor. "I didn't want to think I had been. I didn't want to use that word. But now I've got used to it. If I'd held it inside without talking about it, it would have become like a disease." Carr resisted the first time, and after that decided it would be pointless and painful. "Jon was brilliant," she repeats. "He didn't react, didn't get angry. He prayed a lot." Are they religious? "No, spiritual."

What was her main sense of grief? "The family. We've both got sons, and my son, Ashok, was 11 when I was kidnapped. In the end you have to imagine they're OK. They might have had a car accident, you just don't know. You hold them in your mind all the time."

Carr, 42, is now writing a book about her ordeal, which she thinks may be useful to people, not necessarily hostages. In their tiny space, she and James created room for yoga and tai chi. Like the Beirut hostages, Carr closed her eyes and took day trips to the beach. For a while they shared a cell with Valentin Vlasov, the Russian presidential envoy. Carr said that when he arrived he was tense and angry. He asked how they managed to survive. So they taught him breathing exercises, foot massage, how to smile through your whole body.

And that was enough to keep her from despair? "No. I was really fearful of being physically tortured, of not being able to take the pain. Mental torture I could work with to a certain extent, but physical torture . . . So I used to think how I could cope with that, and I had this belief that I could shut down all my body functions just by using my mind. I'd just shut off so I'd die."

For the first seven months she considered this option as well as a more traditional means of suicide - there was often broken glass strewn around the cell. But for the last seven months they were not tortured and they became mentally stronger, resolute.

They began to talk to their kidnappers and discovered that three of them had lived in Russia and that each had had relatives killed. By night they fought in the mountains and then ran back 20 miles before dawn every day to resume family life. I say that also sounds like a form of torture.

"Yes. It made me extremely sad. It made me understand how war destroys a balanced mind. Once you get an unbalanced mind, desperation sets in. You can't tell how anybody would react whose been a victim of war, whose wife or children have been killed, whose houses have been bombed. In a way it helped me feel sympathy towards the kidnappers. They've been through it. It didn't justify what they did to us, but it makes me wish I could do more to change how things happen in the world. You know . . . there are other ways of solving problems without having to resort to violence and conflict."

The kidnap of the British couple had enormous consequences for Chechnya and became a valuable PR tool for Russia. When asked why they were so intent on reclaiming or destroying the republic, Russian leaders pointed to the kidnappings and said this was a land of criminals. Law and order had to be seen to triumph.

Carr, though, holds no bitterness towards her captors, and says she doesn't think she would have emerged from the experience unscathed if she did. She is dismayed that the west is buying the Russian propaganda - that Chechnya is a nation of psychotics. She thinks it is an excuse for the west simply to watch as the country is reduced to rubble.

A few months after they were freed, Carr and James married. The photo album is again open and we speed past the horror. It's a lovely day, the pictures are full of laughter as her son gives her away. As well as fulfilling their pledge, it was an important part of the rehabilitation process.

I mention how John McCarthy's kidnap seemed to drive a wedge between him and his fiancée, Jill Morrell. "Yes, but you see Jon and I went through it together. It does make a difference. Some couples would have definitely come apart, but it didn't work like that for us."

There have been suggestions that Carr is an Angel of Grozny figure , addicted to the thrill of war, and reckless with it. People have asked how she could leave an 11-year-old son behind to fulfil an idealistic whim. She says that although she and Ashok are close, they had not lived together for six years, and that he had a wonderful father to look after him. Did she feel guilt at being away from him? "No. It's unhealthy to feel guilty about anything."

Would she ever return to Grozny? She is shocked by the question. "No. It would be too dangerous. I couldn't do it. No, it just wouldn't be wise, and it would be awful for our families."

While James has returned to building, Carr is fighting for Chechnya, from home. They both decided that it would make sense for Carr to write the book - James is dyslexic. Hopefully, with a decent publishing deal, the couple will be able to move into their own house.

For now, though, she's content to sit at her mother's, campaigning. Actually, content is the wrong word. Carr is a strange mix of the positive thinker and the disillusioned humanist. She talks about how devastating she has found Russia's latest onslaught on the Chechens. In December, she organised a peace concert that raised £2,000, and now she wants to build on that. She says she doesn't know what has happened to her children, whether they are still alive. Last year, the Little Star Centre was bombed flat. The Centre for Peacemaking and Community Development was due to move into a more suitable building, but she thinks that is probably a ruin too. Like the few other aid agencies which were operating in Chechnya, it has had to move to the relative safe haven of neighbouring Ingushetia.

Carr remembers how traumatised the children had been - introverted, hyperactive, their concentration smashed, and says she can only imagine that things have got worse. Many have TB, dysentery, chest infections, anaemia, malnutrition. Some have been blinded by fragments from cluster bombs, some have taken to playing ever more violent games, pounding each other with rocks. Carr asks, bewildered, why or how the Russians can refuse to let boys over 10 and men under 60 to leave the country, how they can put them into filtration camps that are really concentration camps. "I think they need a scapegoat because Russia is in such a bad state economically . . . It will all come out as soon as people are allowed in." Her voice breaks down into a whisper. "It will be terrible."

Donations to the Chechnya Appeal, which is run in conjunction with the Charities Aid Foundation, can be posted to PO Box 209, Kings Hall, West Malling, Kent NE19 4DB. For credit card donations call 01732 520111

webTitle: Tobacco chief dismisses MPs as 'kangaroo court'

fields.headline: Tobacco chief dismisses MPs as 'kangaroo court'
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Former chancellor Kenneth Clarke and the head of British American Tobacco were accused last night of attempting to sabotage a parliamentary inquiry into evidence that the company profited from cigarette smuggling.
fields.body:
Former chancellor Kenneth Clarke and the head of British American Tobacco were accused last night of attempting to sabotage a parliamentary inquiry into evidence that the company profited from cigarette smuggling.

The pair angrily clashed with MPs on the health select committee as the London-based tobacco giant's own documents were quoted back at them in the face of denials.

Martin Broughton, BAT's non-smoking chairman, ripped up a copy of an internal memo handed to him that referred to smuggling cigarettes into Canada. He said angrily: "The words 'select committee' mean kangaroo court. I think this is absolutely absurd.

"You have given a journalist, who is basically looking to promote his own name and an organisation committed to destroying the industry, a platform for their views."

David Hinchliffe, the all-party committee's Labour chairman, said: "I object strongly to that remark."

Mr Clarke, BAT's deputy chairman, repeatedly claimed he had not read memos obtained from the firm's Guildford files and published in the Guardian. It was alleged he had done this to avoid replying to specific questions.

Labour MP Stephen Hesford told him: "It's a positive charade that...by trying to obfuscate today by saying you don't know about the documents, you don't know about the sources...I will have no nonsense about your lack of preparation. That's rubbish."

Mr Clarke accused the Wirral West MP of "descending to insults" and added: "The suggestion that BAT organises smuggling does not stand up. This is the use of highly selective quotations."

Mr Clarke was summoned to appear before the special session of the committee's investigation into the health effects of smoking. Mr Broughton was called a third time, after the Guardian disclosed how BAT exploited smuggling.

A gladiatorial atmosphere was created as the duo unusually appeared alongside two of their major critics - Clive Bates, director of the anti-smoking group ASH and investigative journalist Duncan Campbell, whose study of 11,000 company documents was the basis of this month's disclosures in the Guardian.

The memo torn up by Mr Broughton had been passed to him by Mr Campbell, who said it showed that Ulrich Herter, the company's managing director, was involved in smuggling in Canada.

Mr Campbell said BAT managed smuggling around the world to beat customs controls and its involvement with black marketeers in Latin America, and particularly Colombia, gave cover to drug smugglers to "launder" money.

Mr Bates called for a department of trade and industry inquiry into BAT's operations as he accused the company of "complicity" over smuggling.

"They manage and co-ordinate smuggling," said Mr Bates.

Mr Clarke hit back: "He has produced no evidence that BAT is the originator, organiser or participant in smuggling."

fields.headline: Amen to our sponsors
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Church of England is so strapped for cash, the Guardian reported on Tuesday, that it may have to seek corporate sponsorship for students training to enter the priesthood. My friend Clive, who's in marketing, says this sort of development makes him despair of the poor old C of E. Why on earth, he demands, has it taken them till the opening years of the 21st century to catch up with techniques which have been commonplace everywhere else for decades?
fields.body:
The Church of England is so strapped for cash, the Guardian reported on Tuesday, that it may have to seek corporate sponsorship for students training to enter the priesthood. My friend Clive, who's in marketing, says this sort of development makes him despair of the poor old C of E. Why on earth, he demands, has it taken them till the opening years of the 21st century to catch up with techniques which have been commonplace everywhere else for decades?

I must say I could see what he meant when we turned up the other day for evensong at Salisbury Cathedral. It is always instructive to see a familiar world through the eyes of a seasoned pro, and I expected we might be in for some powerful innovative thinking as I heard Clive chuntering away to himself through the Nunc Dimittis . Where you and I might see only a church, people like Clive see a howling great commercial opportunity going to waste. The raiment, for instance. The bishop wasn't on duty that Sunday but we were both deeply impressed by all the various uniforms worn by the other functionaries, especially their vibrant colours. I had never previously realised that each cathedral has its own colour scheme. But as Clive pointed out with characteristic asperity, the church has failed to cash in on the implications. "Every time I turn on the TV" he grumbled "I hear someone saying football is the new religion. So why can't religion become the new football?"

Sure enough, the cathedral shop, though choc-a-bloc with commemorative tea towels and mugs, had not a single replica surplice on offer. You'd have thought, as I said to Clive, that in this day and age you'd be able to buy a full set of home kits, through from number one, the bishop, to 35, the verger, with a change strip for any occasion when Salisbury clergy visit another cathedral which sports the same colours. And, as Clive observed with his usual percipience, what an opportunity they are missing for sponsorship! "Just think Man United and Vodafone!" he exploded. "Talk about low-hanging fruit! Imagine the impact of having "Interflora" or "Dunkin' Donuts" displayed on the chests of the dean and chapter! Could bring in millions."

I put it to Clive that some worshippers might find this kind of approach a little bit mercenary, but he told me this was off message. Take the parable of the Good Samaritan, he said: as Margaret Thatcher had once pointed out, he wouldn't have had the wherewithal to assist the needy if he hadn't made his mint first. And then there was the parable of the talents. Hadn't I noticed it was those who exploited their assets to the fullest commercial advantage who came out of the story best? Yet the C of E, Clive complained, had incomparable assets whose potential they never realised. Take cathedrals. If George Carey had any sense, he would get the cathedrals sponsored. Maybe "Carling Canterbury Cathedral" might be considered a trifle over the top, but something a bit more decorous - "Canterbury Cathedral, sponsored by Axa" for instance - would be a win-win situation. Also, when the government wanted a dome, why hadn't George had the nous to offer St Paul's on lease for a year, thus diverting a chunk of the £758m wasted at Greenwich into C of E funds?

"What's more, they still haven't even begun to think global" he raged as we walked round the cloister. "Just look at the way the clubs have made the premiership so much more glamourous by buying in foreign stars. It's time we learned to think of our bishops as the premiership of the church. Just imagine how the takings would rise if Salisbury appointed someone like David Ginola, with his mazy ball skills and smouldering good looks! That would soon fill the pews, I can tell you. The RCs, by the way, are no better. Just look at this fellow they've picked to succeed Basil Hume at Westminster. Sixty-seven-years-old - and he's double-barrelled. I ask you: is that really the sort of image a kid can wear on a t-shirt?"

I must say my friend Clive, who, as I think I have said, is in marketing, helps you see the world in a much more practical way. Driving back across Salisbury Plain I noticed that most of the fields were used in ways which totally failed to exploit their potential. Here and there you could spot the odd sheep or pig or a crop of some kind or other, but the real money-spinning opportunities were going to waste. Instead of whingeing to Tony Blair and clamouring for additional subsidy, why don't farmers exploit the commercial value of so many roadside sites? In my youth you used while riding in railway trains to see effigies in the fields representing two men carrying boards with legends like "Charrington's Coal" and "Hall's Paints". But never today. What on earth is wrong with this country?

webTitle: The Tories' hero-in-waiting lets the farce play itself out

fields.headline: The Tories' hero-in-waiting lets the farce play itself out
fields.standfirst:
Hague keeps Portillo on a short leash but it isn't, ultimately, short enough

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague is doing everything he can to show that he's in charge. He's in charge of the Conservative party and in charge of Michael Portillo. They've begun the election campaign on the back of a truck, talking about the only issue on which they have anything to say. The leader is leading, and the sycophantic grins unfold behind him. He's telling Portillo whom he may allow to work for him, whom they're allowed to talk to, and what they're not allowed to say. By God, he's in charge, he really really is.
fields.body:
William Hague is doing everything he can to show that he's in charge. He's in charge of the Conservative party and in charge of Michael Portillo. They've begun the election campaign on the back of a truck, talking about the only issue on which they have anything to say. The leader is leading, and the sycophantic grins unfold behind him. He's telling Portillo whom he may allow to work for him, whom they're allowed to talk to, and what they're not allowed to say. By God, he's in charge, he really really is.

Michael Portillo does everything he can to play the same game. This is William's party, he insists. Of all the grins, his is the closest replica of the leader's own: same angle, same fakery, same unease, same eyebrows quizzically raised. These are political brothers, we learn. Both lovers of their party, both team players, and now, yoked, carrying more formidable weight than before the wise young leader had the courage to position the new shadow chancellor closest to his side.

The trouble with this, though, is that the leader cannot, in the end, cut it. His greatest quality is resilience, a negative attribute. Even No 10 can't forbear to marvel, genuinely. Hague has the indestructible public confidence of the truly insensitive performer. Because he has read all the texts, he knows how leaders should behave, and duly plays the rule-book which says he must always come up smiling. His capacity for embarrassment is cauterised. Which is just as well, since there is much for Tories to be embarrassed about, starting with their inability to exploit a single one of the government's recent failures.

But in a leader resilience is not enough. At his best, Hague's cheeky-chappy wit in the Commons can seem to be issuing from the ghost of Harold Wilson. Unfortunately, Tony Blair is not Alec Douglas-Home, the dying fall-guy of an ancien regime. However each man might struggle to conceal it, Hague is less credible than Portillo. He just is. It's the difference between a man who was Welsh secretary and one who was employment secretary, defence secretary and chief secretary. But there are other angles too. Where Hague is simple, Portillo is mysterious: Hague exposed, Portillo menacing: Hague slight, Portillo heavy: Hague quietly desperate, Portillo apparently serene.

Portillo acquires this from being the hero-in-waiting. He has every reason to be loyal, because the last thing he wants is for Hague to slip, this side of an election. But it is axiomatic that he awaits the crown. Everything Hague does will be benchmarked by what Portillo might have done better. So we see the beginning of Portillo's trouble, and the possibility that, far from adding weight, the partnership may waste itself away.

For Portillo brings turbulence. He can't help it. Merely by being there, he keeps the Hague issue alive. He is the bigger man, yet he could be double trouble. An army of infatuated party bloods gathers round him, while out in the country the ridicule for Hague is matched, perhaps exceeded, by the hatred for Portillo. He's the living face, the only one anyone remembers that's still extant, of the Major years. Two television series, offered free, gratis and for nothing for self-promotion, seem not to have eradicated the connection. Portillo is still unloved by the nation whose sovereignty he and Hague make it their prime business to defend - as it increasingly sounds, forever - against the European enemy.

Their first outing on the truck, to make this case, turned into a farce. The truck was a phony. Hague didn't arrive in it, leave in it, or speak from it. But more important, the issue turned out to be a non-event. Despite the massive publicity surrounding the anti-euro case, and the seething passions said to be at large in the uncontrollably Eurosceptic soul of the British people, it was hard to find a single free citizen of St Albans turning up to listen to Hague, among the small multitudes of media people and press-ganged local Tories. Here was the great Tory election issue - the conspiratorial fate from which this party alone will save the pound and the people - having its first formal outing on the campaign trail, and an entire town had better things to do.

This wasn't just Hague's farce, however. It was a Hague-Portillo event. The hero darkly lurking is drawn to the front of the stage. That is probably the point of Hague's manoeuvre to promote him. He handed a poisoned chalice to the man already designated as his future nemesis. By giving him complete command over Tory economic policy, he may have made a surrender which no other leader in the history of parties anywhere has ever done. But it brings his rival into the frame of culpability when Gordon Brown's economic record has proved too strong to induce enough voters to desert the Labour ticket. While Portillo's presence encourages daily turmoil in the output of spinners and speculators, at the same time it is guaranteed to diminish his value after the defeat.

This is not, in short, a partnership made in heaven. There's no such thing as reliable political brotherhood. Ultimately, all politicians, the higher they get, are rivals and therefore loners. The complex Blair-Brown entanglements are testimony to that. But when parties are running strong, these human frailties do not matter much. When parties struggle under neurosis and impending failure, they cannot possibly afford the kind of combat - inexplicit and unwanted, but inescapable and lethal - that's in the baggage accompanying Portillo's return to the top.

Nor is that the worst of it, for the Tories. Their agenda, like their truck, shows no sign of breaking out of the bunker occupied by voters already signed up for the semi-hard right. That seems to be the audience they're still addressing, even though there is barely a year to go before the election campaign could well be entering its final stage. Something more than saving the pound is necessary to reach that segment of voters. Having affirmed the pledge to lower taxes over the life of one parliament whatever the economic situation, a decision reached after some dithering, the Portillo-Hague leadership has cut off a major route towards them.

One person no doubt watching this with increased dismay is Kenneth Clarke. He may no longer speak for many Tories. But he thinks like at least as many voters as William Hague himself. Hague-Portillo has written off Clarke-Heseltine as a Conservative irrelevance. Even if that's an accurate judgment in party terms, these people have not ceased to exist. The Tory left has not died at Hague's command. It has merely faded from power. It still has a voice which, if it spoke, could do great electoral damage to the party that gave itself to an inadequate man. Don't bet on that voice not being heard, if Hague and Portillo become the alpha and omega of political philosophy.

webTitle: Only the brave broach Blair's rhetoric-reality gap

fields.headline: Only the brave broach Blair's rhetoric-reality gap
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The lovely Ffion Hague was in the strangers' gallery yesterday (and, no, that isn't sexism. I've met her, and she's great).
fields.body:
The lovely Ffion Hague was in the strangers' gallery yesterday (and, no, that isn't sexism. I've met her, and she's great).

We saw her looking excitedly down at the scene as prime minister's questions began. Why, she might have asked, is that man in knee breeches carrying a sword? Why is stale alcohol wafting over from the press gallery? And who is that strange bald man sitting near Michael Portillo?

Just my little joke - I'm sure she recognises her own husband, even from above. But she did seem to enjoy herself, even laughing merrily at a Charles Kennedy gag. He mentioned the Tory leader's meet-the-people lorry tour of England. "If ever there was a case of dodgy goods falling on to the back of a truck, this is it!"

Next we saw a promising career implode. Rachel Squire, the Labour MP for Dunfermline West, asked her leader about sub-post offices. Thousands of these will close when pensions and benefits are paid by electronic transfer. Tony Blair seems under the impression that because the new system isn't obligatory, the bureaux will magically remain open to service a handful of old folk who don't have bank accounts, or cars to get to cash machines.

Ms Squire pointed out that the post offices are vital source of help for elderly people. "Given the government's commitment to strong communities, don't you agree that post offices need the support of us all?"

If there's one thing Mr Blair doesn't like, it's Tories pointing out the gap between his rhetoric and the reality. What he loathes, though, is Labour MPs doing the same thing. I fear that Ms Squire's brave question will have consigned her to the oubliette of Labour history. She'll know for sure when the chaps in Armani suits arrive in Dunfermline saying they'd heard there was a vacant seat and pretending to like deep-fried Mars bars, Scotland's national dish.

Mr Blair was more effective against Eric Forth, a ferocious Tory who recently won the Channel 4 award for best opposition politician. This may have been a mistake, since Mr Forth tried to ask a trick question. Which of "his friend" Romano Prodi's recent statements as EU commission president did Mr Blair agree with?

This is like digging a bear pit and then sticking a sign on the top saying "Bears beware: bear pit." What did Mr Forth expect? That the prime minister would collapse into a wimpering heap, crying: "I cannot answer you, except to admit that I was wrong, wrong, wrong, oh God, so very wrong!" Instead Mr Blair said crisply: "We have set out our own position." Memo to Channel 4: get that award back, pronto.

Mr Hague then tried much the same device. He asks Mr Blair to read out embarrassing figures, in this case about the fall in the numbers of policemen. The prime minister waffles instead.

So Mr Hague tells him what the figures are (or rather, reads some contorted statistics taken out of context). Then he throws in a kicker, about, in this case, NHS waiting lists. The process is repeated, until we reach asylum seekers.

Mr Blair responds by boring. Golly, he can bore. Statistics are rolled out in an interminable stream. Families of mayfly go through as many generations as the Salisburys while Mr Blair answers a Hague question.

Labour MPs remained almost silent after this harangue, and Tories mockingly waved them on. But they weren't being rude to their leader, merely asleep.

Mr Hague responded: "With your head for figures, it's no wonder it's taking you five days to count those mayoral votes - on your own."

It may say something about modern politics that he could imply, even jokingly, that a British election might be more corrupt than this week's referendum in Zimbabwe.

webTitle: I hate him, but send him home

fields.headline: I hate him, but send him home
fields.standfirst:
Doctors say that the former Chilean dictator is too ill to face torture charges. If they are right about his state of health, says Linda Grant, a trial would be futile and immoral. How does she know? She watched her mother die of a similar debilitating condition

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The doctors who last month examined General Pinochet on behalf of the home office did not give a name to his condition. They described damage to the frontal lobes of the brain caused by a series of tiny strokes.
fields.body:
The doctors who last month examined General Pinochet on behalf of the home office did not give a name to his condition. They described damage to the frontal lobes of the brain caused by a series of tiny strokes. They described the effects of these strokes as depression and loss of short-term memory. They said that the strokes were cardiovascular in origin and may be linked to his diabetes. The doctors concluded that Pinochet could not stand trial because of a loss of memory of recent and distant events and a limited ability to understand complex sentences and questions as a result of that memory loss. Pinochet has, the doctors say, difficulty in processing verbal information.

This list of symptoms is remarkably similar to those experienced by my mother until her death in October. The condition she suffered from had a name; it was called Multi-Infarct Dementia (MID), also known as Vascular Dementia, the effects of which are similar to Alzheimer's disease though different in that speech persists, as does a level of self-awareness that one has the condition.

Like Pinochet, my mother also had diabetes, she also experienced tiny, silent strokes in the brain. She, too, lost almost all of her short-term memory. It was almost impossible to have the most rudimentary conversation with her because memory was reduced to only a few seconds long. Even when she was able to make a reply, she could not remember the beginning of the sentence she had started by the time she got to the end.

Like many people in the baby-boom generation, the knowledge of Pinochet's regime in Chile - his overthrow of the democratically elected president, Salvador Allende, the tortures, the murders in the stadium - have been with me for most of my adult life. I had friends who had gone to Chile to work for the new socialist government and only managed to get out by the skin of their teeth at the time of the coup. One of them was a friend of Charles Horman, the American murdered by the regime, about whom Costa-Gavras made the film Missing.

When it was announced that Pinochet was wanted for trial in Spain I was one of those who felt a deep feeling of satisfaction. It really did seem that if you waited long enough, justice could be done. Unlike those who speak of persecuting old men, I do not believe in being compassionate to elderly war criminals who showed no compassion to their elderly victims. There should be no statute of limitations on justice for torturers because justice is the way we bring the world back into moral balance. But I shall not be one of those who continues to demand Pinochet's extradition to Spain. We now have to accept the fact that we will not have our day in court. Brain scans demonstrate that Pinochet (unlike Ernest Saunders who faked Alzheimer's disease to get out of prison) is not deliberately deceiving the doctors. He is suffering from a ghastly disease for which there is no treatment, let alone a cure.

Multiple strokes of this kind do not operate by a timetable. MID is described as having a step-like progress instead of inflicting a continuous decline as in Alzheimer's disease. The victim may continue at a certain stage for weeks or months before the next phase sets in, and the entire process can drag on for a decade. Whatever name is given to Pinochet's condition, we know that as more and more areas of the frontal lobes are destroyed by the strokes, the brain is no longer able to recognise what was once familiar. The loyal family, friends and supporters who have demanded that he be returned home to Santiago, may come in time to find that he no longer knows who are they are.

Once he is back home, familiar surroundings may be unrecognisable. The world becomes a terrifying, unfamiliar place. There is virtually no certainty left, however expensive and loving the care.

There are two reasons why Pinochet should not be forced to stand trial. The first is that if the doctors reports are correct, he is incapable of doing so. Cross-examination would be impossible. You cannot ask questions of a witness who not only can't remember the events to which you are referring, but also cannot retain the memory of the question for long enough to answer it. There are profound questions about the extent to which personality can be said to persist when memory is lost. The man standing in the dock both would and would not be the Pinochet who inflicted so much terror on the citizens of Chile.

The second reason that the trial cannot go ahead is that for it to do so would be immoral. It would be a grotesque show trial, a spectacle of vengeance and humiliation which better belongs in the litany of sadistic practices carried out in the Coliseum in ancient Rome. There is a difference between justice and revenge.

Has Pinochet got off scot free? When my mother died, over a five-week period, it was like the lights in a house being turned off, one by one. First incontinence, then the inability to walk, then language became a jumble of mismatched syllables, then speech went altogether. At the end there was only heartbeat and breathing. It was a horrible death.

Nature has no morality, but in this case Pinochet's own body has inflicted on him a form of punishment which is itself a type of torture. It is not the kind of justice we would prefer to see, in which Pinochet would be forced to confront his crimes, in which the Chilean people who supported him would have to face the truth about their adored leader. Nor is it a justice that gives much comfort to the victims, who 30 years later would at least see the moral order re- established. But as there was suffering in the stadium, so there will be suffering, too, in a private house somewhere in Chile. I doubt if the general will die with a smile on his lips.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Mistake of the day
fields.body:
Mistake of the day

Shadow education spokeswoman Theresa May, who was courted by an "adult entertainment" TV channel. The approach by Granada Men & Motors cable channel was an innocent mistake.The MP shares the same name as sultry Teresa May, a glamorous brunette who appears most often with little clothing about her. The parliamentary May said: "I just hope that she is not embarrassed to share a name with a Tory MP."

Late in the day

Keith Vaz, minister for Europe, knows his royal duties. So engrossed was he in conversation with an entourage connected with the Queen of Denmark that he delayed the start of a parliamentary debate on the European Union. Proceedings were suspended to await his arrival.

Today

Commons: Armed forces (discipline) bill, second reading. Lords: Learning and skills bill, committee.

fields.headline: Cop show
fields.trailText: Gary Younge (The badness of words, February 14) implies that my policy of "zero tolerance of political correctness in policing" is intended to mean all things to all people and hence, nothing to anyone. Not so.
fields.body:
Gary Younge (The badness of words, February 14) implies that my policy of "zero tolerance of political correctness in policing" is intended to mean all things to all people and hence, nothing to anyone. Not so.

Respect is at the heart of the debate. Londoners' interests are compromised if police officers are unwilling to stop someone because of race, age, gender or sexuality. However, I will not tolerate any police officer who treats any person stopped by them with anything less than the courtesy and respect every citizen is entitled to.

Respect must also be a two-way process. It is only by treating all Londoners fairly that the Metropolitan police can expect respect to be returned.
Steve Norris
Conservative Candidate for mayor of London

webTitle: A cry from the dead and damaged

fields.headline: A cry from the dead and damaged
fields.trailText: Christian Wolmar's article (The untold story behind child abuse, February 16) raises a serious but significantly ignored problem. Is a homosexual who sexually abuses children a homosexual or a paedophile?
fields.body:
Christian Wolmar's article (The untold story behind child abuse, February 16) raises a serious but significantly ignored problem. Is a homosexual who sexually abuses children a homosexual or a paedophile?

Some homosexual men rape children. An unpalatable fact but a fact none the less. As my peers who grew up with me in the children's homes of the 70s know, the Waterhouse inquiry doesn't even begin to scratch the surface. Suicide, life-crushing depression, alcohol and drug abuse, prostitution, Aids, mental illness . . . the list is endless. This is our legacy.

There is no crime greater than using children for sexual gratification. This society should hang its head in shame. And as for those who whinge about equality and justice because they are not allowed to fuck 16-year-old children, where is the equality for me and my dead and damaged friends? We were just little boys.
Danny Carrick
Oxford
danny@carrick-varty.freeserve.co.uk


While Christian Wolmar is right to identify men as committing the majority of child sexual abuse, I am less happy with the link he makes between gay-friendly employment policies and cases of abuse in children's homes. The systematic abuse of children in care by male authority figures is about power and humiliation, and bears little similarity to adult models of consensual relationships (both gay and straight). While it would be naive to assume that all gay men are less of a risk to children than straight men, research suggests that abusers (regardless of orientation) have more in common with each other than with their non-abusing gay or straight counterparts.

Mr Wolmar is likely to provoke the "wrath of the gay lobby" by making clumsy links between male abusers and the majority of gay men who are fed up with stereotypical associations between child sexual abuse and homosexuality. The two are not the same.
Martin Holt
Birmingham


Given what we know about the way children in care have been and continue to be treated, is it not time we gave up the use of the euphemism "care" and substituted it with a word which more accurately represents the experience of these children?
Dr Jennifer Jenkins
King's College, London
jennifer.jenkins@kcl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Fair fees for students
fields.trailText: Your report (Blunkett backtracks over top-up tuition fees, February 16) appeared to suggest that the government's position has changed. That is not the case. The government legislated earlier in this parliament to prevent top-up fees.
fields.body:
Your report (Blunkett backtracks over top-up tuition fees, February 16) appeared to suggest that the government's position has changed. That is not the case. The government legislated earlier in this parliament to prevent top-up fees.

I did say that I recognised that a debate is going on in the wider world about the funding of universities in the future, and I pointed out that it should be conducted with intellectual rigour and openness. I did not announce that there will be another Dearing review in the next parliament, but merely stated that the original report had recommended a further review.

Our new student support system is fair and working well. Student numbers are up and more money is going into universities and colleges - we have already announced an 11% boost in real term funding for higher education in this parliament. The income stream from fees and loans will be £710m in England and Wales next year alone, and will secure more resources in the future that otherwise would not be available.
David Blunkett
Education and employment secretary

fields.headline: Don't damn diamorphine
fields.trailText: I read your report (Police in second drug deaths case check records, February 15) with dismay. For the second time in days you assert that the two patients named died "after receiving 15 and 20mg of diamorphine, compared with the usual dose of between 5 and 10mg". This is simply wrong.
fields.body:
I read your report (Police in second drug deaths case check records, February 15) with dismay. For the second time in days you assert that the two patients named died "after receiving 15 and 20mg of diamorphine, compared with the usual dose of between 5 and 10mg". This is simply wrong.

Strong opioids like morphine are unique in medicine in that they have no ceiling dose. Doses of thousands of milligrams a day are needed on occasion. The right dose is that which controls pain without causing serious adverse effects.

Unfortunately part of Dr Shipman's legacy is that some patients are now frightened of using diamorphine and other opioids and consequently suffer unnecessary and often intolerable pain.
Dr Victor Pace
Consultant, St Christopher's Hospice, London
zf54@dial.pipex.com

fields.headline: Iran's day of reckoning
fields.standfirst:
Elections may boost the cause of reform
More about Iran
fields.trailText: President Mohammad Khatami's drive for reform will be put to the vote tomorrow when Iranians choose a new parliament. His allies, led by his brother, Reza, have high hopes of overturning the conservative majority in the 290-seat Majlis despite the disqualification of many reformist candidates by the Council of Guardians, the religious establishment's watchdog. Mr Khatami, who won a landslide victory in 1997, remains highly popular. But opposed by hardliners antipathetic to his efforts to extend the rule of law, expand civil society, and end his country's post-1979 isolation, he has struggled to overcome Iran's divisions.
fields.body:
President Mohammad Khatami's drive for reform will be put to the vote tomorrow when Iranians choose a new parliament. His allies, led by his brother, Reza, have high hopes of overturning the conservative majority in the 290-seat Majlis despite the disqualification of many reformist candidates by the Council of Guardians, the religious establishment's watchdog. Mr Khatami, who won a landslide victory in 1997, remains highly popular. But opposed by hardliners antipathetic to his efforts to extend the rule of law, expand civil society, and end his country's post-1979 isolation, he has struggled to overcome Iran's divisions.

The powerful mullahs, upholding the absolutist legacy of the late Ayatollah Khomeini, fight any perceived deviation from his strict Islamic path. They impose their dogmas on newspapers, students and dissenters of all kinds, occasionally with great violence. In November, they succeeded in jailing Abdullah Nouri, a leading reformer, on the most specious charges. Last week, conservative MPs were busy discounting a poll defeat, arguing that even if it happened, it would change little. But this is plainly disingenuous. A convincing success would undoubtedly greatly strengthen Mr Khatami's hand. And it would be greeted with jubilation by Iran's younger generations - two-thirds of the population is under 30 - and especially by women, who feel most keenly the joyless, stultifying embrace of clerical correctness.

But those anticipating a second, secular Iranian revolution will be disappointed. Only gradual change is feasible while the unbiddable Ayatollah Ali Khamenei holds sway as supreme leader. Reza Khatami's Islamic Iran Participation Front acknowledges this unavoidable balancing act, advocating judicial reform and curtailment of censorship while stressing economic priorities. Iran has debts of $20bn, high unemployment and inflation at 20%. Its five-year plan postulates foreign investment worth $6.8bn. Yet there is little prospect of achieving that without an overhaul of state monopolies, such as banking, and of other internal barriers to enterprise. The president's opening to the west is also key to effecting the economic modernisation which must be the new parliament's aim. Enhanced prosperity for all is the best guarantee of the societal risorgimento for which so many yearn - and the most effective riposte to the forces of clerical reaction.
