fields.headline: Peter's new friends' old enemies
fields.trailText: Is it not ironic that by insisting on IRA decommissioning to guarantee peace (Peace crisis deepens after IRA pulls out, February 16), the British government and Ulster Unionists are endangering the peace that now exists? The power-sharing assembly was living proof that the peace process was in progress. Declaring its suspension, Peter Mandelson stated that "we have got to clear up this issue of decommissioning once and for all". Does he really believe that what had not been achieved while the assembly was operating can now be brought about in its absence?
fields.body:
Is it not ironic that by insisting on IRA decommissioning to guarantee peace (Peace crisis deepens after IRA pulls out, February 16), the British government and Ulster Unionists are endangering the peace that now exists? The power-sharing assembly was living proof that the peace process was in progress. Declaring its suspension, Peter Mandelson stated that "we have got to clear up this issue of decommissioning once and for all". Does he really believe that what had not been achieved while the assembly was operating can now be brought about in its absence?

If the assembly had been set up and running since shortly after the spring 98 referendum and the election, IRA decommissioning may well have started by now, of its own accord, to meet the deadline of May 2000.

Listening to Mr Mandelson's recent rhetoric ("If the war is over, why do arms still need to be retained?" and so on), which sounds increasingly unionist, one fears that he has little appreciation of the passion and honour involved in this issue on the republican side. It cannot be resolved by the head alone, nor with deadlines and ultimatums. Let us not wreck what has been achieved by insisting on 100%. Peace already exists, and that is easily 95% of what most people want.
Akemi Horie-Webber
St Genis-Pouilly, France
The IRA's statement in response to the suspension of the new institutions in Northern Ireland is just so much self-serving rhetoric. What the IRA and Sinn Fein seem unable or unwilling to accept are the logical implications of their professed commitment to peace. If this is sincere, it implies decommissioning. Why are the guns only "silent" and not removed unless the IRA is reserving the right to resort to violence? The only obvious alternative explanations are misplaced nationalist chauvinism or fear of disunity. We are therefore entitled to be suspicious.
Grenville Wall
Vantaa, Finland
gren.wall@kolumbus.fi


David Trimble asserts yet again that the unionists "jumped first" in entering the Northern Ireland assembly with Sinn Fein. If by "jumping first" David Trimble means that he entered the assembly on the basis of a deadline for IRA decommissioning set by his own party outside the terms of the Good Friday agreement, then perhaps he is correct.

However, it is important to recall how much has been sacrificed by republicans in the current peace process. Guns are silent, articles 2 and 3 of the Irish constitution have disappeared and Sinn Fein have accepted the principle of consent, to the extent that they have sat in a devolved assembly in Stormont, the notorious setting for past abuses of unionist power.

This shift is forgotten as unionists demand IRA surrender in the form of decommissioning. Let us not forget that many guns lie silent in Northern Ireland at this time, not least those belonging to loyalist paramilitaries, the RUC, the British Army and those issued to a significant portion of the unionist community for "personal protection".

Decommissioning is a responsibility shared by all parties to the conflict in Northern Ireland - not just the IRA. That Peter Mandelson has apparently rejected this view and chosen to support David Trimble's implacably (if understandably) biased view is, in the current context, a deeply irresponsible act.
Fergal Quinn
Hampton, Middx
fergal_quinn@ireland.com


Henry McElroy, a farmer in South Armagh, repeats the republican mantra that the guns have been out of commission for five years (We're fed up with waiting, February 11).

This may be so in total but in between the two ceasefires, the IRA killed two British soldiers, two RUC constables and seriously injured two RUC constables, as well as bombing Canary Wharf (two deaths) and Manchester (hundreds injured). Loyalist paramilitaries killed innocent Catholics during those years.

It is partly because hopes were dashed by the collapse of the original ceasefire and the resumption of bombing and shooting that people want decommissioning to take place. It has been said often enough during this peace process that it is not a question of one side winning and one losing. The IRA has not been defeated, it is a stalemate.

Decommissioning was part of the Good Friday agreement, and despite the vague language used in that section of the agreement, people expected it to happen. Surely after 30 years it is time that the paramilitaries on both sides listened to the people and respected their views.

Gerry Adams has tried to move republicans forward but this mantra about the guns being silent for five years is very hurtful to those whose loved ones have been killed by paramilitaries in that time.

Guns and bombs ensuring a democratic process? Ask someone who has been kneecapped or beaten by baseball bats for their views on that. The republicans have a valid political aim. It is time they tried to achieve it politically and left the guns and bombs behind.
Rita Restorick
Nottingham
fields.bodyText: Is it not ironic that by insisting on IRA decommissioning to guarantee peace (Peace crisis deepens after IRA pulls out, February 16), the British government and Ulster Unionists are endangering the peace that now exists? The power-sharing assembly was living proof that the peace process was in progress. Declaring its suspension, Peter Mandelson stated that "we have got to clear up this issue of decommissioning once and for all". Does he really believe that what had not been achieved while the assembly was operating can now be brought about in its absence? If the assembly had been set up and running since shortly after the spring 98 referendum and the election, IRA decommissioning may well have started by now, of its own accord, to meet the deadline of May 2000. Listening to Mr Mandelson's recent rhetoric ("If the war is over, why do arms still need to be retained?" and so on), which sounds increasingly unionist, one fears that he has little appreciation of the passion and honour involved in this issue on the republican side. It cannot be resolved by the head alone, nor with deadlines and ultimatums. Let us not wreck what has been achieved by insisting on 100%. Peace already exists, and that is easily 95% of what most people want. Akemi Horie-Webber St Genis-Pouilly, France The IRA's statement in response to the suspension of the new institutions in Northern Ireland is just so much self-serving rhetoric. What the IRA and Sinn Fein seem unable or unwilling to accept are the logical implications of their professed commitment to peace. If this is sincere, it implies decommissioning. Why are the guns only "silent" and not removed unless the IRA is reserving the right to resort to violence? The only obvious alternative explanations are misplaced nationalist chauvinism or fear of disunity. We are therefore entitled to be suspicious. Grenville Wall Vantaa, Finland gren.wall@kolumbus.fi David Trimble asserts yet again that the unionists "jumped first" in entering the Northern Ireland assembly with Sinn Fein. If by "jumping first" David Trimble means that he entered the assembly on the basis of a deadline for IRA decommissioning set by his own party outside the terms of the Good Friday agreement, then perhaps he is correct. However, it is important to recall how much has been sacrificed by republicans in the current peace process. Guns are silent, articles 2 and 3 of the Irish constitution have disappeared and Sinn Fein have accepted the principle of consent, to the extent that they have sat in a devolved assembly in Stormont, the notorious setting for past abuses of unionist power. This shift is forgotten as unionists demand IRA surrender in the form of decommissioning. Let us not forget that many guns lie silent in Northern Ireland at this time, not least those belonging to loyalist paramilitaries, the RUC, the British Army and those issued to a significant portion of the unionist community for "personal protection". Decommissioning is a responsibility shared by all parties to the conflict in Northern Ireland - not just the IRA. That Peter Mandelson has apparently rejected this view and chosen to support David Trimble's implacably (if understandably) biased view is, in the current context, a deeply irresponsible act. Fergal Quinn Hampton, Middx fergal_quinn@ireland.com Henry McElroy, a farmer in South Armagh, repeats the republican mantra that the guns have been out of commission for five years (We're fed up with waiting, February 11). This may be so in total but in between the two ceasefires, the IRA killed two British soldiers, two RUC constables and seriously injured two RUC constables, as well as bombing Canary Wharf (two deaths) and Manchester (hundreds injured). Loyalist paramilitaries killed innocent Catholics during those years. It is partly because hopes were dashed by the collapse of the original ceasefire and the resumption of bombing and shooting that people want decommissioning to take place. It has been said often enough during this peace process that it is not a question of one side winning and one losing. The IRA has not been defeated, it is a stalemate. Decommissioning was part of the Good Friday agreement, and despite the vague language used in that section of the agreement, people expected it to happen. Surely after 30 years it is time that the paramilitaries on both sides listened to the people and respected their views. Gerry Adams has tried to move republicans forward but this mantra about the guns being silent for five years is very hurtful to those whose loved ones have been killed by paramilitaries in that time. Guns and bombs ensuring a democratic process? Ask someone who has been kneecapped or beaten by baseball bats for their views on that. The republicans have a valid political aim. It is time they tried to achieve it politically and left the guns and bombs behind. Rita Restorick Nottingham

fields.headline: Fighting the giant Want
fields.standfirst: This is welfare spending all can applaud
fields.trailText: How do we make welfare so popular that people are happy to pay for it? That was the challenge thrown down by Tony Blair in his Toynbee Hall lecture last year and now taken up by Gordon Brown with his pledge to introduce an integrated child credit.
fields.body:
How do we make welfare so popular that people are happy to pay for it? That was the challenge thrown down by Tony Blair in his Toynbee Hall lecture last year and now taken up by Gordon Brown with his pledge to introduce an integrated child credit which we report today - a pledge which, although there are no figures attached to it yet because of conventional budget secrecy, will, according to treasury sources, lift the next million children out of poverty. As the prime minister noted, "if people lose faith in welfare's ability to deliver, the politicians have an impossible job of persuading hard-pressed taxpayers that their money should go on a system that is not working." The job of persuasion, it has to be said, might be easier if Mr Blair gave up complaining about social security taking too much of the government's budget. But we also applaud his commitment to the historic goal of abolishing child poverty within 20 years. If he delivers that, public respect for the welfare programme is sure to increase.

Measures already announced by Gordon Brown are due to lift 800,000 children (plus 550,000 parents) out of poverty by the end of this parliament. The mechanisms include the biggest ever increase in child benefit (from £11.45 in April 1998 for first children, to £15 this April), a large increase in the children allowances for people on income support (from £16.90 in 1997 to £24.90 in October 1999), the new national minimum wage lifting 300,000 workers and their children out of poverty, the new working family tax credit (WFTC) and the children's tax credit (£8 for all standard rate taxpayers) that starts in April 2001.

This, though very commendable, is only a start. It has lifted the income of families in the two poorest tenths of our society by 9.2% and 7% respectively compared to the average family's 5%. But it is only one sixth of the way towards abolishing child poverty. It would still leave 3.9m children living in poverty by the end of this parliament. Shamefully, child poverty - defined as living on less than half average income - tripled under the Thatcher and Major governments. An almost unbelievable one out of three of our 13m children were living in poverty when this government was elected. We know from cycle of deprivation studies that this means these children are far more likely to leave school without qualifications, suffer more bad health and unemployment, and die earlier. Middle income earners in comfortable suburbs live seven years longer than poor people in inner cities.

We still cannot be sure how Labour is going to lift the other five-sixths of children out of poverty, but our front page story today on the decision to push ahead with an integrated child credit is another advance. The idea is to provide a seamless and transparent system of support for children, helping parents to understand what they could expect to receive, and promoting public debate about the present level of support. Three different benefits for children (the child element of WFTC, child allowances of income support, and the children's tax credit) will be brought together to create an integrated child credit. The new benefit , in line with child benefit, will be paid direct to the carer, which should help women. Child benefit will remain a separate benefit. The new benefit will be adjusted for income for those in work, ensuring the poor get more, but providing a portable and secure bridge spanning welfare and work. And the chances of shifting the public's response from resentment to satisfaction at money well spent should be greatly enhanced.

fields.headline: If you go down to the woods today
fields.standfirst: From nuclear protests to saving the planet, direct action is all the rage.  Diane Taylor asks whether women do it better
fields.trailText: Morag Balfour has found her wheelchair comes in handy when she takes part in direct actions against nuclear weapons. She and six friends chained themselves to her chair at Faslane, the Scottish nuclear submarine base, on Monday as part of a Trident Ploughshares protest against the weapons stored there. Undeterred by icy rain, 500 protesters turned out, both men and women, 92 and 87 of whom respectively were arrested for public order offences.
fields.body:
Morag Balfour has found her wheelchair comes in handy when she takes part in direct actions against nuclear weapons. She and six friends chained themselves to her chair at Faslane, the Scottish nuclear submarine base, on Monday as part of a Trident Ploughshares protest against the weapons stored there. Undeterred by icy rain, 500 protesters turned out, both men and women, 92 and 87 of whom respectively were arrested for public order offences.

Balfour is no stranger to direct action, but insists it is not always the big adventure people imagine. "You spend lots of time buying chains and padlocks, planning out what you're going to do," she explains. "Then you have about five minutes of adrenaline when you do a lock-on, followed by an arrest and a day in a police cell. Having a good book with you is essential."

While she is happy to work with both men and women, she believes that women have been responsible for most of the major victories in disarmament direct action. "Women seem to push things harder," she says. "They are more able to dream the impossible, then work towards it."

The blockade at Faslane is one of a range of direct actions involving women opposed to war, nuclear weapons, GM crops and environmental damage. While these actions are ingeniously executed and often high-profile, they are also far more fragmented than the Cruise missile protests at Greenham that provided the focus for an unprecedented mass movement of women.

Peace campaigner Ippy D believes women's direct action now is much more "hardcore" than it was in the 80s, involving a smaller group of women and a more sophisticated approach. "At Greenham, I used to just rush off and do things, and was not really concerned about the consequences," she recalls. "In the post-Thatcher years, women's activism has been on a downward slope. We've been encouraged to see equality in terms of being able to get jobs as bank managers, but we've been duped. Achieving that sort of equality does not address the fundamental power issues between men and women."

She is keen to avoid "Mother Earth" stereotypes: "I don't accept that women are naturally non-violent or intrinsically pacifist. Women are just as capable as men of sneaking around in the middle of the night." Yet she is reluctant to work with men on actions. "You can't depend on them to be sensible. I was arrested with men during a protest to try to stop B52s taking off in the Gulf War and some had done really stupid things like not emptying their pockets of bits of paper before the action - a golden rule."

But while she talks of a male/ female split, many women who did not cut their teeth at Greenham focus instead on the differences between activists and the rest of the world. Christiana Tugwell, 15, who is occupying part of Beckney Woods in Hockley, Essex, accepts there are differences between men and women activists, but says: "Different people just do what they are good at. Maybe men build the tree houses, but then women muck in later. We're all committed to protecting this site and when a group of people gather together for the same reason, it creates a tremendous family feeling."

Kathryn Tulip, 40, is happy to work with both men and women, taking action against GM crop test sites. She gave up her job as a solicitor to concentrate on direct action and is currently involved in the Genetix Snowball campaign, openly and peacefully removing a small number of GM plants from the environment, then encouraging others to do the same. As for the difference between men and women activists: "The most important thing is to develop a high level of trust between people."

Fellow Snowball activist Rowan Tilly nevertheless believes there are clear differences between the two. "Men place more emphasis on physical activity, less on communication. Snowball actions are open and accountable, and need a lot of thought beforehand, but men tend to want to just get on with it - let's be completely covert and get this crop pulled up sort of thing. That may well be valid but it's different."

Such difference can be put to good use, according to Ippy D. "We've been taught since we were old enough to hold a Barbie that we can use our vulnerability to get what we want," she says. "That's why some women are happy taking action dressed as fairies or having teddy bears' picnics on military bases. The Aldermaston Ladies Rambling Club climbed fences in search of footpaths, dressed in Edwardian frocks and big hats."

Anni Rainbow, whose own peace campaigning has involved trespassing at US listening station Menwith Hill, believes that while "numbers may be smaller than in the 80s, there is a richer diversity of actions involving women than ever before". Ippy D also believes activism is flourishing among women - and warns men against being left behind. "It's important that they do something about their personal and political development before the gulf between male and female activists becomes even wider."

fields.trailText:
"In case you hadn't noticed, these days we are too often seen as pathetic creatures who can only be redeemed by women: almost redundant sperm banks wandering the post-industrial wastelands like adolescent missing links, our knuckles scraping the ground, our heads hung in shame at what we used to be. At what we could be again, if only we could get rid of the vanity mirror on the sun visor"

Dylan Jones mourns the loss of his metaphoric balls, Independent

"Escort" Adam Phillips on sleeping with experienced women, Mirror

Ross Kemp, aka EastEnders' Grant Mitchell, Arena

"I got stubble rash ... Now I appreciate why women tell men to shave. My heart goes out to you"

Actor Craig Kelly on the perils of his gay sex scene in Queer As Folk

fields.headline: The invisible man
fields.standfirst: When Gwyneth Paltrow appeared alone at a movie premiere this week, the world was aghast.  Maureen Freely  wonders why a solo female can still shock
fields.trailText: Here are a few platitudes we hold to be self-evident. We live in a time of rapid social change. Over the past quarter of a century, women have joined the paid workforce in record numbers. At the same time, the divorce rate has soared. The days of the traditional family are numbered. Its values count for less and less. Now they can command their own bank accounts, women are doing what they want, when they want - in outfits entirely of their own choosing.
fields.body:
Here are a few platitudes we hold to be self-evident. We live in a time of rapid social change. Over the past quarter of a century, women have joined the paid workforce in record numbers. At the same time, the divorce rate has soared. The days of the traditional family are numbered. Its values count for less and less. Now they can command their own bank accounts, women are doing what they want, when they want - in outfits entirely of their own choosing.

And so it was with Gwyneth Paltrow: instead of wearing the standard almost-topless evening gown to the premiere of The Talented Mr Ripley earlier this week, she chose to shock the nation with a sleeveless, emerald-beaded Versace top, aqua blue trousers and snakeskin stiletto sandals. The bold move paid off: most reports of her "understated" ensemble were highly favourable. No one even minded that her hair was in a bun.

But God, what a fuss they made about her decision to attend alone. When queried about this shocking lapse, she was characteristically good-natured. Instead of saying: "What year are we in - 2000 or 1867?" she replied that it was even worse than they thought. It was not just that she was dateless on St Valentine's Day - she had not even received a card.

Compare and contrast the press coverage of her co-star, Matt Damon, consortless on the night but known to be dating Winona Ryder. No one talked about his clothes and no one was amazed about his decision To Boldly Go Solo. No one paid much attention to him, either, so perhaps in publicity terms Paltrow was the winner. But you still have to ask why she can't even walk down a receiving line alone without people acting as if half of her is missing.

The question they ought to have asked her is: "If you had appeared with a man in tow, how do you think that man would have been treated?" Her answer could well have revealed the crux of the mystery. If a woman happens to be linked with a man who is her social or professional equal - or, better yet, if he is in the same business but higher up the ladder - then he can appear with her and still get the respect to which he is accustomed. But if he works in a different business or if, God forbid, his social standing is lower than hers, he can expect to be ignored and dismissed. And if he doesn't like it, if he thinks he's worth more than that, she can expect to be attending the next party alone.

It's not just the tabloids that are keeping the old double standards alive. We all do it. Even if all they are doing is going to a charity benefit or a Saturday night work do, women can still expect to raise eyebrows if they arrive on their own. It is not that everyone they meet will give them a hard time, but everyone does notice and there will always be at least one person who asks: "And where is ..?"

There is always a tinge of pity in the eye of the enquirer. You might think this shouldn't matter, but it does matter to a lot of women I know, even women who started companies worth 14 million after covering 19 wars in Southeast Asia, women who see nothing strange in spending two months hitchhiking around New Zealand with a baby in a backpack. Even very resourceful, independent women mind the leading questions at public functions because they feel they are being judged. The implication is that while they might be successes in the male world, they have failed as women. And as wives.

Remember the fuss Diana caused in 1992 when she visited the Taj Mahal alone? "Solo Diana visits monument to love" was how one paper put it. Charles later admitted he had been "a fool not to be by her side". When she visited Cairo alone later that same year, the headline was: "Postcards from the edge of unhappiness." The accompanying photograph of Diana at Giza was "the picture that captured front pages around the world. The beautiful young princess starkly alone against a backdrop of pyramids."

The underlying concern was made clear in comments about an earlier trip she took to Pakistan at the invitation of Benazir Bhutto: "Advisers fear that travelling without Charles in the Islamic republic may upset fundamentalists." As it turned out, it upset "fundamentalists" in Britain far more.

Does it matter, though, what people think? Well, it does if it bothers you so much that you stay at home instead. Certainly it bothered me a great deal just after I got divorced. I was shocked at the sudden change in the way many married friends and colleagues behaved from the moment they heard about the decree nisi. I would go to a weekend party alone and I was red meat to the men and dead meat to the women if I so much as laughed at their husbands' jokes. Somehow, the very fact that I was single was a threat to their marriages.

It was never this way, though, at the functions I continued to attend on week nights in connection with work. At these, I was a person in my own right; my marital status was not an issue because almost everyone else would be alone, too. The first few minutes in a room full of strangers were still hard to negotiate, but gradually I worked out how to get through them and even enjoy them. Eventually I came to look back on the years of being part of a couple as a pleasant but puzzling aberration.

When I settled down again, it never crossed my mind to ask my partner to be my constant companion. I like it when we can go out together, but because I enjoy going out a good deal more than he does, I still go out alone all the time.

But it isn't always easy to be the lone woman in a room full of couples. People still make comments about empty chairs or rush around in search of a "spare man" to "even out the numbers". Despite all that "rapid social change" they will often spend all evening talking about, their mental images of social balance remain sacrosanct.

How long would these images last if people stopped conforming to them? If more women said: "What the hell, I'm going anyway, it doesn't matter if I get a comment or two, and so what if no one will come with me." At the very least, they'd have other lone females to talk to when they got there. Outnumbered, the couples might no longer want to see lone females as symbols of social decay. So go on, Gwyneth, set a trend.

If a woman happens to be linked with a man who is her social or professional equal - or, better yet, if he is in the same business but higher up the ladder - then he can appear with her and still get the respect to which he is accustomed. But if he works in a different business or if, God forbid, his social standing is lower than hers, he can expect to be ignored and dismissed. And if he doesn't like it, if he thinks he's worth more than that, she can expect to be attending the next party alone. It's not just the tabloids that are keeping the old double standards alive. We all do it. Even if all they are doing is going to a charity benefit or a Saturday night work do, women can still expect to raise eyebrows if they arrive on their own. It is not that everyone they meet will give them a hard time, but everyone does notice and there will always be at least one person who asks: "And where is ..?" There is always a tinge of pity in the eye of the enquirer. You might think this shouldn't matter, but it does matter to a lot of women I know, even women who started companies worth 14 million after covering 19 wars in Southeast Asia, women who see nothing strange in spending two months hitchhiking around New Zealand with a baby in a backpack. Even very resourceful, independent women mind the leading questions at public functions because they feel they are being judged. The implication is that while they might be successes in the male world, they have failed as women. And as wives. Remember the fuss Diana caused in 1992 when she visited the Taj Mahal alone? "Solo Diana visits monument to love" was how one paper put it. Charles later admitted he had been "a fool not to be by her side". When she visited Cairo alone later that same year, the headline was: "Postcards from the edge of unhappiness." The accompanying photograph of Diana at Giza was "the picture that captured front pages around the world. The beautiful young princess starkly alone against a backdrop of pyramids." The underlying concern was made clear in comments about an earlier trip she took to Pakistan at the invitation of Benazir Bhutto: "Advisers fear that travelling without Charles in the Islamic republic may upset fundamentalists." As it turned out, it upset "fundamentalists" in Britain far more. Does it matter, though, what people think? Well, it does if it bothers you so much that you stay at home instead. Certainly it bothered me a great deal just after I got divorced. I was shocked at the sudden change in the way many married friends and colleagues behaved from the moment they heard about the decree nisi. I would go to a weekend party alone and I was red meat to the men and dead meat to the women if I so much as laughed at their husbands' jokes. Somehow, the very fact that I was single was a threat to their marriages. It was never this way, though, at the functions I continued to attend on week nights in connection with work. At these, I was a person in my own right; my marital status was not an issue because almost everyone else would be alone, too. The first few minutes in a room full of strangers were still hard to negotiate, but gradually I worked out how to get through them and even enjoy them. Eventually I came to look back on the years of being part of a couple as a pleasant but puzzling aberration. When I settled down again, it never crossed my mind to ask my partner to be my constant companion. I like it when we can go out together, but because I enjoy going out a good deal more than he does, I still go out alone all the time. But it isn't always easy to be the lone woman in a room full of couples. People still make comments about empty chairs or rush around in search of a "spare man" to "even out the numbers". Despite all that "rapid social change" they will often spend all evening talking about, their mental images of social balance remain sacrosanct. How long would these images last if people stopped conforming to them? If more women said: "What the hell, I'm going anyway, it doesn't matter if I get a comment or two, and so what if no one will come with me." At the very least, they'd have other lone females to talk to when they got there. Outnumbered, the couples might no longer want to see lone females as symbols of social decay. So go on, Gwyneth, set a trend.

webTitle: Scientists confirm earth is hotting up

fields.headline: Scientists confirm earth is hotting up
fields.trailText: The planet's temperature has risen by 1C in the the last 500 years, according to the latest evidence from the rocks. Half of that rise happened in the 20th century.
fields.body:
The planet's temperature has risen by 1C in the the last 500 years, according to the latest evidence from the rocks. Half of that rise happened in the 20th century.

Scientists from the universities of Michigan and Western Ontario report in Nature today that they studied temperatures from boreholes at more than 600 sites around the world.

Air temperatures change dramatically by day and night, and by winter and summer. But the earth's crust, to a depth of 500 metres, acts as a kind of archive of overall temperature change with time.

The readings from boreholes showed that in the northern hemisphere, the temperature since 1500 had risen by 1.1 C - and in the last100 years the rise had been 0.6C.

The news confirms fears that humans have begun to trigger global warming.

There have been other signs of a steady rise in temperatures over the last decades. Sea levels have increased and glaciers retreated, winters have become apparently shorter, and birds have been nesting up to 17 days earlier.

Now climate researchers have solid evidence of long-term change, initially from 358 measuring points in eastern North America, central Europe, southern Africa and Australia, and then from hundreds more in other continents.

Each of the six continents investigated has warmed faster in the 20th century than during any of the previous four centuries.

fields.headline: Small picture, big price tag
fields.trailText: A tiny lost masterpiece has finally been recognised after hanging for 150 years in a little used corridor of an English country house. Nothing like it has come up at auction before.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
A tiny lost masterpiece has finally been recognised after hanging for 150 years in a little used corridor of an English country house. Nothing like it has come up at auction before.

The expert who spotted it, Sotheby's director Richard Charlton-Jones, said he was left weak at the knees when he spotted the lost work by the 13th century Italian painter Cimabue - tutor of Giotto - whose work is now known only from a handful of surviving pieces.

The Madonna and Child Enthroned With Angels is the only Cimabue known to remain in private ownership. Mr Charlton-Jones described it as "a picture of the very greatest rarity and beauty."

Experts are guessing that it will sell for at least £2m at a Sotheby's old masters auction in London in July.

The picture was among the contents of Benacre Hall, a country house near Lowestoft in Suffolk. It is being sold after the death of the last direct heir of the Gooch family, whose pedigree can be traced back to the 12th century.

The picture, on a hardback book sized wooden panel, survived a fire which gutted Benacre Hall in the 1920s, when servants dragged furniture, books, carpets and pictures out of the blaze on to the lawn.

The picture is said to be in remarkably good condition.

The last heir, Sir John Gooch, 12th baronet, a bachelor who died last year aged 69, was a passionate art collector, but may never have realised what a treasure he owned.

After Mr Charlton-Jones spotted the picture, it was taken to the National Gallery, and then to New York for comparison with another Cimabue work.

Sotheby's believes it was bought by Sir Edward Sherlock Gooch, the 6th baronet, while he was in Florence on the grand tour in the early 19th century.

It is regarded as the most important early Italian work to come on the open market since 1976, when a panel from a Duccio crucifixion sold for £1m.

webTitle: Bingham sets criteria for trials of children

fields.headline: Bingham sets criteria for trials of children
fields.trailText: Children facing jury trial in adult crown courts must not in future be subjected to "intimidation, humiliation or distress", the lord chief justice told judges yesterday.
fields.body:
Children facing jury trial in adult crown courts must not in future be subjected to "intimidation, humiliation or distress", the lord chief justice told judges yesterday.

In high profile cases, said Lord Bingham, police help should be sought to protect young defendants from "intimidation, vilification or abuse" outside court. Judges should consider restricting the numbers of reporters and onlookers in court, and making secrecy orders banning the media from publishing the defendants' names.

The senior judge for England and Wales handed down instructions for judges in the wake of the European court of human rights ruling last December that the boy killers of two-year-old James Bulger were denied a fair trial in 1993, when they were tried at Preston crown court.

The Strasbourg court ruled that Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, who were 10 when they committed the murder and 11 when they were tried, were so intimidated and so affected by post-traumatic stress disorder that they were unable to communicate with their legal advisers and play an effective part in the trial.

During the three-week trial they ran a daily gauntlet of enraged crowds shouting abuse and hurling stones at the prison van. In a crowded courtroom surrounded by the world's media, they were the centre of attention on a raised platform - a well-meaning gesture designed to compensate for their small size but which increased their sense of exposure.

Human rights lawyers believe the Strasbourg judgment obliges the government to go further and abandon crown court jury trial altogether for young children, but this requires legislation and is not a step open to the lord chief justice. The law states that youngsters accused of murder or manslaughter must be tried in the crown court and magistrates have a discretion to send those charged with other serious offences for jury trial. Most are dealt with in private hearings in the youth court.

Allan Levy QC, a child law expert, said: "It could be argued that the lord chief justice's practice direction doesn't go far enough, and it might well come under challenge from a human rights point of view."

Last month, in the first ruling of its kind, a judge at Southwark crown court in London refused to allow two 12-year-old boys charged with indecently assaulting a 13-year-old girl to stand trial by jury. He cited the Strasbourg ruling, saying he was not intending to set a precedent for all such cases, but believed a jury trial would not be appropriate for the particular boys.

Lord Bingham said judges should take account of the youngster's age, maturity, intellectual and emotional development in deciding what steps to take. Some children standing trial were "very young and very immature".

The purpose of the trial was to decide guilt and the appropriate sentence and the trial process "should not itself expose the young defendant to avoidable intimidation, humiliation or distress".

He said: "All possible steps should be taken to assist the young defendant to understand and participate in the proceedings. The ordinary trial process should so far as necessary be adapted to meet those ends."

Young defendants should normally be tried on their own even if they were charged jointly with an adult, unless a joint trial would be in the interests of justice, he said.

The youngster should be allowed to visit the courtroom before the trial to familiarise himself with it. Judges should be ready to make orders banning identification of a child defendant.

At the trial, all participants should be on the same level, and the youngster should be free to sit with members of his family and near enough to his lawyers to allow "easy, informal communication".

Lord Bingham said the judge should explain what was happening in simple terms, remind the young defendant's lawyers that they must explain each step of the trial, and ensure "so far as practicable, that the trial is conducted in language which the young defendant can understand".

Court days should be shorter, with frequent breaks. Judges and lawyers should put aside their wigs and gowns.

Unless there was a good reason for it, there should be no police in the courtroom, and those responsible for the defendant's security should not be in uniform.

fields.headline: Clampdown on wildlife criminals
fields.trailText: Criminals are turning to wildlife crime, stealing birds, plants and bulbs from the countryside as a lucrative alternative to burglary and stealing from cars because the chances of being caught are less and penalties minor, Mick Brewer, acting chief constable of Warwickshire, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Criminals are turning to wildlife crime, stealing birds, plants and bulbs from the countryside as a lucrative alternative to burglary and stealing from cars because the chances of being caught are less and penalties minor, Mick Brewer, acting chief constable of Warwickshire, said yesterday.

Professional criminals with convictions for burglary were recently caught with 300,000 snowdrop bulbs, worth £60,000, which they had dug up in a wood.

Mr Brewer said: "As the home secretary clamps down on particular crimes, the chances of getting caught are greater. Criminals just switch to different types of crime, and wildlife crime can provide a big money alternative."

He was speaking at the launch at London Zoo of a national clampdown on wildlife crime, at which Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said the department of environment was setting up a national wildlife crime unit at a cost of £440,000.

Its job would be the national co-ordination of customs and excise, police, local authorities and organisations like the RSPCA and RSPB, to combat wildlife crime. The government also intended to make some wildlife offences, like stealing birds' eggs, punishable with prison whereas at present the maximum penalty was a fine. These harsher penalties would be included in the countryside amenity and conservation bill, to be published shortly.

Mr Meacher said that wildlife crime ranged from people digging up plants to put in their gardens and builders destroying bat colonies, to organised gangs supplying garden centres with bulbs from wild sources.

There were also "anoraks" - people who collected eggs, butterflies or orchids, wiping out the species in the process.

A third group were international criminals who traded in tiger parts, rhino horn and parrots. A single parrot smuggled into Britain could be sold for £20,000.

Mr Meacher said that DNA testing, which could tell the difference between birds bred in captivity and birds taken from the wild, was highly effective in trapping those who were stealing hawks and falcons.

A new DNA test had been developed which meant that if any product contained up to 10% tiger bone or other body parts it could be detected.

webTitle: NHS needs funding gap say analysts

fields.headline: NHS needs funding gap say analysts
fields.trailText: The government should keep the NHS deliberately short of the funding it would need to meet all demands for health care, according to Anthony Harrison and Jennifer Dixon, fellows of the King's Fund health think-tank.
fields.body:
The government should keep the NHS deliberately short of the funding it would need to meet all demands for health care, according to Anthony Harrison and Jennifer Dixon, fellows of the King's Fund health think-tank.

A gap between the supply of free health care and demand for it did not mean a crisis and was in fact "desirable", they said.

In a book on the future of the NHS, the policy analysts argued that it was impossible for any health care system to do everything beneficial. The job of government was to pitch funding so that the demand gap was optimal.

"Within the existing financial framework, the NHS will always appear to be under financial pressure," the authors said. "It would be a sign of poor treasury management if it were not."

Their conclusions will be welcome relief for ministers, coming after the recent flu crisis sparked widespread accusations that the NHS was chronically underfunded and close to breakdown.

The British Medical Association has meanwhile embarked on a fundamental review of NHS funding, premised on an assumption that there was a "large and widening gap" between resources and demand.

The book, The NHS: Facing the Future, said people's expectations of health care rose as its availability rose. To keep pumping public money into the service, chasing expectations, risked depriving other areas where the same investment could yield greater benefits.

"The 'price' or opportunity cost of more health spending would be translated into lower spending on other public sector programmes such as education, or in lower levels of personal consumption of goods and services which lower taxes would allow."

What the NHS needed was sustained investment to a point at which the gap between demand and supply of care was understood by the public and perceived as fair, the authors said.

Mr Harrison said he and Ms Dixon had not determined whether the current gap was appropriate. "My personal feeling is that we should probably be spending more, but that's a gut feeling and not the result of careful study."

fields.headline: Skyjack cost put at £3.6m
fields.standfirst: Stansted hijack: special report
fields.trailText: Police yesterday said that the cost of dealing with the Afghan hijack at Stansted was expected to be about £3.6m.
fields.body:
Police yesterday said that the cost of dealing with the Afghan hijack at Stansted was expected to be about £3.6m.

Essex police has notified the home office of the figure, which includes an estimate of the cost of the continuing criminal investigation.

A spokesman for the Essex force said: "We have asked for confirmation that these costs will be met by the home office through a special grant from the contingency fund."

A total of 78 people have formally applied for asylum, the home office.

The only outstanding case involves a man being held in secure accommodation at the Tinsley House immigration detention centre at Gatwick airport. He was moved there after he warned police he suffered flashbacks which could make him violent.

Decisions on hostages who have sought asylum will be made after five days' grace, said the home office. If successful, applicants would be allowed to leave the Fire Service College at Moreton-in-Marsh in Gloucestershire, with refugee status.

fields.headline: CPS official 'bribed' by crime family
fields.trailText: An official in the crown prosecution service took a bribe to pass on secret intelligence about a feared criminal family and their associates, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An official in the crown prosecution service took a bribe to pass on secret intelligence about a feared criminal family and their associates, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Administration officer Mark Herbert copied details from case files and names of registered informants while working on a legal team dealing with investigations into the London-based Adams family, said Victor Temple QC, prosecuting.

"One of the most sensitive and difficult areas of the crown prosecution service work in 1998 concerned the Adams family," he told the jury.

While working at CPS's headquarters in central London, Herbert copied details from computerised files and passed them to a nightclub manager. He in turn gave it to Billy Isaacs, a man allegedly connected to the Adams family, said the prosecution.

Mr Temple said the Adams family and their associates "had formed themselves into a formidable and feared organisation steeped in the highest levels of criminal activity."

The police and the CPS were taking an interest in them. Their notoriety was already in the public domain, Mr Temple added.

Herbert, 31, was in debt and forced to moonlight as a nightclub bouncer in addition to his £14,000-a-year post with the CPS.

He was taken on by Kevin Sumer who learned, through Herbert's bragging that he worked for the central casework division of the CPS, said Mr Temple.

Herbert, from Twickenham, west London, and Sumer, 41, from Brentford, Middlesex, have denied a joint charge of conspiracy to pervert the course of justice between August and October 1998.

Herbert alone has denied corruption - taking a £500 bribe to supply confidential information from the files and records of the CPS.

Herbert has also denied two counts of disclosing information without lawful authority.

Sumer is accused of aiding and abetting Herbert on the same charges.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Scotland to boost tourism with searches for ancestral roots

fields.headline: Scotland to boost tourism with searches for ancestral roots
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive is pinning its hopes on something more akin to Brigadoon than Braveheart to try and reverse the trade's declining fortunes by encouraging visitors to come and search for their ancestral roots.
fields.body:
It took an Australian acting in an Irish film to boost Scotland's flagging tourist industry last time round.

Now, the Scottish executive is pinning its hopes on something more akin to Brigadoon than Braveheart to try and reverse the trade's declining fortunes by encouraging visitors to come and search for their ancestral roots.

A package of sweeping reforms unveiled yesterday includes a key focus on genealogy, using public records and the internet to try and draw new generations back to the old country. There's also an £11m cash injection, new industry targets and a pledge to have 90% of all hotels, guest houses and B&Bs online by 2005.

But it is the focus on ancestral links and all the tartan baggage that goes with it that marks the big shift in the promotion of Scotland. The new focus on niche marketing, which will would cover Scotland's golfing heritage as well as genealogy, would allow the country to play on its strengths.

"Hidden away in the births, marriages and deaths sections of the Scottish executive is a unique electronic tourism selling point.

7. Holyrood palace: The Queen's other Scottish pile

8. Loch Ness visitor centre

webTitle: European court says M25 pair denied fair trial

fields.headline: European court says M25 pair denied fair trial
fields.trailText: Two men serving life sentences for a murder and robberies 12 years ago near the M25 were denied a fair trial and appeal because vital evidence was withheld from the trial judge and the defence, the European court of human rights ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
Two men serving life sentences for a murder and robberies 12 years ago near the M25 were denied a fair trial and appeal because vital evidence was withheld from the trial judge and the defence, the European court of human rights ruled yesterday.

Raphael Rowe, 32, and Michael Davis, 34, were jailed for life with the third member of the so-called M25 three, Randolph Johnson, in 1990 for a string of violent robberies, one of which led to the murder of a hairdresser.

The unanimous ruling by 17 judges brought immediate calls by Rowe's lawyer for his release from prison. The two were awarded £25,000 costs.

The court found that the prosecution had withheld significant evidence without telling the judge at the trial and without asking him to rule on whether the step was justified.

It was only last year that the defence learned that a key witness was a paid informer who had received a £10,300 reward and done a deal with police to avoid prosecution for involvement in the crimes himself.

The prosecution withheld the information under "public interest immunity" rules, which allow so-called sensitive material, including anything that might put a witness at risk of intimidation or assault, to be kept from the defence. Since the trial the law has changed, and relevant evidence cannot be withheld without a judge's ruling.

Before the appeal in 1993, the appeal court ruled, on the basis of submissions from the prosecution only, that the evidence should not be disclosed. The appeal was turned down.

The case was referred back to the appeal court last year by the criminal cases review commission, and a new appeal is scheduled next June.

But James Nichol, Rowe's solicitor, wrote to the crown prosecution service yesterday asking it to concede the appeal. "What the judges have said is that there was an unfair trial, an unfair appeal and it was entirely the fault of the crown."

The CPS said it would study the judgment before deciding whether to oppose an application from the men's lawyers for them to be freed on bail.

The Strasbourg judges said that if the trial judge had known of the information, he could have kept the question of disclosure under review during the trial. With the material, the defence might have been able through cross-examination seriously to undermine the credibility of key witnesses.

At the appeal, the judges had to rely on the transcripts of the original crown court case, and on the prosecution, for their understanding of the relevant facts, "and may even, to a certain extent, have unconsciously been influenced by the jury's verdict of guilty into underestimating the significance of the undisclosed evidence."

The three, from Sydenham, south London, were convicted of the murder in Warlingham, Surrey, of Peter Hurburgh, who was dragged with his homosexual lover from his car at gunpoint, tied up, beaten and doused with petrol when he refused to hand over his keys. Mr Hurburgh had a weak heart and the assault caused a fatal heart attack.

Later the same night men broke into the home of a retired businessman in Oxted and stabbed his 40-year-old son. The next attack took place in a house in Fetcham where a couple were tied up as their home was ransacked.

The initial description of the perpetrators, given to police by victims and issued to the public, was of a gang of two white men and a black man. One victim described one of the gang as being fair-haired and blue-eyed. However, the three men arrested and eventually convicted were all black.

Rowe and Davis always believed a deal had been struck with the original white suspects in the case in which they offered to provide information in return for cash and protection from prosecution.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said: "The European court of human rights in Strasbourg has raised substantial questions about the fairness of the secret procedures in the criminal justice system." The men's convictions should be quashed.

fields.headline: Woman's 'death sentence'
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: A 33-year-old woman was "sentenced to death" by her parents when she contracted a rare form of CJD from the medical treatment they put her through.
fields.body:
A 33-year-old woman was "sentenced to death" by her parents when she contracted a rare form of CJD from the medical treatment they put her through.

Rachel Gwilliam, of Drybrook, Gloucestershire, was injected with a growth hormone from the age of seven to 16.

But the hormone was contaminated with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease commonly associated with BSE, or mad cow disease.

Rachel's parents, Brenda and Roger Preece, said yesterday after an inquest into her death: "We in ignorance sentenced our daughter to death. We are left with nothing except guilt that we agreed to the treatment."

Seth Lane, a professor and CJD specialist from Frenchay hospital in Bristol told Gloucester coroner's court that Rachel was one of just tens of cases to have contracted the rare strain.

Rachel's family are seeking compensation from the department of health.

Prof Lane told the hearing the growth hormone Rachel was given from 1973 to 1982 was extracted from people who had died.

He said: "It needs just someone who had undiagnosed CJD to pass on the disease. It was not the human growth hormone that was the problem, it was the contaminant.

"The relative number of deaths that might have been occasioned by this is tens of cases."

The Preeces' lawyer, Jonathan Glasson, told the hearing he knew of 35 similar cases including a series of eight in Edinburgh and one in Southampton.

Mrs Preece told the coroner's court she first took Rachel for treatment when she showed no signs of growing as a toddler. As a one-year-old, Rachel weighed just 15lbs, despite weighing a healthy 6lb 7oz when she was born.

After consulting a paediatrician, Rachel was put on a growth hormone treatment in 1973.

Mrs Preece told the hearing she injected the treatment herself at six month intervals.

But she claimed the only side effect she was told about was the possibility of Rachel becoming infertile.

"I cannot remember being made aware of any other risk," said Mrs Preece

Rachel made trips for scans and x-rays at Great Ormond Street hospital in London.

She carried on the treatment until 1982 when she was 5ft 2ins tall, the hearing heard.

But it was not until the mid-80s that Mrs Preece heard that the drug Rachel was injected with had been withdrawn in America after a health scare.

Gloucester coroner David Gibbons recorded a verdict of death by misadventure.

webTitle: Why clubs are in the swim

fields.headline: Why clubs are in the swim
fields.trailText: Next time you hit the clubs for a night of ear-challenging house or garage sounds, try taking your goldfish along. It might share your pleasure.
fields.body:
Next time you hit the clubs for a night of ear-challenging house or garage sounds, try taking your goldfish along. It might share your pleasure.

Researchers at Manchester university have found that our love of loud music could have its source in a tiny organ buried in the ear which is excited by musical frequencies transmitted at very loud volumes.

This organ, the sacculus, is not thought to have any hearing function in humans, but in fish, it does.

New Scientist magazine reports today that the research team leader Neil Todd, a psychologist, is suggesting our fishy ancestors may have bequeathed us the link between heavy duty musical experiences and pleasure.

In humans, the sacculus lies in the inner ear, part of the system which gives us our sense of balance. The effect only appears when volume exceeds 90 decibels. A typical rock concert is 110 decibels.

webTitle: UK out of step as EU takes new approach to problem

fields.headline: UK out of step as EU takes new approach to problem
fields.standfirst:
Europe: Emphasis is shifting away from jailing users

Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Europe is shifting towards the decriminalisation of the possession of drugs for personal use, according to an official report on drug policies across the continent.
fields.body:
Europe is shifting towards the decriminalisation of the possession of drugs for personal use, according to an official report on drug policies across the continent.

The annual report of the EU's monitoring centre for drugs and drug addiction said that while most member states rejected extreme solutions such as full legalisation or harsh repression, there was increasing recognition that the prosecution and imprisonment of individuals with drug problems caused even greater difficulties.

The report revealed that the hardline UK policy of continuing to criminalise all those arrested for cannabis possession was beginning to look like an old-fashioned stance.

But it added that while the trend in many states was to reduce the emphasis on prosecuting and imprisoning drug users, the number of people arrested for drug possession offences was increasing across Europe. The report said that this contradiction suggested some need for "fine-tuning theory and practice within the criminal justice system".

Although most states continued to ban illicit drug use, the report from the Lisbon-based institute said there had been ashift to liberalise the penalties or administrative measures used to enforce it.

At the same time "harm reduction" policies such as needle exchanges, providing injection rooms or even prescribing heroin, were becoming mainstream policy in the EU.

The traditional distinctions between illegal drugs such as cannabis and cocaine and legal recreational substances such as tobacco and alcohol were also being blurred. In France, Germany, the Netherlands and Austria the government agencies that provided treatment and prevention programmes involving illegal drugs now also dealt with tobacco and alcohol.

In Germany the term "addiction prevention" was used rather than "drug prevention" so as to emphasise the danger of addictive substances regardless of their legal status.

The report said Portugal was considering decriminalising the illicit consumption and possession of drugs for personal use as part of reform of its drug laws. In Belgium the occasional cannabis user, if arrested, would find nothing more happened than that the drugs were confiscated and a police report filed. It was a pattern being repeated across much of the EU.

Nevertheless the report said that arrests for drug-related offences had been steadily increasing since the mid-1980s. This might partly reflect the increasing use of illicit drugs. The EU estimated that 40m people had used cannabis in the 15 member states.

The survey said problem drug use was lowest in Germany, Austria, Finland and Sweden and highest in Italy, Luxembourg and the UK.

fields.headline: Police force urges legalisation
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Cleveland has become the first police force to warn the government that the war on drugs is not being won and to say it is time to consider the "only serious alternative - the legalisation and regulation of some or all drugs".
fields.body:
Cleveland has become the first police force to warn the government that the war on drugs is not being won and to say it is time to consider the "only serious alternative - the legalisation and regulation of some or all drugs".

The report from Cleveland's chief constable, Barry Shaw, which has been endorsed by the force's Labour-led police authority, is the first time that senior serving police officers have declared that Britain's drug laws are not working and endorsed the call for a royal commission to reconsider the legal position. The only police figures who have, up until now, voiced their support for a serious debate on legalisation have been retired officers.

The most senior officers in the Cleveland force, which covers the Redcar constituency of Mo Mowlam, the cabinet minister responsible for drugs police, said they strongly supported Tony Blair's 10-year strategy to combat drug abuse because it stressed the need to treat drug users as victims as much as offenders. But they said that underlying it all was a prohibition style approach which relied upon bans and enforcement to restrict availability.

"We have to consider whether this is realistic," said the report written by Cleveland's former assistant chief constable, Richard Brunstrom, and endorsed by Mr Shaw.

"There is overwhelming evidence to show that the prohibition based policy in place in this country since 1971 has not been effective in controlling the availability of or use of prescribed drugs.

"If there is indeed a 'war on drugs' it is not being won; drugs are demonstrably cheaper and more easily available than ever before. The same picture can be seen in the USA and elsewhere."

The report added that there was no logic in making alcohol and nicotine freely available despite very clear evidence of their harmful effects while the ban on cannabis was being enforced with severe penalties, despite being seen as less harmful by many medical scientists.

It said this approach was based on little more than historical accident and led many young people to level the charge of hypocrisy, a view which was very difficult to counter.

The force argued that Britain had yet to learn the lessons of 1920s alcohol prohibition in the United States, Gandhi's civil disobedience campaign in India in the 1940s, or from the campaign against the poll tax in Britain in the 1980s.

"If a sufficiently large, and apparently growing, part of the population chooses to ignore the law for whatever reason, then that law becomes unenforceable. A modern western democracy, based on policing by consent and the rule of law may find itself powerless to prevent illegal activity - in this case the importation and use of controlled drugs."

The Cleveland police said there was a strong link between crime and drugs but added that was a product of prices remaining high because drugs are illegal. A serious heroin user needed to find £50 in cash each day and so turned to crime, mainly shoplifting, selling drugs and burglary. The report noted that nationally about a third of all crime was geared to the purchase of heroin, cocaine or crack.

The officers insisted that most drug users did not commit significant amounts of crime and their only offence was to choose to use a drug which was technically illegal.

"The best example of this is cannabis - the UK has the highest rate of cannabis use in Europe, higher even than in the Netherlands which has a tolerance policy."

The Cleveland police policy paper said that overwhelming health reasons added to the reasons for considering changes in legalisation. It said the illegal nature of the trade caused further unnecessary risk to drug users because of uncertainty over the quality and purity. Heroin might be cut with additives as wide ranging as chalk dust, quinine, lactose, boric acid and talcum powder.

"Legalisation and regulation of currently banned drugs has never been tried properly anywhere in the world so there is little hard evidence available," it said, adding that the experiment in Netherlands in tolerating the personal use of cannabis had resulted in a lower rate of use than in the UK. Some European cities, such as Geneva, were experimenting with issuing heroin under prescription to addicts with results showing some startling reductions in crime.

It concluded by saying that the evidence strongly suggested that prohibition had not been effective in reducing availability of, or demand for, controlled drugs, and might even be counter-productive.

"If prohibition does not work, then either the consequences of this have to be accepted, or an alternative approach must be found," said the report. "The most obvious alternative approach is the legalisation and subsequent regulation of some or all drugs."

Ken Walker, the chairman of Cleveland police authority, which endorsed the report, said it was a serious, sensible and constructive approach. "No one wants to rush into legalising some or all of the drugs proscribed because there are so many serious and complex social implications. But we have to face reality and open up the debate about all the options."

Battles the law won
1998 drug seizures and offender statistics

 Total number of drug seizures increased by 8% to 149,000; 76% involved cannabis.

 Cannabis seizures increased by 7%, but the quantities seized dropped by 28%.

 The number of heroin seizures went up by 19%, but quantity seized fell by 40%.

 Number and quantity of cocaine (including crack) seizures increased, by 36% and 25% respectively.

 Quantities of ecstasy type drugs went up by 9%; the number of seizures fell by 7%.

 Drug offenders up by 13% to 127,900; 90% possession cases, mainly cannabis.

 Cocaine offenders up 32% (excluding crack); a 30% rise in heroin offenders; and a rise of 13% in cannabis offenders.

 47% of offenders were cautioned, 23% were fined and 8% sentenced to immediate custody.

"The best example of this is cannabis - the UK has the highest rate of cannabis use in Europe, higher even than in the Netherlands which has a tolerance policy." The Cleveland police policy paper said that overwhelming health reasons added to the reasons for considering changes in legalisation. It said the illegal nature of the trade caused further unnecessary risk to drug users because of uncertainty over the quality and purity. Heroin might be cut with additives as wide ranging as chalk dust, quinine, lactose, boric acid and talcum powder. "Legalisation and regulation of currently banned drugs has never been tried properly anywhere in the world so there is little hard evidence available," it said, adding that the experiment in Netherlands in tolerating the personal use of cannabis had resulted in a lower rate of use than in the UK. Some European cities, such as Geneva, were experimenting with issuing heroin under prescription to addicts with results showing some startling reductions in crime. It concluded by saying that the evidence strongly suggested that prohibition had not been effective in reducing availability of, or demand for, controlled drugs, and might even be counter-productive. "If prohibition does not work, then either the consequences of this have to be accepted, or an alternative approach must be found," said the report. "The most obvious alternative approach is the legalisation and subsequent regulation of some or all drugs." Ken Walker, the chairman of Cleveland police authority, which endorsed the report, said it was a serious, sensible and constructive approach. "No one wants to rush into legalising some or all of the drugs proscribed because there are so many serious and complex social implications. But we have to face reality and open up the debate about all the options." webTitle: Foster care system 'at risk from abusers'

fields.headline: Foster care system 'at risk from abusers'
fields.standfirst:
Danger is not over, warns Waterhouse as anger grows over 'missing' 28

More about the Wales child abuse scandal
fields.trailText: The man who led the public inquiry into 20 years of abuse in children's homes in north Wales last night warned that abusers could have infiltrated the foster care system and could now prove even harder to detect.
fields.byline: David Brindle, David Ward  and Helen Carter
fields.body:
The man who led the public inquiry into 20 years of abuse in children's homes in north Wales last night warned that abusers could have infiltrated the foster care system and could now prove even harder to detect.

Sir Ronald Waterhouse said the fact that there had been fewer complaints of abuse in children's homes since the 1980s must reflect the closure of many homes, particularly the larger ones, and the switch to foster care.

He warned: "There is no basis for complacency, however, and it would be very surprising if potential abusers had packed their bags and departed into the night."

In Wales, he said, only 31% of children in care in 1974 had been fostered. Over the following two decades, that proportion had risen to 83%.

"Detection of abuse in foster care is likely to be as least as difficult as it is in any residential home," said Sir Ronald, who was giving a lecture at the University of Hertfordshire law faculty in St Albans.

"The disincentive to complain is just as strong, if not stronger; and, shocking though it may seem to an uninformed outsider, many foster children prefer to remain in an abusive household rather than risk the alternative, which may involve placement in a residential home or, at best, transfer to an alien foster home with the loss of friends and a familiar environment."

His comments came as the 48-hour attempt to find 28 "missing" people named in his inquiry report as proven or suspected abusers, or as unsuitable for work with children, descended into controversy.

Local and health authorities are expected to report by 5pm today on whether they have any of the individuals on their payrolls. But some authorities said they did not receive the list until yesterday.

There was also puzzlement and anger that nothing had been done before Tuesday, when the inquiry report was published, even though the inquiry had stopped taking evidence in April 1998.

A department of health spokeswoman said the list had been sent to all authorities by email on Tuesday. Hard copies had been sent by fax as a back-up.

The spokeswoman said it had not been possible to circulate the list before Tuesday because it was only publication of the report which had given privilege to publishing the names of suspects. There was no mechanism to short-circuit the process.

In another development, a senior detective revealed yesterday that he knew the whereabouts of two notorious paedophiles named on the list of 28 "missing" people sent to local councils in the wake of the Waterhouse report, as victims called for the list to be made public.

Detective Superintendent Peter Ackerley, who from 1991 led the investigation into child abuse in north Wales, declined to say where the two men were living but added that neither was working with children.

Both men were convicted of sexual offences before the sex offenders' register was introduced. John Allen was jailed for six years, Stephen Norris for seven. Both were included on the list issued by the department of health and the Welsh assembly.

"We know where they are," said Mr Ackerley at a press conference in Colwyn Bay. "But I don't think it would help for us to say publicly where they are. As far as I know, they have never applied to work with children [since release from prison]."

John Owen, deputy chief constable of north Wales, said the force would wait to be asked before volunteering the men's addresses.

"As a general rule, the principle would be that if either of those individuals sought employment where they had substantial access to children, there is a requirement on the employer to carry out checks on their antecedents," he said. "Those checks would be made and would involve us."

Mr Owen also revealed that further prosecutions are unlikely because the evidence given to the tribunal had already been considered by the crown prosecution service. "If something further were to emerge, then obviously it would be be reconsidered," he said.

More than 300 files were submitted. Charges connected with abuse followed but the CPS did not proceed with any charges involving "malfeasance in public office" (neglect of duty).

The tribunal's report criticised the first investigation by North Wales police in the mid-1980s but found no substantial criticism of the two later inquiries.

Meanwhile, Malcolm King, former chairman of the social services committee on Clwyd county council and a present member of Wrexham council, said he was not surprised that the whereabouts of the missing proven or suspected abusers were unknown.

Mr King, who is vice-chairman of the north Wales police authority, said: "The whole process has been characterised by complete incompetence by every agency involved and still is. So the idea they have lost people doesn't surprise me at all.

He found the report even more disappointing than he had anticipated. "They could have come up with something more radical that was going to take us forward in dealing with a vast number of paedophiles that are trying to get hold of kids."

Abuse victim Steven Messham, 37, who claims to have been sexually assaulted and physically abused in four different Welsh care homes, said he had been promised that no stone would be left unturned.

He expressed disappointment over yesterday's announcement by North Wales police that there would be no new prosecutions.

Mr Messham, chairman of Norwas (North Wales Abuse Survivors) said he had believed that Sir Ronald Waterhouse would name and shame the abusers.

"He only named people we already knew about.

"As far as I'm concerned, the fight will go on and one day we will get the justice we deserve."
