fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Net shopping 'will hit traffic'
fields.body:
Net shopping 'will hit traffic'

The growth of internet shopping will increase traffic in residential areas, according to a report published yesterday.

Fears of a rise in delivery vehicles were expressed by Lex Transfleet, which produced the report. It warned of congestion and pollution problems unless there was more co-operation between suppliers. It said a third of Britons shop by telephone or the Internet, a figure which will rise significantly.

Art job for Lady Irvine

Tony Blair yesterday appointed the wife of Lord Chancellor Lord Irvine to an unpaid post as a trustee of the Wallace art collection.

Downing Street said Lady Irvine was suited to the post because she holds an MA degree in the history of art and has "a broad-based background in the visual arts".

Pro-hunting campaigners yesterday lost their latest court bid to block a Bill to outlaw foxhunting in Scotland.

But the way is not yet clear for the Bill to go before the Scottish Parliament, as the campaigners are now considering taking their case to the House of Lords.

The Scottish Countryside Alliance had brought an action at the Court of Session in Edinburgh on behalf of three individuals whose livelihoods depend on hunting with dogs.

The proposed Member's Bill, brought by Labour MSP for Glasgow Cathcart Mike Watson, would outlaw hunting with dogs in Scotland.

The campaign's attempt to block the Bill at the Court of Session last year failed after judges rejected the interim interdict they sought.

The interdict would have effectively blocked the Protection of Wild Mammals (Scotland) Bill, which Lord Watson hopes to put before Parliament later this year.

After their attempt to bring an interdict failed, the campaign put their case before Appeal Court judges last year - but in the rulings issued today two judges decided against the pro-hunting group, with one ruling for them.

In his ruling, the Lord President Lord Rodger said he had heard full legal submissions, and "concluded that the petitioner's case is unsound. That being so, it appears that an interim interdict would serve no legitimate purpose".

He backed the earlier legal ruling, as did Lord Prosser. Lord Morison's opinion supported the petitioners.

The Alliance had also argued that its action was intended to strengthen rules regulating lobbying at the Parliament.

They had questioned whether Lord Watson had breached parliamentary rules in accepting support from anti-hunting campaigners when drawing up his draft Bill.

Another hearing will be held at the Court of Session tomorrow after the petitioners indicated they may wish to take their case to the House of Lords.

Lord Watson said after the hearing: "I am delighted that I have been cleared for the third time of any wrongdoing.

"I am dismayed that the Countryside Alliance, in whose name this case is being brought, are wanting further time to go the House of Lords.

"To go to the House of Lords would be vexatious, but I am pleased to have had a partial victory."

He said he was unable at this stage to say when his Bill would now go before MSPs, whom he says back it by a clear majority.

He claimed the Alliance had only gone to court to delay the case, adding: "I don't think that is the purpose the courts are for."

Les Ward, of Advocates for Animals said: "Now it is time for a Bill to be debated in the Scottish Parliament, so the brutal and barbaric bloodsport of hunting with dogs can be brought to an end."

Sci-fi fans trash Star Wars movie

Anthony Barnes, Showbusiness Correspondent, PA News

World-wide blockbuster The Phantom Menace has been branded an intergalactic flop by movie buffs who today voted it worst film of the year.

Sci-fi fans handed out a string of dubious honours to the film, rubbishing the poor acting, embarrassing characters and daft haircuts.

But the poll, published in SFX magazine today, gave director George Lucas some consolation, with his Star Wars prequel being voted second best film of 1999, behind Keanu Reeves' hit The Matrix.

The Phantom Menace was an instant box office hit taking a colossal £7.5 million on its opening weekend, but many were disappointed at the lack of plot and reliance on computer effects.

And the unhappiness is reflected in the annual awards of SFX, Europe's best-selling sci-fi magazine, which ranks the film as the second most embarrassing thing of the year.

Floppy-eared Jar Jar Binks, the bumbling computer-generated character from the film, topped the category.

Ewan McGregor's plaited pony tail as Obi-Wan Kenobi earned him second place in the silliest haircut chart, one of four entries for the film. Also mentioned were Ray Parks (who played Darth Maul), Jake Lloyd (Anakin Skywalker) and Natalie Portman (Queen Amidala).

The Keanu Reeves award for wooden acting was won by Reeves himself, but McGregor, Lloyd and Portman took the next three places with Liam Neeson (as Qui-Gon Jinn) at five and Jar Jar Binks at number seven. The entire cast as a group came in at eight.

Binks was also ranked the worst computer effect while the film as a whole came second.

However, Portman had some good news after taking the best movie actress title for her role as the child queen.

Readers showed how much affection they had for the original films in the space saga by voting Star Wars and The Empire Strikes Back at numbers one and two of their top movies of all time, with Return Of The Jedi at number 10.

SFX editor Dave Golder said: "The Phantom Menace may now be the biggest grossing film of all time, but it seems that only the really juvenile audience liked it.

"Fans who have been championing the Star Wars films for over 20 years felt betrayed by what they saw as a kids movie.

"The real proof of its success or failure may only be measured when Episode Two comes out - audiences may be more wary now they've seen how poor the prequel was."

BBC2 show Buffy The Vampire Slayer was one of the major success stories of the poll.

Star Sarah Michelle Gellar was voted best TV actress and sexiest woman for her role as the feisty heroine in the series.

Her co-star David Boreanaz was sexiest man and show colleague Anthony Head - former Gold Blend commercial actor - was runner-up, beating stars like Keanu Reeves and David Duchovny.

Buffy was voted best TV show of the year and of all time.

Councils to pioneer electronic voting

Chris Mead, PA News

Touch key electronic voting will be used for the first time in British elections in the May 4 council contests, it was disclosed today.

The Home Office named 35 authorities given the go-ahead to carry out experiments in poll procedures in a bid to boost flagging turnout.

Electronic voting will be tried out at Bury, Salford, Stratford-on-Avon and Warrington.

Polling in Watford, Hertfordshire, will be on Saturday May 6 and Sunday May 7 instead of the traditional Thursday.

Watford is also being allowed to provide a free election address delivery for parties.

The absence of such a facility in the capital has threatened the contests for London's Mayor and Assembly with Tories and Liberal Democrats threatening to block crucial election rules as a protest in the Lords next week.

A number of areas, in addition to London, will be opening polling stations before May 4 to allow those unable to make it on the day to vote early.

Also in the capital and some other areas traditional ballot papers will be used but they will be counted electronically in a bid to speed the process.

Labour's Sir Jeremy Beecham, Local Government Association chairman, commented: "We are delighted local authorities are taking the initiative with a variety of schemes which we hope will encourage more people to vote.

"Increasing turnout at local elections is crucial if we are to promote the value and importance of local democracy so that more people are involved in shaping the future of their communities."

Some of the experiments cover the whole council area while others only apply to some wards.

Authorities taking part in experiments - subject to passage of the Representation of the People Bill currently before Parliament - are:

 Electronic voting: Bury, Salford, Stratford-on-Avon, Warrington.
 Early Voting: Blackburn and Darwen, Blackpool, Chester, Coventry, Kingston-upon-Hull, Knowsley, Manchester, Norwich, Pendle, Plymouth, Redditch, St Helens, Stoke-on-Trent, Sunderland, Telford and Wrekin and Watford.
 Electronic counting: Broxbourne, Bury and Three Rivers.
 Extending postal vote entitlement: Amber Valley, Eastleigh, Gloucester and Milton Keynes.
 All postal ballot: Bolton, Doncaster, Gateshead, Norwich, Salford, Stevenage, Swindon and Wigan.
 Extending voting hours: Leeds and Mole Valley.
 Mobile voting facility: Norwich, Sunderland, Watford and Windsor and Maidenhead.
 Weekend voting: Watford.
 Freepost delivery of election addresses: Watford.

fields.headline: British firms on bribery charges
fields.standfirst: £1.2m allegedly paid to head of dam project in Lesotho
fields.trailText: Three British companies are to be prosecuted next May in the world's biggest case of alleged overseas aid bribery, involving a £1bn project funded by taxpayers from Britain, France, Canada, Germany, Italy and Sweden.
fields.body:
Three British companies are to be prosecuted next May in the world's biggest case of alleged overseas aid bribery, involving a £1bn project funded by taxpayers from Britain, France, Canada, Germany, Italy and Sweden.

The prosecution involving a hydro-electric dam project in Lesotho in southern Africa follows the arrest of its chief executive after allegations that he accepted £1.2m in bribes over a decade from firms building the scheme.

One British company, Gibb Ltd - formerly Sir Alexander Gibb and Partners - based in Reading, has been charged with bribery and corruption. Two others, Balfour Beatty and Kier International, have been charged as members of two consortiums, the Lesotho Highlands Project Contractors and the Highlands Water Venture, which built the scheme.

All three companies strenuously deny the charges. A spokesman for Balfour Beatty said yesterday that the lead finance company in its consortiums was run by the French company, Spie Batignolles. "We and all the contractors in the consortium on the scheme strenuously deny any involvement in this. As far as we are concerned all the procedures were rigorously applied."

The allegations come at an embarrassing time for the British government because Tony Blair has backed an application for a £200m export guarantee from Balfour Beatty to head the consortium to build the controversial Ilisu dam in Turkey. This is opposed by the Arab League, human rights groups and environmentalists, as well as three cabinet colleagues. Balfour Beatty was also named last week by the department of environment as part of a consortium for reconstruction contracts after the Turkish earthquakes last year.

Sixteen bribery and corruption charges have been laid against the companies in the court action which followed the seizure of Swiss bank records.

These were handed over to Lesotho's director of public prosecutions by the Swiss authorities to pursue criminal charges against Masupha Sole, former chief executive officer of the project.

The companies charged are Acrtes International (Canadian); Coyne et Bellier, Sogreah, Spie Batignolles and Dumez International (all French); ABB and Lahmeyer International (German); Abb (Swedish); Universal Development Corporation and Electro Power Corporation (Panamanian); Associated Consultants and Project Managers (Lesotho) and Sir Alexander Gibb and Partners (British).

Highland Water Venture and Lesotho Highlands Project Contractors were also charged. They include British firms.

The World Bank, which has a £100m stake in the project, and the European Union have agreed to part-finance the prosecution of the companies - which face being barred from World Bank projects if found guilty.

Charges against Mr Sole alleged he took bribes in French francs, Canadian dollars, deutschmarks and South African rand.

The disclosure of the charges against the companies yesterday was an embarrassment to Vivien Brown, chief executive of the department of trade and industry's export credit guarantee department, which underwrote the British companies behind the project.

Only last week Mr Brown denied to MPs on the Commons international development select committee that the companies had been charged at all. He told Piara Khabra, Labour MP for Ealing, Southall: "It is not true that Balfour Beatty have been prosecuted.

"There are inquiries which are being undertaken by the Lesotho authorities at present into the way in which business was procured."

webTitle: Report casts new doubt on living wills

fields.headline: Report casts new doubt on living wills
fields.standfirst:
International Working Party Report on the Vegetative State
Euthanasia.com
fields.trailText: A young woman who had told her family that she would rather die than live in a persistent vegetative state, changed her opinion completely after a car accident left her with such severe brain damage that doctors wrongly thought she was unaware of the world around her and applied to the courts to withdraw feeding.
fields.body:
A young woman who had told her family that she would rather die than live in a persistent vegetative state, changed her opinion completely after a car accident left her with such severe brain damage that doctors wrongly thought she was unaware of the world around her and applied to the courts to withdraw feeding.

The life of Ms X - her identity has not been disclosed - was reportedly saved by Tom McMillan, a clinical neuropsychologist at Glasgow university, who devised tests to establish whether she had any level of understanding.

He found a way of communicating with Ms X and discovered that in spite of her very low quality of life, she wanted to live.

Prof McMillan says his work with the patient, revealed in the week that the Scottish parliament is debating new legislation on euthanasia and the mentally incapacitated, shows the danger of "living wills".

Ms X was 22 when she was badly injured in a car accident. For months it was thought she was in a persistent vegetative state - the same condition as that suffered by Tony Bland after the Hillsborough football stadium disaster.

Mr Bland's family and the hospital where he was being treated successfully applied to the courts to stop tube-feeding him and he died.

"If you do a poll and ask people how they would feel, usually they say they would prefer to die. When they make a living will, that is what people usually say.

"But once somebody is disabled, their point of view can be completely different. Their interests and motivations have become very different," he said.

The case is likely to stoke the controversy caused by guidelines released by the British Medical Association last year, which suggested that doctors, together with families, could make decisions about when to stop the treatment of a patient.

After four or five months, it was thought that Ms X could move a limb or open or shut an eye in response to a request. But doctors felt her cognitive functioning was only just above PVS level.

"The weight of medical opinion in this case was that feeding should be terminated," said Prof McMillan.

Her family said that she had, in effect, given a "living will" when they had discussed the Bland case. They assumed she would not want to go on living.

Prof McMillan was called in to find out how much awareness Ms X had. He found that she could press a buzzer with her knuckles and he devised a series of questions, with yes or no answers, that established her level of understanding and her will to live.

Prof McMillan feels that an independent neuropsychological assessment of any patient in a similar condition and where the will to live is in doubt should be mandatory.

In the light of this case, he says, "it is difficult to maintain an argument that it is for the doctor to decide where the line should be drawn."

His first assessment of Ms X was published in the journal Brain Injury in 1996. Prof McMillan has now re-assessed his patient and found significant improvements in her abilities, even though her quality of life to most people would appear very poor.

She can now speak, although neither well nor loudly, she has limited vision and limited movement in her right arm. She is totally dependent on 24-hour nursing care.

But, writes Prof McMillan in a recent edition of Brain Injury, "despite greater insight into her condition, low mood and pain, it is of note that she continues to state that she wishes to continue living.

"Her consistent wish to live post-injury supports the view that beliefs which are common pre-injury and may be expressed [in a living will] can change radically after brain damage.

A bill now before the Scottish parliament is designed to clarify legal and medical issues around the treatment of people who do not have the mental capacity to make decisions for themselves. An amendment which would forbid the stopping of food or fluid with the express intent to cause death has been proposed.

webTitle: Man held over doctor's acid death

fields.headline: Man held over doctor's acid death
fields.trailText: Police last night arrested the former boyfriend of a hospital doctor, Karenina Longe, who died in agony 10 days ago after swallowing sulphuric acid.
fields.body:
Police last night arrested the former boyfriend of a hospital doctor, Karenina Longe, who died in agony 10 days ago after swallowing sulphuric acid.

Andrew Gardiner, who is 40 and unemployed, walked into a London police station with a solicitor and was later taken to the West Midlands for questioning.

The move came shortly after an announcement by West Midlands detectives that the case was being treated as a murder inquiry, following a postmortem and other checks.

Relatives of the doctor, who was 27 and had dual British and Zimbabwean nationality, had earlier appealed to Mr Gardiner to come forward, after attempts to contact him by the West Midlands police were unsuccessful.

Dr Longe died on February 6 at Heartlands hospital in Birmingham, where she was a senior house officer, after paramedics found her unconscious at a rented house in the city's Sheldon district which she had shared with Mr Gardiner.

Police said that she had moved into a hospital flat earlier in the week, after the couple's 18-month relationship began to break up.

She had called back on the day of her death to collect some belongings.

Mr Gardiner, who is originally from Zimbabwe and has a son aged 15 from a previous relationship, had not been traced since calling the ambulance.

He had previously worked for the blood transfusion service and moved to the house in Birmingham in September last year.

Detectives said after the death that the acid was thought to be drain-cleaning fluid, obtainable from hardware stores.

They said a quantity of drain-cleaner had been found in the house and cups and glasses had been taken away for examination.

fields.headline: British PoWs sue Japanese firm
fields.trailText: British former prisoners of war are to sue a Japanese multinational firm for millions of pounds in compensation over their suffering as slave labourers more than 50 years ago.
fields.body:
British former prisoners of war are to sue a Japanese multinational firm for millions of pounds in compensation over their suffering as slave labourers more than 50 years ago.

Campaigners disclosed yesterday that they are exploiting a new Californian law which for the first time allows victims to sue industrial conglomerates with holdings in the state.

Lawyers for the ex-prisoners will fly to Los Angeles today. They will be joined on Saturday by Arthur Titherington, 78, of the Japanese Labour Camps Survivors Association, who worked for three years in a Japanese copper mine.

Nearly 430 out of the 523 British military personnel at the mine, operated by Nippon Mining, died from ill-treatment. Eighteen other survivors are believed to be still alive.

The action - due to open next week - is against Nippon's successor, the Tokyo-based Japan Energy Corporation. The campaigners' British lawyers are confident they can prove Californian courts have jurisdiction over the company.

The action draws on the precedent of last year's announcement by the German government and a group of the country's largest companies of a £3.2bn compensation package for civilian victims of second world war labour camps.

With 210 subsidiaries and 92 affiliates, Japan Energy is one of Asia's biggest companies. It had 1998 sales of £9bn across sectors from petrochemicals to pharmaceuticals. Its link with Nippon is detailed on a company website.

Mr Titherington said British PoWs endured punishment beatings for failing to fulfill production quotas.

He said: "We worked a 14-hour day in cramped, horrible conditions and had to climb 2,000 steps at the end of it. Men took their own lives. We starved and we were beaten to provide profits for this company. Japan Energy is directly responsible for systematically torturing hundreds of men and profiting from their labour. This is perhaps our last chance to bring them to book."

fields.headline: Pacific rower facing supplies crisis
fields.trailText: A disabled British rower attempting to cross the Pacific Ocean alone could soon be lost at sea unless emergency supplies are shipped to him, his support team said yesterday.
fields.body:
A disabled British rower attempting to cross the Pacific Ocean alone could soon be lost at sea unless emergency supplies are shipped to him, his support team said yesterday.

Andrew Halsey, 42, who set off from California in his 27ft boat, the Brittany Rose, in July last year, vowed to row the 8,000 miles to Sydney, Australia - even if it killed him.

After seven months at sea, he has covered 6,000 miles - but because of bad weather, 4,000 of them have been spent going round in circles.

Family and friends now fear that Mr Halsey, who suffers from epilepsy and has a disabled knee, will refuse the assistance which will enable him to reach land alive.

Kenneth Crutchlow, the executive director of the Ocean Rowing Society, said: "Andrew is very determined and is obviously not going to give up. He has nothing much to come back for. I think he's prepared to row into the sunset."

Mr Crutchlow said Mr Halsey, a divorcee, is just weeks away from being lost from the US coastguard's tracking system and left without enough supplies to reach land.

The society and Mr Halsey's sponsors, Le Shark, appealed for help in raising £15,000 to send a ship with food and new tracking beacons to the Brittany Rose to enable Mr Halsey to continue his bid to be the first disabled man to cross the Pacific unassisted.

Mr Crutchlow said: "The reality is that, on or about April 15, Andrew will run out of supplies. Also his third and last tracking beacon will run out of battery power and cease to transmit his location."

There has been no contact with Mr Halsey, a Londoner, since January 1. He has had four epileptic fits since July.

On his trip he has sent three emergency signals by accident, prompting ships to be diverted to help him. On the third occasion he turned down supplies and simply said: "I will see you in Australia."

The US coastguard will not assist him unless he sends a distress signal, Mr Crutchlow added.

Mr Halsey's family issued a statement, which said: "We have confidence that with his experience and determination he will endeavour to complete his ambition. He has reassured his mother on several occasions that he would end his journey should he consider his life to be in danger."

fields.headline: 'Hostage' inmate's court plea
fields.trailText: A notorious category A prisoner who has spent the last 26 years in jail - 22 years of them in solitary confinement - yesterday told a court of his life of purgatory among inmates including "our very own Hannibal the Cannibal".
fields.body:
A notorious category A prisoner who has spent the last 26 years in jail - 22 years of them in solitary confinement - yesterday told a court of his life of purgatory among inmates including "our very own Hannibal the Cannibal".

Charles Bronson, 47, who was originally jailed for seven years for armed robbery in 1974, said he felt "dehumanised" by a prison system which forced him to live in a windowless cell for 23 hours a day.

He told Luton crown court that if he were an animal the RSPCA would be fighting his case for him.

Sporting a shaven head and eight-inch moustache and wearing sunglasses, Bronson spelled out details of prison life and told of fellow inmates such as "our very own Hannibal the Cannibal".

Bronson, from Luton, Bedfordshire, is accused of false imprisonment and criminal damage. It is alleged that he took teacher Phil Danielson, 37, of Bridlington, East Yorkshire, hostage for 44 hours at Hull prison in January 1999.

A jury of seven men and five women has heard that Bronson tied a skipping rope around Mr Danielson's neck and pulled him around the jail.

Bronson, who is currently held in Woodhill prison, in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, denies both charges. He says he was forced to take Mr Danielson hostage as a result of being under duress.

He was cleared of making threats to kill Mr Danielson and of assault after Judge Ronald Moss ruled there was insufficient evidence.

Bronson said: "I first came to prison when I was 21 in 1974. I have been in prison ever since, barring three months. We are talking about 26 years I have served.

"Twenty-two years of that have been in solitary confinement. At times I feel like I am dehumanised. I get panic attacks when I am with people."

Bronson said his family, with the exception of his elderly mother Eira Peterson, were strangers to him.

"At the moment my bed is a concrete slab four and a half inches from the ground. Never mind what you read in papers that we all have televisions in our cells. I haven't had one for 20 years. I don't even know how to work one," he said.

He added that he was not a rapist nor a paedophile and had never been convicted of killing. "I probably deserve most of what has happened to me. But I don't deserve this," he said.

Bronson, a former unlicensed boxer, told the jury that he spent his time exercising and writing. He said he held several world titles for press-ups and sit-ups and was a published poet. He said he sent a poem a week to his mother.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Blair is worst among equals
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: For such a strict disciplinarian, Tony Blair must have felt a slight shudder yesterday when it was confirmed that he has slipped to near the bottom of the class.
fields.body:
For such a strict disciplinarian, Tony Blair must have felt a slight shudder yesterday when it was confirmed that he has slipped to near the bottom of the class.

Official figures released by the House of Commons library revealed that the prime minister has the worst voting record of the 20 cabinet ministers who sit in the Commons.

Since the Queen's speech in November, Mr Blair has only managed to turn up for 5% of votes, ranking him in 622nd place out of 659 MPs.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has a similar record, although he has the excuse of many overseas trips.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, despite his reputation as a Westminster obsessive, turned up for a mere 16% of votes. Margaret Beckett turned up for 87% of votes, though as Commons leader this is hardly surprising. However, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, who has had to cope with the winter flu crisis, found time to appear in 64% of votes. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, has one of the cabinet's more impressive records, turning up for 53% of votes.

The prime minister's defenders will say that he cannot be expected to vote regularly because he has endless meetings to attend at night and numerous red boxes to devour. Most Commons votes take place after 10pm.

But opponents will say that his dismal voting record, which is far lower than the records of Margaret Thatcher and John Major, shows that the prime minister is indifferent about the workings of parliament.

Bob Marshall-Andrews, the maverick Labour MP for Medway who is close to the top of the class with an 85% voting record, said he was shocked by the prime minister's record.

He understood why Mr Cook had such a bad record, but said of other ministers: "It is very regrettable that senior ministers do not attend the House of Commons, to which they are ultimately responsible. If ministers do not attend parliament, they lose touch with democracy."

William Hague, who has more time on his hands than the cabinet, only managed to turn up for 27% of votes, slipping to 586th place. Top of the class was the Labour MP for Bolton SE, Brian Iddon, who attended 98% of votes.

There were 19 MPs at the bottom of the class, with a voting record of 0%. They included the Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, and his deputy, the Liberal Democrat, Jim Wallace. Ron Davies, the former Welsh secretary who now sits in the Welsh assembly, also failed to vote.

Cabinet's worst voters (participation rate and ranking out of 659 MPs)

Tony Blair, prime minister: 5% 622

Robin Cook, foreign secretary: 5% 622

Gordon Brown, chancellor: 16% 606

Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary: 18% 602

Clare Short, international development secretary: 25% 594

Shadow cabinet's worst voters

William Hague: 27% 586

Michael Ancram, Tory chairman: 33% 573

Archie Norman, shadow transport secretary: 40% 534

Peter Ainsworth, shadow culture secretary: 40% 534

Michael Portillo, shadow chancellor: 43% 520 (only took seat in December)

webTitle: Boy, 12, banned from town centre for bad behaviour

fields.headline: Boy, 12, banned from town centre for bad behaviour
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old boy yesterday became the youngest person in England or Wales to be made the subject of an anti-social behaviour order.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy yesterday became the youngest person in England or Wales to be made the subject of an anti-social behaviour order.

The boy and his 15-year-old brother were banned from the centre of the Somerset resort of Weston-super-Mare for two years after admitting causing harassment, alarm and distress to residents.

But magistrates turned down an application by North Somerset council for a 12-hour night curfew on the two boys who live on a council estate on the edge of the town.

The two boys, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, laughed during protracted legal argument as their solicitor called for the case to be thrown out.

Asked if they understood the orders that had been made the younger of the two replied "yep" before leaving the court with his mother and a social worker.

North Somerset council served summonses on the boys before Christmas following complaints from shop security staff, shop assistants and local people in Weston. Two previous hearings were adjourned, the last at the end of last month when the younger boy complained of toothache and was taken from court for treatment.

Eileen Means, the council's director of housing and social services, said North Somerset had sought the banning order after many complaints.

She hoped the order would help the boys "turn the corner" and avoid further trouble.

The orders were introduced in April last year as part of the 1998 crime and disorder act. A dozen orders are thought to have been imposed to date.

fields.headline: Pinochet suffering brain damage
fields.standfirst:
It is our view that Senator Pinochet would not be mentally capable of meaningful participation in a trial.

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The home office last night demanded an explanation from the Spanish  government into how General Augusto Pinochet's confidential medical report was leaked to newspapers in Spain and Chile.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso  and Adela Gooch  in Madrid Paul Kelso and Adela Gooch in Madrid
fields.body:
The home office last night demanded an explanation from the Spanish government into how General Augusto Pinochet's confidential medical report was leaked to newspapers in Spain and Chile.

The report concludes that the former Chilean dictator suffers from brain damage brought on by multiple strokes and is unfit to stand trial on charges of human rights abuses. It was released to two Spanish newspapers by the foreign ministry of Spain within hours of it being delivered.

A newspaper in the Chilean capital of Santiago reported that it had been given extracts by the Chilean government. Chile was not an official recipient of the report, prompting sources close to the case to suggest that "supposed friends of the general's may be playing games".

The panel of British doctors who examined the former dictator in London last month said in part: "It is our view that Senator Pinochet would not at the present be mentally capable of meaningful participation in a trial. We base this opinion on:
 Memory deficit for both recent and remote events
Limited ability to understand complex sentences and questions owing to memory impairment, and consequent inability to process verbal information appropriately
Impaired ability to express himself audibly, succinctly and relevantly
 Easy fatiguability."

His condition has appreciably worsened during his time in Britain, and he has suffered a number of falls in the garden of the house on the Wentworth estate in Surrey where he has been under house arrest since being detained in London 16 months ago for possible extradition after a Spanish court issued a warrant alleging human rights violations during his 1973-90 rule in Chile.

While the general is homesick and bored, the doctors' report says he is not currently depressed and that his sense of humour "remains intact".

In a statement the home office said it had asked the Spanish authorities, through the crown prosecution service, their legal representatives, for information regarding how the conclusions of the report came to be disclosed.

The general's lawyers have written to the home secretary and the attorney general requesting an investigation into the leak, a potential contempt of court.

Earlier this week the high court ruled that the four states with outstanding extradition warrants against the general, Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland, were entitled to see the report, which carries the conclusions of the three doctors who examined the general last month.

The report, ordered by home secretary Jack Straw to determine whether the general was fit to be extradited to Spain, was sent to Madrid in strict confidence and then passed to the investigating magistrate who first ordered the general's arrest, Baltasar Garzon.

The judge sent a letter yesterday to the national court in Madrid denying that had anything to do with a leak.

"It was a case of the foreign ministry leaking it before Garzon had a chance to do so," said one source.

Many of the documents in the Pinochet case have found their way into Spanish newspapers. An official at Belgium's foreign ministry, which initiated the hearing that led to the release of the medical papers, said last night his ministry "regretted" the breach of confidentiality.

He said a doctor appointed by a Belgian judge to examine the medical findings would report to the foreign ministry within days. The four countries have until Tuesday to pass comments to Mr Straw.

Human rights groups appeared split. "If the conclusions are correct then Gen Pinochet should not stand trial and should be returned to Chile," said Reid Brody of Human Rights Watch.

But other doctors might produce different conclusions: "We would hope that the states study the actual results of the tests and determine whether the proper legal standards have been applied."

Amnesty International demanded that a final decision on the general's fitness to stand trial be made in court.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: "The lyrics of the Plastic People include rude expressions and nonsense whose artistic and formal value is absolutely insignificant." Forget the Pistols, or the Stones, they didn't have the Czechoslovakian Ministry of Culture giving them such enthusiastic reviews. As Document - Happy Hearts Club Banned (8pm, R4) explains, The Plastic People Of The Universe were just about the most dangerous force in underground rock of all time, continually hounded by the secret police, jailed, recording in Vaclav Havel's home and releasing Zappa/Velvet Underground-influenced albums that were illegal to own.

fields.headline: Prescott fights to retain empire
fields.standfirst:
Close Blair aide to coordinate regional reforms

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott was fighting hard to retain the rump of his sprawling ministerial empire last night after Downing Street sent in one of the prime minister's closest aides to coordinate sweeping reforms of the government machine in the regions.
fields.body:
John Prescott was fighting hard to retain the rump of his sprawling ministerial empire last night after Downing Street sent in one of the prime minister's closest aides to coordinate sweeping reforms of the government machine in the regions.

Following growing disquiet about botched-up initiatives, Tony Blair dispatched his long-standing friend Lord Falconer to the department of the environment, transport and the regions to help lead the initiative alongside the deputy prime minister.

Mr Prescott fought a strong rearguard action to protect the department from erosion, and has been given ultimate responsibility for a so-called "bureaucracy busting" unit, although Lord Falconer, a cabinet office minister, will have day-to-day control.

The move followed a cabinet office report which exposed a myriad of confused local government initiatives and which saw No 10 come close to accepting that Whitehall had lost control in the regions.

The report painted a bureaucratic nightmare of overlapping, duplicating regional initiatives, and excessive form-filling undertaken by small civil service empires which rarely communicated.

This red tape quagmire meant the poorest communities, desperate for aid, were being badly let down. Lord Falconer's installation will be interpreted as an attempt to placate restless backbenchers in Labour's heartlands, who believed the government's image is being tarnished by Whitehall's inability to coordinate anti-poverty and inner city regeneration programmes.

Tories immediately claimed the move was a further rebuff for Mr Prescott, following the decision late last year to give Lord Macdonald a bigger role in coordinating transport policy. Archie Norman, the new shadow environment secretary, claimed the deputy prime minister was being sidelined from another key area, urban regeneration and regional policy, by "the minister for the dome of all things".

Downing Street has been stung by charges from local councils and new regional development agencies that the government is wasting millions on overlapping regeneration, health, education and job-creation schemes.

The damning new report from the performance and innovation unit at the cabinet office, which underpinned the new initiative, outlined a catalogue of failure.

It said: "There are too many government initiatives causing confusion ... not enough coordination, and too much time spent negotiating the system, rather than delivering."

While admitting the report was "hard hitting", Downing Street said it supported the recommendation for stronger and higher profile government offices in the eight regions, with better ministerial coordination of programmes.

Downing Street says all big Whitehall departments - principally environment and the regions, education, health, and the home office - will shortly have to report to the new unit before launching any new initiatives. Located in Mr Prescott's department, and run by Lord Falconer and an inter-departmental committee, it will report to the deputy prime minister.

Yesterday Mr Prescott acknowledged that some of the complaints about disjointed government had come from the eight development agencies, chaired by businessmen with local councillors often taking a back seat. But normally loyal Labour backbenchers have begun publicly voicing concern about delayed regeneration programmes and disillusioned voters caught between Whitehall bureaucracy.

Ministers plan to strengthen the role of the eight regional offices, while the development agencies - with a collective budget of around £800m - could be allocated more cash in a forthcoming comprehensive spending review.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Farren Blackburn: Director
fields.trailText: Whatever else, the last couple of weeks have certainly been manic - having won Sky's Cut Short award for my short film Going For Broke, I've gone from just another struggling British director to an award-winner with a feature in the pipeline in the space of a fortnight.
fields.body:
Whatever else, the last couple of weeks have certainly been manic - having won Sky's Cut Short award for my short film Going For Broke, I've gone from just another struggling British director to an award-winner with a feature in the pipeline in the space of a fortnight.

Which, needless to say, is great (although it goes to show how arbitrary these things can be: it's like waiting for buses - nothing happens for ages and then everything kicks off at once). As you can probably imagine, right now it's simply a question of getting my head around things. Because, while the award is nice, where it really pays off is legitimising what I do: if you spend a lot of time trying to get your film-making career off the ground, you wonder whether you can actually call yourself a director. And hopefully I've at least got past that particular landmark now.

I spent six or seven years making short films without knowing if they'd ever see the light of day, which I guess means I'm hovering over the fine line dividing commitment and insanity. In that sense, I think the diversity of my background helped; I started out as a professional footballer, before doing a degree a Theology, which means I've got a sense of perspective both in terms of career and the type of projects I want to do. If I'd just gone and done a Media Studies course somewhere, I may well have just ended up making yet another Reservoir Dogs, but instead, I'm working on a genuinely original idea which I'm really happy with. And all I've got to do is deliver a red-hot script to a deadline for the first time in my life. So, no pressure there, then.

Farren Blackburn's Going For Broke will be shown as part of Cut Short: The Final Five, on Sky MovieMax, 8pm, Saturday 26 February

webTitle: Which of these films will spawn a sequel?

fields.headline: Which of these films will spawn a sequel?
fields.standfirst: The price is right
fields.trailText: Spiderman 1/7
fields.body:
Spiderman 1/7

Wonder Woman 2/7

The Incredible Shrinking Man 2/5

Mystery Men 2/5

The third (and final) chapter in the slasher series Scream has been a box-office hit in the US. It even has a chance to out-gross (no pun intended) its predecessors. It could now be responsible for the re-invention of the sequel genre as a full-bodied cinema treat.

Plus the market is changing: the direct-to-video genre is dead, squeezing out the funding for cheap action films and other exploitation titles. That points the way to getting a franchise and building it up.

"Already in the last 12 months we've heard talk about Blade 2, Under Siege 3, The Mummy 2, American Pie 2, Total Recall 2, Jurassic Park 3 even another Nutty Professor", says Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler. "But looking at films that haven't even been released, and trying to work out if they are going to be successful is tricky", he adds.

"Spiderman has potential with Sam Raimi at the helm. He's already displayed his sequel prowess, having done five films for the Hercules franchise and two Evil Deads. He has the form. The word is that Sony are looking for more franchise films, so Spiderman could go the same way as the Batman films."

"Another with form is Eddie Murphy - he's used to playing screen characters more than once. In Shrinking Man he plays Fred Wolf in this remake of the 1957 flick. An interesting contender."

"There's certainly some hype surrounding Wonder Woman. I think that if Sandra Bullock plays her, she will make it big! And those famous star-spangled outfits will stay on our screens", he adds.

"Mystery Men has good breeding for this sort of thing. Directed by award-winning commercial director Kinka Usher, it includes Oscar winner Geoffrey Rush, and two more nominees, Greg Kinnear (As Good As It Gets) and William H. Macy (Fargo)."

fields.headline: Merciful release
fields.standfirst: In 1969, the Kray brothers were sentenced to a minimum of 30 years in prison. Ronnie is dead, but Reggie is still paying his debt to society.  Piers Hernu  thinks a new documentary proves he should now be paroled
fields.trailText: Next month is an important one for Reggie Kray. On March 5, 1969, Judge Melford Stevenson sentenced both him and his brother Ronnie to serve "a minimum of 30 years" for murder.
fields.body:
Next month is an important one for Reggie Kray. On March 5, 1969, Judge Melford Stevenson sentenced both him and his brother Ronnie to serve "a minimum of 30 years" for murder.

Twenty-six years later in 1995 Ronnie Kray died in Broadmoor mental hospital. Today, after nearly 31 years, Reggie is still serving time in Waylands prison in Norfolk, a frightening high-security red-brick fortress - I know it's frightening because I've done time there. It was actually only an about an hour but that was long enough.

Since Reggie contributes a monthly column to men's magazine Front, which I edit, I felt it only reasonable to pay him a visit last year. I found him to be polite, sane, opinionated and a voracious consumer of choc ices from the prison shop. Including remand, Reggie has now been eating prison food for nearly 32 years - next month the parole board meets to decide his fate.

When Mike Tyson was interviewed in the ring by Sky Sports following his recent pummelling of Julius Francis, his first words were: "I'd like to thank Reginald Kray." The precise reason for Tyson's gratitude remains unclear, but what is clear is that, for the government, the problem of Reggie Kray and what to do with him is one that simply refuses to go away. At this very moment, for instance, one of the most popular bands in Britain, the aptly named Fun Lovin' Criminals, are slaving away over a mixing desk producing songs penned by Reggie Kray - tracks which, when released, will only add to the clamour for justice in the form of Reggie Kray's release. So what part does television play in the debate?

Tonight (10pm, Channel 4) we have Reggie Kray - 30 Years And Rising - an hour-long documentary which in its balanced assessment of the Krays stands in stark contrast to the two hour-long documentaries (The Krays - Unfinished Business) shown on ITV in January. In these, by means of a heady cocktail of dramatisation, speculation, eerily complete access to police, prison officers and secret files, Carlton contrived to paint a pantomime picture of the Krays so simplistically one-sided as to be laughable.

Now, it would take a hardened cynic indeed to suggest that the makers of that documentary had a hidden agenda in portraying the Krays as such evil psychopaths so near to Reggie's parole hearing. After all, who except the Home Office would want to turn public opinion against him at such a time and have the means, the wherewithal and the motive to do so?

In tonight's documentary, however we see, if not the other side of the story, then at least a genuine attempt at uncovering the truth about the Krays, thereby (and some would say unwisely) allowing viewers to make up their own minds about whether Reggie should remain in prison.

Thus on the one hand, we see Roberta Kray, Reggie's wife of nearly four years, poignantly leafing through the wedding photographs that she has been forbidden by the authorities to show to anyone else or even copy. It is, she points out, just a small example of how the British justice system treats her husband differently to any other prisoner. On the other hand we see a former Kray victim telling us how he was tortured by Ronnie and leaving us in no doubt that he is more than happy for Reggie to remain in prison.

This neatly sums up the pro-Reggie side of tonight's documentary - namely that Reggie, unlike his brother, is sane but continues to carry the can for his brother's actions. Emphasising this point, John Pearson, biographer to the Krays, reads a grisly passage from his book detailing how Reggie came to murder Jack "The Hat" McVitie as a result of a situation instigated by Ronnie.

Confirming this version is first-hand testimony from The Lambrianou brothers who were both handed 15-year sentences for the murder. Tony, a personal friend of mine, tells of the shock of what happened and how he drove the body away in the back seat of his car, while his brother, Chris, punctuates the programme with eloquent accounts of the night in question, prison life and how it can change a man. Perhaps the most relevant and objective opinion expressed in the show comes from the obligatory egghead in the form of consultant psychiatrist Trevor Turner who, having professionally assessed Reggie, confirms that he is a long way from mad and is in fact simply an old man in his late 60s who is becoming hard of hearing.

The last word, though, should go to Reggie's wife Roberta, who I phoned last night for a quote and who seems saner than the lot of us: "Justice should mean that everyone is equal in the eyes of the law - it is wrong to have one rule for the majority of people and another one for Reggie Kray." So, should Reggie, having spent nearly 32 years inside for murder, be released from prison? The decision is yours - except that it's not.

When Mike Tyson was interviewed in the ring by Sky Sports following his recent pummelling of Julius Francis, his first words were: "I'd like to thank Reginald Kray." The precise reason for Tyson's gratitude remains unclear, but what is clear is that, for the government, the problem of Reggie Kray and what to do with him is one that simply refuses to go away. At this very moment, for instance, one of the most popular bands in Britain, the aptly named Fun Lovin' Criminals, are slaving away over a mixing desk producing songs penned by Reggie Kray - tracks which, when released, will only add to the clamour for justice in the form of Reggie Kray's release. So what part does television play in the debate? Tonight (10pm, Channel 4) we have Reggie Kray - 30 Years And Rising - an hour-long documentary which in its balanced assessment of the Krays stands in stark contrast to the two hour-long documentaries (The Krays - Unfinished Business) shown on ITV in January. In these, by means of a heady cocktail of dramatisation, speculation, eerily complete access to police, prison officers and secret files, Carlton contrived to paint a pantomime picture of the Krays so simplistically one-sided as to be laughable. Now, it would take a hardened cynic indeed to suggest that the makers of that documentary had a hidden agenda in portraying the Krays as such evil psychopaths so near to Reggie's parole hearing. After all, who except the Home Office would want to turn public opinion against him at such a time and have the means, the wherewithal and the motive to do so? In tonight's documentary, however we see, if not the other side of the story, then at least a genuine attempt at uncovering the truth about the Krays, thereby (and some would say unwisely) allowing viewers to make up their own minds about whether Reggie should remain in prison. Thus on the one hand, we see Roberta Kray, Reggie's wife of nearly four years, poignantly leafing through the wedding photographs that she has been forbidden by the authorities to show to anyone else or even copy. It is, she points out, just a small example of how the British justice system treats her husband differently to any other prisoner. On the other hand we see a former Kray victim telling us how he was tortured by Ronnie and leaving us in no doubt that he is more than happy for Reggie to remain in prison. This neatly sums up the pro-Reggie side of tonight's documentary - namely that Reggie, unlike his brother, is sane but continues to carry the can for his brother's actions. Emphasising this point, John Pearson, biographer to the Krays, reads a grisly passage from his book detailing how Reggie came to murder Jack "The Hat" McVitie as a result of a situation instigated by Ronnie. Confirming this version is first-hand testimony from The Lambrianou brothers who were both handed 15-year sentences for the murder. Tony, a personal friend of mine, tells of the shock of what happened and how he drove the body away in the back seat of his car, while his brother, Chris, punctuates the programme with eloquent accounts of the night in question, prison life and how it can change a man. Perhaps the most relevant and objective opinion expressed in the show comes from the obligatory egghead in the form of consultant psychiatrist Trevor Turner who, having professionally assessed Reggie, confirms that he is a long way from mad and is in fact simply an old man in his late 60s who is becoming hard of hearing. The last word, though, should go to Reggie's wife Roberta, who I phoned last night for a quote and who seems saner than the lot of us: "Justice should mean that everyone is equal in the eyes of the law - it is wrong to have one rule for the majority of people and another one for Reggie Kray." So, should Reggie, having spent nearly 32 years inside for murder, be released from prison? The decision is yours - except that it's not.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Planet Rock Profiles: Depeche Mode
fields.body:
Planet Rock Profiles: Depeche Mode

4pm, VH1

This profile pulls no punches as it charts the career of the band who progressed from Basildon electro poppers to Stateside stadium rockers. There's some nice editing as footage of the gnarled rockers is spliced with that of a younger, sprightlier band, before singer Dave Gahan's suicide attempt, heroin addiction, overdose and arrests. Here the singer talks about his Herculean drug intake, and despite highlights from their remarkable run of hit singles, this is no day at the beach.

Godzilla

(Roland Emmerich, 1998)

1.40pm, 8pm, Sky Premier

Tokyo's favourite monster takes a tour of Manhattan in Emmerich's disappointing follow-up to Independence Day. The story is lame and most of the humans - Matthew Broderick's dopey scientist, Maria Pitillo's newshound, Hank Azaria's irksome cameraman - are in urgent need of squashing. But it makes a fine job of trashing New York, and the chase through a stadium full of hatching lizards.

Much Ado About Nothing

(Kenneth Branagh, 1992)

8pm, FilmFour

Sunny, Tuscany-set feelgood Shakespeare that fairly gallops along from the opening scene. The Michael Keaton/Ben Elton take on Dogberry and Verges gets a bit tiresome, but there are plenty of successes: Denzel Washington's noble Duke; a saturnine Keanu Reeves as John the Bastard (that's both name and description); Branagh and Emma Thompson doing verbal GBH to each other as reluctant lovers Benedick and Beatrice.

My Own Private Idaho

(Gus Van Sant, 1991)

10pm, FilmFour

River Phoenix is superb as Mike, a gay hustler given to narcoleptic fits in Van Sant's heartfelt road movie. Mike and mayor's son Scott (Keanu Reeves) set off in search of the latter's wealthy mother: theatrical references to Shakespeare's Henry IV point up the fact that for one the road is a game, for the other, a matter of life and death.

fields.headline: Carry on, doctor
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Perhaps there have been less auspicious moments in British public life to launch a light-hearted medical magazine series entitled Trust Me, I'm A Doctor (BBC2), but it has to be said that they don't spring readily to mind - and there were several occasions during Dr Phil Hammond's latest foray into pop-science infotainment when the programme almost cracked under the weight of inadvertent irony.
fields.body:
Perhaps there have been less auspicious moments in British public life to launch a light-hearted medical magazine series entitled Trust Me, I'm A Doctor (BBC2), but it has to be said that they don't spring readily to mind - and there were several occasions during Dr Phil Hammond's latest foray into pop-science infotainment when the programme almost cracked under the weight of inadvertent irony.

"Patients generally believe that doctors will always act in their best interests", one expert said, explaining the placebo effect. "The key is to convince the patient that whatever you're doing is going to help", said another. Or, as Hammond noted at one point: "There's evidence that the way our doctor behaves has a direct bearing on our health" - and who, in the light of recent events, could possibly argue with that?

Vagaries of scheduling aside, though, episode one was - in an amiable, understated sort of way - a broadly successful attempt to claw back the science of psychoneuroimmunology ("all that mind-over-body stuff", Hammond called it) from the clutches of crystal-brandishing, psychobabbling Californians. There was the requisite larking about - Dr Phil uses the power of suggestion to persuade a bunch of twentysomethings to get blind drunk on orange juice; Dr Phil has pain-inducing machinery strapped to his arms and is conditioned, Pavlov-style, to yelp in agony when a blue light flashes.

But there was more, too: the tale of Barry, for example, an NHS manager from Hull who - alongside chemotherapy treatment - uses often-mocked techniques of visualisation while lying on the sofa in his living room, imagining white blood cells attacking his liver cancer. And in the shower. And doing the dishes. "When I'm washing up of an evening, I'll visualise myself washing the cancer cells away", he said. His cancer is shrinking, and it would be a bravely traditionalist doctor who would conclude that his imaginings didn't have anything at all to do with that.

Still, there was something missing, symptomatic of an increasing proportion of popular science programming: anything approaching an attempt at an explanation. Yes, this is fringe science, and fully formed explanations aren't to be expected, but even where the scientists clearly knew what was going on, it seemed that the viewers weren't supposed to trouble their heads with it. Here's a typical Hammond conclusion, cutting short an experiment indicating that actual pain and anticipated pain cause fairly similar parts of the brain to light up on a brain scan: "So there you have it. Living proof that what we anticipate and what we experience are clearly linked in the brain."

Somehow, that kind of "proof" sounds far more convincing coming from Agent Mulder of The X Files (BBC1), a show in which mind-over-body medicine is frankly old hat, and credulous faith will always have a fair chance in the battle with rationalist doubt, even when the thesis it's trying to defend - as in this episode - is the notion that a Kansas weather forecaster's repressed love for his high-school crush was manifesting itself in extreme weather conditions. Mulder had an explanation as good as some of Hammond's: "Most people will admit that the weather plays a significant role in the way they feel - so who's to say that it doesn't work the other way around?"

The last time Alan Alda was spotted wearing surgical gloves, it was in a tent in Korea, under the auspices of the 4077th M*A*S*H unit. So for those of us who find the proliferating plot strands of ER (C4) quite confusing enough without rogue characters wandering in from other medical dramas, Hawkeye's sudden appearance on the Chicago wards - as new staff member and emergency-room veteran Dr Gabriel Lawrence - came as something of a shock. A shock, too, for Dr Greene, still smarting at having been denied one of Dr Weaver's natty laminated badges setting out her department's core values, who developed one of his all-too-frequent attitude problems at Lawrence's superior knowledge of medical trivia. But Lawrence - the same character that has seen Alda through a long career with barely an alteration - screwed up in the end, failing to spot that a 12-year-old sickle-cell patient also had a Fallopian pregnancy. Maybe all that shelling had done something to his judgment. It seems you just can't trust doctors these days.

fields.headline: Chance or cheat?
fields.standfirst: If life is a lottery, how do you know when your lucky numbers have come up?  Keith Devlin looks at the laws of probability
fields.trailText: If life is a lottery, how do you know when your lucky numbers have come up? Keith Devlin looks at the laws of probability
fields.body:
You're checking this week's lottery numbers in the newspaper: "24, 9, 48, 33, 34, 17."

No, you haven't won this time. You shrug, and don't give the matter any more thought until next week.

"1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6."

"There must be some mistake," you say to yourself. "The person who typed the numbers in must have made an error."

Why don't you believe the numbers this week when last week you had no such qualms? Why are you prepared to accept that the first sequence is a result of pure chance - a random process - but the second one is a result of design?

Mathematically, both the sequences are equally likely. Each has the probability 1 in 49 x 48 x 47 x 46 x 45 x 44. (With the winning sequence picked by putting 49 balls into an urn, numbered 1 to 49, and picking six balls from the urn randomly one after the other, there are 49 equally likely possibilities for the first number chosen, then 48 for the second, and so on.)

However, you feel something is wrong when the second sequence comes up.

Chance or design? The question arises all the time, in different guises. For those engaged in the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (Seti), the task is to find (and identify as such) a radio signal from outer space that is the result of design and not the random electromagnetic output of some star or other heavenly body. For the detective, the problem is to decide which features of the crime scene are simply the result of happenstance and which provide evidence .

Unfortunately, examples like the lottery draw suggest that the standard procedure for computing probabilities, developed by the French mathematicians Blaise Pascal and Pierre de Fermat in the 17th century, is inadequate for determining whether a given sequence of numbers (or a sequence of events) is random or the result of design.

In the 1960s, the Russian mathematician Andrie Kolmogorov came up with a definition of randomness to try to eliminate this problem: a sequence is random if it can't be generated by a set of instructions shorter than the length of the sequence. That is, the most efficient way to specify the sequence is to write it out in its entirety. But this approach doesn't work either.

For example, if I throw a fair die 600 times, each face will come up approximately 100 times. But the probability that each face will come up exactly 100 times is so small that such an event will not occur by chance. I can generate such an outcome by doctoring the results of an actual sequence of 600 throws, and the resulting sequence will be random according to Kolmogorov's definition, but it won't be random. Incidentally, an outcome that is too close to the mathematical probabilities is the red flag that has alerted authorities to a number of cases of data falsification in scientific and medical research.

As American mathematician William Dembski points out in a recent book, no entirely mathematical approach will tell you that a particular outcome is the result of chance. The reason is that, ultimately, design is a question of history - of how the outcome was actually arrived at-not the form of the outcome.

For example, suppose I invite you to my home to watch the weekly lottery program on television. I show you a piece of paper with six numbers written on it, and I offer you a side bet that these numbers will agree with the winning sequence with at most one number different. After the draw is completed, you find that, apart from the final number, my sequence is exactly the same as the one we just saw drawn on the television. Do you pay up? Or do you suspect a rat? I am sure you will conclude that what you just saw was a videotape of the lottery, which I had recorded moments before you arrived, and that I had copied the first five numbers in my sequence directly from the television screen. In other words, you will conclude that the numbers on my paper-although they undoubtedly constitute a random sequence of numbers-are the result not of chance, but design.

Dembski proposes that we forget the exclusively mathematical approach and adopt a hybrid method that combines mathematics with plain old- fashioned common sense. He starts out by stating a basic principle, which he calls the Law of Small Probability (LSP): "Specified events of small probability do not occur by chance."

The outcome of a process, such as repeatedly rolling a die, is specified, Dembski says, if its pattern can be determined in a fashion independent of the process itself. For example, the winning lottery sequence 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is easily determined independently of the actual lottery draw - it is a specified outcome. Thus, by the LSP it cannot occur by chance.

Deciding whether an event is specified often comes down to a matter of human judgment. If you can find a suitable description, you know the event is specified. But you can never be sure that an event is unspecified. The fact that you have not (yet!) found a specification does not mean none exists. In the end, you simply have to take your best shot.

Starting with the LSP, Dembski sets out a four-step process - called the explanatory filter - to decide whether an event is random or the result of design.

The first step is to ask if the event has high probability (HP): Is it something that is likely to occur? If it is, then there is no problem with concluding the outcome is the result of a random process.

For example, the probability is high that a sequence of 50 tosses of a fair coin will result in at least one head. If someone tells you she tossed a fair coin 50 times and heads came up at least once, you are surely not going to doubt her sincerity. If the event does not have high probability, then you subject it to the next level of the filter: does it have intermediate probability (IP)?

An event that does not have HP has IP if, in the prevailing circumstances, it can reasonably be expected to occur. (For example, rolling a pair of sixes when playing craps is an event of IP.)

If the event in question does have IP, then you conclude that the event occurred by chance.

If the event does not have IP, then you move to the third stage in the filter, and ask: Is it a specified event of small probability? That is, is it an event that (a) can be described independently of the particular circumstances of its specific production, and (b) has probability so small that it cannot reasonably be expected to occur under the given circumstances?

If the answer is no, then you conclude that it is the result of chance. If the answer is yes, you conclude that it is the result of design.

Reference: William A. Dembski, The Design Inference: Eliminating Chance Through Small Probabilities, Cambridge University Press (1998).

 Dr Keith Devlin is a mathematician. His most recent book, The Math Gene: Why Everyone Has It But Most People Don't Use It, will be published in the UK in April by Weidenfeld and Nicolson.

webTitle: Labour MPs hit back over juries and minimum pay

fields.headline: Labour MPs hit back over juries and minimum pay
fields.standfirst: More about the minimum wage
fields.trailText: Backbench Labour MPs fired two warning shots across the government's bows in the name of social justice yesterday when they urged ministers to drop plans to curb jury trials within hours of insisting that the national minimum wage should be uprated annually.
fields.body:
Backbench Labour MPs fired two warning shots across the government's bows in the name of social justice yesterday when they urged ministers to drop plans to curb jury trials within hours of insisting that the national minimum wage should be uprated annually.

Nearly 50 MPs, led by the leftwing QC, Bob Marshall-Andrews, signed a Commons motion warning Jack Straw to drop his criminal justice (mode of trial) bill which restricts a defendant's right to jury trial.

It is widely seen as an illiberal measure which will save little money and was heavily defeated in the Lords last month. The rebels want the proposal postponed pending the review of the justice system by a senior judge, Sir Robin Auld. Failing that, they want to give the Lords an excuse to stand firm in the name of justice.

Backbench rebels drew back from forcing a rare vote on low pay at yesterday's weekly meeting of the parliamentary Labour party.

But they insisted on regular increases in the national minimum wage in the face of trade secretary Stephen Byers' insistence that it should not be treated like a social security benefit and raised regardless of economic circumstances.

Many MPs accept that argument and want regular reviews by the low pay commission, not an automatic uprating linked to inflation or wage levels. The increasingly assertive mood of backbenchers in defence of what they regard as core Labour values reflects growing concern that Tony Blair's cabinet has lost touch with its heartland vote and needs to change course before the election.

Ministers are trying to be seen to be listening to MPs' fears. Yesterday Mr Byers told them: "We lose elections when the government, the party and the parliamentary party are divorced." He spoke after yesterday's PLP meeting heard how Millbank plans to replace the three Rs on which it fought the 1997 general election campaign with three Is of "inform, inspire, instruct" when it fights for a second term.

Labour will seek to inform voters about its positive policies, inspire them with promises and instruct them on the dangers of a hardline Tory party. Millbank aims to retain all 150 seats won in 1997 and add 20 from vulnerable Conservatives.

When Mr Byers faced up to 100 MPs at yesterday's PLP meeting, the mood was described as "conciliatory, but firm" in the light of Monday's sudden change of heart which saw Tony Blair and Gordon Brown accept a 10p increase in the hourly rate of £3.60.

"It was a victory, they capitulated," some MPs said gleefully. But Gordon Prentice, the Pendle MP, who had tabled a motion for a vote - the first in the PLP since the election - withdrew the threat at the start of the debate in which all one speaker backed an annual rise.

MPs sought reassurance that the minimum wage would not become eroded, arguing that it was a linchpin policy appealing to core voters. Maria Fyfe, MP for Glasgow Maryhill, told MPs the policy is "an important part of our justice programme". Newport West MP Paul Flynn said the measure was "absolutely crucial to our core vote".

The rebels want the proposal postponed pending the review of the justice system by a senior judge, Sir Robin Auld. Failing that, they want to give the Lords an excuse to stand firm in the name of justice. Backbench rebels drew back from forcing a rare vote on low pay at yesterday's weekly meeting of the parliamentary Labour party. But they insisted on regular increases in the national minimum wage in the face of trade secretary Stephen Byers' insistence that it should not be treated like a social security benefit and raised regardless of economic circumstances. Many MPs accept that argument and want regular reviews by the low pay commission, not an automatic uprating linked to inflation or wage levels. The increasingly assertive mood of backbenchers in defence of what they regard as core Labour values reflects growing concern that Tony Blair's cabinet has lost touch with its heartland vote and needs to change course before the election. Ministers are trying to be seen to be listening to MPs' fears. Yesterday Mr Byers told them: "We lose elections when the government, the party and the parliamentary party are divorced." He spoke after yesterday's PLP meeting heard how Millbank plans to replace the three Rs on which it fought the 1997 general election campaign with three Is of "inform, inspire, instruct" when it fights for a second term. Labour will seek to inform voters about its positive policies, inspire them with promises and instruct them on the dangers of a hardline Tory party. Millbank aims to retain all 150 seats won in 1997 and add 20 from vulnerable Conservatives. When Mr Byers faced up to 100 MPs at yesterday's PLP meeting, the mood was described as "conciliatory, but firm" in the light of Monday's sudden change of heart which saw Tony Blair and Gordon Brown accept a 10p increase in the hourly rate of £3.60. "It was a victory, they capitulated," some MPs said gleefully. But Gordon Prentice, the Pendle MP, who had tabled a motion for a vote - the first in the PLP since the election - withdrew the threat at the start of the debate in which all one speaker backed an annual rise. MPs sought reassurance that the minimum wage would not become eroded, arguing that it was a linchpin policy appealing to core voters. Maria Fyfe, MP for Glasgow Maryhill, told MPs the policy is "an important part of our justice programme". Newport West MP Paul Flynn said the measure was "absolutely crucial to our core vote".

fields.headline: Adams warns of 'greatest crisis'
fields.standfirst:
Blair tough line prompts Sinn Fein to storm out of talks

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams stormed out of Downing Street after a crunch meeting with Tony Blair last night, warning that the Good Friday Agreement was in shreds following the re-imposition six days ago of direct rule from Westminster.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams stormed out of Downing Street after a crunch meeting with Tony Blair last night, warning that the Good Friday Agreement was in shreds following the re-imposition six days ago of direct rule from Westminster.

Mr Adams, describing the Ulster peace process as in its greatest crisis yet, failed to persuade Mr Blair to signal an immediate return to devolution. He accused Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, of acting illegally in suspending the fledgling institutions of government after only 72 days last Friday.

Mr Blair, who took a tough line during an afternoon of intense negotiations, told him there could be no move back to self-government until the IRA had made clear its initiative on arms decommissioning, made late on Friday. It led General John de Chastelain, chairman of the International Commission on Decommissioning, to suggest resolution of the so far intractable issue was possible.

Sinn Fein indicated that it would refuse to take part in any review of the stalled agreement while the assembly and power-sharing executive were suspended. It appeared, though, that the British and Irish governments, were planning an effective review, calling it inter-party talks.

The IRA withdrew its interlocutor from the decommissioning body on Tuesday, plunging the peace process into turmoil. It also took all initiatives off the table table, including its latest offer.

Mr Adams still wanted to build bridges with the government. But he said: "Any notion that cajoling or coaxing or pressuring people like us to try and get the IRA to do some thing, when the IRA moves so far only to have it rejected, is just nonsense."

Mr Adams earlier warned that "micro-groups" would seek to take advantage of the political vacuum with resumed terror campaigns. He promised to do what he could to prevent any return to sectarian violence.

But he said: "I can only work within the possibilities of human and political endeavour. It is a two-way street."

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, left Downing Street still baffled as to what it was the IRA offered. He wants a clear commitment that decommissioning will come, along with a start date and an indication of how it will proceed before rejoining government.

It was his threat to quit as first minister, after agreeing to devolution in November in the expectation IRA arms would follow by the end of January, which prompted suspension ahead of a critical meeting of his ruling party council. Mr Mandelson calculated the agreement would be over unless he placed the institutions into cold-storage.

Mr Trimble said: "The onus is fairly and squarely on the republican movement to put forward proposals as to how this is going to work.

"The ball is still firmly in their court. We are not interested in cobbling together a formula that enables this to stagger on for a week or two. We want this sorted out once and for all."

Downing Street did its best to paper over the chasm between the republicans and unionists caused by Mr Mandelson's tactics on Friday. They each said they want a short and focused review, but that seemed unlikely yesterday.

Mr Blair, after his meetings with Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, and the three main pro-agreement parties, said: "It's been a set back. I'm not going to pretend that this is not a difficult situation because it is. None of us wanted to suspend the institutions. None of us want to let them stay suspended a moment longer than they need to."

Gen de Chastelain's report, which said that the IRA had indicated the "context" in which it would disarm, had been a "huge advance" but greater clarity was needed as to what was meant.

"We have come such a long way I simply cannot believe that we are going to let this chance slip away," he said.

"The one thing I am sure of having met all the parties is that none of them really wants to see this agreement fall. All of them know it is the only way forward."

"There is no other way it has got to be done and we are going to make sure it is done," he said.

Mr Ahern agreed: "I don't see any reason why we cannot achieve that."
