webTitle: Vatican on defensive as Italian atheists honour their martyr

fields.headline: Vatican on defensive as Italian atheists honour their martyr
fields.standfirst: 400 years after his death, thousands pay tribute to maverick priest who defended science
fields.trailText: Exactly 400 years after flames silenced his philosophical attacks, a swelling legion of followers will today renew Giordano Bruno's battle against his nemesis and executioner, the Catholic church.
fields.body:
Exactly 400 years after flames silenced his philosophical attacks, a swelling legion of followers will today renew Giordano Bruno's battle against his nemesis and executioner, the Catholic church.

Theologians, scientists, politicians, anarchists and atheists will gather at the Rome vegetable market where he was burned at the stake in 1600, and, in a move which is likely to make the Vatican squirm, hail him a martyr to free thought.

Bruno, a Dominican monk who travelled Europe preaching a blend of rationalism, pantheism and magic, was killed in 1600 after he refused to recant his beliefs during the anti-science backlash of the counter-reformation.

Pope John Paul II will next month strive to cleanse the church's soul by apologising for the execution, but he has ignored the clamour to fully rehabilitate Bruno.

Thousands of anarchists are expected to mobilise at a statue of the Dominican priest in the Piazzo Campo dei Fiori - the site of his execution for heresy - to reclaim his legacy.

"He's a symbol of the temporal powers of the church that we want to fight," said Giorgio Villella, of the Union of Rationalist Atheists and and Agnostics.

This week the former European Union commissioner Emma Bonino and members of Italy's Radical party have joined the throngs leaving roses at Bruno's statue, which has become a secular shrine since being erected amid controversy in 1887.

A separate gathering of international scholars will mark the official anniversary of his execution, which has spawned books, debates and acclaim for a maverick who in his brief life infuriated and insulted Protestants, kings and Oxford university professors.

Bruno was born in Naples in 1548 and was ordained a priest, although he quickly fell out with the church on dogma.

In addition to challenging the eucharist, immaculate conception and church authority, Bruno championed natural magic and endorsed Copernicus's correct but shocking claim that the earth orbited the sun, not vice versa. He also claimed that the earth was only one of an infinite number of inhabited worlds.

In 1576 he came to the attention of the Inquisition and fled abroad. While in England between 1583 and 1585, he trained Queen Elizabeth's court in the art of memory before moving to Oxford university. He left there in disgust after claiming the professors knew more about beer than Greek.

Lured back to Italy in 1591, he was arrested and put on trial for his heretical views. Unlike Galileo he refused to recant and was executed in February 17, 1600, also a holy year.

Cardinal Paul Poupard, president of the Vatican's pontifical culture council, has galvanised Bruno's supporters by saying his ideas were incompatible with Christian thought.

"I don't think you can talk about 'rehabilitation' in the Bruno case, since there are no grounds for it," he said.

The pope will apologise only for the execution, not the intellectual rejection of Bruno's ideas.

The apology will be part of a sweeping mea culpa to mark the Vatican's holy year which forms an official apology for persecution and errors committed by Christians over the past 2,000 years.

Gervaise Rosser, an Oxford professor of history, said: "The sad thing about Bruno's reputation in England is that he's remembered, if at all, either as a prophet of modern science or as a weirdo."

But hailing Bruno as a figurehead for science was a mistake, he added. "He used science to look back, not forward. He believed that Copernicus's insight was the fulfilment of an ancient prophecy."

webTitle: Russian spy trial threatens to embarrass MI6

fields.headline: Russian spy trial threatens to embarrass MI6
fields.trailText: A mentally unstable former Russian diplomat who wrote steamy spy thrillers goes on trial for treason in Moscow today, accused of spying for MI6.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
A mentally unstable former Russian diplomat who wrote steamy spy thrillers goes on trial for treason in Moscow today, accused of spying for MI6.

In the final chapter of a bizarre espionage scandal that has dragged on for almost four years, the long-awaited trial of Platon Obukhov, a second secretary at the Russian foreign ministry, threatens to cause the British intelligence service considerable embarrassment.

Mr Obukhov, 30, was arrested in April 1996 by the federal security service (FSB), allegedly while broadcasting classified information "of a political and strategic defence character" to MI6's headquarters in London.

The Moscow Times identified his controller as Norman MacSween, who was listed as a counsellor in the British embassy in Moscow.

If found guilty, Mr Obukhov faces up to 20 more years' mprisonment. The British government has never denied that he was in contact with MI6.

Mr Obukhov's father, Alexei, is a former Soviet deputy foreign minister and senior disarmament negotiator.

The arrest prompted the worst spy row between London and Moscow since the end of the cold war, with Britain and Russia each expelling four diplomats. A senior FSB official heralded Mr Obukhov's exposure as "one of the biggest blows to the world's oldest and most experienced intelligence services".

The trial has been postponed until now to enable him to undergo compulsory psychiatric tests. He was sent to the Serbsky psychological institute, the notorious clinic which used to declare dissidents insane in Soviet times.

Although Russian officials concede that the shock of Mr Obukhov's arrest made him temporarily unbalanced, they claim that he later simulated mental illness to evade the maximum punishment. Government doctors say he is well enough to stand trial.

His parents insist that he has been psychologically disturbed since childhood - attempting several times to kill himself and set fire to the family home - and that he still suffers from schizophrenia.

Footage showing Mr Obukhov confessing to his alleged crimes was broadcast on Russian television soon after his arrest. He was filmed in his prison cell, grinning strangely, rolling his eyes and talking incoherently, dressed in a dunce's hat, odd socks and laceless gym shoes.

Russian television also broadcast grainy extracts, apparently from surveillance cameras, allegedly showing him transmitting messages from a Moscow trolleybus with a sophisticated radio device.

Alongside his confession, he claimed that he made contacts with MI6 officials to provide material for his novels. Mr Obukhov has published 14 espionage potboilers, brimming with sex and violence.

His mother, Olga, said yesterday: "This is a medical case and not a spy case. I don't know why the British secret services recruited a sick person to work for them - they behaved like scoundrels. Now my son is perishing in a gulag."

Mr Obukhov's lawyer, Galina Krylova, spoke to him earlier this week and described his condition as unpredictable. "Sometimes he feels alright, sometimes he becomes extremely aggressive. He does not always understand what is going on around him."

She said he had not received medical treatment since October 1998, when he was moved from the Serbsky institute to a Moscow jail. "Officials said he was faking his madness and they stopped his treatment."

 Russia has more spies than the United States and the gap has widened since the cold war, the staff director of the US house of representatives' intelligence committee claims.

"Most places, it [Russian intelligence] is a factor of several larger than the US intelligence presence, and that factor is larger than it was 10 years ago," John Millis told a symposium at the Smithsonian institution.

Reuters, Washington

fields.headline: Expenses claim exposes agent
fields.trailText: South African television's top political correspondent during the apartheid era, Cliff Saunders, has revealed that he was a spy for the white regime's intelligence service. The confession came to light in unusual fashion - Mr Saunders submitted a demand to the secret service for more than £10,000 in unpaid expenses.
fields.body:
South African television's top political correspondent during the apartheid era, Cliff Saunders, has revealed that he was a spy for the white regime's intelligence service. The confession came to light in unusual fashion - Mr Saunders submitted a demand to the secret service for more than £10,000 in unpaid expenses.

Mr Saunders wrote to the minister of intelligence, Joe Nhlanhla, threatening legal action unless at least half of the money for work done in London and South Africa was paid immediately.

The ministry declined to comment publicly but a source accused Mr Saunders of trying to hold the government to ransom by threatening to tell all in court. He said the ex-spy had worked for the National Intelligence Agency "for decades".

The former political correspondent said in his letter that after the transition to majority rule in 1994 he moved to the newly formed South African Secret Service, which deals in foreign intelligence. He was posted to London where he claims to have recruited the journalist Jani Allen to spy on prominent members of the Inkatha Freedom Party.

Ms Allen gained notoriety after she lost a libel case against Channel Four, which alleged she had sex with Eugene Terreblanche, the leader of the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement (AWB).

Suspicions about Mr Saunders were first aired during the Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearings when former government agents claimed they had paid him to plant or distort stories.

He has also been accused of informing on colleagues, some of whom were targeted by police for detention without trial. Several other white former journalists have also been exposed as spies.

Mr Saunders had little to say about the revelations. "It is a strange situation. It is a no comment situation. I am busy writing a book about my experiences," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Matchbox bid to catch Bin Laden
fields.body:
Matchbox bid to catch Bin Laden

Matchboxes began circulating yesterday in Peshawar, Pakistan, near the Afghan border, offering a reward for helping the US capture the suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden.

There was also the promise of asylum for any informer. The message carried a misprint, offering $500,000 (£315,000) instead of the $5m announced by Washington.

Mr bin Laden, who lives in Afghanistan, allegedly masterminded the bombings of US embassies in Tanzania and Kenya in 1998. There were also reports of 100-rupee (£1.25) notes being circulated announcing the US reward. AP, Islamabad

Sacked Wiranto in plea for calm

webTitle: Nato and Russia re-establish ties as tensions ease

fields.headline: Nato and Russia re-establish ties as tensions ease
fields.trailText: Nato and Russia took the first step yesterday towards ending the year-long freeze in relations caused by the Kosovo war.
fields.body:
Nato and Russia took the first step yesterday towards ending the year-long freeze in relations caused by the Kosovo war.

The Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, said in Moscow: "We've moved from permafrost into slightly softer ground."

The Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, concurred: "We discussed relations between Russia and Nato and decided that we will resume contacts." A Russian diplomatic source said the development did not amount to a full restoration of ties, but it was a beginning.

Friction between the two had seen a return to cold war rhetoric, exacerbated by the Chechnya conflict, in which Nato accused Moscow of using excessive force.

Russia, which signed an agreement with Nato in 1997 to establish close dialogue on security issues, became increasingly suspicious of the west after strikes on Iraq in 1998, followed by the bombing of Serbia.

Moscow feared that Russia could eventually be the target of a similar unilateral action and was especially angry about the bombing of Serbia, with which it has historical ties.

In spite of yesterday's thaw, relations will be strained if the US president, Bill Clinton, approves in July the creation of a new anti-ballistic missile system, which Moscow would interpret as an aggressive move

Lord Robertson, the former British defence secretary who took over the Nato post last year, held meetings yesterday with the acting Russian president, Vladimir Putin, the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, and Mr Ivanov.

Afterwards, Lord Robertson, making his first visit to Moscow, said: "Today was a good day for resuming the dialogue and discussion that forms part of the Nato-Russia relationship." But the Russian side was less effusive.

Mr Putin said the relationship between Russia and Nato was "rather complicated", harking back to Serbia and Chechnya.

Nevertheless, Nato saw it as hugely important in symbolic terms that Mr Putin, who is often portrayed as anti-western, had joined in the talks and had approved the resumption of ties.

Russia broke off almost all ties with Nato and effectively shut down the permanent joint council - in which Nato and Russian officials consulted on a wide variety of security issues - soon after the first strikes on Belgrade. Russia protested it had not been consulted before the bombardments began.

Lord Robertson said Nato's position on Chechnya had not changed, though it understood the threat of terrorism and the other problems Russia faced there.

"We don't believe [the Chechen war] is right in principle, nor do we believe that this is right in practice, simply sowing the seeds for future conflicts," Lord Robertson said. "We have had five hours of very frank and sometimes blunt discussions."

A joint communique issued at the end of the talks said: "Nato and Russia will work to intensify their dialogue in the permanent joint council. They agreed [to] pursue a vigorous dialogue on a wide range of security issues that will enable Nato and Russia to make their mutual cooperation a cornerstone of European security."

The former Russian prime minister, Yevgeny Primakov, said Moscow had no choice but to talk to Nato.

"This does not mean that we should quickly change our stance and return to the permanent council," Mr Primakov said. "But we have to talk, as Nato is a real force and this should be taken into account."

webTitle: US couple admit to banking scam

fields.headline: US couple admit to banking scam
fields.trailText: A former Bank of New York executive and her husband pleaded guilty yesterday to money laundering charges, admitting that they accepted $1.8m (£1.13m) to arrange a scheme linked to the Russian mob.
fields.body:
A former Bank of New York executive and her husband pleaded guilty yesterday to money laundering charges, admitting that they accepted $1.8m (£1.13m) to arrange a scheme linked to the Russian mob.

The former executive, Lucy Edwards, and her husband, Peter Berlin, entered their pleas in US district court in Manhattan a day after arriving from London to surrender to the FBI.

The couple admitted allowing Russian bankers to set up unlicensed banking operations in Queens and Jersey City, New Jersey, so that large amounts of money could be laundered to evade taxes in Russia and the US.

The pleas were the first major admissions in the international scandal that created headlines around the world with details of a scam involving as much as £6bn. An alleged accomplice, Aleskey Volkov, remains a fugitive.

Investigators believe most of the laundered money came from Russian importers trying to avoid paying taxes. But they are still looking into whether some of the money came from other criminal activity and was launderedthrough the bank's accounts.

Ms Edwards was dismissed as the head of the bank's eastern European operations in London last August after her name surfaced as a target of a worldwide investigation. The attention turned to her husband after it was suspected that most of the money was moved through a company he controlled, Benex Worldwide Ltd, and other accounts in his name.

The charges were laid just after Ms Edwards had made a presentation on the latest money laundering techniques at a conference for financial executives in Riga, Latvia.

AP

fields.headline: Judge's trick on lawyer backfires
fields.trailText: Italian justice plumbed new depths yesterday when it emerged that a judge and lawyers had faked a trial in order to trick a new female prosecutor into using obscene Sicilian slang.
fields.body:
Italian justice plumbed new depths yesterday when it emerged that a judge and lawyers had faked a trial in order to trick a new female prosecutor into using obscene Sicilian slang.

Iolanda Apostolico, fresh from the mainland, fought a case in the Sicilian town of Catania not knowing it was bogus and oblivious to colleagues' smirks every time she addressed Judge Licazzi ("licazzi" means "testicles").

The judge, whose real name is Renato Papa, did not object, since he was the ringleader of the hoax. Staff were instructed to keep a poker face while Ms Apostolico, using case notes, addressed them by vulgar names.

Mr Crastello ("castrated") and Ms Sbardasciata ("cretinous") nodded with sufficient solemnity for the deceit to last an entire day. Inspired by Sicily's tradition of farce, the judge wanted to give Ms Apostolico a special welcome, said the newspaper Il Messaggero.

A native of Cassino, just south of Rome, she did not realise the fraud case was fake, but was puzzled after leaving the court to see a colleague holding a sign: "They joke about you in court."

Ms Apostolico returned home and described her day to her boyfriend, Claudio Moffa, a university tutor from Rome familiar with Sicilian slang.

Enraged, the next day Moffa entered the court and approached the judge. Under the gaze of secretaries and magistrates, he looked the judge in the eye, then spat in it. He dropped a note on the judge's bench: "A joke from Claudio Moffa."

A real prosecution against Moffa ensued. He defended the spit as an attempt to reclaim the victim's honour. A 20-day prison sentence was suspended.

Italy's judicial authorities have launched disciplinary proceedings against the judge.

The judicial system was already facing a credibility gap after a series of fiascos. More than 700,000 forgotten court cases were found after being filed away for over a decade. Suspected mass killers were released because their trials dragged on too long. Convicts released early have murdered again within hours of freedom.

For Moffa, the ending has not been happy. His relationship with Ms Apostolico, reportedly strained by the joke, has broken up.

fields.headline: Internet 'creating world of loners'
fields.standfirst: Survey claims to shows why bosses love the web - and how it harms human relations
fields.trailText: The internet is turning people into more solitary beings who can hardly be bothered to call their mother on her birthday. It is also causing them to spend more hours at the office and to take the office home with them at night.
fields.byline: David Streitfeld  in Palo Alto, California
fields.body:
The internet is turning people into more solitary beings who can hardly be bothered to call their mother on her birthday. It is also causing them to spend more hours at the office and to take the office home with them at night.

Those are some of the conclusions of a major new study of internet users conducted by Stanford university's institute for the quantitative study of society.

But even before it was unveiled in Palo Alto, California, the survey of 4,113 individuals, carried out in December, was receiving extensive criticism.

"We're moving from a world in which you know all your neighbours, see all your friends, interact with lots of different people every day, to a functional world, where interaction takes place at a distance," said Stanford political science professor Norman Nie, the director of the institute. "Can you get a hug, a warm voice, over the internet?"

A quarter of the survey respondents who use the internet for more than five hours a week said they spend less time with friends and family, either on the phone or in person. Ten per cent said it had reduced out-of-home social activities.

If personal interaction - and time with such old-fashioned media as newspapers and, particularly, television - were losers, employers benefited. One in four respondents said the time they spent working at home had increased, while their hours at the office had either stayed the same or actually gone up as well.

It was no wonder that Ford recently said that it would give all its employees a personal computer and internet connection, Prof Nie said. "They just bought themselves hundreds of thousands of hours of free labour," he said. "You no longer have to pack a briefcase to work at home. Now it's all sitting there waiting for you."

Yet if people are doing work at home, they have also brought their home into work. One reason that they are not getting everything done at the office may be because they are so busy writing email to far-flung chums, ordering books from Amazon.com, sending cards via BlueMountain.com, checking on the price of shares, researching their holiday, gambling on electronic lotteries and gazing at Pamela Anderson Lee.

"Life becomes a continuous stream organised around the internet," Prof Nie said.

But other academics do not believe that the internet is making employees more productive.

William D Bygrave, of the Blank centre for entrepreneurship at Babson college in Massachusetts, used to monitor the daily traffic for the Drudge Report, which cyber-muckraker Matt Drudge would helpfully post at his site.

"I noticed his weekday traffic was much, much greater than his Saturday and Sunday traffic, even though he was breaking new stories on weekends to heighten interest in his TV show on Saturday evening and his radio show on Sunday evenings," Prof Bygrave said.

"Workers read Drudge's homepage from their offices during the day rather from their homes on evenings and weekends." He noted, too, that eBay always seems to have traffic snarls during weekdays rather than on evenings and weekends.

"It's time that used to be spent at the water cooler or getting a cup of coffee. Except we're still doing that, too," Prof Bygrave said. "So we say, 'I can finish this project tonight or early tomorrow morning.' Before the web there was a lot more pressure to clear your desk by the end of the day. Now it's never cleared."

Two thirds of those surveyed spent fewer than five hours a week on the net, and their behaviour had changed little. But the longer people have been hooked up to the internet, the more time they spend on it, the study found. So Prof Nie predicted that the anti-social trends would only increase.

"The automobile promised a great many things and delivered them," he said. "But if we began to think of the negatives at the beginning of the last century, maybe we'd have done some things differently, and it wouldn't take two hours on a rainy day to get from San Francisco to Palo Alto" - the 40-mile route he drives every day.

But critics dismissed most of what Prof Nie concluded, as well as his research methods.

"The assertion that the internet is socially isolating has not held up to serious scrutiny," said Donna Hoffman, the co-director of the eLab at Vanderbilt university in Nashville. "All of the research evidence I've seen points the other way - not to mention the anecdotal evidence."

A similar, smaller study in 1998 found "small but reliable declines in social and psychological well-being" among heavy net users. But critics argued that part of the reason for those participants' depression might have been because they all lived in Pittsburgh. Washington Post

webTitle: Cloning company offers pet-lovers Rover's return

fields.headline: Cloning company offers pet-lovers Rover's return
fields.trailText: F Scott Fitzgerald's dictum that there are no second acts in American life faced further contradiction yesterday when a company opened for business offering just that to dogs and cats.
fields.body:
F Scott Fitzgerald's dictum that there are no second acts in American life faced further contradiction yesterday when a company opened for business offering just that to dogs and cats.

For an initial outlay of up to $2,500 (£1,570), Genetic Savings and Clone, based in College Station, Texas, promises bereaved animal-lovers the prospect of the next best thing to kitty living for ever.

The firm takes DNA samples from old or dying dogs and cats and stores them in anticipation of the day when they can be cloned.

And that day could come within a year, it seems.

"It's a major scientific challenge, but the team is 90% there," said Mark Westhusin, a Texas A&M university veterinary physiologist, who is heading the project.

"We have just received so many calls from people wanting this. Their pet is dying or got hit by a car or their dog or cat is just getting old."

The company is a spin-off from the university's $2.3m Missyplicity project, an attempt to be first to clone a dog by creating a replica of a border collie called Missy.

Frozen DNA cells will be grown into embryos, and placed in the wombs of surrogate mothers to produce "reincarnation".

But this puppy love does not come cheap: the initial price might be hundreds of thousands of dollars, falling after three years to $25,000.

However, Nathan Winograd of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals recommends caution.

"I don't know anybody among us who loves their dogs and cats and other animals who wouldn't want them to live for ever.

"But those of us who work in animal shelters around the country want to see lives saved as opposed to more lives created. We'd rather see these folks pay tribute to their departed companions by saving another, like by adopting a dog or cat from a local shelter, instead of cloning."

And Ian Wilmut, the scientist who led the groundbreaking cloning of Dolly the sheep in Edinburgh, said: "It's very possible that people will be disappointed.

"That's because genetics accounts for just a fraction of a pet's colouration and demeanour. Coat colour patches will not be the same in the clone as they were in the original."

Perhaps that would be just as well, for recent research suggests that 30% of American pets are overweight.

"The average dog these days is a couch potato," said Julie Churchill, of the university of Minnesota's college of veterinary medicine."Our mental concept of a healthy puppy is a roly-poly, overweight puppy."

webTitle: French children fall victim to the drudgery of rural life

fields.headline: French children fall victim to the drudgery of rural life
fields.standfirst: Police ponder a chilling case, the latest in a spate of child murders
fields.trailText: It was midday in the south-western French village of Flavin when the bodies of Manuela Moulinier and her stepdaughter, Morgane, 12, were found in their converted farmhouse with bullets in the heads. Yesterday, police drained wells and combed rubbish dumps for Manuela's missing newborn baby, Martin.
fields.body:
It was midday in the south-western French village of Flavin when the bodies of Manuela Moulinier and her stepdaughter, Morgane, 12, were found in their converted farmhouse with bullets in the heads. Yesterday, police drained wells and combed rubbish dumps for Manuela's missing newborn baby, Martin.

The facts would be chilling enough on their own, but the killings were the latest of nearly 30 child murders. All were murdered in their own homes during the past five years, 14 of them since 1998.

Most of the victims lived comfortably in typical rural backwaters or in small provincial towns. But these atrocities were not the work of deranged serial murderers; the common factor was that no outsiders were involved. A mixture of boredom, conjugal tension or administrative problems caused their parents' nerves to crack, usually just as a long winter edged towards spring.

However, the murders in Flavin could prove an exception as police have released the father, Patrice Moulinier, 43, without charge following 36 hours in custody.

No one else has been arrested, but the tragedy had the hallmarks of the killings that appear to have made life more dangerous for children in the country than in the cities, and made the streets safer than some of their own homes.

Police have been unable to explain the motive for the execution of Manuela Moulinier, 36.

webTitle: Seeds offered growers a miracle, but may be just another liability

fields.headline: Seeds offered growers a miracle, but may be just another liability
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: When the time came to buy this year's seeds, Wade Louthan had to choose between conventional and GM crops. It was not an easy decision, but he knew whichever he picked, the result would be depressingly predictable - he would not make any money.
fields.body:
When the time came to buy this year's seeds, Wade Louthan had to choose between conventional and GM crops. It was not an easy decision, but he knew whichever he picked, the result would be depressingly predictable - he would not make any money.

As the ranks of ecologists and GM industry lobbyists prepare to do battle once more this year, the US farmer is again caught in between, and finding it increasingly hard to survive. He or she must either buy ordinary seed and pay the added costs of herbicide and insecticide; or go the GM route, and face the possibility that - come harvest time - no one will want to buy the crop.

Mr Louthan decided that when the snow melts he will plant 330 acres of corn and 220 acres of soybeans, entirely with conventional seeds. And the signs are that many US farmers, especially corn-growers, have made the same decision.

But the dilemma facing American farmers is a painful one, without easy answers. With crop prices at an all-time low, the choice is usually between two routes to penury.

"What is better? GM, or all the chemicals I have to spray on my land with conventional crops?" Mr Louthan asked. It was not a rhetorical question. He really did not know the answer. He stood in his yard, wiping engine oil from his gloves, and weighed up the pros and cons.

Monsanto's Roundup Ready soybeans and corn do not require repeated spraying of herbicides to control weeds. They can be sprayed just once when the crop is above knee-high.

Similarly the company's BT corn is genetically engineered to secrete its own insecticide to kill off the corn bore parasite endemic in the region. The new seeds cost a few dollars more a bushel, but represent a huge saving in chemicals and labour.

Mr Louthan's choice was in part, he said, an ecological decision. "You've not just got to worry about what the corn will do to you. You've got to worry about what it will do to everything else, when it crosses with this and crosses with that."

But ultimately, Mr Louthan's choice came down to this: would he be able to sell his crop? Even if he did, grain prices are at a record low, given the current North American glut in production, exacerbated by increased yields from GM crops.

Mr Louthan's dilemma is repeated around the country. In South Dakota, Dennis Mitchell said that when spring came, he would sow half his fields with BT corn, down from 85% last year.

"About half of my corn goes to feed [livestock] and if I have to sell the rest for human consumption, then I thought ... if I'm not sure of what the consumer wants, I better be on the safe side," Mr Mitchell said.

Meanwhile, in Nebraska, Gale Lush is growing far more BT corn than he initially wanted to because he was unable to find any good conventional alternatives on the local seed market, which is dominated by an oligopoly of big agri-industrial companies.

The big distributors running the vast grain silos say they will buy his modified corn after harvest, but Mr Lush is nervous. He is go ing to watch farm prices very carefully. "If the news keeps getting worse, I'll have to use some substandard [conventional] hybrid at the last minute," he said.

This apparent trend away from GM corn is not necessarily mirrored in soybean production, nor is it evenly distributed around the country. Among the arable farmers spread out on the hills between Virginia and West Virginia, Mr Louthan is in something of a minority.

His neighbour, Richard Burns, is planting GM soybeans. He recognises that conventional beans might eventually fetch a premium of up to 30 cents, but he has a different take on "the bottom line".

He said: "Last year, the GMO (GM organism) beans we raised were the best beans we ever raised. They were the cleanest beans - with no weeds. With non-GMOs you have to spray the ground before you plant and, with most farmers, the less chemicals they use, the better they feel about it."

Mr Burns and Mr Louthan are pursuing different strategies, but both agree neither will emerge a winner, given the low crop prices. For many farmers, the GM revolution appeared to offer salvation when it first dawned. Now it offers, at best, a chance of survival. At worst, it is just another liability.

webTitle: British aid to help armies reform

fields.headline: British aid to help armies reform
fields.trailText: Britain is to give more money to help emerging nations review their military spending, the international development secretary, Clare Short, will announce today.
fields.body:
Britain is to give more money to help emerging nations review their military spending, the international development secretary, Clare Short, will announce today.

The programme is controversial because it involves countries like Rwanda and Uganda, whose troops are fighting in the Congolese civil war. Both have been invited to send representatives to a conference in London.

Forging closer links with the defence departments of these states is seen as essential when internal conflicts are destabilising aid projects and preventing investment.

Colombia and Indonesia, whose troops have been criticised for their record in suppressing rebel movements, are also participating in the conference.

Aid organisations and overseas development departments have traditionally shied away from contacts with foreign armies but the international development secretary is now pressing for closer engagement.

"Without basic security it is impossible for poor people to build a better life and to work their way out of poverty," Ms Short is expected to say.

"An accountable, appropriately structured and trained security sector can help provide a safe and secure environment for poor people and communities.

"Conversely, where the security sector is unreformed, ill-disciplined and repressive it can be a major source of insecurity - perpetuating violence itself rather than protecting people from it. In the post-cold war world, conflict is concentrated in developing countries and it entraps them in growing poverty."

Her latest proposals follow an initiative launched last year with the Centre for Defence Studies in Kings college, London.

Ms Short insists that her department will not necessarily be reducing the size of poorer nations' armies. In the past, she admits, "military expenditure was seen as bad... something to be cut ruthlessly, without regard for the very real security threats that countries might face.

"This is wrong-headed and dangerous. If countries that need international assistance are pressed to cut defence spending regardless of the threat they face, they will hide and disguise this spending in secretive budgeting arrangements."

fields.headline: US farmers desert GM crops
fields.standfirst:
Embattled bio-tech industry dealt severe blow as survey in Midwest heartland reveals planting of modified seeds is in decline

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The first firm evidence has emerged that the bio-tech food revolution is in retreat in its heartland - the vast cornfields of the American Midwest where the overwhelming bulk of the world's genetically engineered crops are grown.
fields.body:
The first firm evidence has emerged that the bio-tech food revolution is in retreat in its heartland - the vast cornfields of the American Midwest where the overwhelming bulk of the world's genetically engineered crops are grown.

US farmers have just finished buying seed for the coming growing season, and early studies suggest that a significant proportion are abandoning GM.

A market survey reveals that US farmers plan to plant 16% less genetically modified (GM) corn than they did last year.

The nationwide survey by the American Corn Growers Association (ACGA) lends support to claims to be published today by the Worldwatch environmental group that the global acreage of all GM crops (mainly corn and soybeans) could fall by up to 25% compared with last year.

Though sales of GM soybeans appear to be holding at last year's levels - more than half the total soybean crop - the rapid fall-off in demand for GM corn seeds represents a severe blow to the GM industry at its American core. The mass defection from GM seed will hit an industry already beset with consumer scepticism abroad, and falling stock prices on Wall Street.

Most US market analysts questioned this week doubted that the GM slump would be as pronounced as Worldwatch - a Washington-based environmental watchdog - is suggesting. Even though no clear scientific evidence has so far surfaced proving GM crops are harmful, farmers are increasingly uncertain whether they will be able to sell their bio-tech harvest to a world concerned about its long-term health and ecological impact.

"The doubts are spreading like wildfire," Gary Goldberg, ACGA's chief executive officer, said. "Farmers don't know if they're going to have a market next week."

Producers' concerns were deepened this month when Frito-Lay, a giant producer of corn snacks and other convenience foods, told its suppliers that it would not be buying GM corn this year. Seagram, one of the world's largest distillers, made a similar announcement within a few days. The European Union imposed a two-year moratorium on new GM im ports last summer and in January an international "biosafety protocol" meeting in Montreal agreed that all exports of GM food products should be labelled.

In a statement to be issued today Brian Halweil, a Worldwatch researcher, said: "If more American manufacturers hop on the bandwagon, the drop in demand would be devastating for transgenic (GM) growers and seed producers."

US growers are already feeling the pinch. Steve Mattis, an Illinois farmer and seed dealer, told the Guardian yesterday that while his customers were still buying soybean seed in about the same quantities as last season, demand for GM corn seed was down by 75%.

"There will be very, very little corn being planted around here," Mr Mattis said. "The corn elevators [the wholesale markets] are highly recommending that we don't plant it."

The Midwest slump has come despite a determined attempt by big GM producers such as Monsanto to shore up their share of the market. Monsanto representatives have appeared on television commercials to insist that the elevator operators will buy the harvested crop this autumn.

Monsanto GM brands such as BT corn (genetically modified to produce its own insecticide) and Roundup Ready (engineered to survive Monsanto's all-purpose weedkiller) are being offered at discount prices in Illinois, according to Mr Mattis.

Dean Urmstron, a representative of the seed industry lobby in Washington, said it was too early in the season to judge the market accurately and argued that the soybean market appeared to be "ahead of last year".

But Mr Goldberg said he was confident the ACGA survey was an accurate portrayal of the market. It surveyed 582 farmers and initial results suggested that 35% have concerns about planting GM crops. Of them, 82% questioned their marketability.

At his 600-acre farm in western Virginia, Wade Louthan said he had decided not to plant any GM corn this year, and to stop growing Roundup Ready soybeans.

"Not this year," the 37-year-old Virginian said. "You boys [in Europe] have got us scared."

Interviews with farmers across the country suggested that while many felt the European consumer response to GM foods was not entirely rational, there was growing resentment at what are seen as heavy-handed marketing techniques of the GM companies.

Mr Mattis said: "I've been a seed dealer for Monsanto for 18 years and this is the year we are going to have to part ways. They've forgotten that they have to serve farmers. I don't think they care who we've got to grow for. They're just concerned with making a fast buck."

fields.headline: No: 1579 Michael Caine
fields.trailText: My name is . . . Yes, yes. We know.
fields.body:
My name is . . . Yes, yes. We know.

So, what's the Pearly King of the silver screen been up to? Well, the 66-year-old has just bagged an Oscar nomination for his supporting role in The Cider House Rules (for which his chief competition comes from Harley Joel Osment, 11-year-old star of The Sixth Sense).

Not a lot of people know that: I think you'll find they do.

All right, treacle, no need to take the Mickey Bliss. I take it he's pretty chipper then? Hardly. In a particularly cantankerous interview, the latter-day icon of all things cockernee has vented his spleen - not for the first time - on the dastardly British class system. "I'm every bourgeois's nightmare," the part-time expat exclaimed, "a cockney with intelligence and a million dollars." Still fuming, he later bemoaned the fact that in Britain, "they say 'He is not a real actor, he is a cockney actor.' It's like calling Tony Hopkins a Welsh actor, or Sean Connery a Scots actor."

But Sean Connery is a Scots actor. That's as maybe. The old Merchant's worried he's regarded as someone who routinely goes "down the pub . . ."

What, the rub-a-dub-dub? ". . . to have some jellied eels".

Some meals on wheels? The very same. Anyway, as a five-time Oscar nominee (and one-time winner), not to mention a respected restaurateur, he feels he's due a bit more credit from his countrymen.

Not very keen on Blighty is he, guv? Not so as you'd notice, no. In the past he's remarked that "the same thing's wrong with England as it's always been: we're an island and we're not aware of what's going on in the rest of the world . . . We're always negative about everything, the press is negative, and that's because the people are."

What a Hampton Wick. He's a big man - but he's out of shape.

Do say: "You know, Michael, I always thought Jaws 4 was very underrated."

Don't say: "And cor blimey me old china, strike a light, would you Adam and Eve it, 'ere 'e comes up the Apples and Pears. The winner is . . . "

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Our lead Diary item, page 24, February 11, about what we called the official website of Jörg Haider's Austrian Freedom party, was entirely based on perusal of the hoax site to be found at www.fpo.at and not on the party's real site which is at www.fpoe.at.
fields.body:
Our lead Diary item, page 24, February 11, about what we called the official website of Jörg Haider's Austrian Freedom party, was entirely based on perusal of the hoax site to be found at www.fpo.at and not on the party's real site which is at www.fpoe.at.

A letter published the following day, page 23, which referred to links to the sites of the Ku Klux Klan and various neo-Nazi sites, was also based on the hoax site, which indeed does link to these organisations, although the letter did acknowledge the strong possibility that it was a spoof whereas our Diary item did not. Suspicions should perhaps have been raised by section headings such as Und morgen di ganze Welt (and tomorrow the world) . . .

In a panel about hacking with our Cybercrime feature, page 16, February 10, we had an item headed the Scottish and Welsh parliaments. In fact, the hackers referred to in the paragraph below got into the website of the Scottish executive www.scotland.gov.uk, and not into the website of the Scottish parliament www.scottish.parliament.uk.

On page 16, G2 (Arts), February 14, we misspelt the name of the soprano Angela Gheorghiu. Apologies.

In a correction, February 14, we misspelt the name of Frances Cambrook, a research fellow at Bournemouth University. Apologies.

fields.headline: Ashanti warriors sue for peace
fields.trailText: Peace broke out yesterday among the factions vying for control of Ashanti, allowing the troubled gold miner to apply for a $100m lifeline.
fields.body:
Peace broke out yesterday among the factions vying for control of Ashanti, allowing the troubled gold miner to apply for a $100m lifeline.

A shake-out in the boardroom and plans to speed up the sale of half of the Geita mine in Tanzania united previously hostile shareholders and the 15-odd banks with which Ashanti conducted its ill-fated gold-hedging deals.

The compromise came after two days of talks in the Ghanaian capital Accra involving Ghana's government, Ashanti managers, dissident shareholders and the leading stakeholder Lonmin, formerly the mining arm of the Lonrho group, all previously at odds with each other.

With a deal agreed, Ghana's high court cleared the $100m it needs to complete the Geita project.

Without the loan, Ashanti could have collapsed, brought down by its decision last year to bet heavily on a continuing slide in bullion prices.

The Washington agreement in the autumn, under which big central banks agreed a moratorium on further gold sales, sent the price soaring and left Ashanti owing more than $500m to 15 banks.

These banks have now agreed to roll over their right to call in Ashanti's sour gold-price hedges, and the $100m facility will allow the company to finish Geita.

On Monday, Ashanti fired its finance director, Mark Keatley, and said its chairman, Ghanaian finance minister Richard Kwame Peprah, had resigned to concentrate on his government role.

Five directors are now leaving Ashanti including Philip Tarsh, currently the acting chairman.

webTitle: Abbey to make £250m move into aircraft leasing with

fields.headline: Abbey to make £250m move into aircraft leasing with
fields.trailText: The Abbey National banking group is poised to sign a deal, believed to be worth around £250m, to buy one of the world's largest aircraft leasing operations.
fields.body:
The Abbey National banking group is poised to sign a deal, believed to be worth around £250m, to buy one of the world's largest aircraft leasing operations.

The acquisition will give Abbey control of the former leasing business of the aircraft manufacturer, Boeing, and will boost the group's presence in the so-called "big ticket" leasing market.

A spokesman for Abbey National, which will today unveil 1999 profits of about £1.6bn, declined to comment on the transaction but the banking group has made no secret of its desire to undertake bolt-on acquisitions. A year ago the company bought part of Lombard's leasing operations from NatWest and has made 20 or so similar small acquisitions in recent years.

The Seattle-based Bouillioun Aircraft leasing business is being acquired from Deutsche Bank for a price which industry experts believe will mean the German bank has doubled its investment in the past two years. Deutsche bought Bouillioun from Sumitomo Trust, which backed the original buy out from Boeing in the late 1980s.

It is understood that Abbey, which has been trying to diversify away from mortgage and savings business since its conversion from a building society 10 years ago, will feed the aviation unit into its wholesale banking arm.

The purchase of a high profile leasing operation - Bouillioun owns or has shares in about 75 modern aircraft and has another 60 planes on order - is expected to lift Abbey's profile in the competitive world of aviation lending. Banks are keen to finance airline fleet purchases but the profit margins on this business are small.

One executive in the field said: "It is interesting that a bank like Deutsche with such a big aviation exposure should be willing to sell."

fields.headline: Airtours takes a profits holiday
fields.trailText: Holiday company Airtours yesterday admitted that poor bookings at the new year had added more than £15m to its losses in the final three months of 1999.
fields.body:
Holiday company Airtours yesterday admitted that poor bookings at the new year had added more than £15m to its losses in the final three months of 1999.

The company had warned that its bookings for the millennium holiday period were disastrous, but the disclosure of the scale of the financial damage knocked shares by nearly 30p to 241p. This wiped 12% off the company's stock market value to take it to a new low for the year - just under half the level of last summer.

Chairman David Crosland, confessed: "The results for the quarter reflect the poor performance over the millennium period in all our major markets ... The industry as a whole failed to recognise that people would prefer to stay at home and celebrate the new millennium with family and friends than travel to foreign destinations."

The slide in the Airtours share price underlines a difficult period in which the group had to swallow £5.6m of costs associated with its bid for rival First Choice which was outlawed by the European commission. Further one-off costs are expected to mar results in the first half of the current financial year.

fields.headline: Cadbury wields jobs axe
fields.trailText: Chocolate and fizzy drinks group Cadbury Schweppes reported a 9% improvement in profits yesterday - and plans to shed one in eight of its workforce at its Bournville factory in Birmingham.
fields.body:
Chocolate and fizzy drinks group Cadbury Schweppes reported a 9% improvement in profits yesterday - and plans to shed one in eight of its workforce at its Bournville factory in Birmingham.

The shares rose 19.5p to 342p on the better-than-expected results but they remain more than a third below their 522p peak of 12 months ago.

Sales of sweets and chocolates were flat after a 3% decline in the first half, but soft drinks sales had a sparkling second half. The highlight was sales of Seven-Up and Dr Pepper, the group's US drinks brands, which grew at twice the market rate.

"Both confectionery and soft drinks had strong second halves and we ended the year on a strong note, which makes us confident for the current year," said chairman Sir Dominic Cadbury. Annual underlying profits were £686m, up from £628m last time on sales ahead 5% at £430bn.

Cadbury sold most of its soft drinks business outside the US to Coca-Cola last year for around £650m in order to focus on US soft drinks and the sweets business worldwide. Yesterday Sir Dominic said Cadbury could be in the market to swallow up a few competitors.

"The confectionery industry has a lot of private com panies, and is in need of rationalisation. We could certainly make a significant acquisition in the order of £2bn as we have an ungeared balance sheet."

But any large scale acquisitions are likely to be guided by a new hand. Sir Dominic announced yesterday that he is stepping down as chairman, ending his family's day-to-day links with the business founded by his ancestors more than a century ago.

Sir Dominic has worked in the family firm for 36 years and spent the last 17 as either chief executive or chairman. Headhunters have been called in to find a replacement.

webTitle: Oxford Molecular open to bid talks

fields.headline: Oxford Molecular open to bid talks
fields.trailText: With interests in computers and drug development, Oxford Molecular ought to be a favourite in the City. But somehow the company has failed in the stock market's hi-tech boom. After a string of serious setbacks, the firm yesterday admitted it is ready to listen to takeover offers.
fields.body:
With interests in computers and drug development, Oxford Molecular ought to be a favourite in the City. But somehow the company has failed in the stock market's hi-tech boom. After a string of serious setbacks, the firm yesterday admitted it is ready to listen to takeover offers.

Founded in 1989 by a trio of Oxford university professors, the group's speciality is producing software to help drugs companies find new compounds. It floated in 1993 amid great excitement about the quality of its technology - the firm's advisory committee boasts three Nobel laureates.

In its heyday, Oxford Molecular was worth nearly £300m. But its market value now comes in at a modest £30m, following a hefty loss of £26m last year.

In part, the company is a victim of circumstances - the internet has meant big changes in the distribution of software, allowing products to be marketed much more easily by start-up competitors. There are also fewer customers about - Oxford Molecular's key clients are multinational pharmaceuticals groups, which keep merging with each other.

Critics suggest, however, that the company's strategy has left something to be desired. Chief executive Tony Marchington's business plan has always forecast large, sporadic lumps of income as customers purchase million-pound packages. The company paid a heavy price last year when just a handful of orders were delayed.

Dr Marchington attracted further comment two years ago, when he unveiled a takeover of Cambridge Combinatorial - an outsourcing business carrying out chemical processes under contract from drugs companies. Cambridge Combinatorial is run by Dr Marchington's brother, Allen, who joined the enlarged group's board.

Sources close to the company suggest that a few fraternal fireworks could be on the cards if a bidder emerges - Cambridge Combinatorial is almost the only part of Oxford Molecular still doing well and Allen Marchington is believed to be less than keen on selling his 6% stake.

Oxford Molecular saw its shares gain 4p in trading yesterday to 34p.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The sell-off which has gripped the "heavy" end of the London market came to end yesterday, with a recovery among the banks and an impressive showing by BP Amoco sending the FTSE 100 142.2 points higher to 6,147.4.
fields.body:
The sell-off which has gripped the "heavy" end of the London market came to end yesterday, with a recovery among the banks and an impressive showing by BP Amoco sending the FTSE 100 142.2 points higher to 6,147.4.

The move in BP (up 36p at 510p), which came as the price of crude broke through $30 a barrel, was worth about a quarter of the over all rise on the Top 100, while the banks - led by Barclays, jumping from £14.38 to £15.48, and Lloyds, which recovered 33p to 596p - contributed another 40 points to the premier index.

While the mood on Wall Street was also firm, there was said, however, to be a mood of nervousness ahead of today's Humphrey Hawkins address by Alan Greenspan.

There was a recovery among some of the mining stocks, with Billiton racing from 283p to 317p. American investment bank Salomon Smith Barney was said to be pushing the shares high.

And there was also some action over in the supermarket sector, where Tesco suddenly moved ahead 9p to 171p in relatively heavy volume. Analysts at Deutsche Bank were said to be behind the move, having reportedly identified the grocer as having the best internet strategy among its European peers.

Another unlikely "e" stock - Hilton Group - remained in demand after it explained on Monday how it planned to migrate Ladbrokes on to the internet. Having hit a four-year low last Friday, the shares have advanced 35% since then, closing at 218p yesterday, up 23p during the session.

Computer games group Eidos moved back into fashion after some aggressive profit taking during recent weeks and a mild warning about Christmas trading. In their newly split form, the shares were trading at 781p yesterday, up 145p during the day. The stock peaked at £13.00 in mid-December and hit a low of 420p a month later. Dealers said that yesterday's surge had been fuelled by exceptional demand from private investors following bulletin board tips.

Elsewhere, venture capital group 3i surged 94p to £12.51 and Reuters continued its spectacular rerating, with the shares adding another 86p to £14.06.

Having been pole-axed in the autumn after chief executive Peter Job failed to flesh out the information group's internet policy, details the week before last on how Reuters would tackle cyberspace have taken the shares the new highs.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: New attack on euro plans
fields.body:
New attack on euro plans

The government's campaign to persuade business to get ready for the euro suffers a setback today with publication of research showing the transition could cost £36bn, with few firms willing to make preparations before a referendum.

Attempting to pre-empt the government's updated national changeover plan, due out within the next few weeks, the anti-EMU lobby group Business for Sterling said it was clear neither the public nor business wanted to ditch the pound.

The lobbying group cited a new poll, carried out by ICM and based on a sample of 1,000 companies of varying size, which found that 87% of businesses were not prepared to make significant preparations before a referendum.

Oftel relaxes caller ID rules

Oftel, the telecom regulator, is relaxing the rules on calling line identification, the system which enables a phone owner to see the number from which a call is being made before picking up the receiver.

Technical problems, accepted by Oftel, have forced some companies with private networks to withhold their numbers. Oftel is to allow these companies to choose one particular number to be displayed, even though the call is made from another number.

Versailles writ calls on Clough

Receivers of collapsed trade-finance group Versailles yesterday served a high court writ on the group's former finance director Frederick Clough, who was suspended earlier this year after accounting irregularities came to light.

PriceWaterhouseCoopers is believed to be asking for Mr Clough's assets to be frozen pending further inquiries, although no details were available last night. The writ is in the name of PWC's Anthony Lomas, receiver to Versailles, and is thought to have been served on Mr Clough's solicitors Orchard & Co.

Deutsche Bank profits up 50%

Deutsche Bank reported a 50% jump in net income in 1999, beating forecasts as trading income offset a cost surge linked to restructuring and the integration of Bankers Trust.

Germany's biggest bank said that net profit grew to euro 2.6bn (£1.6bn) last year, up about 50% from 1998 and topping average analyst forecasts of around euro 2.5bn.

Pretax profit reached euro 4.1bn, a rise of about 2%. Net income in the final quarter reached euro 721m, a strong improvement from just euro 77m in the third quarter.

BMW presents plan for Rover

BMW intends to present a rescue plan for its Rover subsidiary in "the next few weeks", according to reports from a German newspaper today, which cited unnamed sources within BMW.

However, there is no guarantee that a solution for Rover can be presented before the next supervisory board meeting in mid-March, it said.

fields.headline: Buy our arms, pleads Clinton
fields.standfirst: United States and Europe pile pressure on Blair over lucrative missile order
fields.trailText: President Clinton has made a last-ditch attempt to persuade Tony Blair to buy an American missile for the RAF's fleet of 232 Eurofighters instead of a European version.
fields.body:
President Clinton has made a last-ditch attempt to persuade Tony Blair to buy an American missile for the RAF's fleet of 232 Eurofighters instead of a European version.

The US President underlined by hand "I feel strongly" about the decision in a letter last week to the prime minister obtained by the Guardian.

The £900m deal has been the subject of the most intense political lobbying for a defence contract since the Westland affair split the Tory cabinet in 1986. Mr Blair has also been personally lobbied by an array of European leaders to back the European missile known as Meteor.

The prime minister is under severe pressure from Mr Clinton and the Pentagon to opt for the "beyond visual range air-to-air missile" proposed by Raytheon and, with it, to prove his commitment to transatlantic defence co-operation.

European colleagues, led by president Chirac of France and chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany, are pressing him equally strongly to back the ramjet-powered Euro-missile and end American hegemony in missiles.

Mr Blair will come under more pressure today when Matra BAe Dynamics, the Franco-British group that heads the six-nation Euro-consortium, plans to disclose that France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Sweden are committed to buying Meteor for their own air forces - provided Britain jumps first.

The White House note, signed simply "Bill", is the second Mr Clinton has sent in the past six months to underline how seriously the president takes the deal, worth around £900m.

"Ultimately, I know there are many factors that must enter into your BVRAAM contract selection," wrote Mr Clinton. "I feel strongly that the Raytheon option is the one that best serves the interest of both our nations."

Mr Clinton stresses the track record of the Raytheon missile and the American company's plan to co-operate with European firms including Shorts in Belfast.

Andy Head, a Raytheon Systems director in Britain, confirming the letter's existence, said the Clinton administration had made an unprecedented offer to share top-secret breakthroughs in missiles technology with Britain and the Pentagon had put up an initial $250m (£160m) for this.

The President's intervention came as both sides claimed that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, favoured their version of the missile - because they would create jobs in or near his Dunfermline constituency.

The Euro-consortium has cut its price to around £750m. Raytheon, which is offering a cheaper £450m version capable of upgrade, claims to have the "secret recipe" for treasury approval in cost-savings and "smart" procurement that prevents over-runs.

But industry insiders point to the American firm's declin ing share price. "They are looking to the UK taxpayer to bail them out of a real financial crisis," one said. A senior Whitehall source said: "New projects have a history of massive over-runs and it is true to say the treasury has some concerns."

The ministry of defence's equipment approvals committee will recommend either the US or European versions next week amid mounting evidence that it favours Meteor.

But the final decision will be Mr Blair's, who is also said to favour Meteor. He chairs the cabinet's defence and overseas policy committee that meets early next month.

The White House note, signed simply "Bill", is the second Mr Clinton has sent in the past six months to underline how seriously the president takes the deal, worth around £900m. "Ultimately, I know there are many factors that must enter into your BVRAAM contract selection," wrote Mr Clinton. "I feel strongly that the Raytheon option is the one that best serves the interest of both our nations." Mr Clinton stresses the track record of the Raytheon missile and the American company's plan to co-operate with European firms including Shorts in Belfast. Andy Head, a Raytheon Systems director in Britain, confirming the letter's existence, said the Clinton administration had made an unprecedented offer to share top-secret breakthroughs in missiles technology with Britain and the Pentagon had put up an initial $250m (£160m) for this. The President's intervention came as both sides claimed that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, favoured their version of the missile - because they would create jobs in or near his Dunfermline constituency. The Euro-consortium has cut its price to around £750m. Raytheon, which is offering a cheaper £450m version capable of upgrade, claims to have the "secret recipe" for treasury approval in cost-savings and "smart" procurement that prevents over-runs. But industry insiders point to the American firm's declin ing share price. "They are looking to the UK taxpayer to bail them out of a real financial crisis," one said. A senior Whitehall source said: "New projects have a history of massive over-runs and it is true to say the treasury has some concerns." The ministry of defence's equipment approvals committee will recommend either the US or European versions next week amid mounting evidence that it favours Meteor. But the final decision will be Mr Blair's, who is also said to favour Meteor. He chairs the cabinet's defence and overseas policy committee that meets early next month.

webTitle: Debt relief plan is slipping behind

fields.headline: Debt relief plan is slipping behind
fields.trailText: The west's programme of debt relief for the world's poorest countries is in danger of slipping behind schedule, the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The west's programme of debt relief for the world's poorest countries is in danger of slipping behind schedule, the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, warned yesterday.

Leaders from the world's seven biggest economies pledged last autumn to deliver debt relief to 11 countries by Easter, but yesterday Mr Wolfensohn admitted that they were unlikely to reach that target. He said just eight would be through by Easter and warned that the total for the year could be a lot lower than the G7 hoped.

Mr Wolfensohn insisted the hold-up in debt forgiveness was "delay for delay's sake". To qualify, poor countries must show they will spend the savings from debt relief on programmes to relieve poverty but the process is proving time-consuming for the bank and the International Monetary Fund and for the countries themselves.

However Clare Short, Britain's international development secretary, warned yesterday that some poor countries were in danger of being bogged down by the paperwork required.

"What is happening in Washington is that there's a delay looking for the perfect poverty reduction strategy, which means that the timetable for debt relief won't be kept," Ms Short said. "If you ask for perfection you'll be waiting for decades."

Britain has argued that countries should not be required to spell out to the last letter how they will spend the money before they get the first instalment of debt relief. However, other G7 countries are insisting on seeing detailed plans.

Mr Wolfensohn said that the Bank was under considerable pressure from creditor countries to speed up the process.

"We have people working day and night on this," he said. But many poor countries lack even basic information about existing education and health programmes. "In a lot of these countries they don't even have the statistics," he said.

fields.headline: Selfridges proposes new London landmark
fields.trailText: Department store group Selfridges hopes to build one of the country's tallest towers in the heart of London's West End.
fields.body:
Department store group Selfridges hopes to build one of the country's tallest towers in the heart of London's West End.

The retailer has called in architects Norman Foster & Partners to work on designs for a "landmark" tower in the capital, which Selfridges envisages will be a big tourist attraction.

"We would demolish the car park and hotel at the back of our Oxford Street store, above, and, depending how high we are allowed to go, build a centre that would bring together retail, residential, restaurant and office space," said finance director Peter Williams.

"And we would like to put a public viewing gallery on the top. There is nowhere in London that you can go to get a panoramic view of the city, apart from the Millennium Wheel and you are only at the top of that for a few minutes." The tower complex would be known as the Selfridges Centre or the Selfridges Tower.

Norman Foster & Partners is the architectural inspiration behind some of London's most imaginative projects - including the new Wembley Stadium, the egg-shaped glass building which will house the new Greater London Assembly and the soon to be opened Millennium Bridge across the Thames.

Selfridges grand plan for a new London skyscraper emerged as the store group confirmed its third store is to be built at the centre of Birmingham's Bull Ring redevelopment. For that project the company has enlisted the award-winning architects Future Systems, which dreamed up the space-age media centre at Lord's cricket ground.

The cost of building the new stores will be met by developers although Selfridges said it would be pumping £40m into the new store.

"The reason for calling in Future Systems is that we want the store to stand out", said Mr Williams. "We want a building of architectural distinction. We probably won't even put a Selfridges sign on it. People will just know it is Selfridges."

webTitle: Shares slip on poor Glaxo SmithKline results

fields.headline: Shares slip on poor Glaxo SmithKline results
fields.trailText: Merging drugs Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham revealed patchy profits growth yesterday, prompting SmithKline's chief executive Jan Leschly to admit that the combined company may struggle to maintain its lead as the world's largest pharmaceuticals corporation.
fields.body:
Merging drugs Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham revealed patchy profits growth yesterday, prompting SmithKline's chief executive Jan Leschly to admit that the combined company may struggle to maintain its lead as the world's largest pharmaceuticals corporation.

Glaxo's underlying annual profits edged up 3.8% to £2.78bn, held back by poor sales of the migraine drug Imigran and smoking cessation product Zyban earlier in the year.

SmithKline produced a stronger performance - its profits climbed 13.3% to £1.94bn, amid surging demand for flu drug Augmentin and a first contribution from diabetes product Avandia.

The figures disappointed the market. Glaxo's shares slipped 50p to £14.59, while SmithKline's dropped 19p to 6755p.

Mr Leschly conceded that the two groups were growing more slowly than Pfizer and Warner Lambert, the two American companies also in the middle of merging. He said: "That Pfizer happens to be up with us is an advantage for them but not a disadvantage for us." Glaxo SmithKline will initially hold the top spot as the world's largest drugs company, ahead of Pfizer Warner. However, Mr Leschly insisted: "It really is not relevant if we are number one or number two. The two merged companies will lead by themselves - they are well ahead of the rest."

Both Glaxo SmithKline and Pfizer Warner are likely to have market shares of around 7% after the tie-ups. Their closest rivals are likely to have around 4%.

Mr Leschly's successor, Jean-Pierre Garnier, said: "You have to see this not as a 100-yard dash, but as a marathon."

Mr Garnier insisted that Glaxo SmithKline had "considerable advantage" in research and development but admitted that "in the next year, it is true that a combination of Pfizer and Warner will be growing faster than Glaxo SmithKline."

The £105bn merger of Glaxo and SmithKline has had a cool reception on the market so far - shares in the two companies have fallen by 20% since the deal was unveiled a month ago.

Analysts suggested that yesterday's figures were unlikely to change sentiment. One said: "Everyone knew these were not going to be particularly strong figures. People are just feeling jaundiced about the sector generally."

The merger is likely to mean thousands of job losses - unions predict more than 15,000 jobs could go worldwide, including up to 5,000 in Britain.

webTitle: Pin-ups and porn? You must be joking

fields.headline: Pin-ups and porn? You must be joking
fields.standfirst: Marlene Dumas paints pictures of men, women and children in highly sexualised, provocative poses. So why can't she understand when people get steamed up about them?  Adrian Searle  talks to her
fields.trailText: Sex, bodies, painted situations. Marlene Dumas paints men and women in provocative poses, mooning and proffering themselves. A man looking at his erection, someone corseted in a straitjacket, a long-legged supermodel, a pregnant woman. The faces are sometimes alluring, sometimes ferocious, sometimes vulnerable or empty.
fields.body:
Sex, bodies, painted situations. Marlene Dumas paints men and women in provocative poses, mooning and proffering themselves. A man looking at his erection, someone corseted in a straitjacket, a long-legged supermodel, a pregnant woman. The faces are sometimes alluring, sometimes ferocious, sometimes vulnerable or empty.

Some of Dumas's recent works are now on display at the Camden Art Centre in London. The rawness and directness of her paintings have led viewers to some very odd conclusions about their maker. "I've had people complain that I'm not black, not a soul singer and not Janis Joplin either," Dumas says during a break from hanging the show. She is at pains to point out that she is not Dutch either, although she has lived in the Netherlands for more than 20 years. She is simply a white, South African-born, Amsterdam-based painter.

Marlene Dumas once dubbed herself Miss Interpreted, part of the wordplay in which she names her paintings and exhibitions. That nickname points up the painter's fate, the artist seen in the light of criticism and commentaries. She has no time for those who equate her images to real life. Her drawn and painted figures are not actual people, whose lives might have a moral dimension.

"My work isn't a politically correct project. It isn't about shock either. And it isn't a narrative, or the story of my life and loves," she says. One of the most uncomfortable things about her paintings is precisely that they don't tell stories, or imply moral judgment. "Paintings can't really be narrative," she says, "because you never get a story, only a single image. I don't paint a kiss, for example, because you look at the kiss and the people kissing, but somehow you remain outside the image." Instead, Dumas wants the experience of looking to be charged or dramatised, to drag the viewer in.

She insists that her paintings don't present us with prostitutes, readers' wives, porno glamour girls, male and female strippers. They're images, with all the ambiguity that images entail. Maybe there are no innocent images. Even when she paints a baby, or a naked infant, it is a sexualised image. It's natural, she says, that a figurative painter would address the sexual, and use images of nakedness as source material. Dumas says she needs something to react to. Rely on what's in your own head and you come up with stereotypes. Meaning arises out of the encounter between the artist, the images she works from, and the image she creates, plus that later encounter between the viewer and the work.

Does Dumas think women and men see her work in the same way? There's a difference, she suspects, and it is largely cultural, rather than innate. She muses that Michelangelo was great at painting naked men, terrible at women: they're just men with tits. "Women, I think, are more interested in touching; men are interested in looking." Painting, as much as it is visual, is a tactile activity. For Dumas, it is as often about taking paint off, wiping paint away, as putting it on. The painting reveals its sense as it goes along.

Dumas's drawings are shown just as they would be in her studio, pinned directly to the wall. Pinned-up but not pin-ups, although her models often come from her own photographs, from fashion spreads and porn mags. You can never escape the paintedness of the images, the language of her art. Dumas's drawings are worked rapidly in washy paint and have a slightly crazy air. The liquid soaks and spreads into the paper, creating puddles, drooling runs and feathery bleeds, through which Dumas navigates faces, torsos, sexual organs. Drawing for her seems to be a process of containment of these controlled accidents. And never doing too much, that's the key. This takes confidence.

In the show there's an image of a man looking down at his engorged penis. "Originally he was looking out at the viewer, which had a completely different reading. It didn't work, so I changed his hair to hide his eyes." Now he looks like Ruud Gullit, peering down at himself. The image, it seems to me, has flipped into completely different territory. We're looking at a man looking at himself, a collision between voyeurism and narcissism. There's another image of a Turkish girl, legs up, sex exposed. Her feet are cropped by the top edge of the painting. This makes you feel uncomfortably close to the image - as though your vision is cropped by your proximity too it. And the girl does look back, watching you watching her.

Of course, we're watching Dumas too, watching her painting when we look at her work. This is one of the preoccupations of her writings. Dumas's notes and texts - poetic, aphoristic, funny and fierce - range from the entirely self-referential to her encounters with Goya and Rubens, and run in tandem with painting and drawing, which is why she's been spoken of as a painter "with one foot in the conceptual camp". "I talk too much," Dumas says. "I'm going to get angry now!" She clearly finds the idea that painters should stick to painting, rather than talking or writing, horribly oppressive. She talks and goes on talking.

She wanted to be a writer, she says, but she's a painter. No, I protest, she is a writer, a painter who writes. And don't paintings, if they're any good, always have a foot in conceptualism? "My mother asked me why I didn't go back to making more 'philosophical' works instead of all this stuff about sex. And why not address things like child abuse, she said, because that's a big issue now in South Africa. But I said that would be even more pornographic..."

She laughs about artists' interviews, the way many of her peers insist on giving an "official version" of themselves, saying the same things over and over, honing the act. It's much more fun to make it up as you go along. But here's the warning: in her book of collected writings, Sweet Nothings, Dumas includes a short text called No More Interviews, in which she listed the reasons she didn't want to give any more "spontaneous" interviews. "I can't think things over properly with a stranger facing me," she said. "I'm not an entertainer." She wrote those lines more than 15 years ago. They may not haunt the artist, but they haunt the interviewer, the misinterpreter.

MD: Marlene Dumas is at Camden Arts Centre, London NW3 (0171-435 2643), till March 26.
