fields.headline: Body talk
fields.standfirst: Tango shouldn't even exist in the 21st century, with its submissive women meekly following dominant males. So why did  Judith Mackrell get such a thrill from her afternoon at the tea dance?
fields.trailText: It is Sunday afternoon and a man, a total stranger, has me pinioned to his chest and groin. "Just stay in front of me," he orders quietly, "and keep calm." All around me are elegantly dressed men and women, impervious to my plight. But why would I want to be rescued? I'm having my first tango lesson - and the time of my life.
fields.body:
It is Sunday afternoon and a man, a total stranger, has me pinioned to his chest and groin. "Just stay in front of me," he orders quietly, "and keep calm." All around me are elegantly dressed men and women, impervious to my plight. But why would I want to be rescued? I'm having my first tango lesson - and the time of my life.

The scene is the gilt extravagance of the Waldorf Hotel's tea room, where Sunday dances are organised by tango dancer and zealot Christine Denniston. Denniston was once a graduate in theoretical physics but when she learned to tango in 1992 she discovered a way of life. She ran off to Buenos Aires, hung around its dance halls and learned her skills from some of Argentina's great tango masters. Now she is one of Britain's leading performers of the dance.

Many of the Waldorf dancers are pupils and friends of Denniston; some of them have embraced tango with almost equal fervour. Over the past five years it has attracted a huge following, not only through clubs and classes, but also through stage shows - the latest of which, Una Noche de Tango, is about to open in London.

The cult of Latin dance isn't new to drizzle-bound Britain. Various crazes have come and gone, inspired by Massine's flamenco-based ballet Le Tricorne (1919), Valentino's Hollywood tango, and visits from authentic Spanish virtuosos such as La Argentinita. Since the 80s our enthusiasm seems to have been unbroken, sustained by flamenco films like Carmen, visiting companies such as Cumbre Flamenca and the enduring salsa craze. For audiences, these hot foreign dances offer a mini-break to an exotic culture, but for participants they provide a special form of release. Many argue that they don't so much become a different person when they dance the steps of another country, rather they become more themselves.

Tango lovers further insist that its qualities are unique. Its glamour, of course, is notorious. Tango is a dance to dress up for - beckoning women to put on their highest heels and men their sharpest suits - and while it evokes the heady perfume of European salons it also has the low-down, dirty whiff of the Buenos Aires barrios where it was born. It possesses too the most sensually wayward of rhythms, in its long, teasing, improvised glides and flick knife meshing of legs, its high, elegant strides and yielding arch of the back.

The regulars at the Waldorf are dressed to the nines; the tourists who wander in off the street gape into the tea room as if it were a scene from an old movie. But image is the least of it, as I discover from the men who selflessly volunteer to steer me around the floor (three of whom are part of Denniston's ineffably gallant team of "taxi dancers").

Barry Jones, for instance, is perfectly styled in 40s mobster chic, with a flamboyant, macho suit and classically spivvy moustache. He looks like an extra from The Godfather, but when I ask what attracted him to tango his answer floors me more than the dancing. "I got into it through yoga," he replies calmly. "It has the same quality of inwardness. It's like meditation for two. It's body, mind and spirit."

As soon as I start getting the hang of it, I realise that Barry is not some New Age tango mutant. Learning to tango is not about struggling, competitively, to perfect alien steps. It's about relaxing deep into a partner's practised embrace, feeling, literally, the beat of his heart and allowing him to lead you through the music. The more tuned two dancers become to each other, the more elegantly they elaborate their moves and the less obvious it becomes who is leading and who is being led. A dancer will learn all of the tango's characteristic steps, but as Denniston says, "it's by contagion rather than imitation".

The analogy with sex is so obvious I hate to mention it. But as everyone remarks, the greatest tango dancers aren't necessarily the ones who can do the flashiest moves; they're the ones who are the most responsive, the most physically at ease.

Denniston has an interesting theory about why tango evolved this way. In the first decades of the 20th century, Buenos Aires was teeming with immigrants, many of whom were men, many of whom felt painfully isolated from their families back home. The tango's embrace, its technical requirement of intimacy, was a way of getting close to strangers. Even in the plush Waldorf I was startled by how much I learned about my partners and how fast. Every turn around the floor was like an intense physical conversation, characterised by the relaxed, witty confidence of one partner, the more tender formality of another.

Denniston also describes how tango used to be a man's most guaranteed form of dating women. When an Argentinian boy hit puberty he would be initiated by an older man, who'd lead him around the dance floor. After a year he'd practise with other boys, taking it in turns to lead and follow. After three years he'd finally ask a real woman to tango, by which time he'd not only be a divinely proficient dancer, he'd also, as Denniston says, "have spent three years learning how to put himself in a woman's place, understanding how to make the dance easy and comfortable for her". He'd be irresistible.

This tango culture was current until the 50s when dance halls were banned by fascist governments. In 1983 the fall of the junta sparked a massive revival but the old ways weren't fully restored. As a lot of people wanted to learn the tango fast, many teachers taught it as they would any other dance, by demonstrating its steps in isolation and getting pupils to copy them.

In today's commercial shows it's easy to distinguish the dancers who have "been infected" by tango from those who have picked it up in the dance studio. The latter tend to be highly professional Argentinian folk dancers who have been cast because they are younger, glossier and more disciplined than authentic tango dancers. They may be virtuoso performers but it's the dumpier middle-aged couples who usually make our hair stand on end. They make us feel that they are dancing heart to heart, that they're not only dancing steps, but an entire lifetime, even an entire history.

The loss of tradition worries Denniston deeply. Not only does it breed a culture where qualities of style and musicality are often sacrificed to superficial competence, it also denies tango's unique form of contact. Even for beginners, old-style tango involves an element of emotional as well as physical communion: two people hearing the music as one, improvising their moves as one. Denniston argues that in high-tech societies where people increasingly live alone, this intimacy is one we can ill afford to lose. Among her own pupils, many report that tango changes the way they behave: they get better at intuiting body language, they learn how to assert themselves without being aggressive, they find they can give in to people without feeling weak.

Is tango simply an excuse for male control freaks to boss submissive female partners around the floor? Women do sometimes dance with other women in public, and even take the lead with a male partner, but in Argentina this is still rare. In Sally Potter's film The Tango Lesson, Pablo, her Argentinian partner, rants at Potter's over-active dancing. "You should do nothing... When you dance, you should follow. Otherwise you block my freedom to move - You destroy my liberty and I can do nothing." This may sound like male pride dressed up in Lawrentian metaphysics, but the reality is much more attractive. Alan Brown, one of my own partners, admits that some "warped" men do get off on the idea of power, but he insists they're a tiny minority. Before we start to dance he tells me to think of him "as a tango sweet shop. I'm here for you to take all kinds of delicious tango sweets from." It's a perfect image. Alan guides me expertly around the floor, covers up all my mistakes, and makes it possible for me to do steps I didn't know I could do. As Denniston says, "If this is macho, then I wish the world were a more macho place."

webTitle: Mental barriers to Pinochet standing trial

fields.headline: Mental barriers to Pinochet standing trial
fields.standfirst:
The following is an edited version of the findings of a medical examination of General Pinochet conducted at Northwick Park Hospital, London, on January 5, 2000, by Professor Sir John Grimley Evans, Dr MJ Denham and Professor Andrew Lees.

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: An edited version of the findings of a medical examination of General Pinochet conducted at Northwick Park Hospital, London, on January 5, 2000, by Professor Sir John Grimley Evans, Dr MJ Denham and Professor Andrew Lees.
fields.body:
Past medical history

Asthma diagnosed 1980; diabetes mellinus type 2 diagnosed 1990. Cardiac conduction defect identified 1992. A pacemaker was inserted and amiodarone prescribed. Previous attacks of gout, previous repair of left inguinal hernia; deafness due to accoustic trauma. Parkinsonian features and memory defect.

Recent medical history

For the last eight to nine months he has noted difficulty in walking, and can now only cover 200 yards before his legs become too weak to continue. He now walks with a stick. Numbness over the soles of his feet has progressed over that time.

Over the last 10 months he has noticed a gradual progression of problems with memory which have become much more marked recently. He has difficulties in remembering people's names and in recalling events of long ago. He has been reported as talking as if he had difficulty in turning ideas into speech.

On September 9, 1999, he was walking in the garden and developed sudden headache and imbalance. Other episodes ... reported to us include once failing to recognise his wife and once failing to register that his son had visited him. He recalls an instance in which his vision became dim.

When seen by Dr Thomas on September 14 ... the clinical diagnosis was of multiple small bilateral cerebral infarcts.

When reviewed later ... further deterioration with probable further cerebral ischaemic event on September 20 and October 9. A definite increase in parkinsonian features was noted, with ... speech difficulty, deterioration in hand writing, inability to dress himself, and needing help in rising from a chair.

Since then the senator has had two further falls, one in the garden and one in the bathroom, both due to loss of balance without impairment of consciousness. His voice ... has deteriorated.

There is a history of urinary symptoms - hesitancy, poor stream, urgency and occasional minor incontinence. He can generally stay in bed until early morning but thereafter may have to void three or four times.

Senator Pinochet was depressed last summer but following a change of medication ... this has ceased to be a problem. He still feels homesick and bored and frustrated by physical ills.

In recent months he has lost interest in former activities. He used to read and use the computer but now tends to sit watching television and says he has forgotten how to use the computer. Letter writing has become a chore. Recently he has developed difficulty in shaving without cutting himself.

Examination

Senator Pinochet arrived in wheelchair and was interviewed in bed. He is severely deaf ... he was alert and cooperative but easily tired. His voice was quiet and monotonous in tone and speech was indistinct.

Cerebration: Showed slowness in comprehension with difficulty in understanding complex instructions.

Mood: Good rapport and cooperative. Face immobile but smiled appropriately. Sense of humour intact. No evidence of depression.

Gait: Required help in getting out of bed and in steadying when standing. Wide-based short-paced gait holding stick in right hand and no swinging of left arm. Tendency to fall backwards. Turning unremarkable.

Neuropsychological assessment undertaken in Spanish by Dr Maria A. Wyke, Devonshire Hospital, London. "Gen Pinochet shows a moderate/severe deterioration of intellectual function beyond that due to his age. He was a person of superior intelligence and at present in functioning within the low/average range. Short term memory, learning ability and delayed recall all show severe deficit. His greatest difficulty is his inability to retain information over time. There is no evidence Gen Pinochet is attempting to fake disability. In my opinion he would not be able to cope with the legal complexities of a trial."

Conclusions

General: Senator Pinochet has a complex medical history, but the main active medical problems at present are diabetic peripheral neuropathy and recently progressive cerebrovascular brain damage. The diabetic neuropathology is contributing to difficulties in walking and ... will also have predisposed to arterial disease as will a past history of smoking.

The cerebrovascular disease has manifested partly as minor strokes and transient asthmatic attacks but also causes progressive damage without acute symptoms. There is clinical evidence of extensive damage to the brain ... producing features of parkinsonism.

Fitness for trial

Physically: Senator Pinochet would at present be able to attend a trial but ... further deterioration in both physical and mental condition is likely.

Mentally: It is our view that Senator Pinochet would not at the present be mentally capable of meaningful participation in a trial. We base this opinion on:

1. Memory defecit for both recent and remote events;

2. Limited ability to understand complex sentences and questions owing to memory impairment and consequent inability to process verbal information appropriately;

3. Impaired ability to express himself audibly, succinctly and relevantly;

4. Easy fatiguability.

With these impediments he would be unable to follow the progress of a trial sufficiently to instruct counsel. He would have difficulty in understanding the content and implications of questions put to him.

His memory of remote events is impaired. He would have difficulty making himself heard and understood in replying to questions.

We are satisfied that the impediments we have identified are due to brain damage, as they are coherent in nature and consistent in manifestation and formal neuropsychological testing showed none of the features of deliberate exaggeration of impairment.

Situational stress, as likely to be occasioned by trial, produces physiological responses that could accelerate the progression of vascular disease. We were told, however, that Senator Pinochet has in the past shown notable personal abilities in managing stress. We therefore do not feel able to express any useful opinion on the possible effects on his health of undergoing trial.

Although some day to day fluctuation in functional abilities is characteristic of brain damage due to cerebrovascular disease we consider further sustained functional improvement of a significant degree unlikely.

Doctors support report findings

 David Black, consultant geriatrician: "I think what it [the leaked report] shows is that he [General Pinochet] is a frail, elderly gentleman with many of the common diseases and conditions associated with old age.

"The main problem he has is with strokes. He has had a number of small strokes in different parts of the brain which not only impede his short term memory, but his ability to deal with complex ideas.

"Strokes are unfortunately common among the elderly, but Pinochet has diabetes which makes strokes more likely. The likelihood is that people with diabetes tend to have further episodes in the future.

"He also has physical symptoms similar to those of a Parkinson's sufferer. He may suffer falls, have difficulty walking and dressing himself.

"It should be said that this is an incredibly detailed and thorough report. While mental capacity to stand trial is ultimately a decision for the courts, my opinion is that it would be very difficult to try someone with the damage described."

 Professor Janet Askham, social gerontologist: "The people who examined [General Pinochet] are all very reputable people and the conclusions they have drawn are much as any reputable medical practitioner would have drawn: that such a person would have difficulty in standing trial.

"On the evidence, I am in no position to disagree. [General Pinochet] has difficulties with memory, both short term and long term which would be difficult for a trial though not necessarily for every day life, especially if he lives with others. Obviously, he is not severely demented."

 Dr Brian Williams, president of the British Geriatrics Society: "The report shows he has multiple medical problems and quite a significant medical history going back over 10 years which had accelerated in the last six months, particularly since September and October. The major aspect of this report is that there is significant brain disorder due to a disease of the blood vessels and no doubt strokes have affected the brain.

Clearly he is a highly intelligent man who due to disease of the blood vessels would now appear at best to have difficulty in understanding complex conversation and at worst to have difficulty in taking part in anything complex. Frankly he is a man who is very unwell."

Interviews by Angelique Chrisafis

fields.headline: Kuwait over the moon
fields.standfirst: Bhutan's part in a 20-goal soccer thriller
fields.trailText: Life could be worse, even if you are Middlesbrough. The Teessiders lost 4-0 at home to Aston Villa on Thursday with Paul Gascoigne breaking his arm while assaulting a Villa player, leaving manager Bryan Robson in danger of losing his job. But at least he does not manage Bhutan, who in an Asian Cup group 5 qualifying match on Monday lost 20-nil to Kuwait, not usually rated one of the world's more notable footballing nations, in the biggest defeat at this level on record. Kuwait's star striker Bashar Abdullah scored eight of the goals, as Bhutan conceded four penalties and had two of their players sent off for making rugby tackles.
fields.body:
Life could be worse, even if you are Middlesbrough. The Teessiders lost 4-0 at home to Aston Villa on Thursday with Paul Gascoigne breaking his arm while assaulting a Villa player, leaving manager Bryan Robson in danger of losing his job. But at least he does not manage Bhutan, who in an Asian Cup group 5 qualifying match on Monday lost 20-nil to Kuwait, not usually rated one of the world's more notable footballing nations, in the biggest defeat at this level on record. Kuwait's star striker Bashar Abdullah scored eight of the goals, as Bhutan conceded four penalties and had two of their players sent off for making rugby tackles.

This result raises questions familiar to every supporter in Britain. Does the rot begin in the schools? Is Bhutan spending as much as it should on its playing fields? Are politicians to blame for discouraging a competitive culture? Is there a dearth of left-sided attackers? Or are there, perhaps, too many overseas players flooding into Bhutan, depriving home-grown talents of their places in leading sides? Are they lining up 5-3-2 when they ought to play 4-3-3, or 4-3-2-1 when it ought to be 3-5-2? Then the manager: is he a turnip? And if not, which locally popular root crop is he being compared with?

No doubt an agitation will now begin in Bhutan for a miracle-worker to be brought in from some great footballing nation - perhaps even from Britain. Whether we have such magicians to spare is a matter of doubt. What we certainly have in profusion, though, is a band of pundits, some recently retired from the game and others even more recently returned from the bar, as skilled as any throughout the world in interminably posing questions involving words like disgrace and malaise, which they then fail to answer. Bhutan is welcome to every one of them. As for Bashar Abdullah, there might be an opening for him at the Riverside Stadium, Middlesbrough, TS3 6RS, England.

fields.headline: Try a hard drive-in movie
fields.standfirst: Movies via the net could do more than hit your local video hire shop. Jack Schofield looks at the implications for the whole film industry
fields.trailText: Movies via the net could do more than hit your local video hire shop. Jack Schofield looks at the implications for the whole film industry
fields.body:
Cliff Stanford has made one fortune by bringing the internet to the mass market, through Demon Internet, and now he'd like to make another by using the net to deliver movies. This week the Redbus Film Group, of which Stanford is chairman, said it had secured the rights to some notable films, but the two-year old film distribution company won't launch an internet service until high-speed access is more widely available.

Not everyone is waiting. There's already a fast-growing market for what the traditional media business calls "video on demand", but the net knows as "streaming media". The net can't yet deliver what Stanford wants - "full-screen TV pictures with VHS quality" - and what the mainstream film-watching public requires. But if you want to be entertained for a minute or three, are receptive to independent productions, and don't mind watching a screen image the size of a credit card, the internet already has lots to offer.

It's been disparaged as "cinema for the MTV generation" and "short attention span theatre", but you get a front-row seat without leaving your desk, and the latest releases are only a mouse-click away. The leading websites include Atomfilms and iFilm, a film community site, Yahoo! Broadcast and ShortBuzz. Pseudo and LoadTV also provide streamed content but in a more TV-like style. (LoadTV has Death Row Records' music videos.)

Michael Cornish, managing director of Atomfilms in Europe, says: "We stream more movies than any other website, as far as I know: we're shipping one to two million movies a month, and it's growing month on month. But if you're expecting a television-like experience, you'll be disappointed." But this is just the start of a development that could change the industry, and some of the major players have noticed.

Film industry hot shots Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg think streaming video has, in the latter's words, "unlimited potential": their company, DreamWorks, is working with Imagine Entertainment on a site called Pop.com, which is expected in the spring. Warner Bros Online is also exploring web-based video through its Entertaindom site, launched late last year. Others will follow.

Perhaps the digital wind of change that blew through the publishing industry in the 80s and the music industry in the 90s will have a similar impact on the film industry in the coming decade. Certainly the arrival of affordable digital cameras, powerful personal computers and video-editing software will enable a wider range of people to make movies. However, it's really the internet that has changed the picture. Thanks to the net, movies that wouldn't normally be seen outside a film festival are now available to a global audience. In fact, the net has suddenly made short films a prized commodity, with more than a dozen websites competing to attract the best.

While there may not be much money in it, there are real prizes: the Charged webzine and Film.com are running ChargeCoupled, a competition for one-minute movies, while the web-based Hollywood Film Festival has recently added a Hollywood Digital Film Festival.

It's a somewhat arty market, but Cornish says this reflects the demographics of the net, which is skewed towards young males. "It also reflects what's available: the big entertainment companies are not putting their movies on the internet, so you're seeing alternative forms of content. Having said that, we've got the best British content [at Atomfilms] including several Bafta award winners and Nick Park's Aardvark films...." In the US, at least, the net has been adopted by experimental film makers, and the Binary Theatre specialises in student films.

British independents and film students don't seem to have taken their chance. The Institute of Contemporary Arts in London, for example, runs Uncut, a series of monthly meetings for up-and-coming film makers, but Christine Atha of the ICA's education department says the internet hasn't made any impact so far. She couldn't think of anyone who'd put a film online.

Nor could Eric Janssen at the London International Film School, "the oldest film school in the world". He said: "none of our students are doing it at the moment - the technology is moving way too fast for us - but it won't be long now, that's for sure."

That's a shame because the cinema is going digital in a hurry. "We have digital editing, digital production, digital projection, and in the future we'll have direct digital distribution," says Cornish, "so film will disappear. It's happening at a speed far greater than people realise." Gill Henderson, chief executive of the London Film and Video Development Agency, which has a £700,000 budget to support independent film, video and television, says: "From the short film maker's point of view, the net is going to be the easiest, quickest and cheapest way of distributing your work. The changes [digital technology] will bring to the exhibition [of films] could in some ways be the most revolutionary part of the process.

"It will blow open a lot of things like copyright and [restricted] territories for selling films. I don't think a lot of people have thought this through, yet." Everyone also agrees that the breakthrough will come with high-speed broadband internet access via ADSL phone lines or cable modems. These work at least 10 times faster than standard 56K dial-up modems. "By moving to broadband you get a quantum leap in the quality of the entertainment experience," Cornish says, "because the picture size moves from being quite small to quite large. It's as simple as that! You can also bundle in a lot of ancillary information, as with DVD, which makes it much more compelling. So broadband becomes the inflection point for really serious growth."

And when that happens, the film students, experimental movie makers and pop video directors who are attracting an audience on today's web will have to compete with full length features made with big budgets and Hollywood production values. Companies like Stanford's Redbus Internet Distribution will be on the web selling streamed movies on a pay-per-view basis, to save you the trip to a video rental shop. Stanford says: "we're working on compression techniques to get the bandwidth down to 512 kilobits per second, which is well within the capabilities of cable modems and ASDL. We could be ready by the end of this year, maybe." You could be logging on to the web to watch movies sooner than you think.

Stream that video... or download it?
Short-film and TV-style websites like to use "streaming media", which means the movie starts within 20 or 30 seconds of clicking the icon or hot-link to display it.

The advantage is that you can start watching a video without having to download the whole thing, which could take 10 or 20 minutes. The main disadvantage of streaming a film or video clip is that it will inevitably suffer from a slow frame rate, gaps (dropouts) and image corruption due to network congestion and delays.

It will also be small, because a small image requires less data - and therefore less bandwidth - than a large one. Websites often offer a choice of 56K and 28.8K videos for different modem speeds. The smaller 28.8K version needs less bandwidth and will usually stream better.

An alternative is to download films to your hard drive and play them back later. This avoids network congestion and bandwidth limitations, though bigger and better images still mean a bigger file download.

An advantage of downloading films is that, once saved to disk, you can play them as often as you like, or "burn" them onto a CD for long-term storage. However, it's annoying to download a 10MB or larger movie file, find you don't like it, and delete it after watching the first few seconds.

Surfers with broadband (high bandwidth) internet connections such as ADSL and cable modems should get good results with streaming video. Those with dial-up modem connections will get better results by downloading files.

Downloading files can take some time, so it helps to have a free or flat-rate internet connection, even if the "free" periods are only in the evening and/or at weekends.

However, it's also essential to have Headlight Software's GetRight or a similar utility, which can be downloaded from the net.

In the web's early days, if the phone connection was dropped (or often if it wasn't) a file download would stop, and you'd have to start again from the beginning.

For maximum aggravation, downloads usually stopped when 90-95% complete. However, GetRight can automatically redial and resume a broken download (if the server supports the resume feature).

You can also run it in the background and download a file over several sessions, when you happen to be on the web for other purposes. This is a very efficient use of bandwidth and should make short films available to all but the most parsimonious users.

To play back a movie you also need player software, which is usually free.

RealNetworks' RealVideo is probably essential - Michael Cornish of Atomfilms reckons it has about 85% of the streaming video market - with Macromedia's Shockwave Flash for cartoons.

Microsoft's Windows Media Player supports a wide range of streaming and playback formats such as .avi, .asf, .mpg, .mpeg, .mp2 and .mp3, including Apple's QuickTime (.qt, .mov etc), though you may also want Apple's own player. (Yes, there is a Microsoft Windows Media Player for Macintosh.)

Media sites usually provide links to sites where visitors can download any player required.

fields.headline: Logic
fields.standfirst:
Logic
****
Chelsea Centre, London
fields.trailText:
Logic
****
Chelsea Centre, London
fields.body:
The Chelsea Centre is proving itself a hothouse of new writing talent. Not content with bagging a minor Tony Kushner premiere, it also showcased Amy Rosenthal's Sitting Pretty. The follow-up, Stephanie McKnight's intriguing two-hander, is equally impressive.

Thirty years ago Helen left her toddler Issy in the care of her husband while she went to work in Lebanon as a nurse. Now Issy is grown up and her unhappiness is a blight on the lives of those around her, particularly her half-sister Frankie, herself a mother. When Helen reappears, the stage is set for a showdown.

McKnight's script may be low on probability, but the writing is taut, playing with our shifting sympathies. Best of all, the play opens out beyond its themes of maternal guilt and responsibility into a drama about the way our families make us and the knots that must be cut to survive.

Cleverly designed by Rebecca Hurst to re-create the claustrophobic interior of a London tube train, Suzanne Bell's production creates a nervy netherworld, a kind of surrogate confessional box where the hurt of being survivors comes tumbling out. It is a sharp, compelling production of a really good little play, made all the more lethal by razor-like performances from Michelle Newell as the prodigal mother and Raquel Cassidy as a young woman with a mile-wide chip on her shoulder.

 Until February 26. Box office: 0171-352 1967.

fields.headline: The clown's requiem
fields.standfirst:
Hopeless Games
Komedia, Brighton
*****
fields.trailText:
Hopeless Games
Komedia, Brighton
*****
fields.body:
The station is empty. The last train has departed. But there are ghosts lurking in the shadows. Coats hanging in a rack sprout hands and bowler hats grow heads; a fat headless midget waddles across the stage holding a blue balloon that solemnly stands to attention.

To the wail of music interspersed with catches of children's song and calls, other ghostly figures emerge. These are the vagrants, the outcasts, and the eternal refugees who, with suitcases in hand, pick their way across the train tracks on the moth-eaten map of Europe. At one point a train looms out of the video screen on the back wall and, in a screech of whistle and smoke, appears to thunder over the stage and into the audience. As the carriages rumble over the outcasts' prone bodies, the light wraps their limbs in a deadly caress.

Yet somehow you can't quite squeeze the life out of these spectres who dance their way to disaster and clown their way to catastrophe. They giggle and play Russian roulette as if they can cheat death; they stamp and dance with giddy defiance, shirts flapping like the wings of dying swans.

Played by a company of five whey-faced, shaven-headed clowns who are also skilled dancers, this hour-long piece from the Potsdam-based Russian-German theatre company Do-Theatre/Fabrik is both a requiem and a celebration. Stylistically, this company has much in common with that other Russian-German company, Derevo.

Drawing on both Butoh and European folk traditions it takes us on a surreal and playful journey in the heart of darkness. It awakens the past, breathes life into all those old black and white photos and forces us to remember not the ghosts, but the flesh and blood. It turns millions into individuals.

Towards the end, the back of the stage erupts in fireworks. The figures walk towards the light and their bodies are illuminated by exploding patterns of colour and light. Like the entire show there is something both joyous and terrible about this image. These people are transfigured. But it's hard not to avert your eyes from the burning.

 Until February 19. Box office: 01273 647100.

webTitle: Former building societies in scramble for dot.com credibility

fields.headline: Former building societies in scramble for dot.com credibility
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Woolwich
Halifax
fields.trailText: Woolwich and Halifax yesterday joined the banking sector's scramble for "dot.com" credibility by proclaiming their technological advances.
fields.body:
Woolwich and Halifax yesterday joined the banking sector's scramble for "dot.com" credibility by proclaiming their technological advances.

As it reported a 5% rise in 1999 pre-tax profits to £530m, Woolwich set out its future on combining an old fashioned branch network with the "first" Wap (wireless application protocol) mobile phone banking service.

Halifax, which is due to report its profits figures tomorrow, linked up with BT and BT Cellnet to offer banking over Wap and GPRS (general packet radio service), the next generation of mobile phone technology.

Halifax named two non-executive directors to its board as a retailer "for the 21st century": Charles Dunstone, 35, the founder of Carphone Warehouse and Coline McConville, also 35, the chief operating offer of Clear Channel, the New York advertising group.

The two former building societies are expected to be followed today by Abbey National detailing plans for a stand-alone internet bank, codenamed Aquarius, in addition to its own-branded internet site.

Halifax is expected to follow tomorrow with further details of its new greenfield.co stand-alone bank.

NatWest, in the throes of being taken over by Royal Bank of Scotland, also claimed to be on the Wap map, developing a service with Orange, the mobile phone system.

"All banks are trying to position themselves as being on top of things as regards new distribution channels," said Nick Lord, banking analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, the US investment bank.

Banks' languishing share prices, pummelled of late by investors dumping "traditional" stocks, jumped yesterday when Halifax gained 22p to 453p and Woolwich rose 9p to 280p. Barclays, which claims to be country's biggest internet bank, jumped 7% to £15.48.

Richard Meddings, finance director of Woolwich, which has been regarded as being ahead of its rivals with its technology plans, admitted: "It's the year of delivery. It's a watershed year."

The bank has set its future on technology, through link-ups with Nokia and Vodafone, and its "open plan" Woolwich-branded integrated banking service, on which it will spend £30m developing in 2001 and 2002.

Woolwich is aiming for 2m "open plan" customers by 2002 and said that 20% of the 44,000 it had at the end of last year were new customers to the banks. It also has 100 customers piloting its Wap service, which allows customers to bank via mobile phone.

Woolwich is spending £125m on its technology plans. Mr Meddings said: "We have a clear strategy which people are increasingly seeing the merit of. That will come through in (stock market) value," he said.

James Crosby, the Halifax chief executive, said the mobile phone services would be introduced to its 2m current account customers, greenfield.co customers and clients of "other, as yet announced, internet ventures" in the summer.

fields.headline: Phantom inflation needs exorcising
fields.standfirst: Figures that do not figure
fields.trailText: It was always too good to last. Banished on Tuesday, inflation was back by 9.30 yesterday morning. Britain may have the weakest price pressures in the European Union but, if the latest data on the labour market are anything to go by, not for long.
fields.body:
It was always too good to last. Banished on Tuesday, inflation was back by 9.30 yesterday morning. Britain may have the weakest price pressures in the European Union but, if the latest data on the labour market are anything to go by, not for long.

According to the hawks in the City, the UK's recent good inflation record is history; what matters is what happens next, and ahead the warning lights are flashing bright. Average earnings picked up strongly in the year to December, with the annual rate of increase of 5.5% inconsistent with achieving the government's 2.5% inflation target. The rule of thumb is that part of the increase in earnings is covered by higher productivity, which improves by around 2.5% a year on average. Earnings at 5.5% minus productivity of 2.5% equals inflation of 3%. Inflation of 3% is higher than 2.5%, ergo interest rates are going up again.

But hold on a minute. Most of the increase in earnings was due to bonuses in the City and one-off millennium payments to hotel and catering staff. There is no suggestion that the level of pay settlements is on an upward curve; on the contrary, recent reports have shown they have come down in response to the fall in headline inflation, which remains the benchmark for wage negotiations.

We have been in the position before, in the summer of 1998 when the Bank of England raised rates in response to a phantom inflation threat from higher earnings caused by City bonuses. Presumably, the monetary policy committee will be operating on the basis of once bitten, twice shy - particularly since any further ratcheting up of interest rates would add to the impression that monetary policy is being set for overpaid bond dealers and internet millionaires in the south-east with more money than sense.

But this is not the real reason why the Bank needs to reflect before raising interest rates for the fifth time since the autumn. Let's assume that the hawks are right and the increase in earnings is not just a one-off but a sign that the labour market is overheating. What then? The experience of the past 25 years suggests companies will respond by passing on their extra costs in higher prices. But in the Britain of 2000, despite eight years of growth, that is not an option for vast chunks of the corporate sector. To take one example: sales of household goods were up 10% in the final three months of last year but prices are 0.7% lower than they were a year ago. Firms are simply not able to pass on higher costs in the way they did in the 70s and 80s; they take the hit on their margins instead.

The combination of a one percentage point increase in interest rates and the stronger pound means that monetary policy has already been tightened significantly in recent months. Real interest rates are 3.9% using the government's measure of inflation and 5.2% using the harmonised European index - high enough for an economy that grew by just under 2% last year and is on course for around 3% this year.

Moreover, any increase in short-term rates is likely to hurt precisely those parts of the economy that need some tender loving care - manufacturing and exporters. The government has taken comfort from indications that factory output has started to recover a little, but the message on the ground is that companies are hanging on by the skin of their teeth, increasing output but working on negligible or non-existent margins.

As for rising property prices in the south-east, most of those sitting on big capital gains and tempted to fund consumption by equity withdrawal have fixed-rate mortgages which are priced according to long-term interest rates. Pushing up short-term rates increases the Bank's anti-inflation credibility in the City, leading to lower long-term rates.

The treasury is aware of all this, and there will be fiscal measures in the budget to target house price-inflation in the south-east. Average earnings picked up strongly in the year to December, with the annual rate of increase of 5.5% inconsistent with achieving the government's 2.5% inflation target. The rule of thumb is that part of the increase in earnings is covered by higher productivity, which improves by around 2.5% a year on average. There is no suggestion that the level of pay settlements is on an upward curve; on the contrary, recent reports have shown they have come down in response to the fall in headline inflation, which remains the benchmark for wage negotiations. fields.headline: Mind over matter
fields.standfirst:
Steve Reinke: The Hundred Videos
Shoreditch Town Hall and Soho House, London
****
fields.trailText:
Steve Reinke: The Hundred Videos
Shoreditch Town Hall and Soho House, London
****
fields.body:
Video art is becoming so ambitious that it now rivals anything you can see at your local multiplex. No one bothered to tell Canadian artist Steve Reinke. There would be a perverse ambition to his setting out to make 100 videos "before the year 2000 and my 36th birthday" were it not that Reinke's definition of video art is something cheap and tacky.

The 100 videos are showing on nothing grander than a television monitor; when a tape finishes you put in another. Where's the projector, the multiple screens? This guy is living in the stone age. He's showing in London courtesy of the Peer Trust, who also commissioned Martin Creed's neon sign Everything is Going to be Alright; like Creed, the 100 videos stand for a back-to-basics aesthetic.

Reinke talks about himself in a funny, apparently direct way. There's a tape about his love for clean-cut bowling star Corey and another about how he used to be in a Canadian institution called the Childrens' Video Collective.

Looking back at his videos now, he finds them unbearably didactic. Cut to a child reading what sounds like Michel Foucault. You wonder if his fellow alumni included Atom Egoyan and David Cronenberg. Like them, Reinke twists the real to the shape of his fantasies.

The art is in imagination rather than technology and it becomes a joy to watch him assault our expectations with nothing but a camera and a sense of humour. His letter to Corey turns a bit weird, but not as weird as the conflation of Paul Anka's singing career with a gay porn video. Porn constantly interrupts the homey discourse of Reinke's videos. Except what is porn? He shows a public information film that made a huge impact on him as a child, in which an Indian boy is woken by an elephant's trunk playfully nudging him.

Reinke delights in the slack fuzziness of TV watching. One tape features an excerpt of Oprah Winfrey meeting Jeffrey Dahmer's father. In another, he gives a raw confession of love and pain as he tells us how, shortly after his father's death, he heard someone in the street tell a joke his father always used to tell, and was jealous of that person for owning a part of his father.

The Hundred Videos are funny, intimate, disconcerting - which goes to show you can't go wrong with a graduate of Canada's Children's Video Collective.

 Peer, Shoreditch Town Hall, London E1, and Soho House, London W1 (0171-739 8080), until February 27.

webTitle: It's not the job I expected

fields.headline: It's not the job I expected
fields.standfirst: Can you change jobs every three months?
fields.trailText: Can you change jobs every three months?
fields.body:
The problem

In the summer of last year I was offered a job which meant I had to move well away from my family and friends. Because of personal reasons and family illness I had to move back after only 4 months in the job and took the first available job that came up. At first things looked great, less hours, £4,000 salary increase. Problem is I hate it.

I'm not being challenged or stretched at all and as an engineer, it's not the sort of engineering I want to do. It's not the job I was led to believe at the interviews. I've been here 3 months and would really like to move on. Is it too soon to move, given the fact that I wasn't in the last job that long? How do I explain to other potential employers moving twice in one year. David McDermott

The solution

Dear David

The answer to your question depends largely on your previous job history. If you have a track record of stable employment (i.e. you have been in at least one job for more than three years), then why not give it a go and test the waters? You do, after all, have good reasons for leaving both these recent posts.

Having said that, the longer you can stick it out in your current job, the better, especially if you don't have an ideal past employment record (or if that stable job was several posts ago). You have two options (other than quitting); stay and grit your teeth for another six to nine months, or make efforts to improve the nature of your job. This might not be possible, but if you were misled at the interview, it could be that there is more stimulating work available - just not, as yet, to you! Approach your line manager and explain what you thought the job would be (does your job description or the original vacancy advert, suggest that the job should be more challenging?). Ask for opportunities to do more challenging work - suggesting, perhaps, some trials first to demonstrate your capabilities. If your boss is less than forthcoming, find out the reasons - do you lack skills or experience, or perhaps there is no more challenging work available? If you lack skills, ask about training. Obviously, if the work you seek doesn't exist in this company, your options are rather more limited.

If you do find another job, make sure you get a full and clear job description first so that you know exactly what will be expected of you.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: Philharmonia/ Vernon Handley
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonia/ Vernon Handley
***
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Philharmonia/ Vernon Handley
***
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
A fundraiser for two sailors' charities, this was on the face of it an old-fashioned, patriotic programme. But if the concert was intended to paint a picture of Britain, it was a rather muddled portrait that emerged, by turns introspective and outward-looking.

The work that began the concert received the most satisfying performance. Vernon Handley has earned a reputation as a champion of British music, and his Elgar interpretations are perhaps his most instinctive. He conducted the overture Froissart with just the right ebb and flow, with a generous amount of caprice alongside a sense of grandeur.

The same care for detail was apparent in his direction of Elgar's Cello Concerto, though the atmosphere of this postwar work, written in 1919 by a disillusioned man, was in stark contrast to the optimism of Froissart. Cellist Colin Carr stood in for an indisposed Kathryn Price; his was a solid performance, perhaps a little heavy on vibrato, but confident and thoughtful. The opening melody was subdued and rather steady, but the second movement danced, and the slow section of the Finale had enough impassioned gravity to make a convincing case for it as the core of the whole concerto.

There was no autumnal feeling in the second of Granville Bantock's Heroic Ballads, Kishmul's Galley. Based around a folk song from the Outer Hebrides, it was an evocative enough depiction of open seas, wheeling gulls and rolling waves, but its triumphalism sounded empty, especially when put next to the Four Sea Interludes from Britten's opera Peter Grimes. Like the Bantock, these were written in wartime, but their stifling atmosphere seemed truer to an era when careless talk cost lives.

Despite the link with King Arthur, Bax's Tintagel owes little to British tradition. It's much more firmly rooted in the musical world of Debussy's La Mer, while the composer identified most with Celtic and Irish nationalism. But it's an effective depiction of a view onto an expanse of ocean, and the Philharmonia brought its lush orchestration vividly to life.

webTitle: Earnings rise fuels fear of rate increase

fields.headline: Earnings rise fuels fear of rate increase
fields.trailText: Record City bonuses powered a sharp acceleration in earnings in the latest quarter, prompting fresh jitters about higher interest rates.
fields.body:
Record City bonuses powered a sharp acceleration in earnings in the latest quarter, prompting fresh jitters about higher interest rates.

Official figures published yesterday showed average earnings growth jumped to 5.5% in the three months to December from 4.9% in November, the largest increase for nearly eight years.

The office for national statistics said that half of the rise was caused by higher pay and bonuses in the City, linked to commissions from a frenzy of mergers and acquisitions and high bond issuance.

The rest of the surge was accounted for by millennium-related bonus and overtime payments in other sectors, including manufacturing and hotels and catering.

Other data confirmed the gentle downward trend in unemployment, with the number of people out of work and claiming benefit falling by 9,900 in January to a total of 1,157,900, 4% of the workforce. The figure for all those seeking work is 1,718,000, 5.9% of the workforce, unchanged on last month.

Financial markets focused on the unexpected strength of average earnings, interpreting them as shortening the odds on further interest rate rises.

Economists were divided about the implications for inflation. Dharshini David, of HSBC, said the figures were worrying. Although higher bonuses probably reflected increased profitability and productivity, they could also mean firms were having difficulty re cruiting and retaining staff in a tight labour market. Moreover, they still meant more money in consumers' pockets.

"With signs that activity is no longer accelerating, the tight labour market is the key threat to the inflation outlook, and these figures could tip the balance in favour of a rate hike in March," said Ms Dharshini.

The Bank of England's benchmark lending rate is 6%, having been raised four times since September.

Richard Iley, of ABN Amro, played down the importance of the data, pointing out that the fall in the claimant count was below the 15,000 average of the last three months, suggesting demand for labour was slackening. He added that basic pay settlements were subdued and that the bonus effect would wash out of the earnings fig ures in the next few months.

"While these data will clearly discomfort the monetary policy committee [at the Bank of England], it is far from automatic that they will induce a Pavlovian interest rate response," said Mr Iley.

"Rather we continue to expect that, having taken out significant inflation insurance in the last six months, the continued strength of the pound will force the committee to adopt a wait and see approach to policy in the coming months."

The MPC's own thinking on the prospects for inflation will be outlined today in its quarterly inflation report, though financial markets are more likely to be transfixed by Alan Greenspan's Humphrey Hawkins testimony to the United States Congress.

webTitle: Oil price back over $30 per barrel

fields.headline: Oil price back over $30 per barrel
fields.trailText: Oil prices yesterday crashed through $30 a barrel for the first time since the Gulf war nine years ago, raising inflation fears across the industrial world.
fields.body:
Oil prices yesterday crashed through $30 a barrel for the first time since the Gulf war nine years ago, raising inflation fears across the industrial world.

Higher world demand, coupled with a year's worth of production curbs by the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, has trebled the oil price in the 13 months since January 1999. At that point, fears of a global recession sent prices tumbling below $10 in today's money and, in real terms, to a level not seen since before 1973.

Next month sees a critical Opec summit in Vienna, at which the cartel has to decide what changes to make to its tough cuts package which is hacking 4.4m barrels a day out of production, now at 74.2m barrels, against demand totalling 77.1m barrels. The shortfall is made good by running down the stockpiles built up during the oil glut of the late 1990s.

Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi sought yesterday to reassure markets that Opec had no desire to send the world economy back into recession, with the sort of increases seen in 1973 and 1979. "I am positive the major oil producers will continue to guard against a disequilibrium that would negatively affect world economic growth," he said in Tokyo.

The US energy secretary, Bill Richardson, said he will try to reason with leading oil-producing countries in the next few days in an effort to have them ease oil prices, now at their highest since the 1991 Gulf war.

"I'm going to go out to Saudi Arabia, to Kuwait, to Mexico, to Norway in the next few day to try to talk to Opec and non-Opec members about the importance of not having energy prices so high," Mr Richardson told CNN television.

Western economies are feeling the pinch of rising energy costs. In Britain, one third of the inflation increase during the past 12 months has been caused by the sharp rise in oil prices, while the euroland countries faces inflation pushing through the 2% ceiling set by the European Central Bank, largely because of its oil bill.

In Russia - a big producer - the windfall of higher revenues is set to expand the trade surplus to $30bn in 1999, from $14bn in 1998.

fields.headline: BT hurt by Brown effect
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor's 'local loop' plans damage share price

E-finance: special report
BT.com
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, found himself at the centre of a row between British Telecom and Oftel yesterday after leaking a speech which disclosed plans by the regulator to open BT's local network for competition earlier than previously agreed.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, found himself at the centre of a row between British Telecom and Oftel yesterday after leaking a speech which disclosed plans by the regulator to open BT's local network for competition earlier than previously agreed.

Excerpts from the speech wiped billions of pounds from the market value of BT in early trading after they were published in the Financial Times.

The share price movement caused the stock exchange to take the unprecedented step of calling on the Treasury to publish the speech in full - it appeared on the exchange's regulatory news service in the early afternoon.

Oftel, it emerged, is poised to appoint outside consultants to examine ways of bringing forward the previously agreed date of July 2001 for BT to give up its monopoly of the "local loop". BT shares closed 42p lower at 971p.

BT's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, reacted angrily to the suggestion and the way the news was released. The episode seems certain to chill relations between BT and the regulator, which had improved with the departure of former Oftel chief Don Cruickshank.

"BT shareholders own the network and BT not only needs to be consulted but to agree any timetable with Oftel," Sir Peter said. "We have already agreed with Oftel a deadline of July 1 2001 and there will be no change to this date without our agreement. That would, anyway, be a matter for Oftel and BT - not for the treasury."

Mr Brown met with Oftel director general David Edmonds on Tuesday where they discussed ways of increasing internet penetration in Britain. Mr Edmonds is understood to have asked for Mr Brown's support in bringing the deadline forward but could have exposed the government to accusations of meddling.

The aim of opening BT's so called local loop to competition is to accelerate investment in the network to upgrade it for broadband applications including high speed internet access. That can be achieved by a new technology called ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) which supercharges existing copper wires.

"I know that Oftel believes this timetable can be improved," Mr Brown said in the speech delivered to business leaders at the Smith Institute in London last night. "Let the industry be in no doubt that I stand full square behind Oftel in these aims. We will not al low any foot-dragging here." Five European countries have already "unbundled" the local loop - Austria, Denmark, Finland, Germany and the Netherlands.

Separately Mr Brown set targets to reduce the cost of internet access in Britain to US levels by 2002 and warned that regulatory action could be taken if prices do not fall.

The cost of peak-rate charges in Britain remains roughly 20% higher than Italy, 50% higher than the US and 100% higher than Canada, according to government figures.

The statement attracted further barbed comments from BT which is planning to launch an unmetered internet access product in the spring. "BT has had its Surftime package - the UK's first unmetered call package - on the table since December," Sir Peter said.

Net costs

BT: weekend 1p a minute, evenings 1.5p a minute, daytime 4p a minute (before Friends and Family discount)

NTL: 1p a minute at all times.

CWC: 0.6p a minute to 1p evenings and weekends. Daytime 1.8p to 3p a minute.

Telewest: £10 a month for unlimited access.

Modems: Standard phone line: up to 56kb. ISDN line: 64kb. Cable modem: 500kb to 2mb. ADSL: 2mb. Current Wap phones: 9.6kb. GPRS: up to 114kb. UMTS: up to 2mb

Excerpts from the speech wiped billions of pounds from the market value of BT in early trading after they were published in the Financial Times. The share price movement caused the stock exchange to take the unprecedented step of calling on the Treasury to publish the speech in full - it appeared on the exchange's regulatory news service in the early afternoon. Oftel, it emerged, is poised to appoint outside consultants to examine ways of bringing forward the previously agreed date of July 2001 for BT to give up its monopoly of the "local loop". BT shares closed 42p lower at 971p. BT's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, reacted angrily to the suggestion and the way the news was released. The episode seems certain to chill relations between BT and the regulator, which had improved with the departure of former Oftel chief Don Cruickshank. "BT shareholders own the network and BT not only needs to be consulted but to agree any timetable with Oftel," Sir Peter said. "We have already agreed with Oftel a deadline of July 1 2001 and there will be no change to this date without our agreement. That would, anyway, be a matter for Oftel and BT - not for the treasury." Mr Brown met with Oftel director general David Edmonds on Tuesday where they discussed ways of increasing internet penetration in Britain. Mr Edmonds is understood to have asked for Mr Brown's support in bringing the deadline forward but could have exposed the government to accusations of meddling. The aim of opening BT's so called local loop to competition is to accelerate investment in the network to upgrade it for broadband applications including high speed internet access. That can be achieved by a new technology called ADSL (asymmetric digital subscriber line) which supercharges existing copper wires. "I know that Oftel believes this timetable can be improved," Mr Brown said in the speech delivered to business leaders at the Smith Institute in London last night. "Let the industry be in no doubt that I stand full square behind Oftel in these aims. We will not al low any foot-dragging here." Five European countries have already "unbundled" the local loop - Austria, Denmark, Finland, Germany and the Netherlands. Separately Mr Brown set targets to reduce the cost of internet access in Britain to US levels by 2002 and warned that regulatory action could be taken if prices do not fall. The cost of peak-rate charges in Britain remains roughly 20% higher than Italy, 50% higher than the US and 100% higher than Canada, according to government figures. The statement attracted further barbed comments from BT which is planning to launch an unmetered internet access product in the spring. "BT has had its Surftime package - the UK's first unmetered call package - on the table since December," Sir Peter said. Net costs BT: weekend 1p a minute, evenings 1.5p a minute, daytime 4p a minute (before Friends and Family discount) NTL: 1p a minute at all times. CWC: 0.6p a minute to 1p evenings and weekends. Daytime 1.8p to 3p a minute. Telewest: £10 a month for unlimited access. Modems: Standard phone line: up to 56kb. ISDN line: 64kb. Cable modem: 500kb to 2mb. ADSL: 2mb. Current Wap phones: 9.6kb. GPRS: up to 114kb. UMTS: up to 2mb

webTitle: A walk in the woods with Shelley

fields.headline: A walk in the woods with Shelley
fields.standfirst:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/ Rumon Gamba
Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
A walk in the woods with Shelley

BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/ Rumon Gamba
Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
There was precious little room on stage in the Royal Scottish Academy's Matt Thomson Hall for the world premiere of Silvina Milstein's A Media Luz.

One of three first performances given by Rumon Gamba and the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra as part of a live Hear and Now broadcast for Radio 3, the Debussian voluptuousness of Milstein's work was the most ambitious on the programme.

Splashes of percussion overlaid a heaving welter of string sound, while woodwind and brass provided a dense, weaving cantus firmus to bind the texture.

Milstein fashions a seductive drama between individual lines, including a violin solo which rides precariously atop the crest of a tumultuous wave of string sonority.

There was an overall abundance of colour. In some passages, all melodic clarity is sacrificed in favour of a vivid, chaotic wash of sound, as Milstein piles hundreds of different parts on top of one another in a Babel-like confusion.

But then, at the end of the work, Milstein pares her palette down to the intimacy of a lone violinist. This betrays the origins of the piece's heightened passions in her memories of an Argentinian popular song of candlelight and romance.

Magnus Robb's Luscinian Blue is based on his transcriptions of a nightingale's song, but its effect could hardly be more different from the sumptuous exoticism of Stravinsky's famous nightingale evocation in his Chant du Rossignol.

In the BBC SSO's performance, Luscinian Blue was played simultaneously with another of Robb's nightingale pieces for two percussionists. Unlike in Messiaen's music, birds and birdsong do not represent a spiritual or emotional transcendence for Robb. Instead, the combination of Luscinian Blue's pointillistic orchestration and the percussion's woody onomatopoeia sounded like an amplification and celebration of the usually ignored sounds of a forest walk.

Judith Bingham's trumpet concerto, The Shooting Star, is an attempt to convey the intense and destructive idealism of the poet Shelley's life. Bingham's writing for the solo trumpet is appropriately stratospheric, and Mark O'Keeffe dealt convincingly with the difficulties of the solo part. But Bingham's music, whatever its well-written cinematic narrative and accessible, post-Romantic idiom, scarcely conveys the danger or thrill of Shelley's convictions.

The confidence of Stuart MacRae's handling of the orchestra in his 1999 Sinfonia is a mark of the benefits of his associate composership with the BBCSSO. Broad, tortuous string lines and woodwind fragments gradually fuse in a thunderously impressive climax.

But MacRae's structure contains its surprises too: in the way the storm clouds suddenly part to reveal a separate strata of woodwind chatter, and the final reprise of the opening music's uneasy tranquillity. Gamba and the BBC SSO forces strongly conveyed the work's rugged outlines, even if there were hints of raggedness about the ensemble in the thick, dark textures of MacRae's orchestration.

fields.headline: Endymion Ensemble/ Quentin Poole
fields.standfirst:
Endymion Ensemble/ Quentin Poole
Purcell Room, London
****
fields.trailText:
Endymion Ensemble/ Quentin Poole
Purcell Room, London
****
fields.body:
The Endymion Ensemble has made its Composer's Choice series an annual event at the Purcell Room, where major British figures are challenged to concoct a programme that places their own music in context. Jonathan Dove, George Benjamin and Alexander Goehr were invited this year, and for Tuesday's concert Goehr had put together a typically thoughtful programme, in which his works were heard alongside Eisler and Webern, two composers from the 20th century Austro-German tradition that has formed the backdrop to his creative development.

At a time when Eisler's songs are finally getting the recognition they deserve, it was good to hear an example of his beautifully crafted instrumental writing. Fourteen Ways of Describing Rain doubled as a 70th birthday tribute to his teacher Schoenberg (the instrumental ensemble echoes that of Pierrot Lunaire) and as a film score, each of its neat, sparkling sequence of miniatures perfectly distinct in texture and colour. Then two of Webern's most densely impacted sets of songs - the Three Traditional Rhymes and the Five Canons on Latin Texts - enclosed Goehr's own Three Songs Op 60, which take texts describing mysterious rituals from Ovid, and give them quirky, sometimes disquieting musical frames.

One of the most impressive of Goehr's recent compositions filled the second half of the programme. Sing Ariel is a 50-minute song-cycle, though of an unconventional kind. The text, compiled by the literary critic Frank Kermode (a Cambridge colleague of the composer), is a work of art in its own right. Goehr describes it as a "poem of poems", taking extracts from a wide range of sources - Spenser to Stevens, Milton to Craig Raine - and shaping them into a marvellously allusive sequence that charts a kind of progression from youth to old age. Auden's poem The Sea and the Mirror, a line from which forms the title of the cycle, acts as prologue and epilogue.

Goehr's setting is by turns elliptical and witheringly direct. The mezzo soloist (Louise Mott, making every syllable matter) is shadowed by a pair of sopranos (Sarah Leonard and Eileen Hulse, soloists in the earlier Goehr and Webern respectively); the instrumental ensemble contains saxophone and trumpet. There are sudden eruptions of instrumental virtuosity, including a wracked double-bass cadenza, and a centrepiece of mysterious bleakness with a complete setting of Philip Larkin's Unfinished Poem. Perhaps the work is fractionally too long, but there are many rewards along the way.
